HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Connecticut Bank Bill Advances

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Connecticut House and Senate on Wednesday approved legislation that allows out-of-state banks to buy Connecticut banks.
The bill, which amends a law that had limited out-of-state bank ownership to institutions from other New England states, is expected to be signed by Gov. William A. O'Neill.
The law would remove an obstacle to the long-planned acquisition of Northeast Bancorp in Shelton, Conn., by the Bank of New York Corporation. But it may not be the catalyst for immediate moves into the state by other New York banks, analysts said, even though New York banks have for years expressed a desire to expand into Connecticut, especially into the wealthier towns close to New York City. 
 
Massachusetts Is Interested
Legislators in Massachusetts have also recently considered allowing acquisitions by banks outside the region, but they have not yet changed the law. As banking problems have mounted in the area, officials at some leading Massachusetts banks, including the troubled Bank of New England Corporation, have supported measures to allow acquisitions by out-of-state banks.
''Given the economic climate right now in the Northeast, I don't expect you will see quick acquisitions in Connecticut,'' said Richard Barrett, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc. The new Connecticut law would allow out of state banks to open new Connecticut banks on Feb. 1, 1992.
 
Deal Was Made in 1983
The Bank of New York agreed in 1983 to acquire Northeast Bancorp, if the deal could be completed by Aug. 15, 1990. But after the once highly profitable Connecticut banking company announced large losses from its real estate lending in the fourth quarter of 1989, executives at the Bank of New York indicated they wanted to lower the price.
In January, J. Carter Bacot, the chairman of the Bank of New York, said a ''preliminary'' examination of Northeast's books ''showed that loan- loss reserves will have to be increased by significant amounts.'' Those increases could cause losses at the bank, which would reduce its capital, and thus lower the price that Bank of New York would pay under terms of its purchase agreement.
When the agreement to acquire Northeast was amended in 1986, the Bank of New York agreed to pay 2.5 times the Connecticut banking company's book value, or $635 million based on its current capital.
According to Bank Mergers and Acquisitions, a trade publication in Hoboken, N.J., a $635 million price, if paid in Bank of New York shares, would give Northeast shareholders about 20 percent of Bank of New York's stock, even though Northeast would contribute only about 7 percent of the combined companies' profits.

HEADLINE: OPEC in Strong Position at Meeting

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 15

 BODY:
OPEC oil ministers will start a meeting on Friday in which they will wrestle with how to play a strong hand: essentially whether to settle for oil prices at about $18 a barrel or to try to raise them.
This situation represents a sharp contrast with OPEC's problem in the last decade. Prices collapsed to as low as $10 a barrel in 1986, and OPEC's production, which now stands at 24 million barrels a day, sank to around 14 million.
The change in the fortunes of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began a few years ago. It is tied, experts say, to the fact that demand for oil has been steadily rising around the world, and there is no end in sight as long as prices stay low and supplies outside OPEC continue to shrink. 
 
Demand Up at About 3% a Year
Over the last three years, demand has steadily increased by about 3 percent a year, while production of oil in countries outside OPEC, including large producers like the United States and the Soviet Union, has dropped by at least a million barrels a day, giving OPEC an opportunity to fill the void rapidly, pump more of its oil and raise prices.
Libya's oil minister, Fawzi al-Shakshuki, opened the OPEC bidding contest on his arrival in Vienna today by declaring that he will push OPEC to raise prices. ''Libya will ask OPEC to raise the price to at least $20 to compensate for world inflation, which has put the real price below $14,'' Mr. Shakshuki told reporters.
But Kuwait, a prime advocate of lower oil prices, said it wants prices closer to $18 for some time, to encourage consumers to buy more oil. Kuwait's stand matters most since it has the ability to lift production far above the current level of two million barrels a day, thus drowning the market and preventing prices from rising.
 
Support for Kuwait
More important, oil experts point out, Kuwait has the tacit support of other conservative Arab producers, like the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, which also have considerable excess capacity to produce more oil above their current levels of 2 million and 5.5 million barrels a day, respectively.
''Oil prices are fluctuating between $18 and $20 a barrel,'' Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said this week. ''That is ideal.'' His country has been openly flouting all OPEC production discipline for more than three years, producing twice its official quota.
The oil ministers' meeting in the Austrian capital comes at a time when oil prices have been at or above the ''minimum reference price'' of $18 for 13 months despite OPEC's overproduction, suggesting that demand has been so strong as to leave the group immune to the customary cheating on quotas by several of its members.
 
Current Production Estimate
Oil experts estimate current production for all of the group's 13 countries at close to 24 million barrels a day, or far above the official ceiling of 22.1 million in effect since January.
So the big question facing OPEC now is not so much a return to discipline, they say, as it is an agreement on a ''price philosophy'' to set price levels for the rest of this decade. Indeed, virtually all OPEC experts agree that the group is slowly getting back in the driver's seat when it comes to regulating the price that consumers must pay for energy.
In that respect, OPEC officials have argued for months about two strategies.
Some like Kuwait, have openly called for the freedom of countries that have large reserves to produce more oil. The guiding wisdom behind this view is that only three or four countries in OPEC can produce more - namely Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Iraq. In addition, Kuwait says, such a policy is necessary to keep prices low, which is the key to the rise in demand for oil.
 
End of Quotas Sought
Last month Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, declared in an interview that the whole quota system should be scrapped.
''From a practical standpoint the quotas are already irrelevant,'' he said.
He argued that OPEC should revert to quotas only if oil prices fell below $18 a barrel. The Kuwaiti official went on to say that OPEC's objective from now on must be ''the maintenance of price'' at a moderate level that encourages further consumption.
Iraq, which does have the capacity to produce more, has gone on record saying that it prefers to produce less and have a higher price because it needs the money to rebuild its damaged economy, run down from eight years of the war with Iran that ended in 1988.

HEADLINE: Agency Votes to Sell Houses Owned by Savings Units

BYLINE: By GREGORY A. ROBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
The Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, today approved its first program to sell the housing stock of failed savings institutions to low- and medium-income families.
The board approved a joint financing program between the trust corporation and the State of Texas under which the Texas Housing Authority would issue $140 million in tax-exempt bonds to provide financing for low-rate mortgages for the low- and moderate-income families.
The trust corporation will select the private lenders and the mortgages will be used exclusively to buy half of the 5,200 housing properties for sale by the agency in Texas. 
 
No Borrower Fees
The agency will be allowed to spend up to $6 million in commitment fees for the new mortgages. Under the plan, low-income borrowers will not have to repay the fees. The program will be put into effect within 30 to 60 days pending the final approval of the Texas agency, which originally proposed the plan.
In addition to managing the bailout, the Resolution Trust Corporation has a separate mandate to sell affordable housing. The program was inserted in the bailout legislation by Congressional Democrats.
''We hope that R.T.C. will actively negotiate with other states and local housing agencies to form affordable housing partnerships to provide low-interest-rate loans to buyers of R.T.C.'s housing properties,'' said Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and a member of the Oversight Board.
Officials of the Oversight Board said there are an estimated 10,000 properties held by savings institutions in conservatorship across the country that will ultimately be eligible for the affordable housing program.
The board urged the agency to negotiate similar agreements with other states. Florida has expressed interest in a similar program.
 
Nomination Made
In a separate development today, President Bush nominated Robert C. Larson, the chief executive officer of the Taubman Company, a national real estate developer based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., to a three-year term on the Oversight Board. He would fill one of two remaining vacancies on the board if he is confirmed by the Senate.
In addition to Mr. Kemp, the other members of the Oversight Board are Nicholas F. Brady, the Secretary of the Treasury, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Noting that the Oversight Board had been criticized for moving slowly to fill vacancies, Mr. Brady, chairman of the board, said that the delay was caused because of Mr. Larson's long experience in the real estate business.
''We had a choice to approach people who really knew something about the business and therefore would have a long period of examination because of the possibility of conflict, or we could have taken somebody with no knowledge and move it quite quickly,'' Mr. Brady said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Ease in Slow Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits after Wednesday's strong rally and awaited the release of new economic statistics.
This morning, reports on housing activity, industrial production and producer prices for February will be released. The producer price figure, in particular, is of interest in the credit markets.
''Inflation is what this market has been focusing on for some time, and with some of the recent economic numbers showing some strength, the market would sell off sharply if we got a bad producer price number,'' one Government bond trader said. 
An increase in producer prices would be expected to lead to an increase in consumer prices later on, and that could lead to tighter credit and higher interest rates as the Federal Reserve tried to fight inflation.
 
Effects of Energy and Food
Most analysts expected that the index would be unchanged to down slightly from January levels because of declines in food and energy prices. Excluding those sectors, they saw a rise of about two-tenths of a percentage point.
''Anything greater than a three-tenths of a percentage point increase in the Producer Price Index excluding food and energy will spell further trouble for the market,'' analysts at MMS International, an economic information company, noted in their daily commentary yesterday.
With so much data expected today, traders were reluctant to take positions in the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 25/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.61 percent, up from 8.60 percent on Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered in late trading at 99 7/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.67 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 22/ 32, down 1/32, to yield 8.67 percent.
Treasury bill rates were little changed. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.92 percent, unchanged on the day. And six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, or hundredth of a point, to a late offered rate of 8.67 percent.
 
'Junk' Prices Steady
Uncertainty continued in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market about the disposition of the $3.5 billion portfolio of securities owned by the Columbia Savings and Loan Association. However, traders said that prices of most issues were largely unchanged.
One exception was the bonds issued by the Charter Medical Corporation, a hospital owner and manager based in Macon, Ga. Those bonds were quoted down sharply after the company announced it had discovered inaccuracies in its reporting of contractual allowances, bad debts and expense accruals. The correction reduced the company's operating income by $28 million.
Analysts said they were surprised by the company's brief announcement. As a result, prices of some of the company's bonds dropped almost 10 points, to 67, although dealers said that little actual trading took place.
A number of new debt issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including a $155 million debenture issue for the General American Transportation Corporation.
The 10 1/8 percent securities, which mature March 15, 2002, were priced at $99.80 to yield 10.155 percent, 1.5 percentage points higher than the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The debentures, which are noncallable for life, are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the transaction.
 
Notes of Morgan Bank
Morgan Bank Delaware offered $200 million of floating-rate deposit notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
The notes, which have a final maturity of Sept. 22, 1992, were priced at 100. The interest rate will be reset weekly at 62.50 basis points over the prevailing bond equivalent yield on three-month Treasury bills.
The issue is rated triple-A by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Market participants said that prices of most actively traded issues in the secondary market for corporate bonds dipped by about 1/8 of a point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most issues were unchanged on the day, dealers said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended March 5. The report had little impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Amid Concern Over Falling Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against most leading currencies except the Japanese yen amid selling spurred by speculation about lower American interest rates.
Currency dealers said a comment by President Bush suggesting that he would welcome a drop in rates sapped positive sentiment toward the dollar out of the foreign exchange market.
A rumor that Japan might raise its discount rate by one and a half percentage points also hurt the dollar. Higher Japanese rates would enhance returns on yen-denominated investments and tend to bolster demand for the yen. 
Robert Morrissey, a senior currency trader at the Bank of Boston, said the President's comments to the National Association of Manufacturers renewed speculation that the White House and the Federal Reserve might be at odds over interest-rate policy.
Mr. Bush told the manufacturers that lower rates remained a priority of his Administration, saying, ''We need to keep interest rates down.''
Meanwhile, Mr. Morrissey said the Japanese discount-rate rumor reinforced selling pressure on the dollar. But the dollar still closed in New York at a higher rate against the yen than on Wednesday.
The dollar was also under pressure from profit taking before United States economic reports are released today on inflation, industrial production and housing starts.
The dollar closed in New York at 1.6990 West German marks, down from 1.7110 marks late Wednesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.47 yen, up from 152.20. In London late yesterday, the dollar closed at 152.55 yen. In New York, the dollar bought 152.285 yen, up from 152.18 late on Wednesday.
In London, the pound regained some of the ground lost recently against the dollar. It closed at $1.6177 in London, up from $1.6090 late on Wednesday. Later, in New York, a pound fetched $1.6215, compared with $1.6103 on Wednesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Wednesday, included: 1.5180 Swiss francs, down from 1.5245; 5.7415 French francs, down from 5.7805; 1,255.00 Italian lire, down from 1,263.00, and 1.18085 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1733.
Gold prices edged slightly higher in New York after falling overseas.
The Republic National Bank of New York quoted an ounce of gold at $398.20 late yesterday, up 20 cents from Wednesday's late bid. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $398.10 an ounce, up 10 cents.
An ounce of gold was quoted at $398.50 late yesterday in London, down from $399.05 late Wednesday.
In New York, silver for current delivery closed at $5.079 an ounce on the Comex, down from $5.081 on Wednesday. Silver traded late in London at $5.10 an ounce, up from $5.09.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Soybean and Sugar Prices Rise on Rumor About Brazil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Soybean and sugar futures prices rose sharply yesterday, partly reflecting fears that Brazil's new President will seek higher taxes and restrictions on exports of some of the country's principal commodities.
On other commodity markets, grain futures advanced, petroleum futures rose and copper surged, while precious metals were mixed, cattle futures retreated and pork futures were mixed.
Soybean futures settled 9 to 13 1/2 cents higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, with the contract for delivery in March at $5.86 a bushel. 
Analysts linked some of the buying to rumors that President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil, who took office yesterday, planned to seek an export tax on soybeans and soy products as one of many measures aimed at stabilizing the country's foundering economy.
Such a tax would put the cost of Brazilian soybeans closer to that of United States soybeans on the world market and could discourage Brazilian growers from marketing their crops quickly.
The late rally in the soybean pit erased much of the losses registered earlier in the week and prompted speculation that prices may have to move even higher to persuade American farmers to market their soybean stocks.
 
New Export Business Indicated
Indications of new export business also supported the grain and soybean markets. The Soviet Union was believed to be in the market for American corn, while China was said to have bid for 300,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices.
Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 3 1/2 cents higher, with March at $3.84 1/2 a bushel; corn was 3/4 cent to 3 1/4 cents higher, with March at $2.47 a bushel, and oats were 1/2 cent lower to 3/4 cent higher, with March at $1.44 a bushel.
Sugar futures made new eight-and-a-half-year highs on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on rumors that Brazil may eliminate or reduce exports to divert more sugar to the country's fuel alcohol program.
Sugar futures settled 0.23 to 0.39 cent higher, with May at 15.93 cents a pound, after trading as high as 16.02 cents during the session for the first time since mid-1981.
Copper futures prices rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange on fears that the four-day-old strike at the Southern Peru Copper Corporation could force cancellation of copper shipments.
Copper ended 0.05 cent to 3.05 cents higher, with March at $1.2805 a pound.
Futures prices of refined oil products climbed sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, leading crude oil higher, on news of minor problems at two Exxon refineries and an ARCO oil pipeline shutdown in Texas caused by flooding.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 16 to 36 cents higher, with April at $20.38 a barrel; heating oil was 0.63 to 0.98 cent higher, with April at 54.98 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 1 cent to 2.09 cents higher, with April at 57.94 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Business Stakes East Bloc Claims And a 'Gold Rush' Hits Hungary

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
With some of the biggest companies in the United States leading the way, Hungary has become corporate America's main port of entry into Eastern Europe. In recent months, General Electric, General Motors, Levi Strauss, McDonald's and others have set up businesses in Hungary, and the stream of American concerns seeking joint ventures here is accelerating daily.
''It's a stampede - it's like the gold rush,'' said Michael J. Shade, president of the four-month-old American Chamber of Commerce in Budapest, which already has 75 members. Mr. Shade estimates that 100 American companies have established joint ventures in Hungary, and another 50 have set up representative offices.
There are several reasons why Hungary has proved particularly attractive. It is the most open of the Eastern European nations to foreign investors, offering liberal joint-venture laws and generous tax incentives. Another lure is that the Government makes it comparatively easy for job-creating foreign companies to transfer home the profits they make in Hungary. 
 
2 Decades of Reforms
American executives also say Hungary's two decades of step-by-step economic reforms mean that among Eastern European nations it has the closest thing to a market economy. Hungarian workers are also low paid.
For some American executives, there is a personal incentive as well. When the Communists took control of Hungary after the 1956 revolution, many of the best and brightest immigrated to the United States and succeeded in American business.
George Varga, for example, is returning to his native country after 34 years to run the General Electric Company's joint venture. ''I want to be part of this process,'' Mr. Varga said. ''I want to do something good for this country.''
David A. Hughes, commercial attache at the American Embassy here, says more than 200 American companies have visited him so far this year to inquire about Hungary. ''And we get so many faxes about people planning to visit that we can't read them all,'' he said.
Last month, the Ralston Purina Company agreed to an animal-feed joint venture, and the Digital Equipment Corporation recently decided to set up a sales and service venture for its computers. The Ford Motor Company, the Eastman Kodak Company, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and the Proctor & Gamble Company have all sent executives in to prospect for joint-venture partners.
Though a small market, with just 10.6 million people, Hungary is increasingly viewed as a model that other Eastern European nations will need to follow to encourage foreign investment, which is expected to bring in management skills and capital to revitalize stagnant economies.
 
'Leading the Way'
''All Eastern European countries are trying to have more foreign direct investment, and Hungary is leading the way,'' said Jan Stankowski, an economist with the Institute for Comparative Economic Studies in Vienna.
To be sure, Austrian and West German companies have set up more joint ventures here than the Americans. But United States companies have weighed in with the biggest ventures by far.
G.E. agreed in November to pay $150 million for a 50.1 percent stake in Tungsram, Eastern Europe's leading light bulb manufacturer. In January, General Motors said it would invest more than $100 million in a joint venture with Raba, a state-owned truck and engine manufacturer, to build engines and assemble some 30,000 cars a year. And Guardian Industries of Northville, Mich., owns 80 percent of a joint venture that is building a $120 million glass factory.
''The G.E. investment had a symbolic effect,'' said Theodore S. Boone, a lawyer in the Budapest office of Baker & McKenzie. ''When G.E. moves, people take notice. Now it seems that no one wants to be last.''
Five American accounting firms and two United States law firms have set up offices in Budapest to assist in the fast-growing corporate presence. DHL Worldwide Express has started overnight air-freight service to the United States. The investment craze is so fierce that bidding wars among Westerners have caused rents for some Budapest apartments to soar to $2,000 a month, while prices for some houses, especially mansions overlooking the Danube, have jumped to more than $1 million.
Finding office space is also a problem. The operations of Price Waterhouse have been scattered among several apartments until the accounting firm's new office building is completed. The telephone system is a constant source of irritation: long-distance calling can be nightmarish, and it took Levi Strauss a year to have a phone installed at its jeans factory.
 
Shipping to the West
''Some Americans are coming to Hungary because they see it as a market to sell products they already have,'' said Mr. Shade, the Chamber of Commerce president. ''That's the case of McDonald's. Some have come to Hungary looking for a low-cost site to manufacture products that they will ship back to the West. That's the case of General Motors and Schwinn.''
Fourteen months ago, the Schwinn Bicycle Company, based in Chicago, began a joint venture with Csepel, Hungary's largest bike maker, and pumped in several million dollars to upgrade the old Csepel factory in western Budapest. Now Steven M. Bina, director of Schwinn's European operations, is boasting that the joint venture has improved the quality of the bikes so much that they are ready to be exported to the West.
 
Low-Cost Base for Sales
Many Western executives at first viewed Hungary as a springboard to sell thoughout the East bloc. But given the disarray in Comecon, the Soviet-led trading system, many now see the country more as a low-cost base to sell to the West.
''A lot of people think that if you have a place here, all of the Eastern market will open up for you,'' said Mr. Varga, the G.E. executive who was sent to run Tungsram. ''The way the trend is going, that doesn't happen to be the case.''
Mr. Varga said G.E. was interested in Tungsram because it gave the American company about 12 percent of Europe's light bulb market. He said his most pressing need was to improve Tungsram's internal information system - he wants monthly profit statements done by computer, to replace statements that Tungsram used to do every six months by hand.
Mr. Varga is confident that Hungarians can compete internationally. ''After 40 years of Communism, they seem very open to change,'' he said.
 
Quickening Tempo
Hungary became the first country in Eastern Europe to allow joint ventures, in 1972. But by the end of 1988, only 280 ventures had been formed. The tempo picked up dramatically last year, however, thanks to the far-reaching foreign investment law and the collapse of Communism here and elsewhere in Eastern Europe.
As a result, more than 750 foreign joint ventures were set up last year alone. These included a McCann-Erickson advertising joint venture, a Rupert Murdoch investment in two Hungarian newspapers, and a U S West venture to set up a mobile telephone network.
Another eye-catching deal involved Ronald S. Lauder, heir to the Estee Lauder cosmetics fortune and former New York mayoral candidate, and R. Mark Palmer, a former Ambassador to Hungary. They helped to form an American-Canadian consortium that bought half of the venerable General Banking and Trust Company.
In February, Digital signed a deal with two Hungarian software companies, KFKI and Szamark, to sell computers and provide software. Yves Sarrazin, director of Digital's country development group, said he had decided to invest in Hungary partly because it had so many computer experts, some of them so skilled that they were already producing ''clones'' of Digital computers. Digital owns 51 percent of the joint venture.
Mr. Sarrazin predicted that Digital's annual sales here could soon exceed $10 million, because the banking, railroad and air-traffic systems in the country badly need computers, as do many of its enterprises. 5-Year Tax Holiday Hungary's departing reform-minded Communist Government has created many incentives to attract foreign investors. The new joint-venture law offers a five-year tax holiday to many investors and pledges to compensate foreigners for any nationalizations of their operations in the future. One of the law's biggest attractions is that it gives foreign investors complete freedom to repatriate profits. This means that whatever investors earn in Hungarian forints can be freely converted to dollars and sent home as dividends.
''I'm not sure if we would have invested here if the investment law hadn't changed,'' said Harrison Givens, director of the Ralston Purina joint venture. The St. Louis-based company is investing several million dollars in a 50-50 joint venture with a union of farm cooperatives to produce animal-feed concentrate.
Because Hungary's huge foreign debt makes it hard for the nation to borrow, Hungarian officials and executives say joint ventures are essential to bring in money to modernize the manufacturing base.
Speaking about the joint venture with G.M., Ferenc Romvari, acting general manager of Raba, said his company could not possibly build an auto assembly plant without help from a foreign partner. ''Raba simply couldn't afford to build it,'' he said. ''What is more, making automobiles requires such a vast background in industry that we just don't have all the expertise to do it ourselves.''
 
Profits Exceed Investment
Not only are American investors doing good, some are doing very well. Andras Pinter, manager of the Levi Strauss joint venture, said his factory's annual profits exceeded the initial $1 million investment by the company in its 200-employee factory. Fotex, a joint venture backed by private American investors, earned more than $1 million in its first year of selling and developing film - far more than its original $200,000 investment.
The profits do not always come so easily. Many foreign executives complain that Hungarians do not work hard enough. To make ends meet, many juggle two or three jobs, generating complaints that they do not concentrate enough on any single one.
But Mr. Pinter has made his Levi Strauss plant as efficient as any in Europe. ''We get good work from our people by paying them twice as much as the average Hungarian makes and prohibiting them from taking a second job,'' he said.News Corporationd Interpublic Groupd (McCann-Erickson)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1329 words

HEADLINE: Families of Hostages Tell of Living A Seesaw Life of Hope and Despair

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Thomas Cicippio feels like a hostage, too.
It is his brother, Joseph, who is the actual captive, one of eight Americans held somewhere in the Middle East, presumably in Lebanon, by pro-Iranian terrorists.
''But most of the time I feel like I'm being held,'' Mr. Cicippio said today as he arrived in Washington from Norristown, Pa., for ceremonies to mark the beginning of the sixth year in captivity for Terry A. Anderson, the hostage who has been held longest.
''Until all the hostages are freed,'' Mr. Cicippio added, ''no hostage family is going to be free. We live on a roller coaster of emotions, up and down, up and down. We can't get off, not as long as Joe or Terry Anderson or any of the others are still being held.'' 
Terry Anderson was the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, based in Beirut, when he was kidnapped at gunpoint on March 16, 1985. He was the first United States citizen to be taken.
 
They Hurt, Too, They Say
Joseph Cicippio was acting comptroller of the American University of Beirut when he was kidnapped on Sept. 12, 1986, and was the fourth American taken.
Thomas Cicippio and the relatives of other hostages say their loved ones' ordeal has traumatized them as well, and the latest high-intensity round of rumors that the hostages might be freed was especially wrenching.
The hostages' relatives are the first to admit that nothing they have been through could compare to what has happened to those in chains behind locked doors in the Middle East. But they hurt, too, they say.
They tell of waking in the night, sometimes in a rage, sometimes feeling drained, sometimes flush with expectation that, come the sun, their loved one will be coming home.
 
The Births, the Deaths
They tell of struggling to explain to a child, again and again, why a father has been absent for two, three, five years.
They tell of family births - Mr. Anderson has never seen his 4-year-old daughter, Sulome - and of family deaths that the captives are presumed not to know about.
They tell of keeping scrapbooks for absent sons, fathers and brothers -Mr. Cicippio has six - some now filled with clippings that have yellowed.
 
'That Glimmer of Hope'
They tell of weekly phone calls from State Department officials to discuss the latest reports and rumors or to compare notes on the latest hostage letter or photograph to be released. The letters and photos can be roller coaster rides in themselves, depending upon what can be read between the lines or perceived in the grainy, fuzzy prints.
They tell of becoming addicts to hourly news broadcasts, of always, absolutely always, turning on the set with some hope, however faint, that this time the announcement will finally come. ''You just always have that glimmer of hope - you have to,'' Mr. Ciccipio said. ''In a way, we're even hostage to the radio.''
Kit Sutherland of Fort Collins, Colo., daughter of the hostage Thomas M. Sutherland, puts it another way. She says hostage families eventually learn that the only way to survive is to keep hopes high and expectations low.
''You learn not to talk about 'if' the hostages are released but 'when' they're released,'' said Ms. Sutherland, whose father, dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, was kidnapped on June 9, 1985. He was the second American to be taken.
 
The Families as Hostages
In a letter sent to a Beirut newspaper, Sulome's mother, Madeleine Bassil, made the point that the relatives of the hostages are themselves hostages. The newspaper, she hopes, will eventually make its way to the cell, the room or the dungeon where Mr. Anderson is being held.
''We are in as much capitivity, Terry, only our living space is bigger and it's shared by the millions,'' she wrote.
Mr. Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, has been particularly active in the effort to win freedom for him and the seven other hostages, organizing many ceremonies and making many trips abroad, on behalf of all the hostage families.
''They are an incredible group of people and they just humble me,'' she said of the families at today's ceremony, attended by several dozen relatives of hostages and representatives of Congress, the State Department, the armed services and the media.
 
Prayers and Yellow Ribbons
The ceremony was held at noon in Lafayette Park, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House, in sunny spring-like weather. There were prayers and hymns, some tears were shed, and a whole sea of bright yellow ''Free the Hostages'' ribbons fluttered.
Shortly before the ceremony, Mrs. Say met privately with President Bush to discuss the latest round of rumors about whether the hostages might soon be freed. She said that the President was doing everything possible to speed freedom for the captives, but that he could offer little more at this point than ''faith'' that he would achieve his goal.
The families clappled loudly when Ms. Say finished her report, apparently satisfied that all was being done that could be done.
In recent weeks the hopes of the families have been again and again boosted, then undercut. ''It just seems to drag on and on and on,'' said Brian Polhill of Queens, the son of Robert Polhill, an assistant professor of business at Beirut University College who was kidnapped on Jan. 24, 1987.
 
Once More, a Photo
''Will it ever end?'' Thomas Cicippio asked. ''This has been a really rough one.''
First came reports that President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran had declared that the hostage issue should be settled, apparently so that Iran could get on with rebuilding its war-damaged economy.
Then came rumors that talks were under way on freeing the hostages, perhaps with third parties mediating. Mr. Cicippio's hopes took flight. Then the hostage takers released a picture of Joseph Ciccippio in which he seemed in ''reasonable'' physical condition, to use Thomas Cicippio's word. The whole family took heart: earlier photos had been less encouraging.
But then came reports that the hostage takers had said no release was imminent, followed Thursday by a statement from President Bush that nothing was happening on the hostage front that promised an immediate ''payoff.''
And, as if to deflate Mr. Cicippio and the other hostage families totally, one group of hostage takers threatened Thursday to kill three captives unless some captured Arabs were freed by Israel.
 
It's Not the First Time
The threat was taken seriously by the hostages' relatives, but Virginia Steen, the wife of one of the threatened captives, Alann Steen, said she would not despair.
''We have been through this before,'' she said. ''I will not give up hope. I saw a picture they released of my husband and I looked at that photograph and I could see he was fighting back. I could just see it. I will fight with him.''
Mr. Steen was a professor of journalism at Beirut University College who was kidnapped. He was taken with Mr. Polhill, on Jan. 24, 1987, along with a third professor, Jesse Turner, a member of the mathematics department at the college.
Completing the list of American hostages held in the Middle East are Frank Reed, director of the Lebanon International School in Beirut, kidnapped on Sept. 9, 1986, and Edward Tracy, an author of children's books, kidnapped on Oct. 21, 1986.
While the hostage ceremony here today marked the beginning of Terry Anderson's sixth year in captivity, Thomas Cicippio prefers to think of hostage captivity in terms of days. On his lawn in Norristown are large white signs on which he has painted the names of each of the living hostages. Next to the names is the number of days each has been held.
Each evening, just after watching the late news, Thomas Cicippio goes out into the darkness and changes the numbers to reflect the correct total when the sun comes up. He has worn a path in the grass that leads from his front door to the signs.
Tonight he will change Joseph Cicippio's number to 1,283.

The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a former hostage who was freed in 1986, placed a yellow rose on a placard with names of hostages who have died in Lebanon (The New York Times/Jose R. HEADLINE: The Instincts of Parenthood Become Part of Crack's Toll

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 16

 BODY:
Crack can overwhelm one of the strongest forces in nature, the parental instinct, specialists in drug addiction say. As a result, some of them say, the United States is giving birth to a new underclass of disadvantaged youth like none seen before.
''The maternal instinct gets blocked out because the only thing that matters is the addiction,'' said Kate Vandegrift, director of New Image, a residential rehabilitation program here for women and their children. The program, for homeless addicts, tries to reverse personal priorities, providing therapy, lessons on being a parent and time for 18 women and their 24 children to renew or create a loving bond.
Sharon Hoyle, a resident, wept for joy the other night at her daughter Janine's 10th birthday party - a tangle of balloons, flashing cameras, wriggling children and proud mothers. 
Only months ago, because of crack addiction, these same women were letting their children wither and in one case die from neglect. On this night a year ago Mrs. Hoyle got high on crack instead of giving Janine a party or even a birthday cake.
''I am proud of myself,'' Mrs. Hoyle said. ''I love you,'' Janine told her mother. Rise in Cases of Children Children's advocates blame the crack epidemic for more and more of the 2.2 million cases of child abuse and neglect that are reported to child-protective services each year. A surge in the number of children reported to have died of abuse and neglect is also linked to crack.
The deaths rose by 36 percent, from 899 in 1985 to 1,223 in 1988, the most recent year for which statistics are available, according to the National Committee for the Prevention of Child Abuse. Social service workers say many cases of child abuse never make it into official reports.
Leslie B. Mitchel, the committee's senior research analyst, said: ''In the early 1980's, when we talked to child-protective agencies we used to hear that 30 to 40 percent of the reported child abuse and neglect cases involved substance abuse, and much of that was alcohol abuse. Now we are hearing anywhere from 50 to 90 percent of the cases involve substance abuse and much of that is crack cocaine.''
Some authorities on child abuse say that crack, like any addictive drug including alcohol, is just one symptom of a bigger social problem. ''There is no place for children in the crack world,'' said Dr. Marsha Rosenbaum, a sociologist, ''but it's not crack so much as the other circumstances of poverty that lead to neglect and sometimes abuse.''
Dr. Rosenbaum and an associate, Sheigla Murphy, has begun interviews with 125 women who use crack in San Francisco.
Other specialists in treating addiction say crack threatens families more than other drugs do because it is widely available and has a stronger appeal to women than other drugs like heroin. It does not have to be injected, and a single dose is inexpensive.
 
Crack Accelerating Abuse
Dr. Elizabeth Rahdert, a research psychologist in the division of clinical research at the National Institute on Drug Abuse, said: ''We know that it chemically impairs people's functioning so they can't make decisions, can't take responsibility for paying the rent or seeing that there is food on the table for their children.
''We know that the drug is a powerful stimulant that creates high volatility, makes people lose control, become very tense and jumpy. All of these things can lead to not thinking before you act, striking out, more rapid abuse.''
Addicted mothers are often single parents, and this can add to the stress of the family situation. Nine out of 10 men leave women addicted to drugs, said Ms. Vandegrift, New Image's director. Conversely, only one out of 10 women leave addicted men, she said.
An estimated 1.9 million men and 1 million women, almost all of childbearing age, use cocaine, according to the 1988 National Household Survey of Drug Abuse. Those figures, based on interviews with 8,814 people over 12 years of age by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, include 282,000 men and 203,000 women who use crack.
 
Stereotypes Are Dashed
And crack use among women seems to be cutting across economic lines and in some cases dashing stereotypes. Surveys in Pinellas County, Fla., by Dr. Ira J. Chasnoff, president of the National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education in Chicago, indicate that slightly more pregnant white women in private clinics than pregnant black women in public clinics test positive for cocaine in urine samples.
Nationwide, Dr. Chasnoff estimated, as many as one baby in 10, or up to 375,000 a year, are born with some illicit drug in the blood. And particularly because of what crack does to these children and their parents, experts say, there is greater risk of abuse and neglect.
''Crack addicts are more susceptible to all stresses in the environment, and children become stressors,'' said Dr. Rahdert of the drug abuse institute. ''When you have infants and children fetally exposed to crack, they may be easily excitable, hyper-arousable and do more crying. So if the child is impaired and the mother or care giver is impaired, the situation is even more explosive and dangerous.''
As for the scope of the problem, researchers are just beginning to study families damaged by crack use and to follow the development of hundreds of thousands of babies neurologically impaired by the drug in the womb who are now growing up in dysfunctional families with addicted parents.
But few researchers doubt that most of these children will have mental, emotional and social deficits that will harden their lives and threaten society. ''What it boils down to is that some kids will make it and some won't,'' said Nancy C. McDaniel, a spokeswoman for the American Humane Association, a 114-year-old nonprofit organization in Denver concerned with child abuse.
 
Families That Don't Bother
If social service agencies do not intervene, families with addiction simply slip out of sight, said Dr. Judy Howard, a professor of clinical pediatrics at the University of California at Los Angeles. She said that when courts do not order drug-addicted parents to bring in their children for free medical care, the families do not bother. ''Mandatory intervention is needed to keep these kids visible, so we know they are not being abused or neglected,'' she said.
But Dr. Howard acknowledged that family courts and social agencies are overwhelmed. And drug treatment programs are few, even though the Federal Government is spending $1.3 billion this year to support new state programs.
New Image is one of only about 21 such residential programs for women and children. Many of them started just in the last two years, and they can help only 500 to 1,000 families a year. The cost to public agencies, in the case of New Image, is $75 a day per family.
Mrs. Hoyle, among the first group of women to complete New Image's rehabilitation program, speaks of her past addiction with detached horror.
The 31-year-old mother, who is separated from her husband, wound up in a city shelter in April 1989 with her three children after being evicted from a house in North Philadelphia for not paying rent. For two years she used the family's entire public assistance grant, about $600 a month, to buy crack.
''I sold the food out of my refrigerator to get high,'' Mrs. Hoyle said. ''I sold my clothes, the TV, the washing machine and all our furniture to get high. The house was a mess, and after a while the only thing that worked was the bathtub.''
''The kids hardly ate,'' she continued. ''They didn't clean their rooms or go to school much. Their mom didn't care about them, and they just started not caring about nothing and fighting with each other a lot. I saw what I was doing to my kids, but getting high was more important than taking care of my family.''
Crack has the same effect on all people, said Dr. Lorraine E. Hale, president of Hale House in Harlem, which cares for addicts' babies and tries to find homes for them. ''We see all racial groups, including 8 to 10 percent who come from nice middle-class homes,'' she said. ''Of course, everybody's become poor by the time we see them.''
The one thing crack addicts have in common, she said, is utter disregard for their children: ''I've been working with female drug addicts and their children for 21 years, and I've never seen anything like it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sharon Hoyle, who a year ago was addicted to crack, with her children, Janine, 10, and Dana, 12. Ms. Hoyle is now enrolled in a residential rehabilitation program in Philadelphia for women and their children. (The New York Times/Bill Cramer)

HEADLINE: Governor Florio's Budget Bombshell

 BODY:
It took Jim Florio only a few months to admit something he wasn't prepared to concede last fall when he was running for governor: New Jersey needs new taxes. The time has come, Mr. Florio said this week, to confront ''harsh realities and hard decisions.'' He then unveiled a budget with $1.4 billion in tax increases. 
Setting aside the merit of his specific proposals, Governor Florio's bombshell was a refreshing display of candor. It was all the more welcome for its sharp contrast with the behavior of New York's Governor, Mario Cuomo, who has been silent as the Sphinx in the face of mounting deficit projections for his state.
It's hard to believe a politician as experienced and savvy as Jim Florio didn't have an inkling of New Jersey's revenue problems. But when his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, promised not to raise taxes under any circumstances, Mr. Florio countered with his own formula: ''I see no need for new taxes.''
However, as governors throughout the Northeast have discovered, economics has made a mess of revenue projections.
Mr. Florio's plan consists of more than tax increases. He would close a $600 million gap in the current fiscal year by an assortment of spending reductions, ranging from hiring freezes to refinancing of the state's pension system to delaying certain payments to local governments. For the fiscal year starting in July, he proposes reducing spending by an average 15 percent across the board; only prisons and social services would be shielded. At the same time he would raise the state sales tax from 6 percent to 7 percent and eliminate exemptions for certain products; substantially raise ''sin'' taxes on alcohol and tobacco, and impose a new tax on petroleum products.
The biggest and most explosive change would come next year. Mr. Florio would raise income taxes on people who make more than $55,000, enough to produce $1.25 billion. The money would be used to lighten property taxes for those with incomes under $65,000, to boost aid to poorer school districts and relieve local governments of welfare and social service responsibilities that appropriately belong to the state.
New Jersey has long had punishingly high property tax rates. Mr. Florio's proposed substitution of income taxes is a wise response to persistent demands for relief. And it has the added virtue of being progressive. The proposed sales tax increase is another matter. That will hit hardest at the poorest New Jerseyans - at a time when income supports are to be frozen.
The Legislature will need to chew hard on these proposals before deciding how to dispose of them. But however it ultimately disposes, Mr. Florio deserves praise for having the guts to do what governors are supposed to: lead.

HEADLINE: No Low-Income Catch In Social Security Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I appreciate your acknowledgment in ''Why End Social Security to Save It?'' (editorial, Feb. 22) that my proposal for a system of individual Social Security retirement accounts would end Congressional manipulation of the Social Security Trust Fund and create savings and economic growth, your major objection - that such a system would devastate the retirement benefits of low-income workers - is wrong.
My plan would contain the same skew of payments for low-income retirees as now under Social Security. Minimum benefit funding and the disability program would also continue under the trust fund as now.
Members of minorities, who statistically do not survive to retirement age in the same numbers as whites (and thus collect nothing under the present system), would have in the retirement accounts substantial funds for families and heirs if they die young. Even the lowest-income Americans - those who have never been able to save for retirement - would for the first time have a growing nest egg and a stake in the nation's economy.
I do not dismiss the difficulties involved. But low-income retirees would not suffer, and their benefits are likely to improve.
 
JOHN PORTER
 
Member of Congress, 10th Dist., Ill.
 Washington, Feb. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: Perestroika on the Prairie

BYLINE: By Dick Armey; Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, is on the House Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The idea of a central committee putting together a five-year plan for agricultural production seems archaic in the age of perestroika. But that's exactly what we are about to see in Congress.
In committee rooms, farm-state Congressmen will soon meet to do some old-fashioned logrolling on the 1990 farm bill. Americans will pay doubly over the next five years for the subsidies, price supports and import barriers traded on the floors of the House and Senate. They'll pay first in taxes and again every time they go to the grocery store. 
In the 1985 farm law, the Government invited farmers to raid a richly stocked pantry. It paid dairy farmers to kill 1.6 million cows and take five-year vacations from farming. It provided incentives to crop farmers to idle 61 million acres of farmland (an area equal to all of Ohio and Indiana plus half of Illinois). Through ''marketing orders'' designed to maintain artificially high prices, it forced fruit growers to destroy three billion oranges, two billion lemons and millions of pounds of raisins. Total cost: about $20 billion a year in taxes and $10 billion a year in higher prices.
Farm programs, unrivaled for their sheer economic absurdity, are fertile ground for serious spending reductions this year. We don't pay truckers not to truck, we don't pay miners not to mine and we shouldn't pay farmers not to farm. Farm policies represent an unparalleled Government war against productivity. They function precisely as if the Government were to pay Detroit to shut down half its auto factories to drive up the price of cars. It's not only enormously costly to taxpayers and consumers, but often to farmers as well.
Farmers who get Federal subsidies gain a competitive advantage over those who don't. To compete, even farmers who detest the idea of going on the dole are forced to scramble for Government handouts. Inept farmers are encouraged to go even further into debt than they would have in the absence of Government assistance. When the Government forecloses, it has to swallow more debt.
Since our agricultural programs encourage farmers to maximize yields rather than minimize costs, they favor corporate farms over family farms. Wealthy farmers can afford the huge combines that allow them to outproduce small farmers. Crop subsidies also raise the value of farmland, which is good for the landowners but bad for the nearly half of American farmers who rent their land. When the Government raises the value of the land, their rents rise.
Programs that pay farmers not to farm often devastate rural areas. The reductions hurt everyone from fertilizer companies to tractor salesmen. According to the Agriculture Department, policies to reduce acreage cost the rural economy 300,000 jobs, and cost the ''farm input'' industry $4 billion in lost sales, in 1987 alone.
If our goal is to help needy farmers, we should do so directly with welfare payments. A leading agricultural economist, Clifton B. Luttrell, estimates that a welfare policy would cost no more than $4 billion a year, less than one-third of what we now spend. Shifting to a direct welfare system would also lower food prices, giving a break to consumers and a much-needed lift to the poor.
Current programs do not distinguish between the needy and the greedy. Eliminating direct payments to farmers with annual adjusted gross incomes of $100,000 or more, or gross receipts of $500,000 or more, would target aid to smaller, needier farmers while saving taxpayers around $1 billion a year. No one can justify subsidizing farmers whose incomes are three times the average of the American family of four.
''To destroy a standing crop goes against the soundest instincts of human nature,'' said Henry Wallace, the Secretary of Agriculture under Franklin Roosevelt, who instituted many of today's farm programs as ''temporary emergency measures'' 50 years ago. We cannot afford to spend billions of tax dollars and billions more in higher food prices to perpetuate an outdated, inefficient series of five-year plans.
When it takes up this year's farm bill, Congress should keep in mind the interests of taxpayers, consumers and small farmers. We should repeal marketing orders, we should target subsidies to needy farmers and stop paying farmers not to farm.

HEADLINE: Cheney Calls 50% Cut a Risk to Status

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the United States would fall from superpower status if military spending were cut in half over the next decade, as proposed by some military experts.
Mr. Cheney's assessment, which came in a speech to the National Newspaper Association, appeared to be aimed, in part, at William W. Kaufmann, a former Pentagon consultant whose proposals for sharp cuts in the military budget have figured prominently in public debate. One of Mr. Kaufmann's proposals is that the Navy reduce the number of its aircraft carriers by more than half, to 6 from 14. In his speech, Mr. Cheney said: ''When serious people propose cutting the defense budget by half over the next 10 years, leaving us, for example, with a mere six aircraft carriers at sea, they are not talking about simple budget shifts. What they are suggesting is a radical change in our global status.'' 
 
'A Second-Class Power'
''They would give us the defense budget for a second-class power, the budget of an America in decline,'' the Secretary added.
Congressional critics like Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have charged that Mr. Cheney has been too timid in proposing spending cuts in the wake of the political changes sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
And a recent study in which Mr. Kaufmann, a consultant to several Defense Secretaries in Republican and Democratic administrations, called for a 50 percent reduction in military spending over 10 years has been cited by critics who believe that such cuts should go to domestic programs.
But Mr. Cheney, who has appeared to be on the defensive in the military spending debate, struck back at his critics today, portraying proposals for such far-reaching spending cuts as irresponsible and complaining that the Congressional budget deliberations are being driven by petty politics.
 
Concern for National Strategy
''In Congress, we face the possibility of radical cuts based on nothing save grand compromises over what parochial interests need to be satisfied,'' Mr. Cheney said. ''This willy-nilly approach to defense makes tatters of our national strategy.''
He reaffirmed his position on the future of the Soviet military threat, a position that had put him at odds with William Webster, the director of Central Intelligence, who said recently that the Soviet nonnuclear military threat is fast receding and seems unlikely to reappear in the decade ahead.
''It is too soon to say that the Soviet Union will never again pose a threat to ourselves or our allies,'' said Mr. Cheney. He repeated arguments that the United States can not assume that changes begun by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will endure.
Since the debate between Mr. Cheney and Mr. Webster over the future Soviet military threat became public two weeks ago, the two men's agencies have sought to discourage reports of major differences between them.
But the thrust of Mr. Cheney's comments ran counter to Mr. Webster's thesis that economic and political pressures will force a decline in the Soviet nonnuclear military threat even if Mr. Gorbachev is deposed and succeeded by hard-line leaders.
 
Two Views on What Is Needed
Mr. Kaufmann, professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a consultant to the Brookings Institution, did not hesitate to underscore his differences with Mr. Cheney.
''We have differing definitions of what is necessary to our standing as a great power,'' said Mr. Kaufmann, who argued that substantial sums should be diverted to domestic programs to restore the country's economic standing in the world.

HEADLINE: Japan's Latest American Foray

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Japanese financiers are making a strong push to expand their role in financing new office buildings in the United States just as American banks, dismayed by shrinking profit margins and loan losses from a glut of unoccupied buildings, are becoming more cautious and cutting back.
The expansion by Japanese and other foreign banks into real estate lending led Citibank yesterday to announce a revamping of its real estate business to cut back on lending for large projects and concentrate on related fee-producting services. Bankers say they can often earn more from specialized transactions such as interest rate swaps than from direct loans.
As the largest bank in the country, with the largest portfolio of real estate loans, Citibank has not avoided the losses from bad real estate loans that have hit many American banks over the last 18 months. In its annual report, Citibank said it expects the level of bad loans that are not currently paying interest to continue rising in 1990. 
 
Opportunity to Expand
 Already well known in real estate circles as buyers of prestigious office buildings, from Rockefeller Center in New York to the Arco Plaza in Los Angeles, Japanese bankers say they see an opportunity to expand their business and are busy hiring American experts in construction lending.
Included among the new projects they are financing are buildings in Jersey City for Merrill Lynch & Company; an office tower next to Carnegie Hall in Manhattan, and the Park Hyatt Hotel in Santa Monica, Calif.
''There is a real war going on for market share of first-class construction projects between foreign and domestic banks,'' said David Schulman, a real estate analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''The domestic banks have to decide if they want to fight for the large, high-visibility projects.''
Japanese bank executives recognize that real estate markets are slumping in many parts of the country. But looking ahead to better times, they want to become better established in real estate lending, particularly for new construction, because it can be much more profitable than other areas of bank lending.
And to earn the greatest profits in the few good projects available, Japanese bankers want to take roles as lead banks, rather than continuing to be junior partners of American and other foreign banks. Executives at American and European banks and real estate developers say Japanese bankers will probably succeed.
American bankers facing the stiffer competition from Japanese and other foreign banks say they are handicapped by fear of criticism from Federal bank regulators. Tougher standards by Federal bank examiners on real estate loans forced the Bank of New England Corporation to announce a $1.1 billion loss for 1989.
And other banks around the country have pulled back from real estate lending until they know more about the new standards and there are more signs of stability in real estate prices. These new standards do not apply to branches of Japanese and other foreign banks, greatly improving their ability to attract developers' business.
 
'Alternative Sources'
 Robert F. Upton, a vice president at the New York branch of the Mitsui Bank, said that the contraction of the savings and loan industry was also favoring expansion by Japanese bankers.
''Developers who once worked with savings and loans who are no longer in business will now have to look for alternative sources of credit,'' said Mr. Upton, who joined the bank last October. Japanese banks are already active in making mortgage loans, he said, and are now hiring technical experts who can handle construction lending as well.
Haruhiko Watanabe, vice president in the New York branch of the Fuji Bank, said that the Japanese bank could remain active in real estate financing during the slump because it was a conservative lender during the building boom of the 1980's and avoided the losses now hurting many American banks. ''Even though the market is bad, we think there can be good projects,'' he said.
As Japanese banks gained experience, Mr. Watanabe said, they have received many loan requests from developers who were attracted by the lower interest rates available from Japanese banks.
Henry Elghanayan, owner of the Rockrose Development Corporation, developer of a 60-story office building next to Carnegie Hall on 57th Street in mid-Manhattan, said that Fuji Bank's interest rate on a $125 million construction loan was a percentage point lower than that offered by American banks. ''And Fuji took the entire loan without it being conditioned on their being able to find other participants,'' he added. ''That's something U.S. banks don't do.''
For many years, American banks have welcomed the Japanese as junior members of the lending groups needed to finance large office buildings. Such sharing is likely to continue, bankers said, even though Japanese banks are now competing for the more profitable role of lead bank.
 
Lower Rates for Juniors
 All junior members of lending groups for construction loans, not just Japanese banks, normally find themselves ''scalped,'' collecting a lower interest rate on their loan than the full rate charged to the borrower. The difference, typically five-hundredths to 25-hundredths of a percentage point, is pocketed by the lead bank. In addition, the lead banker usually keeps half or more of the loan commitment fee, which can equal about 1 percent of the total loan.
Although the lead bank has more responsibilities and expenses, such as studying the feasibility of the project and monitoring construction so that money is not paid out faster than needed, the extra payments make the role of lead banker more profitable and very desirable.
''As long as we were going to be involved and exposed to the risk of loss, we decided to do the business as a lead bank, in a way that gives us control over our destiny,'' said Yasuhisa Fujita, deputy general manager at the New York branch of the Tokai Bank Ltd. ''Japanese banks have been regarded as merely funds providers,'' Mr. Fujita said, ''but with the proper people, we can establish ourselves as professionals who can handle all aspects of the business.''
Mr. Fujita said Tokai planned to increase its American commercial real estate lending, including construction loans, by three or four times this year, but he declined to identify a dollar goal.
 
Americans Hired
 To guide the expansion, the Japanese bank last year hired Kevin J. Mulvaney and Bruce F. Evans, two Americans with construction-lending experience at other banks. Among Tokai's early construction-lending efforts was co-managing with the Bank of Montreal a $180 million loan for an office building at 101 Hudson Street in Jersey City, where Merrill Lynch will move much of its back-office operations.
Stephen W. Laver, a principal at the Trammel Crow Group, a real estate development firm, said Japanese lenders were involved to some degree in almost every Trammel Crow project. Rather than merely joining lending groups managed by others, he said, ''the Japanese banks are increasingly developing a direct-lending ability.''
One aspect where Japanese banks can be especially effective, he said, is in attracting money from other Japanese investors who want to own or make long-term investments in American buildings. Japanese regional banks, about three dozen of which have American offices, have money to invest but do not have the personnel to originate their own loans. They are prime candidates to participate in loans managed by larger banks like Tokai, Mr. Fujita said.
 
Reputation for Price-Cutting
 In an effort to improve profitablity - an area where Japanese banks lag far behind competitors from other parts of the world - some Japanese bankers are trying to shed the image as price-cutters.
''Profits in construction lending are already shrinking due to price competition, and we do not aim to aggravate that situation by competing for new deals on price,'' said Mr. Mulvaney of the Tokai Bank. ''Our pricing plan is to be the equal of American banks. We would rather do half as many deals if it meant the profit margins would be twice as high.''
As Japanese bankers push for more business, real estate experts are wondering if the Japanese can avoid the losses incurred by some savings and loan associations that reached for the profits of construction lending but ended up making too many bad loans.
Japanese bankers vow that they will be cautious. But the real estate market has been treacherous, even for the most experienced American banks.
''The near-term outlook for real estate is not positive,'' the Real Estate Research Corporation said in the 1990 edition of Emerging Trends in Real Estate. With domestic banks and insurance companies awash in bad loans, it said, ''increasingly active foreign banks might look at the carcasses before they try to pick up the slack.''

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Unchanged in February

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
After posting the biggest increase in more than 15 years in January, producer prices were unchanged last month, the Labor Department said today.
Analysts attributed the 1.8 percent surge in January almost entirely to the effect of the harsh December weather on food and fuel. The flat figure in February stemmed from the milder weather early this year, they said.
''This confirms the fact that January was an aberration,'' said Dirk Van Dongen, president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group whose members pay the prices used in calculating the Producer Price Indexes. 
With other statistics released today, the producer price figures indicated that inflationary pressures had abated. A Federal Reserve report said industrial production was up six-tenths of a percent in February, less than had been expected, and the Commerce Department reported that housing starts were down 7 percent last month. [Page 34.] ''If good news is low inflation, then the February numbers are good news,'' Mr. Van Dongen said.
The financial markets had little reaction to the report, which was generally in line with expectations. But in the credit markets, Treasury securities advanced sharply in response to the industrial-production report, which was weaker than expected and indicates that the Federal Reserve will be less inclined to try to contain inflation by making borrowing more difficult.
Economists cautioned against drawing conclusions from one month's figures. The so-called core prices, which exclude the widely fluctuating energy and food prices, rose by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, close to the average monthly increase over the last year.
Thus, few economists expect the Federal Open Market Committee to raise or lower interest rates when the Federal Reserve policy makers meet the week after next.
''It's too hard to get a firm reading on the economy right now,'' said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at the First Fidelity Bancorporation in Philadelphia. He also said the lack of change in prices charged by producers last month was a further indication that a slowdown in economic activity late last year would be reflected in lower inflation this year.
Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said he read the figures as showing that the underlying inflation rate was still between 4 percent and 4.5 percent, where it has been for the last several years. Still, he said of the producer price numbers, ''This wasn't bad news.''
The Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, the most widely watched of today's statistics, was unchanged in February. The prices of intermediate goods fell by seven-tenths of a percent, and the price of crude goods rose by four-tenths of a percent.
Finished goods are those ready for sale to retailers; intermediate goods are partly finished items that require further processing or completed items that are parts of other products. Crude goods are those entering the production chain for the first time. For example, raw cotton is a crude good, a bolt of cloth is an intermediate good and a suit of clothes is a finished good.
 
Influence of the Weather
 Energy prices fell by 5 percent last month after a 13.6 percent increase in January. The change in weather was mostly responsible for the fluctuation. For example, fuel oil prices rose 25.3 percent in January and fell 30.2 percent in February. Gasoline prices rose 3.2 percent in January and fell 2.3 percent last month.
Food prices rose by nine-tenths of a percent, much less than the 2.1 percent rise in January, which was the largest monthly increase in six years. But the effect of the December freeze was still being felt. The index for fresh and dried vegetables soared 23.3 percent, following a 58 percent surge in January.
The index for finished goods now stands at 117.4, with 1982 equaling 100. That means a basket of goods that cost $100 wholesale in 1982 now costs $117.40.

HEADLINE: A 'Witching' Lift Pushes Dow Up 45.50

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks rallied strongly in spirited trading yesterday for the week's best gain by far, with the much-anticipated ''triple witching hour'' playing a significant role.
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 45.50 points for the day and 57.89 for the week to close at 2,741.22. It was the strongest gain since Jan. 31, when the industrials rose 47.30, to 2,590.54.
After four straight days of exceptionally slow trading, volume rose sharply to 222.5 million shares, from 144.4 million the day before, with a solid 884 stocks advancing and only 591 declining. 
 
Big Takeover Move
 And in an added attraction to an already busy day, Wall Street got a taste of its first big unsolicited takeover move in a long time.
BTR P.L.C., the British industrial giant, offered to pay $75 a share, or $1.6 billion, for Norton, the American abrasives company. In what appeared to be a sign that traders liked the deal, Norton rose to the No. 2 spot on the New York Stock Exchange most active list, surging 16 5/8, to 74 7/8, or just under the offering price, with 5.2 million shares changing hands. Norton said it would consider the bid.
Still, traders were not yet willing to believe that the heavy buying on the Big Board, particularly in blue chips, came from the big financial institutions and other ''real buyers.'' Many felt that much of the activity, particularly toward the end of the day, represented professional traders transferring into stocks and out of investment positions that expired yesterday at what has come to be known as the triple witching hour.
In the last 10 minutes before the closing bell at 4 P.M., the heavy rush to buy pushed the Dow up its final 10 points.
Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton, said, ''It's very encouraging that the market held its gain, but traders are skeptical that it'll carry over to next week because it happened on a triple witching day.''
 
Blue-Chip Best Sellers
 Orders from traders looking for blue chips catapulted several companies onto the most-active list, with General Electric up 3/4, to 64, on volume of 2.9 million shares; A.T.&T. up 3/4, to 41 7/8, on 2.7 million; I.B.M. up 1 5/8, to 108 5/8, on 2.6 million; General Motors off 1/8, to 47 1/2, on 2.5 million; Exxon up 5/8, to 47 1/2, on 2.4 million, and American Express, the last of the 10 most active, up 3/8, to 28 3/8, with 2.1 million shares changing hands. Buying in just the 10 most active accounted for 30 million shares.
Trading in the key 30-stock industrials pushed the Dow up right from the start, and except for a couple of dips early in the day, it continued up.
Along with the pep that the witching hour pumped into the market, traders accepted new economic indicators on producer prices, industrial output and housing starts as further evidence that the economy is mending slowly - but not enough to drive investors out of the stock market and into bonds in search of better returns.
Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers, said: ''The stock market interpreted the economic numbers positively, that the economy is still moving ahead slowly. But the preponderance of advisers and money managers are still cautious to negative on stocks for the year and feel that bonds are better values.''
Among the best and broadest gainers yesterday were computer and other high-technology stocks, particular in the Nasdaq market, where strong buying lifted volume to 176.04 million shares, the highest this year and up from 128.68 million on Thursday.
Cobe Laboratories, a medical services company, jumped 15, to 36 1/4, with 3.1 million shares changing hands in the Nasdaq market. Gambro A.B. of Sweden, a designer of blood systems, offered to buy it for $37 a share, or $240 million.
The common stock of Intel, the maker of semiconductor memory circuits, rose 2 1/8, to 42 1/2, on 6.5 million shares, pushing it to the top of the Nasdaq most-active list. Intel warrants jumped 3 5/8, to 23 3/4, on 1.1 million shares. Craig Barrett, executive vice president, said at a technical conference that plans were well under way to raise output of a new chip.
Highly favorable comments on earnings by Intel, Compaq Computer and Apple Computer helped lift almost the entire computer list, with I.B.M. up 1 5/8, to 108 5/8; Digital Equipment 1 1/4, to 77 1/2; Compaq 2, to 98 7/8; Apple 3 1/2, to 40 1/4; Hewlett-Packard 1 1/8, to 45 1/8; Tandem Computers 1, to 29; Automatic Data Processing 1 1/2, to 53 3/8; Microsoft 3, to 114, and Sun Microsystems 1, to 25. Cray Research fell 1 1/4, to 46 1/2.
