HEADLINE: The Making of a Census: First, Cardboard Desks

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 14

 BODY:
Just over a year ago Bill Buchanan, a personnel specialist between jobs, was given 5 assistants, 150 unassembled cardboard desks, a budget of $500,000, an office key and a mission: Make sure the residents of 42 counties in western North Carolina are counted in the 1990 census.
''First, we assemble the desks,'' said the 34-year-old Mr. Buchanan, who helped run a wilderness training camp for troubled youths before becoming a district manager for the Federal Census Bureau. ''Then I hire hundreds of people. Then, here they come. We train 'em; we do all these crazy things for a few weeks. Then they're gone. Then I sweep up. Then I look for another job.''
The once-a-decade job of counting American residents has been a study in standardization, its aim and no-frills esthetic like those of a McDonald's meal: make it quick, make it cheap, make it good, make it disposable. 
From February 1989 to May 1990, a bureaucracy of 9,000 people grew to nearly half a million people, more than 330,000 actively working, 150,000 more on call. By the end of this year, the Bureau of the Census will be back down to 9,000 employees again, and 25,000 cardboard desks will be headed for recycling centers.
 
Captured by Their Quarry
Mr. Buchanan had a head start. Most of the 484 district managers started assembling their cardboard desks only six months ago. Step-by-step directions told them how to fit Tab A into Slot C. Step-by-step memos and packaged kits sent from Census Bureau warehouses in Jeffersonville, Ind., guided every step of the process, from payroll management to space acquisition, from Federal purchasing requirements to employee relations.
Now, as the peak work period approaches, the district managers and the 12 regional managers are finding that the demography they want to capture has already captured them.
To assemble a work force, they must find people who aren't working or aren't happy in their work. To describe accurately the ethnic mosaic that is the American population, they need to find workers from all parts of that mosaic. To penetrate sometimes close-knit localities, they need local people.
''Fundamentally, we used to do this job with housewives,'' said Bill Hill, the regional census director who oversees the area from Washington, D.C., down to North Carolina, and from Virginia west to the Mississippi River. Now, he said, most of these women have left for the workplace. Students were also a prime labor pool for jobs lasting two to eight weeks. Now the baby bust of the 1970's has cut that pool back.
But the number of retired people has grown, and so has the number of younger men and women whose work is either intermittent or flexible. The ranks of many minorities have swelled, particularly among Asians. The bureau is trying to recruit as many black, Hispanic, Vietnamese, Korean and Chinese Americans as it can to penetrate their communities and get as full a count as possible.
 
Playing the Numbers Game
Thus far, according to regional officials from Denver to Boston, overall recruiting is going well. The first task that will need a lot of workers, a census of the homeless set for Tuesday night, seems to be adequately staffed.
But overall numbers are deceptive. ''If I'm at 200 percent of our target in one place, it doesn't help me if I'm at 20 percent 400 miles away,'' said Mr. Hill. The Census Bureau does not have much money to pay for moving or accommodations.
Then there's the question of who knows a given area and who is known there. Brian Monahan, Mr. Hill's deputy, explained: ''In the mountains of Kentucky, there are different communities in different hollows. You do not hire people from one community to go and count people in the next community or the next hollow. They are not well received.''
 
Picking Up Those Laid Off
The misfortunes of others are often the bureau's good fortune. Veterans of the prolonged and bitter Eastern Airlines strike are sitting at some of the cardboard desks. The depressed mining areas of Kentucky furnish so many workers that the bureau has put out ''thanks, but no thanks'' signs on its doors.
But in Concord, N.H., where high-technology industry is making the economy hum, things are tough for the bureau. Likewise, in Northern Virginia, where the per capita income is nearly the highest in the country and the unemployment rate, about 1.8 percent, is nearly the lowest, the Arlington district manager, Arthur E. Rives, is recruiting barely a third of the people he needs to meet his quotas.
 
Taking the Count on Time
An adequate pool of applicants, one that can accommodate a 60 to 90 percent attrition rate and still provide enough workers, is essential to beat deadlines.
Each missed deadline means a new expenditure. Too many missed deadlines and the bureau goes over its estimated $1 billion 1990 budget. Too many missed deadlines and there is a risk of missing the ultimate deadline, Dec. 31, when the Constitution requires the bureau to submit the overall count to the President.
Despite the recruiting trouble he is having, Mr. Rives is optimistic. ''We're doing wonders with ex-military and retired people,'' he said. And the polyglot neighborhoods of Arlington are providing a steady flow of minority workers.
A flier at a local library brought in Tuyet B. Huynh, a 54-year-old Vietnamese woman who has been in the Arlington area since 1972 and worked until recently as a part-time sales clerk.
''It's easier to get a job with this office than another Federal job,'' she said, looking up from the phone where she spends the days recruiting. ''I was thinking about going to work for the Federal Government. This is a foot in the door.''
This year, for the first time, census workers are being paid hourly rates that vary rather than a standard piecework rate. In most of Kentucky, enumerators - those who knock on the doors of households whose forms were not returned - will make $5.50 an hour. In Northern Virginia, the same job will pay $7.50. In New York, it will pay $8. Bonuses of up to $375 may also be paid. In the past 18 months, Congress has also passed some temporary measures to help census recruiters. Food stamp recipients' allotments are not reduced if they go to work for the Census Bureau, and neither are retirement checks for veterans and former Federal workers.
Many applicants have little idea what the census is all about. ''I didn't know what the job was,'' Habon Farah, a 24-year-old native of Somalia, said after her brother sent her in to take the standard 30-minute general knowledge and literacy test at the Arlington office. ''They said I may be counting people, going into houses. It would be good to learn about people in my neighborhood.''
The written test is graded and sent to headquarters for checking; at the same time, the Federal Bureau of Investigation checks to make sure the Federal Government is not sending convicted felons into people's homes.
''It's difficult for the average person to be prepared for how fast all this moves,'' said Mr. Buchanan, the district manager in western North Carolina. ''We're still hustling to get everything together for the next job.''

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Proposes Rail Line to Link Major Airports

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have introduced a plan for rail service to airports that would be financed by the state, city and local transit agencies.
The line would link the central terminals at Kennedy International and La Guardia using Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway rights of way. Stations at Shea Stadium and Jamaica would connect to the Long Island Rail Road and subways. 
Many proposals for train lines have been made, but none was built because estimates of ridership failed to justify their high costs. Transportation agencies also bickered over paying for a system.
Although the new proposal is extremely tentative and a formal agreement may be years away, the plan is the first developed with the cooperation of the major transit agencies, which would pay the money.
 
Advantages of Trains
Advocates of rail service to the three major regional airports say the service is needed to ease worsening traffic congestion and to keep New York competitive with other cities. Trains are more energy efficient and less polluting and prone to tieups than other forms of transportation. Rail service is also needed because the airports are employment and commercial centers, the supporters of the proposal said.
The proposal became public at a meeting of the Metropolitan Transportation Council on Friday. The M.T.A., the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and the State and City Transportation Departments participated in the planning.
The cost and time for building were not announced. Transportation experts estimated that the system could cost more than $2 billion to complete. The proposal would have to cross major hurdles before being built.
The Transit Authority and the Port Authority, which operates Kennedy and La Guardia, have argued for years over paying for rail lines to airports. Transit Authority officials have accused the Port Authority of spending billions of dollars on airport improvements while failing to contribute to build a link to Kennedy. Port Authority officials have said they support a jointly financed program.
 
Economic Conduits
The director of planning of the M.T.A., Gregory Johnson, said the rail line was needed to preserve the integrity of the airports, which are economic conduits for the region, attracting business and tourist money. More than 50,000 people work at the airports, and the aviation industry represents $19 billion a year in economic activity.
The Transit Authority plans to end the express subway service between Manhattan and Kennedy, known as the ''train to the plane,'' next month because of low ridership. The proposed rail link is expected to have a substantially higher ridership than that train because it will go directly into the airports and would appeal to business travelers and airport employees, M.T.A. officials said.
The M.T.A. estimates that the rail link would take 30 minutes from Kennedy to La Guardia, and the frequency of service would initially be every 15 minutes. There would be a two-track alignment with two trains on the track in each direction at any given time.
Under the proposed airport-rail link, the average travel time from Manhattan to Kennedy would be about 45 minutes using the L.I.R.R. and assuming a small amount of time to transfer to the new line, the agency said. To La Guardia, the average travel time from Grand Central Station using the No. 7 subway would be 47 minutes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A proposed rail line would link central airport terminals. (The New York Times/March 18, 1990)

HEADLINE: Stephanie Kupin, Principal, Is Wed

 BODY:
Stephanie Kupin and Mark David Greenwald, both school administrators in New York, were married last evening at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I., by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein. Mrs. Greenwald is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kupin of Yonkers. Her husband is a son of Jenny Greenwald of New York and the late Jay Greenwald. 
The bride is the principal of the Middle School of the Anglo-American International School. She graduated magna cum laude from Syracuse University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and she received a master's degree in education from the University of Pennsylvania. Her father is an accountant in Yonkers. Her mother, Evelyn Kupin, is a membership coordinator at the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
The bridegroom is the dean of student affairs and a history and economics teacher at the Dwight School. He graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and received a master's degree in education from Columbia University. His mother is the executive vice president of Regina Porter, a maker of women's clothing in New York.

HEADLINE: Pastimes;
Camera

BYLINE: By Andy Grundberg

 BODY:
Those of us who have to sort trash into piles of glass, cans and paper are already aware that there is a garbage crisis. Americans generate more than our fair share of refuse, much of it in the form of non-cycled, non-biodegradeable plastic.
There's a slogan, ''Every litter bit hurts,'' the obverse of which is that every less bit of litter helps. We should be happy whenever somebody does something to reduce the load on overburdened landfills. 
That's what the Eastman Kodak Company has been trying to do with a program designed to recycle the plastic containers that come with every roll of 35-millimeter film. Last November Kodak started a pilot recycling project at several processing labs. Guess what? It worked so well that many of the major labs are now clamoring to get on board.
The recycling project applies not only to film containers but also to the plastic spools and metal cartridges that are part of the trash that processing labs have to deal with. Kodak's role is to match up recyclers with interested labs. So far 15 such marriages have been arranged. (That reportedly adds up to 40,000 empty canisters a day.) Another 60 labs will be added to the network this year, Kodak says.
If, like me, you've always felt a little guilty dropping your used film containers into the wastebasket, there are now two things you can do. One is to save the containers and take them to a lab that will recyle them. The second is to encourage the lab where you do business to join the Kodak program.
What do the labs get out of it? For one, recycling companies pay a few cents a pound for the privilege of owning the plastic. For another, the labs don't have to pay as much for rubbish removal since they generate less rubbish. Finally, there's the potential for a public-relations payoff, as labs involved in recycling appear to be genuinely concerned about the environment.
The latest beneficiary of this public-relations payoff is the Ritz Camera Centers store in Newport News, Va., which was the subject of a recent Kodak press release about the expanded recycling program. A North Carolina recycling firm picks up the store's empties and delivers them to a plant that grinds them up into reusable chips.
Other labs now in the recycling stream include Wal-Mart in Texas, Guardian Photo in Slippery Rock, Pa., Crest Photo in Elgin, Ill., Photo Service of Cincinnati and District Photo in Maryland. Most significantly, Qualex, Inc. plans to have all 37 of its labs participating by the end of the year. Qualex operates the megalabs that used to be solely owned by Kodak.
One logistical problem remains. Large-volume processing labs can fill a trailer truck in a few days, but camera stores and one-hour labs don't offer recyclers the same economy of scale. As the program expands, the economic advantages may filter down to smaller and smaller businesses. And heaven knows, Americans will surely find new uses for all those tons of shredded film containers.
Speaking of which, Kodak and Fuji came under criticism from environmentalists (including the New York City Commissioner of Sanitation) when they introduced so-called ''single use'' cameras. The criticism didn't seem to hurt the cameras' popularity; indeed, both companies have added to their single-use line. Kodak's Stretch 35 panorama model was one of 1989's unexpected marketing success stories. But some of us still worried about all the trash they generated. Well now we can worry a bit less about the environmental consequences of using Kodak's Fling, Stretch or Weekend 35 models. Beginning this year, Kodak is planning to reuse the pieces of its spent single-use cameras, incorporating some of the components into factory-fresh new ones.
Once again, Kodak is working with the major labs that process the film inside the plastic-and-paper cameras to have the emptied-out bodies returned. The company hasn't announced how many of the parts inside each body will be re-manufactured, but it is demonstrating its desire to be seen as an environmentally responsible company.
Soon, of course, photography may become a much cleaner preoccupation, without the chemistry, litter and assorted health hazards it has long entailed. The day when we all make pictures on palm-sized magnetic disks and play them on television sets is not too distant.
Already Kodak is selling something called an ''image enhancement system'' that allows commercial users to retouch and revise photographs electronically. This brave-new-world device still depends on conventional film emulsions, but it makes a lot less mess than a single-use camera and doesn't require plastic containers.

LENGTH: 856 words

HEADLINE: ART AND TYRANNY;
Pieces Missing From the Picture

 BODY:
To the Editor:
John Russell's article ''Tyrants Fall; Art Endures'' [Feb. 18] was learned, moving - and disconcerting. His account of the toppling of dictators across Eastern Europe was disturbing in the evident disconnect between what was happening in the world of art and literature - and politics - there and here over the last half-century. For, while Vaclav Havel, Mircea Dinescu, Andrzej Wajda and other dissident writers and artists were bravely standing up to tyranny, and languishing in jail cells for having done so, many in the West now celebrating their counterparts' triumphant ascent into freedom were saying and doing things that almost certainly damaged the dissidents' situation, morale, and hope.
We know, of course, how geopolitical concerns led successive American administrations of both parties to acquiesce in the repressions of the East Bloc regimes imposed by Moscow, how our Government paid lip service to the ''captive nations'' while keeping its distance from East European emigres with their unpronounceable names and unassimilated anti-Communism. Now fashionable, then they were pariahs, these somewhat strange immigrants who, like the Cuban exiles, made us slightly uncomfortable with their blatant talk of freedom and liberation. 
But what of the intellectual and artistic community in the West for whom unconventional people and ideas are their very sustenance? Did they rally to the cause of human rights behind ''the Iron Curtain'' (dreaded right-wing phrase) as fervently as they did against abuses in countries allied with the United States, such as Vietnam, the Philippines, South Africa? The question answers itself. Indeed, the word communism never appears in Mr. Russell's lengthy article, nor do Marxism-Leninism, totalitarianism, Soviet Bloc, or any of those other distasteful cold-war phrases.
It is as if all these East European countries whose uprisen peoples are fervently cutting the hammer and sickle out of their national flags happened randomly and coincidentally to produce a crop of unrelated individual tyrants - a Ceausescu here, a Honecker there - bound to each other by no system or ideology. McCarthyism, it surely can be said, ultimately proved to be Moscow's greatest ally: it gave anti-Communism such a bad name that in liberal and intellectual circles in the West that epithet became more feared and despised than the charge of Communism itself.
What of those many artists and intellectuals over more than seven decades who were passive in the face of Communist anti-intellectualism and anti-spiritualism, who, if they did not argue the outright moral superiority of Communism, retreated into that intellectual cop-out, the ''moral equivalence'' of the superpowers and their systems? In his address to Congress, Mr. Havel eloquently reminded us of what the cold war was all about - the elemental struggle between ''two enormous forces, one a defender of freedom, the other a source of nightmares.'' Nor, unlike Mr. Russell, does the playwright-turned-president have either intellectual or diplomatic qualms in identifying the name and fundamental character of the tyrants he knows so well:
''The Communist type of totalitarian system has left both our nations, Czechs and Slovaks - as it has all the nations of the Soviet Union and the other countries the Soviet Union has subjugated in its time - a legacy of countless dead, an infinite spectrum of human suffering, profound economic decline, and above all enormous human humiliation. It has brought us horrors that fortunately you have not known.''
When Havel as victim could say, as he did to his Parliament and our Congress, ''I feel - along with my fellow citizens - a sense of culpability for our former reprehensible passivity,'' it cannot be ill grace to examine our own silence - and the culpability of those in that special class Mr. Russell celebrates, who purport to speak for the very soul and values of our society. President Havel includes in his startling moral denunciation the entire Czechoslovak nation which ''as someone's meaningless satellite - has refused to face up honestly to its co-responsibility for the world. It has a lot to make up for.'' What then, in the interest of truth and moral lessons for the future, must be said of the rest of us who, unlike the Czech people, did not live under the ''boulder'' of oppression? How shall we answer our children and grandchildren when they ask, what did you do in the cold war? We especially need to hear from those in the arts, those ''honorable men and women'' for whom, Mr. Russell tells us, ''what matters, in the end, is to bear witness, to tell what no one else can tell to the best of one's ability.''
By that rigorous but fair standard, it is difficult to apply Mr. Russell's sweeping congratulatory account of the record of artists, writers, and intellectuals in the West:
''Looking back on the last 50 years - as tumultuous a time as any in human history - we see that, over and over again, literature and the arts did not let us down.''
Not all in that esteemed community deserve an encore.
 
JOSEPH A. BOSCO
Washington

HEADLINE: Why Steinbeck's Okies Speak to Us Today

BYLINE: By ALAN BRINKLEY; Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at the CUNY Graduate School, is the author of ''Voices of Protest: Huey Long, Father Coughlin and the Great Depression'' (Knopf).

 BODY:
The image of the dust bowl migration is imbedded in American consciousness, permanently linked to our memory of the Great Depression. It was an epic event. More than a million people, most of them dispossessed farm families, left the declining agricultural regions of Texas, Arkansas, Missouri and Oklahoma during the 1930's and moved west to California. Though millions of other Americans uprooted themselves in those years, the travails of the ''Okies''captured attention in a way those of other groups did not. That was in great part because of the publication in 1939 of John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath,'' which the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago now brings to New York in a production opening Thursday at the Cort Theater.
Steinbeck became aware of the Okies in the mid-1930's as migrant workers poured into the agricultural areas surrounding his home in northern California. Their story possessed him, and he distilled it into his account of the Joad family's troubled journey from drought-stricken Oklahoma to the false promise of the west. The novel had a sensational impact, greatly strengthened by John Ford's classic 1940 film adaptation. Even 50 years later, the book, which won a Pulitzer Prize, is generally (although not universally) recognized as a masterpiece of American literature - and as one of a relatively small number of important American novels centrally concerned with issues of social and economic justice. 
The director, actor and writer Frank Galati first read ''The Grapes of Wrath'' as a boy. He never forgot its impact on him, particularly the impact of Steinbeck's storytelling. ''My life was shifted invisibly by the book,'' he recalls. Decades later, when he began an association with Steppenwolf, the ensemble company founded in 1976, he thought immediately of the novel as a project for the group. He spent three years adapting it for the stage and then directed the Steppenwolf production, which first opened in Chicago in 1988. It played briefly last year at La Jolla Playhouse in California and at the National Theater in London.
Mr. Galati, who co-adapted Anne Tyler's novel ''The Accidental Tourist'' for film, has always been drawn to literature as a source for theater. His Ph.D. dissertation was a study of Vladimir Nabokov, and as a young director he took a special interest in adapting novels to the stage in ways that would ''let the characters live dramatically without losing the heart of the narrative modality.'' It is a genre he calls ''chamber theater.''
No one would call his $1.5 million adaptation of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' a chamber piece. With its 35-member cast, musical ensemble and length of more than two and a half hours it is one of the largest productions in New York. But there is a simplicity to the staging that reflects Mr. Galati's commitment to making the original story, not his own adaptation or direction, the center of attention.
The set consists of a largely bare stage. The most significant prop is the heavily laden Hudson Super Six truck (reminiscent of the canteen wagon in Brecht's ''Mother Courage'') that becomes the Joad family's home on its long, troubled journey. Everything is designed to draw attention to the actors and, through them, to Steinbeck's words, story and social message.
''This production,'' Mr. Galati said recently, ''emerged out of a very intensive reading that made the essential elements of the novel clear to me. The book has a deep structure, an architecture, on which all else hangs. I made that the spine of my own work.'' He contrasts his play with the 1940 film, which he admires: ''Ford brought a rich visual poetry to the story. I can't re-create that on stage. For me, the language of the book is central and the spectacle secondary.'' One reason that Mr. Galati, who is 46 years old, chose ''The Grapes of Wrath'' as a project in 1985 was that he considered it appropriate for Steppenwolf. ''We are a young, committed, ensemble company, very much like a family,'' he said, ''and 'The Grapes of Wrath' is above all else a story of family.'' (Much of the original cast has followed the production to New York. Among its members is Gary Sinise, who helped begin the project while serving as Steppenwolf's artistic director in 1985 and who now plays Tom Joad. Lois Smith as Ma Joad and Terry Kinney as Jim Casy were also in the Chicago production.) But Mr. Galati also had other reasons for wanting to put the tale of the Joads on stage. ''This story needs to be told again for our time,'' he insisted. ''It tells us that buried in our success is a deep failure. Steinbeck was expressing a hope that human generosity would rescue these homeless and dispossessed people.'' He noted a parallel today in Vaclav Havel's recent statement to the United States Congress: ''The salvation of this human world lies nowhere else than in the human heart.'' We are, Mr. Galati said, ''on the threshold of a new world, at the end of a catastrophic century. This story comes back to us from a dark time to invite us to reflect on what we really value.''
Steinbeck, too, was preoccupied with the question of what Americans really value. He rebelled at the idea that individualism and material success were the only elements of the American Dream. He wanted there to be something more, and he spent much of the 1930's looking for it.
It was a long and difficult search, and at times he nearly gave up. His 1936 novel ''In Dubious Battle'' was bleak, cynical and almost hopeless in its portrayal of a failed strike by migrant farm workers in California's Salinas Valley (and of the futile, heartless efforts of Communist organizers to harness the strike to the party's purposes). Individuals, he seemed to say, were incapable of mastering their own destinies in the face of oppression; but they were also incapable of effective collective action. A second novel on the plight of the migrants, a vicious attack on growers inelegantly titled ''L'Affaire Lettuceberg,'' was bitter, angry and so unsatisfying to him that he burned the manuscript. He later described it as a ''mean, nasty book.''
''The Grapes of Wrath'' (whose title Steinbeck borrowed from ''The Battle Hymn of the Republic'') was his third attempt at using the Okies to assess the meaning of the Great Depression. Here, again, there were signs of hopelessness. The novel's main characters, the Joads, come to the end of their long ordeal in worse shape than when they began it - the family dispersing, their possessions washed away in a flood, their prospects bleak.
There were signs, too, of anger - in the unvarying harshness of Steinbeck's portrait of bankers, landowners, local sheriffs and other capitalist flunkies; in the bitter commentary on the human costs of industrial ''progress''; and in the radicalization of Tom Joad, who, thinking he has killed a policeman, leaves the family late in the novel to join an undefined movement committed to social struggle. He promises his mother: ''Wherever they's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever they's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there.''
But to Steinbeck, as to much of the vast audience his novel (and Ford's film) attracted, neither despair nor rage adequately expressed the real meaning of the Depression. And in ''The Grapes of Wrath'' he found at last a philosophical stance that expressed both his outrage at social injustice and his belief in the possibility of transcending it.
The true lesson of the times, he now suggested, was the importance of community - not community defined in traditional, geographical terms; not the community of a neighborhood, or a town, or a region; but a community of the human spirit, for which the only real model was the family. The apostate preacher Jim Casy (an almost purely allegorical figure whose principal function is to convey Steinbeck's spiritual yearnings) expresses something of this idea in his diffident way: ''Maybe it's all men an' all women we love, maybe that's the Holy Sperit - the human sperit - the whole shebang. Maybe all men got one big soul ever'body's a part of.'' Tom Joad later parrots his words as he explains to his mother why he must leave the family's struggle to join a larger one.
But while Steinbeck's men talk about a transcendent community, they generally do little to help create it. The male characters die, run away from responsibility, get into trouble and disappear, or descend into helplessness and paralysis. It is the women in ''The Grapes of Wrath'' who have the strength to endure and to lay the foundations of a new human community based on universal love.
Ma Joad, the center of both the family and the novel, gradually expands her own notion of ''fambly'' to include ''anybody.'' Her daughter, Rose of Sharon, helps a starving stranger by allowing him to nurse at her breasts. (Steinbeck's publishers considered this concluding scene so maudlin they tried to persuade him to remove it, and John Ford omitted it entirely from his film. Mr. Galati has retained it in his stage adaptation, convinced that it conveys the essence of Steinbeck's message.) ''Man, he lives in jerks,'' Ma Joad explains. But to woman life is ''all one flow, like a stream, little eddies, little waterfalls, but the river, it goes right on.''
To its many critics, ''The Grapes of Wrath'' is a hopelessly romantic novel, bordering on sentimentality. The treacly hopefulness and boundless generosity of its beleaguered characters often strain credulity. The political message is muddled and at times naive. But the novel's occasional bathos is part of what makes it such an important document of the Great Depression. Analysts of the 1930's have long struggled to understand why in the face of such misery and distress the United States experienced so little genuine upheaval - such limited radicalism, such modest violence. The most frequent answer has been the power of individualism - the tendency of desperate people to blame themselves for their problems, America's cultural inability to think in collective terms. But Steinbeck suggests another answer to that question.
He was hardly alone among artists and intellectuals of the 1930's in scorning the conventional American dream of individual success and material progress. But he scorned as well the Marxist dream of a great collective future driven by history and ideology. He embraced, instead, another social vision, no less deeply rooted in American culture than the individualistic ethos with which it competed.
It rested on an almost romantic notion of the natural goodness of ''the people.'' It imagined a culture in which a simple, folkish warmheartedness - a spontaneous generosity - would compensate for, and eventually overcome, the cruelty and oppressiveness of the economic system. The story of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' is a harsh one, to be sure; but in many ways the novel's message was as comforting to Americans of the 1930's as that of Frank Capra's warm, hopeful, populist comedies - and not, in the end, very different from it.
Steinbeck was expressing a radicalism of sorts, challenging the celebration of the individual that had so enchanted Americans in the 1920's and that many believed had caused the Great Depression. But it was a folkish unthreatening radicalism resting not on dreams of revolution but on a faith in the simple decency of common men and women. That same evocation of community has often been the source of intensely conservative appeals. Ronald Reagan loved to point to examples of spontaneous neighborliness to justify his opposition to ''paternalistic'' government. George Bush's ''thousand points of light'' similarly evoke an imagined Norman Rockwell world in which a spirit of community emerges of its own accord, without official compulsion (or Federal financing).
That ''The Grapes of Wrath'' has never stopped attracting readers, that it has become now the basis for Steppenwolf's ambitious and scrupulously faithful dramatization, suggests the fascination with which Americans still regard the Great Depression. But Steinbeck's novel is more than an intriguing period piece. Despite its many flaws it speaks to modern audiences, as it did to audiences in the 1930's, by evoking one of America's most powerful and cherished images of itself. It suggests that running like a river beneath the surface of the nation's cold, hard, individualistic culture lies the spirit of Ma Joad, a spirit of ''fambly'' and community that, once tapped, might redeem us all.
 

 
TOM JOAD, BY THE BOOK
 The image is etched in the minds of the millions who have seen John Ford's 1940 movie version of ''The Grapes of Wrath'': Henry Fonda (in photograph at right) as Tom Joad, telling his mother not to worry, he will triumph, though he is forced to flee the corrupt officers of the law.
Now, in 1990, Tom Joad is speaking again. ''I'll be all aroun' in the dark,'' he says. ''I'll be ever'where - wherever you look. Wherever they's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. An' when our folks eat the stuff they raise an' live in the houses they build - why, I'll be there.''
But the words this time are said by Gary Sinise (below), a founding member of the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago. The group's production of the epic John Steinbeck novel opens Thursday in New York.
The Steppenwolf credits of Mr. Sinise, who is 35 years old, include directing and co-starring with John Malkovich in Sam Shepard's ''True West'' and directing Lyle Kessler's ''Orphans.'' Throughout his latest venture, he says, the image of Henry Fonda has not followed him, has not been ''ever'where,'' ''all aroun' in the dark.'' He is not at all cowed about having a tough act to follow.
''I know that people identify Tom Joad with Henry Fonda, and he's certainly one of my favorite actors,'' Mr. Sinise says. ''But there's a whole audience out there coming to 'Grapes of Wrath' for the first time through the play.''
His primary source was the book, not the movie: ''I spent a lot of time with the book. I've seen the movie a few times. It's a good film, but it's 50 years old. In the 30's and 40's in Hollywood there were restrictions and barriers. You could not do things in the movies in the 1940's that you can in the 1990's. And the acting styles we have in the 90's are different from what they were in the 40's.''
Certainly, there was little in those days to compare with the Steppenwolf style of acting, which has been described as a robust and gritty kind of naturalism with the bristling energy of the best rock-and-roll.
And just how is Mr. Sinise interpreting his role? ''Tom Joad is a very simple man,'' he says. ''He's not complex in his moral judgments or values. He is somebody who during the course of the play goes through a kind of spiritual awakening, having his eyes and mind opened to a world much greater than his small one.
''A lot of the time he's like the mythic American hero,'' Mr. Sinise says. ''But I can't play a mythic American hero. I'm just playing a farmer who lost his farm, and whose family is dispossessed, and who is searching for land, and a home to call his own, and laws to protect them. He's somebody who just wants to find a job so he can pay for some food.''
 
 - Mervyn Rothstein

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Blue Collars, Both Fashionable and Frayed

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
And now, ladies and gentlemen, heeeeer's - the Common Man.
The blue-collar brigades may constitute this country's overwhelming majority, but they have been generally neglected, misrepresented or patronized on television, the very medium they use most. These days, however, working-class men and women are emerging as forceful personalities in an increasing number of weekly entertainments on network schedules. Some notable examples: ABC's blockbuster hit ''Roseanne'' and the new ''Elvis,'' NBC's ''Grand,'' Fox Broadcasting's ''Married . . . With Children'' and, spilling over into animation, ''The Simpsons.'' Possibilities for next season include ''Social Studies'' (NBC), about a working-class mother raising two teen-agers, and ''Babes'' (Fox), featuring three overweight sisters squeezed into a small New York apartment.
Entrenched, as ever, are standard stereotypes. Formula entertainment couldn't survive without them. There's no doubt that being a sarcastically jolly fatso enables the outspoken Roseanne to get away with being outrageous. But the new batch of ''ordinary'' citizens on prime-time entertainment are also proving to be significantly less predictable and more complex than their predecessors. Today's working men and women confront and squawk about inadequate paychecks, failing schools, ridiculous politicians, rocky marriages. 
Back in ''Golden Age'' days, ''The Life of Riley'' and ''The Honeymooners'' were played largely for innocent laughs. Later, in the early 1970's, Archie Bunker could get closer to sensitive social issues in ''All in the Family'' but only on condition that he remained parochial and, scattering malapropisms, ignorant. Carroll O'Connor's shrewd performance kept the character from becoming a complete buffoon. The real point: Masses of viewers, legions of ordinary citizens, embraced Archie enthusiastically. They found someone who lived in their kind of neighborhood and shared their kind of concerns.
A 1971 Federal report, ''Work in America,'' pointed to the almost total lack of dramatic representations, in contrast to the 1930's, of men and women in working-class occupations. The report said: ''Research shows that less than 1 character in 10 on television is a blue-collar worker, and these few are usually portrayed as crude people with undesirable social traits. Furthermore, portrayals tend to emphasize class stereotypes: Lawyers are clever, while construction workers are louts.'' For the most part, those regrettable depictions still hold. But there are some unmistakable signs of change. Offering dramatizations based on the life of ''the legendary'' Elvis Presley, the ABC series ''Elvis'' puts a halo around the singer's early years of struggle in the 1950's, in the process almost revering his working-class roots. The future king of rock 'n' roll is a hard-working boy, protective of his family and mindful of his manners. Unlike the stereotypes of working people that emerged in the late 1960's, when activist students ''discovered'' the poor, Elvis is not dumb or reactionary or bigoted. Despite the packaging, which is sometimes as self-consciously glossy as one of Steven Spielberg's ''Amazing Stories,'' the series inches through to new territory.
Some reasons for television's growing respect for the working class can be traced to lofty outside sources. Led by scholars such as Fernand Braudel and Herbert G. Gutman, historical studies over the last several decades have gone in new directions that, while emphasizing quantifiable statistics over official pronouncements, highlight the roles not of Presidents and elites but of laborers, slaves and office workers. These studies, in turn, have influenced writers such as Barbara Ehrenreich, whose recent book ''Fear of Falling'' offers a trenchant analysis of class structure in this country. A gradual trickle-down of these ideas to various aspects of popular culture was to be expected. But television operates on a far more practical level, and that means only one thing: ratings. Fact No. 1: The networks have lost a substantial share of their audience over the last decade. Fact No. 2: Up-scale, more well-heeled viewers are those most likely to sample the newer entertainment outlets of cable, particularly pay cable, and videocassettes. In short, the vast bulk of viewers who are stuck with traditional commercial television are the kind of working people who simply cannot afford many of the new alternatives (and may not even have cable available in their neighborhoods). And as that group becomes an ever-larger piece of the shrinking network pie, attention must be paid - and will probably be rewarded. The rapid rise of ''Roseanne'' to the top of the charts was not an accident. Roseannes across the country were making themselves heard.
Recalling the blue-collar backlash to the liberal activism of the 1960's, Ms. Ehrenreich points to a sense of exclusion and neglect permeating the white working class. Television had become simply a new channel through which middle-class professionals could talk down to them. Ms. Ehrenreich writes: ''At work they gave orders. In schools and social agencies they judged and condescended. Now here they were in one's own home, as televised commentators and experts, scolding, moralizing, carping.''
Today? Ms. Ehrenreich continues: ''Television, that great enforcer of emulation, brings to the most decrepit ghettodwelling intimate glimpses into the 'lifestyles of the rich and famous,' not to mention the merely affluent. Studying the televised array of products and comforts available, seemingly, to everyone else, the poor become more dangerous. There are no models, in the mainstream media, suggesting that anything less than middle-class affluence might be an honorable and dignified condition, nor is there any reason why corporate advertisers should promote such a subversive possibility.''
Television has been generous about letting working-class characters into certain types of programs, most notably action-adventure series and made-for-TV movies. Yes, all those police officers and firefighters, from ''Starsky & Hutch'' to the current ''H.E.L.P.,'' are, quite literally, blue-collar workers, but they have been used, for the most part, as handy tools to keep thriller plots rolling. Little if any time is spent exploring their own lives and concerns. Meanwhile, television movies are partial to depicting working-class characters in assorted crises - Farrah Fawcett as a battered wife, that sort of thing. But even here, there have been some recent advances. Christine Lahti and Jeff Daniels, for instance, starred in ''No Place Like Home,'' a movie that chillingly traced the descent of a struggling blue-collar family into homelessness.
It must be admitted that viewers, all viewers, are not yearning for programs that may leave them even more depressed than they were before they sat down to watch television. Pure escapism can be something of a necessity, as was demonstrated during the Great Depression of the 1930's when movie audiences showed a strong preference for frothy Fred Astaire musicals and Katharine Hepburn romantic comedies. But obviously the depiction of working citizens on television need not be identified exclusively with downbeat situations. On the contrary, there are those who argue that, as the nation copes with its hangover from the excesses of the 1980's, a ''rediscovery'' of the working class may be very much in order. Here, the familiar, more comforting stereotypes are again being trotted out: a supposed capacity for self-denial and deferred gratification, and especially an abiding loyalty to friends and family, a quality that even Tom Wolfe found admirable in his otherwise scathing ''Bonfire of the Vanities.''
Fox Broadcasting, eager to carve out a distinctive role for itself in the hierarchy of networks, has been consistently wooing working-class audiences with formats ranging from the drug shoot-outs of ''Cops'' to the sociological parables of ''Alien Nation.'' One of its most successful ratings performers has been ''Married . . . With Children,'' with the Bundys bringing ever-new dimensions to the stereotype of lower-class grossness. One recent episode featured Mom (Katy Sagal) cheering on Dad (Ed O'Neill) while he tangled with grotesque lady wrestlers in a Las Vegas competition. Fox usually defends this kind of exploitation with the explanation that the series is the equivalent of a cartoon.
But Fox's ''Simpsons,'' which really is a cartoon, is a considerably more perceptive treatment of the contemporary American family of modest means. Homer and Marge live in a town called Springfield, which, unlike the Springfield of ''Father Knows Best,'' has a nuclear-reactor plant and, among other things, a mediocre school system. Unlike the clan on ''The Cosby Show,'' the Simpsons battle each other and just about all outsiders as they struggle to survive in a world of rapidly falling expectations. They are strange creatures, thoroughly impossible and totally believable. And like ''Roseanne,'' ''The Simpsons'' has been climbing the ratings quickly, all the more startling given Fox's relatively low profile in terms of big stations.
By far the most rounded depiction of a working-class character can be found in ''Grand,'' an ambitious new half-hour show that tries to encompass the activities, often interrelated, of people from three different classes in the fictitious town of Grand, Pa. At the bottom is Janice, once the high-school cheerleader who married the football star, now a single mother living in a trailer. Janice works as a maid for a former classmate and her father, who happens to own the biggest business in town. Played by Pamela Reed, who refuses to stoop to caricature or easy laughs, Janice has become the most refreshingly honest character in the series as she copes with her own problems and those of her teen-aged daughter in a world where all the rules seem to be changing.
It is what Katherine S. Newman, in her book ''Falling From Grace'' (Vintage), refers to as the relatively new experience of downward mobility in American life, creating a situation in which children will not necessarily do better economically than their parents. Ms. Newman asks: ''If the 'approved program' of higher education, professional credentialism or devotion to home and hearth does not provide security and access to a life of fulfillment, then what does?'' The question sets off reverberations nowadays in the least expected places, including television entertainment.
The prospect of more blue-collar types breaking into prime time has rarely seemed more assured. Now it is a matter of treating the worker intelligently and with a degree of respect. The one obvious danger would be in programmers, the professional elite, deciding to talk down to these audiences, giving them what they supposedly want. Lord Reith, the unapologetic elitist who founded the British Broadcasting Corporation in 1927, stated the obvious danger: ''He who prides himself on giving what he thinks the people want is creating a fictitious demand for lower standards, which he will then satisfy.''
The resurgence of the Common Man should not be made an excuse for falling into that uncommonly barren cycle.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 18, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 16, Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2100 words

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Blue Collars, Both Fashionable and Frayed

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
With enough money, ingenuity and chutzpah, movie makers can do anything. They are able to re-create 19th-century Africa, the battles of the Civil War, volcanic eruptions and the new Dark Ages that will follow World War III. In movies, fetuses can talk and horses fly. Movies make the impossible look ordinary. What they can't do with any ease is imagine the time and place we live in now.
When, by chance, they present this world in some relation to its reality, the result looks strange, almost exotic, like the wasteland of Flint, Mich., seen by Michael Moore in ''Roger and Me,'' and Spike Lee's vision of Bedford-Stuyvesant in ''Do the Right Thing.''
The sight has the effect of being a major discovery. Take Martin Ritt's otherwise scrupulously commonplace ''Stanley and Iris.'' 
Shortly after a thief makes off with her purse and her weekly paycheck, Iris King, a cake icer on the assembly line at the Nevins & Davis Bakery, arrives home to receive the latest unemployment reports from her sister Sharon and brother-in-law Joe. They've been staying with Iris until they get back on their feet and, on this night, tempers are short.
Neither Sharon nor Joe has had any luck finding a job. Sharon is belligerent about it. ''Don't expect anything from us this week,'' she tells Iris, the only breadwinner in the family at the moment. Iris is a widow who is also raising two children.
''I wouldn't be here if I didn't have to,'' says Sharon. ''I'd be in my own house with my own Drexel furniture and air-conditioning.''
A few minutes later, Sharon blows up when she sees Joe go the fridge and take out a can of beer. ''Where'd you get the money for the beer?'' Joe, feeling no pain, doesn't answer. Sharon finds that Joe has spent the cash she had hidden in a cupboard. ''You stole my money!''
Now Iris is interested, since everyone is supposed to be contributing to the household expenses. Sharon becomes defensive. ''Well,'' she says, ''it's not as if I was going to go out and get a face lift. I was saving that money for my teeth.''
Joe swats her on the side of the head. Sharon screams, Joe swears and Iris sends her children out of the kitchen.
Though it is sad and desperate, this scene, which comes near the beginning of ''Stanley and Iris,'' is also funny and exhilarating.
''Stanley and Iris'' is not about teeth. Teeth are mentioned only once. The audience never does find out whether Sharon is saving for fillings, extractions or root canal work. But that one line is important.
It establishes the particularity of characters who live in a recognizable world where teeth are a fact of ordinary life. They are neither the joke they are in W. C. Fields's ''Dentist'' nor an excuse for torture, as in ''Marathon Man.''
Because the line is so specific, it identifies the social and economic setting. In this way, it helps to certify the film's real subject, which is worthy but not immediately riveting. ''Stanley and Iris'' is about illiteracy, but anybody who goes to see the movie will be ahead of it on that score: they will have read the ads. Yet ''Stanley and Iris'' is something quite uncommon. Here is a big-budget American movie, with big-budget American actors (Jane Fonda and Robert De Niro), in which characters worry about jobs, money and how to pay the bills. When they work, they work in any jobs they can find, rather than at those designed to realize innermost spiritual or artistic needs.
The innermost needs of the people in ''Stanley and Iris'' are rent, food, clothes and electricity. They are back to basics. So, too, are the unemployed in ''Roger and Me,'' and the colliding temperaments in ''Do the Right Thing.''
''Stanley and Iris,'' ''Roger and Me'' and ''Do the Right Thing'' are each, in one way and another, about the quality of life of that endangered species that used to be called the working stiff, even when out of work.
Movies about working stiffs have never been numerous or particularly popular in this country. In England, where class still counts, they constitute a genre to themselves. The most memorable being Lindsay Anderson's ''This Sporting Life,'' Karel Reisz's ''Saturday Night and Sunday Morning,'' Tony Richardson's ''Look Back in Anger'' (based on John Osborne's seminal play) and, most recently, Mike Leigh's ''High Hopes.'' No such tradition exists in America.
There have been exceptions, such as ''Joe,'' in which the working stiff turns out to be a paranoid, homicidal maniac, and ''The Deer Hunter,'' in which the working stiffs go off to fight in Vietnam. ''Marty'' found the highly romantized nobility of a Bronx butcher. Such movies are even more rare today. For one thing, the members of the American blue-collar or working class are no longer immediately categorized as such. Many blue-collar workers earn more than those in the so-called white-collar market. If income defines class, as it seems to do in this country, the most easily identifiable members of the working class would seem to be those who are at the poverty level, or who aren't working at all.
Oliver Stone's ''Born on the Fourth of July'' has so much on its mind that it doesn't depend on a single scene to give it credibility. Yet neither the harrowing Vietnam War sequences nor those in the Bronx Veterans Hospital, where the wounded Ron Kovic is sent for therapy, would have the impact they do if the film didn't so clearly establish the nature of Ron's background.
It's only against this background that the character's evolution into an antiwar activist has emotional weight.
Ron's initial optimism seems as much a result of how his large working-class family lives, with everyone squeezed into a small house that allows little privacy, as of the strict Roman Catholicism in which he was raised. The family isn't badly off. Ron's father works in a supermarket. Nobody is starving. But life is lived largely in terms of future opportunities, when things will be better.
The Kovics' house in Massapequa, L.I., the way it is laid out, where the bedrooms are in relation to the kitchen, living room and bathroom, is as important to the film as the locations that stand in for Vietnam.
At the beginning of the film, the house meets the family needs. After Ron returns from the war, paralyzed from midchest down, confined to a wheelchair, the house doesn't function any better than he does. He has grown up but not away. When he comes wheeling home one night, drunk again after being out with his pals, the truth of his condition overwhelms him.
Ron is fed up with everything, including the loss of all sexual power. His father tries to get him into his room. His mother screams that he has become a drunk. Ron pulls out his catheter and bluntly describes his problem. His mother is beside herself. ''I will not have the word penis spoken in this house!'' For Ron, childhood ends. It's time to move on. When movies blur class distinctions, it's because those distinctions are blurred in life. There's nothing wrong with movies about people who exist in a timeless present where the only worries are emotional and psychological. That is, as long as they don't effectively deny the other pressures with which most of us contend, including work, income and future solvency.
The difference between Nancy Savoca's ''True Love,'' a comedy about a probably doomed lower-middle-class marriage in the Bronx, and Herbert Ross's ''Steel Magnolias,'' which also has to do with marriage, among other things, is a matter of acuteness of observation in details of character, behavior, setting and speech.
Nobody in ''True Love'' worries much about the high cost of the wedding or future finances, but the way in which the characters talk and act is so accurate that one understands that, off-screen, there are other aspects to their lives.
The one-liners by which ''Steel Magnolia's'' proceeds from one dramatic moment to the next are so removed from recognizable character, except the playwright's, that the comedy seems thin and artificial.
What is reassuring in ''Stanley and Iris,'' ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' ''Do the Right Thing'' and ''True Love'' is not any so-called important theme but the manner in which each film recognizes the world in which it exists. Sometimes this recognition happens only in passing. Reginald Hudlin's ''House Party'' is a teen-age rap movie designed for the teen-agers. It doesn't mean to be a slice of life. It doesn't have any goal other than to keep its audience enraptured by comedy routines and music.
Yet ''House Party'' appreciates the quirky subtleties of these kids' social lives. It offers, seemingly offhand, details that give unexpected substance to froth. One fellow looks down on girls who live in ''the projects,'' not because of any nonsense about class, but because there's no possibility of getting a girl alone in a small apartment.
In the 1930's, 1940's, 1950's and into the 1960's, it used to be that movies were judged to be important or not, serious or not, by what they were about, not how good they were. For years John Ford's westerns were thought to be inferior to his melodrama about the Irish troubles, ''The Informer.''
Only later was it possible to admit that movies that tackle large social subjects tend to be clumsy. They stumble over their own important feet. Such films as ''The Ox-Bow Incident'' (anti-lynching), ''Gentleman's Agreement'' (anti-discrimination), ''On the Beach'' (anti-nuclear war) have always been seen by people who couldn't agree more, even before they enter the theater.
Ford did his best with his screen adaptation of John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath'' (anti-societal indifference to poverty), but it's still not the equal of ''She Wore a Yellow Ribbon.'' The movie is so elegantly photographed in high-contrast black-and-white that the images embalm in poetic feelings what should be primal outrage.
Hollywood once felt obligated to make the occasional socially conscious film. Darryl F. Zanuck, Jack Warner and the other great studio chiefs earned their brownie points by these considerations of the less fortunate. Today such relevant, or timely, movies are made more often for television than theaters, which have yet to receive one major movie that acknowledges the existence of AIDS.
A few stubborn film makers persist. Martin Ritt did not chance upon ''Stanley and Iris.'' It was written by his two longtime collaborators, Harriet Frank Jr. and Irving Ravetch, with whom he made the even more successful ''Hud'' and the Oscar-winning ''Norma Rae.''
Today nobody wants to see a string of what Zanuck might have called ''problem pictures.'' It isn't the problems that one misses on the screen. It is, rather, a kind of fiction that is not totally self-referential, to the extent that the world we inhabit seems not to exist, or to exist only in a kind of negative way.
The war on drugs is seen almost entirely in terms of enforcement, never in terms of the social conditions that make the taking of drugs so pervasive. It is fiction's equivalent to a policy that puts more emphasis on interdiction than on the treatment of root causes.
Most of these films seem lazy. Knee-jerk cynicism passes for healthy skepticism, which might ask the same kind of embarrassing questions about drugs that Mr. Moore raises about unemployment.
These days days when working stiffs go to movies, the working stiffs they see on the screen are mostly policemen or members of some other branch of the law-and-order business.
''Tango and Cash,'' ''Hard to Kill,'' ''Internal Affairs,'' ''Blue Steel,'' ''The Last of the Finest,'' to name a few. You might well get the impression from our movies that we live in a police state. In that context, a small reference to teeth is rejuvenating.
In the Feb. 18 Film View on the Oscar nominations, I gave the mistaken impression that members of Hollywood's various talent guilds are automatically members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The fact is that guild members must be invited by the academy to join the appropriate academy branch. Of the many called by their profession, only a small percentage are chosen by the academy.
Examples: Of the 9,000 members of the Directors Guild of America, 250 are members of the academy's directors' branch; of the 11,000 members of the Writers Guild of America, 381 are academy members; of the 72,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild, just over 1,000 belong to the academy.
The members of these academy branches vote for the nominees in their particular fields. The entire academy membership then votes in all categories for the final awards.

(pg. 16)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 18, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1515 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: March 11-16

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Geffen Gets the Gold From MCA Inc.
 
Joni Mitchell once wrote a song about someone ''Stoking the star-maker machinery/Behind the popular song.*'' The song's subject, some say, is David Geffen. On Wednesday, Mr. Geffen sold the company that records Ms. Mitchell's songs to MCA Inc. for more than $550 million in stock. Several giant entertainment companies had entered the bidding for Geffen Records, by far the biggest independently owned record company left. To the winner goes a roster that also includes Guns 'n' Roses, Aerosmith and Cher. The shine on their gold records translated to tarnish on MCA stock. It fell 3 points to 52 3/4 last week as major shareholders complained about the dilution needed to make Mr. Geffen an MCA executive and a rich man. 
 
 
 
Selling Junk by the Block
 
''Junk bond'' traders and investors bravely tried to convince themselves last week that the Columbia Savings and Loan Association could unload its huge holdings without wrecking the market. With its $3.5 billion portfolio, Columbia's cache is the largest single junk holding of any savings institution. The news last Wednesday that Columbia would try to sell the bonds in one block caused bond prices to fall. Robert Lupo, a junk bond analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, is one of those expressing confidence that Columbia can find a buyer. ''Not at market value,'' he said. ''But they will get a better value than they would have by dumping.''
 
 
 
Thirsting For the Saks Cachet
 
Like a newly rich entrepeneur striving for higher status, the Tobu Department Stores Company of Tokyo joined Saks Fifth Avenue management in an offer last week to buy the Saks chain. B.A.T. Industries of London has received at least two other offers for the high-fashion retailer. Tobu's own style is closer to 14th Street than Fifth Avenue; its flagship store isn't even on the Ginza. But Japanese consumers thirst for the many labels that Saks serves up. Initially, Tobu hopes to open Saks shops in its stores.
 
 
 
Now It's Cigars Giving Up Castro
 
The cigar world's most hallowed alliance has turned to ashes. Zino Davidoff said on Thursday that the company he founded has ended relations with Cuba. Davidoff International plans to produce cigars elsewhere. Mr. Davidoff said that the quality of Cuban cigars had fallen off. Some blame Castro's decision to quit smoking. Davidoff's Havanas, costing as much as $60 each, are forbidden in the United States; Geneva's cigar merchants have become specialists at rapidly removing the incriminating cigar bands for the benefit of American tourists. With the Cuban Government still licensed to market cigars under the Davidoff name, the company plans to certify its own products by labeling them, ''Qualite Controlee par Davidoff & Cie., Geneve.'' Mr. Davidoff's motto, after all, has been, ''In Zino Veritas.''
 
 
 
In Brief
 
The Norton Company, a maker of abrasives, received an unsolicited, $1.64 billion takeover offer from BTR P.L.C. on Friday.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Facing Limits on Aid Control
 
The United States wants to make sure a Marshall Plan for Eastern Europe doesn't aid the Soviet Union as well. Last Wednesday, Nicholas F. Brady, the Secretary of the Treasury, threatened not to join a new development bank for Eastern Europe if the Soviet Union stood to benefit. Under pressure from Western Europe, the United States dropped its opposition to Soviet participation in the bank. Mr. Brady's latest remarks are likely to ignite another feud over limits on Soviet borrowing. But it should be understood in Washington that, in contrast to the confident years after World War II, the flow of international aid is now beyond American control.
 
 
 
Sales, Output and Housing
 
Retail sales were down nine-tenths of 1 percent in February after a 2.8 percent gain the month before. Industrial production moved in the opposite direction - up six-tenths of 1 percent in February after dropping 1.0 percent the month before. Economists say these figures, released last week, reflected higher production but lower sales of cars. As Neal Soss, chief economist at First Boston, said, ''The auto cycle is the theme.''
 
*
 
Housing starts declined 7 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported on Friday. They had risen 24.7 percent in January as warm weather allowed more building.
 
 
 
Trade: Deadlocked on Deadline
 
Talks aimed at solving nearly all the trade problems between the United States and Japan appeared likely by last week to solve none. Meetings since September seem to be making tensions worse. The United States has asked Japan to stimulate consumer spending, break up huge business combines, reduce the price of land and lower import barriers. Japan says that the United States must improve its competitiveness by cutting the Federal budget deficit, encouraging savings and spending more on research and development. Negotiators fear that next month's deadline for producing an interim report will leave them with little progress to speak of.
 
 
 
What Joy in Producer Prices?
 
February's flat producer prices caused more rejoicing among investors than economists. Economists saw that Friday's figures included a core inflation rate, excluding food and fuel, of four-tenths of 1 percent. Food and fuel prices have retreated from the sharp increases caused by January's cold weather, they say, but underlying inflation persists. ''The economy is stuck at an inflation rate of about 4 1/2 percent,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic advisor at the WEFA Group. Tight money is unlikely to keep costs like college tuition and health care under control, he said. But traders said they were relieved by the inflation report. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 57.89 points last week to close at 2,741.22, the best since Jan. 11.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Gorbachev's New Muscle
 
Now maybe Mikhail S. Gorbachev, having assumed the Soviet Union's new executive presidency, can ram through some real economic reforms. Presidential decrees to allow the leasing of factories and farmland, introduce free-market pricing and encourage private enterprises are expected. Mr. Gorbachev has called for sweeping reforms before. ''But they haven't been sweeping enough,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. The Soviet leader finally sees the futility of merely tinkering with a planned economy, Mr. Mandelbaum said. Things are in such sad shape, he added, that Mr. Gorbachev ''has nowhere to go but up.''
 
 
 
Lithuanian Independence: Costly
 
Lithuanian independence from the Soviet Union is likely to carry prohibitive costs, even if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev drops his demand for $33 billion in compensation. The Lithuanian parliament declared the nation a sovereign state last week. But Lithuania depends on shipping manufactured goods - engines, machine tools and television sets - to the rest of the Soviet Union, a captive market for items that are shoddy even by the standards of Eastern Europe and a source of cheap raw materials in return. With just 3.7 million people, Lithuania is too small to attract Western investment, said Jan Vanous, research director of the Planecon consulting firm. ''The Soviet Union can live without Lithuania, but Lithuania can't live without the Soviet market,'' he summed up.
 
 
 
East Germans on Wheels
 
Once the Berlin Wall came down last November, East Germans had another fear: Would their sputtering Trabant sedans see them as far as the border? Volkswagen A.G. aims to relieve that worry by replacing East German Trabants with VW Polos in that nation's largest joint venture by far. Volkswagen announced plans last week to invest $3 billion in a partnership to produce 250,000 cars a year by 1994. Hauke Andersen, vice president for sales at the DG European Securities Corporation, predicts that, especially in VW's price range, there will be plenty of East German demand: ''The problem is not that people don't have any money, but that they have to wait 13 years to buy a car.
 
 
 
Free-Market Blitz in Brazil
 
Brazil has inflation so bad it causes indigestion: Restaurant patrons have to eat in a hurry or risk a higher tab by the time they are done. To the rescue of Latin America's largest economy comes Fernando Collor de Mello, a new President who took office Thursday. He has an ambitious, free-market plan to lay off civil servants, sell off state companies, improve tax collection, devalue the currency and tame the nation's 2,751 percent annual inflation. Even as he spoke, police raided supermarkets that were raising prices in anticipation of the price freeze he announced on Friday. United States banks have a huge stake in Mr. Collor's success, since Brazil is the third world's largest debtor. The new President vows to cut annual payments due on the $114 billion debt by half. Since last July, Brazil has paid nothing.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Bullish, but Just Barely, on Gold

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
''So,'' you ask, ''where is the price of gold going?'' ''Up,'' say the gold prognosticators, the gold bugs. This is the beginning of a new bull market.
But for these forecasters, the last few months have been a bit queasy. Every time the price of gold was about to settle at around $420 an ounce, it jerked back as if tied to a stake at $400. 
From November to early January, gold rose from $396.50 to $416.25, then dropped back to $404, up to $417.25 and down again to $394.50 on the third day of the new year. Since then, it has hit $417.75, and fallen. By Feb. 5 it had sprung all the way to $423.25, only to plunge to $396.25 on Tuesday.
The volatility has had an impact on the shares of gold mining companies in South Africa, Australia, Canada and the United States, and the gold funds that invest in them. The Morgan Stanley & Company gold index, which covers the major producers in these countries, hit a high at the end of Janaury but has fallen more than 17 percent since then.
While these declines present an opportunity for investing, they also call for caution. There are some forecasters who are less bullish than they were just months ago.
Among the factors that will influence the future of gold are the strength of the dollar, the smoothness of moves toward German unification and the success of the West German Bundesbank, the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve in holding down inflation. Serious political turmoil in the Soviet Union or Eastern Europe would also affect gold.
Jordan Estra, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, expects gold to reach $450 in 1990. He said the recent decline was triggered by gold sales in Japan by investors who needed to meet margin calls as the Tokyo stock market tumbled.
But he is positive because, even in this current rut, gold is about 10 percent higher than it was six months ago. He also said he expects the dollar, which has been persistently strong against the Japanese yen and has rallied recently against the West German mark, to weaken again soon. The dollar and gold have generally moved in opposite directions. Gold inched up to $400 at the end of the week as the dollar fell a little against the mark and the yen.
David A. Poole, chief economist at International Investors Inc., a gold fund in New York, sees hints of higher gold prices in the rise of long-term interest rates around the world and the jump in total debt in the United States. He reads both increases as portents of higher inflation, which always has pushed up the price of gold. But the central banks in Japan, West Germany and the United States are ready to move short-term interest rates higher in their efforts to curb inflation. If they are more successful than some analysts expect, gold could fall.
Warren Myers, vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, is also a gold bull and agrees that the dollar is the main lever on gold now. If German unification goes well, the dollar will weaken against the mark, which would be good for gold. And if the Japanese finally raise interest rates again - which is expected - the dollar could weaken against the yen, too.
But with gold in its current range, he is also worried. One indicator he watches closely is the relationship of the current price of gold and a 12-month moving average he constructs. In the past, when the price of gold has fallen below the 12-month average, that has indicated the end of the bull market. Now, the 12-month average is at $385, just ''spitting distance away,'' he said.
So for now he is recommending that investors only put a ''toe in the water.''
''I feel this is just a consolidation and that we are on our way to a bull market,'' he said. ''But if I am wrong, I don't want to be overcommitted.''
 
Stock Market Stars
 The little stock markets in Austria and Norway, which both touched new highs Friday, are still far outdistancing the world's major stock markets. For the year, Austria is up 53.6 percent and Norway is up 23 percent in dollar terms. Shipping stocks and oil prices have helped in Norway. Austria has been immune to the political and inflation concerns that have caused sharp swings in West Germany.
