HEADLINE: Stemming the Losses: Trying for a Leaner Macy's

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
In the fickle world of consumption in which R. H. Macy & Company makes its living, every day is another dollar and every day may bring another horror. How is one going to sell those weasel-skin mufflers that only yesterday seemed so haute couture? Why did the buyer have to take 7,000 of the musical cutting boards?
In recent months it seems there have been nearly as many horrors as dollars for New York's biggest retailer, crowned by last week's report of a staggering loss in the latest quarter, which included the vital Christmas selling season. Thus there is a growing conviction among retailing analysts and suppliers that this is a crucial year for Macy's to wring fat from its operations and prove that it is once again capable of making money.
In an interview last week at his stately office above the Herald Square flagship store, Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's steel-willed chairman and chief executive, shouldered partial blame for the poor results but ascribed them mostly to aberrational external factors. He said that he was convinced Macy's will merchandise its way out of its woes. 
Last week Macy's reported a $39 million loss in its second quarter, ended Jan. 27, compared with a profit of $72.6 million a year ago, though sales did manage to climb by 7.2 percent, to $2.44 billion. The deficit was the fourth consecutive quarterly loss for the company. Meanwhile, Moody's Investors Service Inc. last Wednesday downgraded Macy's already low-rated ''junk bonds,'' to the annoyance of Macy's management.
 
Blankets of Debt
 The problem with a succession of losses is that they put pressure on Macy's in paying down its mountainous $5.6 billion debt. Macy's has been covered with blankets of debt since Mr. Finkelstein and 350 of his associates spearheaded a leveraged buyout of the company in July 1986. Additional debt was tacked on when the company bought the Bullock's and I. Magnin chains in 1988.
Unquestionably, Macy's was roiled by abnormalities last year. The debt crunch that sank the Campeau Corporation and provoked it to broadly mark down merchandise in its stores impelled Macy's to rewrite its price tickets to cling to its market share. What's more, the San Francisco earthquake last October crimped the sales of Macy's important San Francisco store, which has yet to rebound.
More generally, the big retailer is fighting a grim climate characterized by too many stores and by a flight by customers away from department stores to specialty boutiques that stock focused merchandise.
Management error has also played a role. ''It wasn't only Campeau,'' Mr. Finkelstein admitted. ''I think I have to take responsibility. We have always taken deep inventory positions and we realized in late October that it was too much and we had to take markdowns.''
In recent months, Mr. Finkelstein has worked at scaling back inventory to the levels held in 1988. Last fall, he said, inventory ran at an average of $3.4 billion in retail dollars, while this year he expects it to be at $3 billion.
''We are going to have plenty of merchandise,'' he said. ''But we are going to be leaner.''
Why did the company let inventory levels get so high? ''It was ill conceived,'' he said. ''We got a little exuberant.''
Though Mr. Finkelstein said he remains committed to a basic merchandising strategy of vast selection and a mix of store and national brands, he said he would steer the company away from the frequent promotions of the past. ''We were a promotional, value, high-fashion company,'' he said. ''We are going to move away from this.''
Over the next two years Macy's plans to eliminate half its one-day sales, bargain days that Mr. Finkelstein said draw more than double the surge of shoppers who file in on a normal day. Last year, he said, Macy's had 11 one-day sales. He expects there will be eight or nine this year (forget waiting for the April bonanza, for instance; it will not come) and probably six next year. At the same time, sales will be promoted less heavily with advertising.
Moreover, the retailer intends to cut back on the more isolated day-in and day-out, 25-percent-off-type sales that surface in various departments. As Mark Handler, Macy's president, put it: ''We're not going to give the customer the electric shock each day.''
The problematic question is how much the reduction in promotions will affect those customers whose lives are dedicated to bargains. Mr. Finkelstein acknowledged that he expects some sales volume will be lost. In what he is expecting to be a slow-growth year, he estimated that revenues will continue to climb in 1990, but perhaps 2 to 3 percentage points less than with the full panoply of sales. Yet he said margains should be higher.
Though he said Macy's is not keeping up with the seven-year plan that was crafted when the company went private and will continue to show losses the next couple of quarters, he predicted that the deficits will be appreciably below the latest quarter. ''For sure we will be profitable for the Christmas quarter,'' he said. ''That's a slam dunk.''
With the raft of sour news, the morale of Macy's employees has become a worrisome matter. Recruiters who specialize in the retailing industry report that they detect substantial uneasiness among Macy's personnel, including some of the people who are part of the buyout group, and there have been persistent rumors of impending waves of layoffs. Mr. Finkelstein said the company is constantly reviewing functions and weeding out unneeded people, but he insisted there will be no mass layoffs. ''Not while I'm running the company,'' he said. ''You can't do business from empty wagons and without people to sell it.''
 
Symbolic Actions
 While Mr. Finkelstein said he didn't think morale was bad - though he admitted, ''I might be the last to know'' - he has initiated certain symbolic actions. He has exhorted his top executives to wave the Macy's banner for longer hours, a maneuver that may have partially backfired on him.
At a conference last month of the presidents and chairmen of the Macy's divisions, Mr. Finkelstein implored them to put in another workday to prop up the mood of the troops. ''I told my associates that I'm going to start coming in every Saturday,'' he said. ''I didn't think it would hurt the morale of the employees if they saw the chairman here and walking around. I suggested they might do the same. We had had a lousy quarter and we're supposed to be hands-on management. We ought to be here. I was under the impression that people were doing it anyway.''
Some Macy's executives who were not doing it anyway were subsequently quoted in newspaper reports as being miffed about the prolonged hours.
Mr. Finkelstein's response is: ''If somebody feels put upon by this, they shouldn't be in the business. They should leave.''
Macy's bankers and investors maintain that the recent red numbers have not caused them fitful sleep. They feel the company remains viable enough to plow through the nasty retailing climate.
A number of analysts, though, are looking for Mr. Finkelstein to impose gutsy measures. ''I think they may have to cut back on everything but on the selling floor to get leaner and meaner,'' said Walter Loeb, a retailing analyst. ''They have to look at some of the outlying stores to see if they make sense and if perhaps they should sell them and throw the resources to the stores that are making the profits.''
 
'People Do Want Action'
 Many in the retailing community feel this year is crucial for Mr. Finkelstein to demonstrate beyond doubt that he has matters under control. ''People do want action,'' one analyst said. ''He's got a half a year to show the suppliers and everyone else how tough he can be. And I think he can do it.''
In viewing the Macy's situation, it is important to distinguish between Macy's and Campeau. Campeau's debt load is appreciably steeper than Macy's, and Campeau had not been meeting its interest payments. Macy's has. That being said, too many more quarters of heavy losses could hurl Macy's into a financial abyss of its own.
Yet it would probably take a recession or another Christmas as poor as the last one, financial analysts say, for Macy's to be severely crippled.
Evan Mann, an analyst of high-yield bonds at Dillon, Read & Company, said that by using a model that assumes a continued weak retailing environment, he produced projections that suggest Macy's will be able to satisfy the interest and principal obligations on its debt over the next few years. ''We think Macy's will be a survivor longer term,'' he said. ''There will be some bumps along the road. But we don't think we'll have too many Christmases like the one we just saw.''
Although Mr. Finkelstein said he had no plans to sell any stores, he did say that he intends to sell several unencumbered assets - worth some $150 million, he estimated - and use the proceeds to retire debt.
Mr. Finkelstein also said that Macy's has been approached recently by several groups of investors he declined to identify who are interested in buying into the company. He rated the odds of that happening as small, but said that if minority stakes are sold those proceeds would also be used to retire debt.
Though rumors of great distress at Macy's have sped through retailing circles this year, suppliers say they continue to get paid and are sanguine that sunnier times lie ahead.
''I've had no problem getting paid and have not hesitated to ship out goods,'' said Ken Zitomer, president of Russ Togs Inc., a clothing wholesaler. ''I think they're going through a blip with the rest of the marketplace.''
''They want to get away from the promotional syndrome where you have 500 sales days in 365 days,'' said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller Inc., another clothing wholesaler. ''They know there's no competing with suicide. If people want to commit suicide, you can't beat them. Now Macy's is backing off from the promotions and selling a lot of merchandise of ours and others at full price.''
In order to do that, Mr. Konheim said, Macy's and other stores have been putting heavy pressure on him to trim his prices. ''The mood of the country is not to go spend your brains out on merchandise that's not essential,'' he said. ''This is emotional merchandise we're talking about.''
Macy's greatly expanded its private-label business during the 1980's to bask in the higher profits to be wrung from store brands. But with sales of women's clothing contracting, suppliers and analysts say Macy's has been cutting back on private labels. Mr. Finkelstein, though, said the overall share of Macy's merchandise that is private label is about the same and he plans no change. Should Macy's have known better in preparing for the rough times? Mr. Finkelstein was quick to say that he and his top executives do not sit around staring through windows designing grand plans. ''We are busy running the business,'' he said. ''It's a rag business. It's a detail business. That's how we spend our time.''
 
DEAR INVESTOR: HERE'S BAD NEWS
Knowing things have gone poorly, the top executives at Macy's have spent a fair amount of time in recent months penning letters and meeting with skittish bankers to pacify their fears.
The company has sent out a string of ''Dear Investor'' letters to divulge how things are progressing - or not progressing.
Last Dec. 12, for example, investors received a four-page letter spelling out the turmoil in retailing. It related that the integration of Bullock's and I. Magnin was proving ''frustrating'' and taking ''longer than we would like.'' It also pointed out that no new stores would be opened in 1990 and only one in 1991 to hold down capital expenditures and focus on improving existing stores.
A March 12 letter, in addition to furnishing investors with the bleak numbers for the Christmas quarter, cautioned them about expecting too much too soon: ''We expect a flat economy in the spring and fall seasons and have planned our sales and expenses accordingly.'' But the message was still spiced with optimism: ''We view the future with enthusiasm and, though the past season was a difficult one, it is behind us.''
Besides the investor letters, Myron E. Ullman, Macy's executive vice president and chief financial officer, has conducted a number of meetings with small groups of lenders to assure them that Macy's is not in dire shape.
''We don't want to be cavalier,'' said Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman. ''When you have bad news, it's important to communicate.''

HEADLINE: The Battle Over Regulation of the Futures Markets

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Washington's version of a hostile takeover is starting to take shape. No money is on the table and no stock will change hands. But the outcome could change the markets far more - and far longer - than even the biggest billion-dollar deal.
The battle is pitting two of the nation's leading financial regulators against each other. It is also re-igniting a decades-old rivalry between New York's old-line Wall Street firms and Chicago's rough-and-tumble world of the commodities and futures trading pits.
The target of the would-be takeover is the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, regulator of all futures trading. The agency is led by Wendy L. Gramm, a scrappy economist and former whiz kid at the Reagan budget office. 
The raider is the much larger Securities and Exchange Commission, watchdog of Wall Street, and its new no-nonsense chairman, Richard C. Breeden, a former securities lawyer and a self-assured protege of President Bush who was the chief architect of the Administration's bailout plan for the savings and loan industry.
Behind Mr. Breeden is Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady, close friend of President Bush and one-time head of Wall Street's Dillon, Read & Company. In recent weeks, Mr. Brady has sent shock waves through the Chicago pits by saying that the Treasury is studying a plan that would merge the two agencies, with the clear implication that the S.E.C. would come out as the dominant regulator. (The case for a merger: Forum, opposite.) At the heart of the Treasury thinking is the contention that the divided regulatory responsibility for stocks and stock-index futures is weakening the American capital markets. Stock-index futures are contracts whose value is tied to a basket of underlying stocks; they permit investors to speculate on the future course of the market without owning any actual shares.
Among other things, Mr. Brady and Mr. Breeden argue that because of the split in jurisdiction, the Government cannot pursue effective enforcement of price manipulation between the futures and equities markets, and that different margin requirements create unacceptable levels of volatility. They also contend that jurisdictional squabbles are hampering the development of new financial instruments, jeopardiz-ing the future competitiveness of the United States in global markets. (See box.) They point to a lawsuit by the futures industry last year that stopped three stock exchanges from trading a new type of financial instrument. Within months, that same instrument was being traded in London.
For their part, supporters of the C.F.T.C. argue that any risks are being overdramatized and that the agency is doing its job well. The move, they say, is nothing more than a naked power play by forces allied with Wall Street that have bridled at Chicago's growing influence.
While it is anybody's guess whether Mr. Brady and Mr. Breeden will pull off a full-blown merger, many people close to the infighting say it is all but certain that the S.E.C. will at least wind up with expanded jurisdiction over stock-index futures. ''Anything less than that is unacceptable,'' said one senior Treasury official.
There are now many players in the growing battle, and few doubt that there will be plenty of blood on the floor by the time the fighting is over.
One of the other major figures is Leo Melamed, who earlier this month announced that he would step down at the end of the year as the chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the most dominant of the commodities exchanges in that city.
Long considered the godfather of the financial futures industry, the outspoken Mr. Melamed has adroitly used his stature and Washington contacts to keep at bay for more than two years the forces that favor stripping the C.F.T.C. of its jurisdiction. Now, his lame-duck status is sure to weaken Chicago's hand.
Meanwhile, the fracas is likely to create deep tensions between the House and Senate Agriculture Committees, which have jurisdiction over the C.F.T.C., and the Senate Banking Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversee the S.E.C.
In the House, Dennis E. Eckart, Democrat from Ohio, and Dan Glickman, Democrat from Kansas, promised last week to introduce a bill to merge the agencies. In the Senate, Slade Gorton, Republican from Washington, has said he would propose a measure to give the S.E.C. jurisdiction over stock-index futures.
And ever in the background is Mrs. Gramm's husband, Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican. Senator Gramm, an influential member of the Banking Committee, is also known as one of the Senate's most skillful tacticians. So far, he has been silent on the agency squabble. But Senate etiquette will require those who oppose his wife's position to proceed gingerly.
At the center of the fracas, of course, are Mr. Breeden and Mrs. Gramm, two formidable adversaries.
Mr. Breeden, who is 40 years old and who has earned a reputation as an astute Washington operative, has declined to say that he favors taking over part or all of the C.F.T.C.'s turf. But that has not stopped him from turning out a drumbeat of warnings about split jurisdiction.
''I have not publicly argued for any change in jurisdiction; I have tried to talk about the problems,'' Mr. Breeden said in a recent interview. ''But I am not unwilling to eventually support some way of solving these problems.''
Mrs. Gramm, 44 years old, is not in as strong a position politically. A Reagan appointee, she and her agency have come under intense criticism in the wake of last year's trading scandal in Chicago, which has resulted in the indictment of more than 30 traders on charges of price manipulation and trading fraud.
Moreover, her term expires next month and she is hoping to get reappointed. Thus, Treasury officials say it will be difficult for her to stand in the way of a full or partial merger with the S.E.C., especially if Mr. Brady convinces President Bush to put his weight behind the issue.
Nonetheless, she is a long way from waving a white flag. ''In the coming year, the future of this industry will be written in large part in Washington, not Chicago or New York,'' Mrs. Gramm told traders at the Futures Industry Association's annual meeting in Boca Raton, Fla., earlier this month. ''We believe that the same agency that regulates all other futures should continue to regulate stock-index futures.''
The debate over the need for two regulators is not new. In the 1970's, the Chicago markets began trading interest-rate futures and currency futures, transforming the C.F.T.C. into more than just a regulator of pork belly, wheat and orange juice trading. Even then, the S.E.C. argued that it should regulate trading of the new financial instruments because of their impact on the securities markets.
A truce came in 1982. The S.E.C. got jurisdiction over stocks and options, and the C.F.T.C. got futures trading.
But the advent of stock-index futures began to raise concerns again about split jurisdiction, concerns that were heightened by the October 1987 market crash. The Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms, headed by Mr. Brady, then a private citizen, concluded that the use of index futures by major investment houses had exacerbated the market plunge. Mr. Brady also warned that low margin levels on index futures permitted excessive speculation and that authority to set margin levels be given to a Government agency, rather than left with the futures exchanges.
David S. Ruder, then S.E.C. chairman, took up the fight, arguing that since the stock-index futures were so linked to the price of the underlying stocks, the S.E.C. should regulate both instruments.
But Mrs. Gramm, who had just assumed the head of the agency, effectively parried Mr. Ruder's claims, convincing lawmakers that her agency was up to the task and that low margin levels on futures were not a cause of the stock market plunge.
Most important, in the high-powered White House Working Group on the Markets set up after the crash to promote greater regulatory coordination, Mr. Ruder found himself the lone voice, and Mrs. Gramm enjoyed the support of the Reagan Treasury.
Now the equation has changed. Mrs. Gramm finds that she is outnumbered on the Working Group, which over the last six months has made jurisdiction its primary concern. Treasury officials say that Mr. Brady has also decided to make jurisdiction a major issue this year.
In a March 2 letter to two Senators - Christopher Dodd, Democrat from Connecticut, and John Heinz, Republican from Pennsylvania - and again in a speech last week, Mr. Brady said a complete merger was one of several options being considered.
The rumblings by Mr. Brady and Mr. Breeden have definitely put the Chicago traders on the defensive. In a turnaround, Mr. Melamed said early this month that he would be willing to consider letting stock exchanges trade index-type products.
But not every Wall Street specialist is convinced that the markets will benefit by the demise or weakening of the C.F.T.C.
Edward H. Fleischman, an S.E.C. commissioner, thinks that the two regulatory bodies actually promote more innovation than they suppress. The C.F.T.C. has been much more willing than the S.E.C. to let exchanges develop new products, he said.
And he wonders whether the S.E.C. would be able to regulate the futures markets as effectively as the C.F.T.C. does.
''We really don't understand those markets, it is a different world,'' Mr. Fleischman said, adding that the S.E.C. has not earned a stellar reputation for its regulation of options. ''You tell me what we would do differently. I would venture to say, nothing.''
 
THE GLOBAL PERSPECTIVE
When Richard C. Breeden became chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in October, he said one of his top priorities was insuring that the country's capital markets would remain competitive globally.
And the debate over whether the financial markets benefit from split jurisdiction over stocks and stock-index futures is a large part of that effort.
Looking at trends in the development of foreign markets, Mr. Breeden may be justified to be concerned.
In 1980 the total value of all stock traded in the United States was $1.4 trillion, compared with $357 billion in Japan and $425 billion in the European Community.
By 1989 the value of United States stocks had more than doubled, to $3 trillion, but Japanese capitalization had risen more than tenfold, to $4.4 trillion, and Europe had surged 400 percent, to $2.1 trillion.
Though he concedes that split jurisdiction over stocks and index futures did not create that shift of dominance in world finance, he argues that Washington has to make sure that the capital markets are as efficient as possible if the United States is to remain a major player.
''The world is changing around us and things that we did not need to do at one point in time may become necessary,'' Mr. Breeden said. ''In 198l we could afford certain inefficiencies in our markets, but you may not be able to afford those if you are in second place and in danger of slipping into third.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
More Power to the Regulators

BYLINE: By CHARLES SCHWAB; Charles Schwab is chairman of Charles Schwab & Company, a discount brokerage firm in San Francisco.

 BODY:
Since the crash of 1987, America's financial markets have taken a number of actions that attempt to corral the more abusive aspects of program trading. But events clearly show that even stronger measures are required not only to restore the integrity of the markets, but to help stem what is rapidly becoming an international crisis.
Clearly, the time for debates on program trading has passed. I believe that we must move quickly and forcefully to bring regulatory oversight of the stock-index futures markets under a single agency. 
Specifically, I believe every investor should urge his or her Congressional representative to expand the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission to include power over both the securities markets and all derivative contracts - including stock index futures and options - that are influencing stock market prices.
Expanded S.E.C. powers are the essential prerequisites for increasing the flow of funds into equities, establishing a sounder balance between equity and debt and restoring the vigor of our capital markets in the 1990's.
Everyone acknowledges that in order to function smoothly, our markets need liquidity - the ability to quickly convert an asset into cash. However, little attention has been given to the different liquidity needs of ''natural'' investors and index arbitrageurs.
By natural investors, I mean the broad spectrum of short-term traders, speculators, institutions, foreign owners and long-term individual investors - those investors who own most stocks. Within this diverse group, liquidity needs vary because of different time horizons for investment holdings.
The short-term trader may sell the hour after buying to take a profit. A pension fund sells to meet the monthly withdrawal requirements for pensioners. Individual investors may sell to pay for a child's education or because they have altered their view of a company or the market outlook.
Despite different investment objectives, these natural investors have a limited need for liquidity, a need that can be easily accommodated by the existing market mechanisms under most circumstances.
On a fairly normal day, 135 million shares change hands at the New York Stock Exchange, excluding approximately 10 percent for program trading. This is about one-sixth of 1 percent of total shares outstanding. Since the current market value of shares traded on the Big Board is about $3 trillion, natural investors normally require from $4 billion to $5 billion in daily liquidity.
In the ongoing debate over index arbitrage, proponents invariably defend the practice on the grounds that it adds liquidity to markets by increasing the number of participants.
Because the brokerage commissions and deposits on futures contracts relative to their market impact are significantly lower than for stocks and bonds, more players participate. Also, they argue that imposing restrictions on domestic markets merely forces trading offshore. The volatility caused by index arbitrage, they say, is a small price to pay for more efficient, more liquid domestic markets.
However, during traumatic periods when the need for liquidity is greatest, index arbitrage acts like a bomb, demolishing the liquidity of the market by scaring off would-be natural investors.
Computer-driven trading programs come into play during both up and down markets. But they produce the most sinister effects - and the greatest profits for arbitragers - when the market is falling rapidly.
Then, all but the most gutsy natural buyers step aside. Even stock exchange specialists appear to perform only their obligatory buying during such periods. As the number of investors willing to buy declines, liquidity vanishes and prices continue their downward spiral.
When program trading by arbitragers represents 10 percent or less of stock exchange volume, this crowding-out effect is fairly benign. During the crashes of 1987 and 1989, however, there were brief periods when program selling generated more than 40 percent of the orders. And on the day news broke of the American invasion of Panama, programs accounted for 56 percent of exchange trading.
Indeed, there are no natural limits for the selling of stocks by index arbitragers, except the absurd prospect of converting an entire index to cash. For the Standard & Poor's 500 index at today's prices, that would require more than $2.3 trillion - a sum greater than the total time deposits in our nation's banks.
Our policy makers need to take the lead, establishing an example for all of the markets in restoring investor confidence. Now is the time for Congress to act. Give the Securities and Exchange Commission the tools and authority to derail runaway program traders.
And, once the S.E.C. has been granted the powers it needs, let all investors stay vigilant to demand that it does in fact accomplish its mission.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Going in Two Directions

 BODY:

It was a week of inaction, with mixed results for the dollar. The head of the Bank of Japan returned from a trip to Europe but did not act to raise the country's official discount rate, a move that most analysts have been expecting and feel is necessary to support a very weak yen. So the yen fell a little further against the dollar. At the same time, the Bundesbank and other European central banks stopped selling dollars in what had been an effort to weaken the dollar against the mark. Despite the pause, the dollar weakened anyway. That was because inflation numbers on Friday and comments by President Bush favoring lower interest rates in the United States made some traders fear that rates could be heading down, which would make the dollar less attractive.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Bill Farley Learns More of The Downside

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Going down. And down.
That was the story of the great asset sale engineered by Bill Farley, the one-time presidential hopeful whose Drexel-financed industrial empire features none other than Mr. Farley in its television ads. 
Mr. Farley planned to help finance his takeover of West Point-Pepperell Inc. by having that venerable textile company sell off its Cluett Peabody operations. When that cash came into West Point, the banks and bondholders would see what a great buy Mr. Farley had made, and they would rush to provide the cash to complete the deal.
When Cluett went on the auction block last spring, at least $800 million was expected. The price was down to $600 million in October, when a preliminary deal was reached to sell it to the Bidermann Group, a French textile firm hoping to expand vastly its American operations.
The transaction was delayed repeatedly as Cluett operations failed to meet projections and Bidermann tried to get a better deal. With no other buyers knocking, Bidermann got the prize onFriday. It will pay $350 million in cash, plus a $60 million note on which no cash payments will be made for eight years.
The money goes to West Point, which last week also managed to get some of its bank loans extended until 1994. That will keep it going, but it doesn't solve Mr. Farley's problems at Farley Inc., the company he uses for his takeovers. It needs another $80 million or so to buy the remaining West Point shares still in public hands, but can't find a lender. Richard Byrne, a Merrill Lynch analyst, thinks Farley will propose a restructuring within two weeks, asking bondholders to take big losses.
Mr. Farley once was a very public man. He campaigned for president in Iowa a couple of years ago but dropped out when support failed to materialize, and he proudly spoke to the Georgia legislature last year after he got control of the Georgia-based West Point. Now he tries to stay out of sight.
The stock market, whose death was widely forecast in the wake of the ''junk bond'' woes that have contributed to Mr. Farley's problems, continued last week to move up anyway, hitting a two-month high as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 57.89 points, to 2,741.22. Program trading helped on Friday, as March stock-index futures contracts expired. Inflation seemed under control as producer prices were unchanged in February, with lower energy prices offsetting other increases. Industrial production rebounded, but not by enough to scare the bond market.
Another market where optimism reigns is fine art. Christie's, the auction house, broke a long-standing policy and guaranteed that five paintings would sell for more than $40 million. Christie's used to warn that an auction house could be destroyed by a guarantee that went wrong in a bear market, but now it shrugs off that risk.
After all, everyone knows that the value of high-quality art can only go up. It's just too bad Bill Farley invested in the other kind of asset, the one whose prices can fall as well as rise.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Mystery of the Rising Stock

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The shares of Southland Communications Inc., a small paging company based in Santa Ana, Calif., jumped 43 percent in over-the-counter trading last Wednesday. With refreshing candor, the company's executives put out a statement that day saying they knew of no reason for the rise in the share price.
A review of Southland's financial records doesn't suggest any explanation either. Indeed, the company's finances have become so frail that some Wall Street bears have been betting heavily that Southland will not sustain its recent rally. And that, in Wall Street's perverse way, may help explain last week's price jump. 
According to Southland's most recent public filings, for the fiscal year that ended Oct. 31, 1989, the company is nearly out of cash and running out of credit, both from its bankers and its paging-equipment suppliers.
And while the company's reported revenues in 1989 climbed substantially over those in 1988, so did its costs, including the amount of interest it paid on money it borrowed to meet its cash needs. In fact, Southland's auditors, in their review of the company's annual results, cautioned that chronic losses and a lack of working capital ''raise substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern.''
Moreover, a supposedly beneficial purchase of another small paging operation, which company officials have been promising for more than 18 months, has hit some new and potentially time-consuming regulatory snags, according to the company's public filings. Pacific Bell has asked the California Public Utilities Commission to block Southland's acquisition of the A-plus Beepers Company. A spokesman for Bell said his company is claiming that A-plus's customers actually belong to Pacific Bell, because A-plus had been acting as its Bell's agent when it signed up the customers. The P.U.C. has scheduled a hearing on the case for April 3, the spokesman said. Southland said it will review its plans if the P.U.C. blocks the deal. In short, Southland is facing a host of problems. But Ahmad N. Bayaa, Southland's chairman and leading shareholder, said he believes the company's troubles are largely behind it. In this business, he said, ''there is a lot of investment up front and the rewards come later.''
Of course, the ''beeper'' business itself has become increasingly competitive. In this regard, Southland's corporate structure would seem to give it something of an edge. It transferred its Federal and state P.U.C. licenses to a separate corporation, owned by Mr. Bayaa's brother, Ziad, and rents its airtime back at bargain rates.
But even so, the company's paging business has never been able to make ends meet. And the arrangement has stripped Southland of one of the most valuable assets of any paging company, its transmission license.
Of course, investors can be durable optimists at times, seeing silk purses where only sow's ears are visible to others. That may explain Southland's stock-price history. The shares, which were trading at $3.63 last May, had moved up to $13.50 by early September.
That rally cooled a bit by Christmas, but prices hovered around $9 through the end of January. After the company filed its fiscal 1989 results on Jan. 29, the stock even began a modest rally and spent February in the neighborhood of $9.50 a share, before sliding back to $8.75 in early March.
On March 6, Southland announced somewhat vaguely that it ''intended to raise up to $5 million'' by privately selling an undisclosed number of shares to ''a select group of foreign investors'' whom it did not identify. The market ignored the news, and Southland's shares continued to be quoted at $8.75 through last Tuesday.
Then, between Wednesday morning and Thursday afternoon, the stock soared to $12.75 on uncharacteristically heavy volume.
The move got the O.T.C. market's attention - especially among bearish short-sellers, who had borrowed Southland shares and sold them at those earlier single-digit prices, expecting to profit by later replacing the borrowed stock with even cheaper shares.
Some of these bears were complaining bitterly last week that they were the victims of a ''short squeeze.'' In this classic Wall Street maneuver, bullish investors demand the physical return of their own shares, which their brokers may have loaned out to the ''shorts.'' The move forces the short-sellers to become purchasers of the stock - unwilling ones, since they must buy shares in the marketplace to replace the ones they have borrowed from brokers and sold.
Several market-makers, who did not want to be quoted by name, attributed last week's climb to just such a squeeze. Such strategies are easier to execute, they pointed out, if a stock is illiquid and not widely held. And Southland's latest reports show that it has just 77 shareholders, fewer than the 300 required for listed companies on the National Association of Securities Dealers automated market, where Southland trades. The company explains that many of these investors ''were believed to be nominees for the actual beneficial owners.''
In any case, the bears on Wall Street aren't the only ones who were selling Southland shares as the price was climbing. The Bayaa brothers, the company's top executives, have been selling some of their original holdings as well, according to S.E.C. records. Since the stock began to rally last spring, the two men have reported sales of more than 82,000 shares.
Ahmad Bayaa explained: ''We all have our own personal needs . . . I needed to take care of some personal matters, but we believe very strongly in the company and we're in it for the long term, for sure.''
Assuming that these shares fetched $9 each, the prevailing market price when they were sold, the executives made about $738,000 on the transactions - an amount that almost equals the entire book value of the company itself.
 
 
 
 UTILITY INDEX: A CRYSTAL BALL FOR INTEREST RATES?
Interest rate forecasters often seek clues to the future in the behavior of dividend-paying utility stocks, considered to be the Big Board equivalents of long-term Treasury bonds.
But the trick these days is to detect when utility-stock traders are being prescient, and when they're simply being practical.
The 15 stocks in the Dow Jones utility index certainly have been running out of steam, falling 8 percent since mid-December. But is the index just reacting sensibly to the 10 percent decline in the price of 30-year Treasury bonds in the same period? Or giving a Delphic warning of even higher rates ahead?
''We really don't know,'' concedes Mickey Levy, chief economist at First Fidelity Bank in Newark. ''I would say it is because interest rates have already risen more than people expected, while economic fundamentals remain weak.''
If the index is simply mirroring the rise in the long bonds, as Mr. Levy suspects, ''then it isn't necessarily indicating that rates will go higher,'' he said.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Saudis and Soviets: Oil's Odd Couple

BYLINE: By HOSSEIN G. ASKARI; Hossein G. Askari, a professor of business administration at George Washington University, is senior advisor to the Petroleum Finance Company Ltd. in Washington.

 BODY:
The Soviet Union is the world's largest producer and second-largest exporter of oil. Saudi Arabia is the largest exporter.
Together, these two oil giants contribute nearly one-third of the world's oil production and exports and as a result, their futures are intertwined. Cooperation between Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union could be the catalyst for the disintegration of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, to which the Soviet union does not belong, and the most important factor in determining the future direction of oil prices worldwide. 
Since the close of World War II, relations between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia have been virtually nonexistent. Saudi Arabia chose to become a staunch ally of the United States and has had almost no formal contact with the Soviet Union or its Communist allies. But in recent years, as a result of policy differences with the United States on the Palestinian issue and on arms sales, Saudi Arabia has embarked upon a foreign policy initiative with the Soviet Union.
The emerging Soviet-Saudi relationship can be seen in the visits to Moscow by the Saudi Arabian foreign and oil ministers, and visits to Saudi Arabia by a Soviet deputy minister, a Soviet soccer team, Soviet astronauts and members of the Soviet press - all of this in the last 18 months.
In my opinion, these expanded contacts, though political and cultural on the surface, were in large part motivated by the collapse of the oil market in 1985-86 and by the Saudi Arabian desire to influence Soviet oil production policies in a way that would keep prices stable and at reasonable levels.
Economic liberalization in both Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union has helped to further the emerging relationship between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia.
The demise of Comecon, the trade and economic organization that binds the Eastern European and Soviet economies, foreshadows a return to market prices for oil sold by the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe. This in turn will give the Soviet Union an incentive to maximize its return on its oil exports over both the short and long term.
Saudi Arabia has in recent years witnessed several changes in its oil industry. Production has declined from its peak of nearly 10 million barrels a day during the 1979-1981 period, to 4.9 million barrels a day in 1989. Sustainable production capacity - the level at which Saudi Arabia can produce oil indefinitiely - has also decreased from about 10 million barrels in 1981 a day to 7.5 million barrels a day today. These recent decreases in production capacity have been due to reduced expenditureson the maintenance of the oil fields.
For Saudi Arabia, with its tremendous oil reserves, the best stategy for continued prosperity is to produce enough oil so that market prices will not increase to the point that they encourage conservation among the oil importing countries. It is therefore in Saudi Arabia's interest to have oil prices range from $14 to $18 per barrel, given the current exchange rate between the dollar and other major currencies.
To stabilize prices at this level requires an increase in Saudi Arabia's production capacity. For this reason, it has recently begun a new program of investment to return to the 10 million barrel level by 1995 with the potential of expanding capacity to 12.5 million barrels a day by the turn of the century.
The Soviet Union, with smaller oil reserves than Saudi Arabia, would prefer higher prices if they do not affect its export volume. But in the real world of market economics, it will have to adjust its production and exports to levels that will sustain prices over the long haul.
To achieve this end, and avoid a replay of the 1986 price collapse, the Soviet Union will have to support Saudi Arabia's efforts to achieve a sustainable longterm price. If a fight develops and the Soviets increase their production to put pressure on Saudi Arabia's oil exports, another price collapse would be likely. This makes cooperation between the two countries the most likely scenario.
The oil markets of the future will be largely controlled by three main countries - Saudi Arabia, the Soviet Union and Iraq. Kuwait, Iran and Abu Dhabi will play a far smaller role than they do now. If, as expected, Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union can reach a working arrangement, oil prices should be controlled by this small group of countries and become less volatile, rising very gradually in real terms over the next 10 to 15 years.
These are the developments that are likely to result in the disintegration of OPEC as it is constituted today.
The level of Saudi Arabian oil production will be a major determinant of oil prices in the future and will have a big impact upon Soviet aspirations for rapid economic modernization and for growth. At the same time, given the importance of oil to Saudi Arabia, the Soviet Union's energy policies will in part shape Saudi Arabia's economic future.
The significance of the emerging relationship between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia cannot be overestimated.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (90%); 

COUNTRY: SAUDI ARABIA (97%); EUROPE (93%); UNITED STATES (92%); EASTERN EUROPE (86%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); 

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); 

COMPANY: SAUDI ARABIA CONCRETE PRODUCTS LTD (92%); ORGANIZATION OF THE PETROLEUM EXPORTING COUNTRIES (91%);

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
S & L's: Big Money, Little Outcry

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BEFORE the decade is out, the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry is expected to cost the Government more than $200 billion. That is much more than the Government will spend on such critical social problems as preschool education, drug control and aid to the homeless. It is more than will be spent on highways, air traffic control and pollution abatement. It amounts to more than $1,300 for every American taxpayer, and it will not enhance national security, promote economic growth or improve public welfare one bit.
It is, by any measure, the biggest debacle in public finance in the United States since the Great Depression. One way or another, the public will pick up the tab, in the form of higher taxes or reduced spending for other programs. A natural question is, why has it not become one of the biggest political scandals as well?
To be sure, some elements of scandal are there. Lies, greed, graft, negligence, back-room deals and outright corruption were behind a huge raid on the public till. Powerful politicians and tycoons were largely responsible. 
But it has not become a scandal like Watergate or Teapot Dome in part because too many politicians have had their hands soiled by the savings and loan mess. So many are to blame that few are left to blame them.
 
Beyond Comprehension
''Literally hundreds of people have culpability on the issue, either through sheer negligence or by working on behalf of savings and loan executives operating renegade financial institutions,'' said Peter B. Teeley, an adviser to George Bush in the last Presidential campaign. ''It is impossible to say this is a Republican problem or a Democratic problem because you have so many people involved on both sides.''
Other factors have also limited the political damage:
* The enormous scale of the problem makes it difficult for people to grasp. ''Small corruption is easy to understand and, for politicians, usually fatal,'' said Ted Van Dyk, a longtime Democratic strategist. ''Big corruption is seldom fatal because it is beyond most people's comprehension. People can't understand a $200 billion loss.''
* The difficulty is concentrated geographically. The vast majority of thrift institutions that have failed have been in the Southwest and California. ''In most parts of the country, it's a nonissue,'' said Donald F. Kettl, a professor of political science at Vanderbilt University, who has been studying the situation.
* No depositor lost a dime. The deposits in the savings and loan associations that went belly up were Government insured. The investors alone suffered directly, not the general public.
For an issue to be a cutting issue, said V. Lance Tarrance, a Republican poll taker based in Houston, it must have three characteristics: People must be aware of the elements; it must be meaningful to them in that it affects their pocketbooks or their trust in Government, and it must highlight a difference between the political parties. The savings and loan situation fails all three tests.
 
A Deal Made in Secret
The seeds of the financial disaster were planted in the Carter Administration, when galloping inflation and sky-high interest rates threatened to bankrupt the savings and loan industry. With their money tied up in long-term low-interest home mortgages, the thrifts could not compete with other financial institutions permitted to pay high rates of interest.
In 1980, with Congress controlled by Democrats, a law was enacted lifting the limits on interest rates the savings associations could pay and allowing them to make a limited amount of consumer loans and investments in commercial real estate. Moreover, in a deal made in secret that was never debated in public, the law raised the ceiling on Federal deposit insurance from $40,000 to $100,000.
In 1982 and 1983, with Ronald Reagan in the White House and the Senate under Republican control, legislation was approved broadening the institutions' capacity to make unsecured commercial loans and to invest in huge amounts of commercial real estate. In the following years, for budgetary and perhaps ideological reasons, the Reagan Administration appointed far too few regulators to monitor the changing system.
Many savings institutions remained conservative in their investments, but others rolled the dice in the hope of a jackpot. In the mid-1980's, falling oil prices led to a collapse of land values, especially in the Southwest and California, creating huge losses for thrifts heavily invested in commercial property. Once they had lost their own investment, unscrupulous owners of thrifts could essentially gamble with Government money. If a risky investment paid off, they got the profits. If, as often happened, the gamble failed, the Government had to pay off the depositors.
 
The Bubble Popped
Savings and loan executives bought some insurance of their own by developing close relationships with lawmakers in virtually every Congressional district and contributing millions to their campaigns.
Finally, the bubble popped. Thrift institutions began to fail by the hundreds. In the last years of the Reagan Presidency, the Administration, in Professor Kettl's words, ''fiddled while the savings and loans burned,'' ignoring the burgeoning crisis at a time when it might have been solved much more cheaply than now.
In 1987, Congress was assured that the problem could be solved for about $10 billion. By last year, the estimated cost had reached $159 billion. And now, as troubled savings institutions that have not been closed continue to lose money, private analysts say the total is likely to exceed $200 billion.
In 1988, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, Fernand J. St Germain, a Rhode Island Democrat, was defeated for re-election primarily because of revelations about his connections with savings and loan lobbyists. Last year, the top two Democrats in the House of Representatives - Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, and Tony Coelho of California, the majority leader - were forced from office in part because of questionable dealings with savings officials.
Five Senators, four Democrats and a Republican, came under investigation because of their relationship with Charles H. Keating Jr., perhaps the highest roller of all. The failure of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in Irvine, Calif., will cost taxpayers more than $2 billion.
None of the five senators - Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Republican John McCain of Arizona - are up for re-election this year. But public opinion polls show their standing has slipped, and the issue would probably complicate their campaigns in 1992 or 1994.
Other lawmakers who could be hurt include Representative Denny Smith, an Oregon Republican, who sat on the board of a savings and loan that failed, and Representative Frank Annunzio, an Illinois Democrat, who is chairman of the regulatory subcommittee and who accepted large contributions from Mr. Keating.
But the detritus is so widespread that few politician can afford to point a finger. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis tried tentatively in the last Presidential campaign to blame the Reagan Administration but quickly pulled back when Republicans singled out Speaker Wright.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, accused the Bush Administration last week at a Banking Committee hearing of failing to move swiftly enough because of internal bickering and turf battles within the Government. But no one joined him.
''It's regarded as a tar baby,'' Representative Schumer said afterward. ''No one wants to get ensnarled in it. You know, there aren't too many ribbon cuttings when you deal with S. & L. matters.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Latin America Is Transformed; Making Progress Is Another Matter

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
THERE were smiles and embraces all around as the popularly elected leaders of Latin America came together last week to meet the two newest members of their club: Patricio Aylwin of Chile and Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil. But the festive atmosphere barely began to convey the mix of giddy pride and apprehension permeating the region.
In the last year Latin America has gone through a surprising transformation, quiet compared with Eastern Europe's but profound nonetheless. The culmination was the defeat in free elections of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and the inaugurations last week in Santiago and Brasilia of elected presidents who owe nothing to their militaries. That combination of events produced the odd sight of Vice President Dan Quayle in Santiago shaking the hand of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, just hours after supporters of Gen. Augusto Pinochet had attacked Mr. Quayle's motorcade. 
In Brazil, as in Chile, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Honduras, recent elections have ended with the victory of center-right presidents who believe in the market economy, popular suffrage and all the other values that the United States holds dear. The results offer an extraordinary opportunity, one that last week allowed President Bush to announce the lifting of a five-year economic embargo against Nicaragua and the creation of a ''fund for democracy'' to help the new governments in Nicaragua and Panama, where the American invasion and overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has brought to power a government of the same ideological bent.
Washington, though, still seems to be merely reacting to - and sometimes misinterpreting - events. The tentative peace feelers extended to the Sandinistas just before the Nicaraguan election last month suggest that despite statements to the contrary, the Bush Administration had expected Mr. Ortega to remain in power. The recent withdrawal of United States support of Nicaraguan rebel leaders based in Miami, allowing them to be replaced by younger, more aggressive contras, may have deprived Washington of leverage essential to a peaceful transition in Nicaragua.
''We don't plan ahead,'' said an American official in the region. ''We didn't have an aid package sitting there ready for Panama or Nicaragua, so we've had to develop one on the spot. It's not the best way to do things, but it seems to be the way that we always end up doing it.''
The reluctance of some congressmen to approve a $1 billion aid package for Panama because they believed the money would be better spent in Eastern Europe has also raised questions about Washington's commitment. Throughout Latin America there is envy of the attention the United States is giving Eastern Europe and alarm that this hemisphere is being ignored. Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel laureate novelist from Colombia and a longtime supporter of the Cuban revolution, was probably speaking for many when he said in Santiago last week that ''the day the United States launches a perestroika of its own, Latin America will change fundamentally.''
 
Widening Distinctions
In the 1980's, only one country in Latin America enjoyed an increase in per capita income: Colombia, whose economy is skewed by its principal exports, cocaine and marijuana. Elsewhere, the money that ordinarily could have gone to relieve poverty and improve education and health has been eaten up by inflation - 80 percent a month in Brazil as Mr. Collor takes office - or diverted to repay a collective foreign debt of over $400 billion.
For those reasons, political liberalization and the disappearance of autocratic military regimes have not brought anything resembling economic democracy. If anything, class distinctions have probably widened; much of the middle class that seemed to be forming 25 years ago has been driven back into poverty, especially in South American countries such as Brazil, Argentina and Peru. Peasants who were just beginning to move out of a subsistence way of life have disappeared from the economic map altogether.
All that lends credence to the claim that Latin America remains ''a volcano waiting to erupt,'' in the words of President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela. More than half of the Latin American population is under 30, has no memory of prosperity or democratic transfer of power and holds a demonstrated affection for charismatic young leaders claiming to offer new solutions to old problems.
Last week's inauguration in Brasilia means that neither of the presidents of the region's two largest countries, Brazil and Mexico, has yet celebrated his 42d birthday. Both Mr. Collor and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico come from traditional political families but they represent a new leadership class: technocrats, either foreign-educated or inspired by developments abroad, who have denounced the economic stagnation and concentration of political power in their societies.
The hemisphere's longest-reigning head of state - and last remaining despot, given the fall eight days ago of Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril of Haiti - also made his way to Brasilia, but his presence served mostly to emphasize his own growing eccentricity and isolation. Fidel Castro said he was going to Brazil to strengthen contacts with other Latin American governments and because ''you have to show the imperialists you aren't afraid of them.''
He warned that if Cuba abandons Marxism-Leninism, ''the independence of the other peoples of Latin America will be reduced practically to zero'' because Cuba will no longer serve as a lightning rod for American hostility. But coming after he had just jailed a group of human rights leaders and introduced bread rationing, his words seemed hollow.
 
An Out-of-Step Relic
''When are they going to begin to understand us?'' Mr. Castro complained in Brasilia, referring not only to his enemies in the United States but the growing number of Latin American political leaders and intellectuals who see Cuba as a relic, out of step with the times.
In the next few weeks, Peru, Colombia and the Dominican Republic are scheduled to hold their presidential elections, rounding out the cycle of more than a dozen elections in little over a year. None of them has been challenged by sore losers or overturned by military men worried that the winner will embark on radical social experiments.
Given Latin America's turbulent past, that forbearance in itself may be cause for celebration. But if the new leaders fail to deliver on their promises of better times or are left in the lurch by the United States, Latin Americans will once again have to worry about falling back into a cycle in which their choices seem limited to apocalyptic revolutionary movements or military governments determined to resist change.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
No-Strings Help for the Soviet Union: Yes or No?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR those who listen closely, a new debate on American policy toward the Soviet Union can be heard stirring in Washington.
The Bush Administration has gone through several phases in its approach to Moscow. In round one, immediately after coming into office, the White House dismissed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a ''drugstore cowboy - all hat and no cattle.'' Round two came last spring, when in the face of change in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, and under pressure from Democrats in Congress, the White House actively engaged the Soviet leader. The bywords became ''mutual advantage'': the United States would do business, from arms control to trade agreements, provided it was in the mutual advantage of both countries to do so, with the emphasis on American interests first. 
The prospects for a third round were raised last week by the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt. He argued that the changes in the Soviet Union are so fundamental and so ripe with the possibility of an irreversible transformation that the United States has to go beyond a narrow interpretation of ''mutual advantage.'' Washington, Mr. Gephardt said, should be aggressive in helping the Soviet Union make the transition from Communism to democracy, even if it means taking steps which, in the short run, appear to be of advantage only to Moscow.
Mr. Gephardt argued: ''How can the Soviets pull Red Army troops out of Eastern Europe if they have no jobs and no homes for them to return to in Russia? Stability, democracy and a market economy in the Soviet Union are in America's strong self-interest.'' Therefore, he added, the United States should provide Moscow with food aid, waive trade restrictions, relax bans on high-tech exports, consider Export-Import Bank loans and encourage private investment in Moscow.
Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, lost no time in denouncing the proposal. Calling Mr. Gephardt a ''frustrated fount of trivia,'' Mr. Simpson said, ''two-thirds of the American people oppose substantial aid to the Soviet Union.''
President Bush himself dismissed Mr. Gephardt's suggestion as partisan sniping, saying: ''We have no request for food aid to the Soviet Union. You just want to put it on a ship and send it over there?''
The answer to that question, more and more Soviet experts say, is yes.
''We can make a difference,'' said Robert Legvold of the W. Averell Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union at Columbia University. ''Why? Because the Soviet Union itself has arrived at the moment of truth. If Gorbachev is not able to move toward a radical economic reform program, at a time when you already have a radical political atmosphere created inside, he and the entire process he has set in motion could be undermined, producing just what we have wanted to avoid all along - unstable change.'' Even extensive American aid would make only a marginal difference, Mr. Legvold said, but at such a critical moment, it may be precisely the slight difference that will help.
An Administration official countered that the Soviet Union is not any shorter of food this year than in the previous 20; rather, its problem is inefficient distribution. If the country would institute the proper reforms quickly and stop wasting money aiding Cuba, this argument goes, it would not need any significant help from abroad and would attract investment.
In summarizing the emerging debate, a Harvard University political theorist, Michael J. Sandel, said one should draw a distinction between dealing with Eastern Europe and dealing with the Soviet Union. It made sense, he said, for Washington not to give any real aid to Poland or Hungary so long as the Communists were still in power, to avoid the risk of forestalling reform by shoring up Communist governments.
But the Soviet Union isn't Eastern Europe. The Communist Party is more deeply rooted; it will only be uprooted by a gradual transition process.
Said Mr. Sandel: ''What we now have to debate is this: How realistic is it, if we held out and let Gorbachev sink or swim without substantial aid, to suppose that the Soviet Union would move to a genuine multiparty democracy in the short term? That is the issue. If that is realistic, then we should show restraint. If it isn't realistic, if full democratic reform will take much longer to unfold, then we have to support a transition process, which Gorbachev represents.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 784 words

HEADLINE: Yes: Drive Down the Deficit
No: Don't Punish the Poor

 BODY:
George Bush wants to be the Education President. Yet he won't spend much money on schools. He wants to end drug abuse. Yet he won't spend much for treatment. He wants to help the poor. But in his 1991 budget, discretionary programs for low-income families are only half what they were, adjusting for inflation, 10 years ago.
Why the stingy contradictions? Because, the President claims, the nation cannot afford expensive public programs while the Federal deficit remains so high. That proposition lacks both logic and evidence. Even worse, many people believe it, thoughtlessly. 
Americans may not want to help the poor or rebuild schools. But they surely can afford to do both.
The specter of Federal deficits has contorted public discourse. Deficits must be controlled. But that does not require victimizing the poor or sacrificing investment in the economy. If Federal borrowing is too high, the nation can pay for valuable programs the old-fashioned way: with higher taxes.
 
Of Course, Reduce the Deficit
Federal deficits threaten the economy. By siphoning money from private capital markets, Federal borrowing leaves less for corporations looking to invest in new plant and equipment. That could stunt the nation's capacity to produce.
Federal deficits also make the nation increasingly dependent on foreign loans. These loans are O.K. as long as the money is used for productive investment. But foreign loans are also used for private and public consumption. That merely postpones the day of reckoning when the Japanese or West Germans must be repaid - with interest. To protect the economy from both of these threats, Federal deficits need to be lowered.
 
But by How Much?
No one knows the right amount. Some experts argue that Congress only needs to keep the deficit from rising. As the economy grows, the importance of the deficit will fall. Other experts call for more radical medicine: cut spending and raise taxes by enough to turn the current $100 billion deficit into, say, a $60 billion surplus.
Congress is already headed toward a deficit that is comfortably between these two targets. Under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, the deficit - including Social Security - will fall to zero by the mid-90's.
Once that's achieved, saving and investment levels should recover from their depressed levels and compare favorably with Western Europe.
Though the evidence is murky, that deficit reduction path seems right. It has not always seemed so. Over recent years, students of the deficit have wavered. So has this page. A year ago, for example, we called for surpluses. The present path to an even balance seems sufficient. That is because there is as yet no compelling evidence to drive the deficit much lower. By doing so, Congress would probably postpone needed investment in airports, scientific research and education.
 
Besides, What's the Rush?
There remains the question of timing. Whether the deficit is $20 billion higher or lower next year is of no great importance. What is paramount is for Congress to control the path of deficit reduction over time.
That is why the recent proposal by Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is unnecessarily hasty, and punitive. Despite noble ideas for protecting the poor, his one-year freeze on spending, including Social Security, and tax increases would harm many low-income families in ways that a longer-term solution would not. Their pain would be justified only if the deficit posed an immediate crisis. But it doesn't.
 
Face the Right Choices
Now, having settled on a prudent target, Congress faces two tasks. The first is to eliminate the gimmicks that it has devised to evade the budget law. Next, Congress has to get on to the central business of politics: choice.
Programs must be judged by their individual merits, not by some twisted relationship to the size of the deficit. Is the nation better off with more missiles in silos or fewer potholes in highways? Should the taxpayers give more to the poor or spend more on themselves?
These are hard questions. It's up to Congress to decide which programs work and then pay for them with a reasonable combination of taxes and borrowing. Contrary to the teachings of supply-side zealots, raising taxes to pay for valuable public programs does no economic harm. Rejecting them on grounds of public poverty is a disgraceful deceit.
The task for Congress need not be daunting. The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law offers a realistic target for the deficit. And after a decade of slashing tax rates, there is plenty of room to take care of both the economy and the needy. The deficit can be controlled without distorting America.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Keep Those Economists Out of the Vineyards;
Chile Next?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Wine Equation Puts Some Noses Out of Joint'' (front page, March 4), you quote me as saying that France's Bordeaux region is ''somewhere between violent and hysterical'' about Prof. Orley Ashenfelter's theory that wine is the product of weather conditions.
I basically agree with Professor Ashenfelter and his new and interesting system of rating through weather conditions. After all, the grape is a fruit and subject to the variations of good or poor weather. My selections for the 1980 decade closely parallel Professor Ashenfelter's, with 1983, 1985 and, potentially, 1989 as the greatest of vintages.
On a scale of 1 to 10, here are my ratings of 1980's Bordeaux
vintages:
 
 1981 . . . 7-9
 1982 . . . 6*
 1983 . . . 9-10
 1984 . . . 4-5
 1985 . . . 9-10
 1986 . . . 7-8
 1987 . . . 5-7
 1988 . . . 7-9
 1989 . . . potential 10
 
(*Hugh Johnson has described this vintage as clumsy and thick, though he rates it 8-10.)
As for California, Professor Ashenfelter believes it's too hot there to make much difference, but the combined day and night average temperatures of Bordeaux and Napa are nearly identical. Therefore, it is practical to assume Napa could easily match Bordeaux and, in some cases, has already done so; witness the Mondavi 1986 pinot noir reserve and the classic 1987 Mondavi cabernet sauvignon reserve.
I am keeping an eye on Chile as the next great liquid asset area. The general wine-growing region seems to be a cross between Bordeaux and Napa. Thank you for this highly interesting article.
 
WILLIAM SOKOLIN
 New York, March 4, 1990
 
The writer is a retailer and importer of wines and spirits.

LENGTH: 739 words

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
AIDS: The Price of Vendetta

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
In the annals of medicine, cures for diseases have come through one person's inspiration or years of research by teams of scientists.
But never have researchers, working alone or together, had to struggle against some of the conditions that surround much of the AIDS work in this country: hate, bigotry, vendetta, rage and contempt.
The five uglinesses that enmesh AIDS work took root almost from the moment the AIDS epidemic was discovered in this country less than a decade ago. Now it is taking a new form - vilification of those who say heterosexual transmission of AIDS is a growing danger in the world. 
In the beginning fear was the soil for the anger and the fury. AIDS came so quickly, struck so hard and was so deadly. Who would not be afraid? But fear was nourished by prejudice against those who were seen then to be the only sufferers from the disease and its carriers -male homosexuals.
Brand them, put them in concentration camps. Rarely heard anymore -but remaining in the memory.
Then it developed that the disease was being spread widely through infected needles used by drug addicts, as well as through homosexual intercourse.
Walls began to go up in the mind. These were poor addicts, usually black. All anybody else had to do to be safe was avoid people like that. Just live elsewhere, have more money.
The particularly callous used the connection between AIDS and drugs as a reason for legalizing drugs. Needles would be cleaner!
Even when AIDS babies began filling special wards in city hospitals, even when it was discovered that the blood-donor pipeline had been contaminated, most Americans felt safe behind their walls.
Then, slowly, not so safe. The realization began to take hold that heterosexual transmission of AIDS was not a possibility, but was right here with us.
The evidence seemed to be that drug addiction or contact with infected homosexuals or bisexuals could usually be tracked down. But sometimes, here and in Africa, there was no such track.
The scientific community argues about the extent of the danger of heterosexual transmission in the United States. That is right and inevitable. AIDS figures have to be revised constantly, up or down, as more information comes in about this new disease that has such a long, undetectable incubation period.
In any case, with more American women getting AIDS through their own addiction or through sex with needle users - and with heterosexual transmission already a devastating plague in Africa - it was sensible to send out warnings.
The issue has plain political and economic significance. If increased heterosexual transmission is seen as a possibility, many people who never thought of AIDS as being part of their own world would push for more research and hospitalization money.
Altogether an important, still developing issue to be researched and discussed seriously. But what is happening is that those AIDS specialists who are worried about the spread of heterosexual transmission are being attacked anonymously by some of their colleagues and publicly by some journalists as if they were despicable, fund-grubbing criminals.
The latest outbreak comes in a book, ''The Myth of Heterosexual AIDS,'' by Michael Fumento. It is interesting principally because it shows how a writer can turn an important subject into a display of petulance and vendetta that sadly diminishes the value of his own considerable work and inquiry.
Coincidentally, Dr. Jonathan Mann, the American who heads the AIDS work of the World Health Organization and has warned about the spread of heterosexual AIDS, resigned Friday because of undisclosed differences with the head of the organization.
That is a loss to the work of W.H.O. The scientific community hopes and expects him to stay in the struggle against AIDS.
But chances are that all of us are already paying a price for vendettas targeting those who work against AIDS.
Researchers, clinicians and science writers are human. So some - this has no reference to Dr. Mann - are beginning to avoid a hard and sometimes dangerous field where one of the rewards is likely to be endless calumny.
Still, the fact is that all the nastiness may snarl and slow AIDS research but it has not destroyed it.
That is a small miracle. It is also a large testimony to those who say they will be damned if they give up work against AIDS - love them or not. It is what they want to do with their lives.
