HEADLINE: Where the East Bloc Rocks

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. RYBACK; TIMOTHY W. RYBACK is the author of ''Rock Around the Bloc,'' which was published recently by Oxford University Press.

 BODY:
ON a Friday night in Prague in June, as couples strolled across Wenceslas Square or promenaded down the Narodni Street toward the National Theater, Czechoslovak rock fans lined up outside Chelmnice, one of the hottest spots to hear rock in Central Europe.
The club, in a working-class district of Prague, 20 minutes by tram from the city center, stood in the grim shadow of concrete housing blocks, known in Czech as sidliste. There was no sign, no billboard, no marquee. But the hundred or more Czechs - a collage of punks, fashionably dressed youths and aging hippies - that crowded the sidewalk before the doorway were evidence enough that something was ''happening.''
As the doors opened, the crowd pressed up the narrow stairs, surrendering their cover charge of 25 crowns (about 75 cents) at the second-floor entrance. Inside, the cinderblock walls were hung with paintings by underground artists; the sinister images evoked the mood of Franz Kafka's Prague. To one side, wine and schnapps were sold in small plastic cups. 
The crowd shuffled across the cement floor and into a stark amphitheater lined with metal bleachers. The room quickly filled; the standing-room-only crowd pressed together so that the doors could be shut. After some delay, the members of Garaz, one of Prague's fiercest punk bands, wandered listlessly onto the stage, picked up their guitars and unleashed a barrage of high-decibel rock - the new sound of Socialism.
For 30 years, Communist regimes, especially in Czechoslovakia, annoyed by the proliferation of rock music among their young, tear-gassed, clubbed and sometimes imprisoned rock musicians and their fans. That began to change in the late 1980's. Yet even while official campaigns railed against rock music, Eastern Europe had a thriving rock culture that has come to include domestic renderings of blues, punk, rap, reggae, pop, disco and heavy metal.
''A lot of their rock is derivative, but there are also some very interesting bands,'' says Hope Carr of Sightwaves, a management company based in New York that represents several top East European bands. According to Ms. Carr, the best groups are those that allow distinctive East European qualities to ''infiltrate the rock idiom.''
Currently, the East European rock scene is centered in small clubs in obscure corners of large cities, with Prague and Budapest offering the most diversity. Most of these clubs, not intended to cater to Western tourism, have a Spartan, often gritty feeling that is closer to the everyday reality of East bloc life, and in a sense, closer to the original roots of rock and roll.
THE grit has a price - which is extremely low. Cover charges and ticket prices are negligible, ranging from under $1 to $3 in local currency: 3 to 10 marks in East Germany; 20 to 30 crowns in Czechoslovakia; 10,000 to 25,000 zloty in Poland; 60 to 80 forint in Hungary. (Western visitors can avoid long lines in front of rock clubs by extending a tip in hard currency - 5 West German marks should do it.)
 
East Berlin. In East Berlin, the rock scene is in Prenzlauer Berg, a prewar, working-class district of the city, accessible by tram from downtown. Prezlauer Berg has long been a refuge for East German counterculture. Local punks, their hair spiked with sugar water, loiter in the entryways to crumbling, war-ravaged, turn-of-the-century buildings.
In the evening, East Berliners retreat to their apartments, or, in recent months, to the West Berlin night scene. By 9 o'clock, the city is deserted. As life drains from East Berlin streets, lines begin to form outside clubs in Prezlauer Berg such as Erich Franz, which showcases mainstream rock and progressive East German rock bands, and the Jugendklub in the Langhannstrasse, a center for local blues and heavy metal bands.
If you want to spare yourself a tram ride to Prenzlauer Berg, the Haus der jungen Talente in the Klosterstrasse, a five-minute walk from the Alexanderplatz in central East Berlin, features live rock concerts every Tuesday night, and has disco evenings on the weekend with occasional live performances. The dim interior has a stark, utilitarian atmosphere, like an overgrown garage.
As few concerts are announced on billboards and the rock clubs are not prominently advertised, East Berlin rock fans rely on the daily paper B.Z. am Abend for concert information. The paper, which costs 30 pfennig (less than one cent) and arrives at kiosks between 2 and 3 in the afternoon, lists the concert schedule for each evening.
Compared with West Berlin's nightlife (one of the most dynamic on the Continent), the East Berlin club scene is desperately limited. But there are good reasons for checking out the rock bands there. The East Berlin critic Ralf Dietrich insists that his country's bands generally have ''more guts'' than their counterparts in the West. ''Most of our bands are not as polished as West German groups,'' Mr. Dietrich observes. ''They don't have good guitars or amplifiers, but they play more from the stomach, more from the heart.''
East Berlin rock bands offer a diverse musical fare, including new wave by Vision, ''post-punk punk'' by Sandow, mainstream hard rock by Rockhaus, and heavy metal by Babylon. Three up-and-coming bands that Dietrich especially recommends are Iron Henning, Big Savod and Deep Manko.
Two of the most respected and professional groups on the East Berlin scene are Silly and Pankow, both new wave bands from the early 1980's. Silly features the sassy Tamara Danz, who emerged as East Germany's leading lady of punk and funk following Nina Hagen's 1977 defection to the West.
Pankow, named after a Berlin suburb populated by high Communist party officials, originally showed the influence of the Rolling Stones, but has developed into a dynamic band that combines the energy of the Clash with the innovation of the Talking Heads. Although its lead singer, Andre Herzberg, recently broke from the group, Pankow intends to continue making appearances.
 
Prague. In contrast to East Berlin, Prague has a vibrant club scene. ''There are about 30 discos in the city of Prague,'' says the Prague rock promoter Richard Houska, ''and quite a number of very good live rock venues. It has gotten much better for rock in the past year.''
At the moment, Mr. Houska says, two of Prague's leading rock clubs are KD Barikadniku and Chmelnice. Chmelnice, a theater that features stage as well as music productions, has opened its doors to many of Prague's leading cult bands, including Pulnoc. Pulnoc, heavily influenced by Lou Reed and the Velvet Underground, is a favorite of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel.
KD Baribadniku, a leading club for heavy metal, achieved notoriety two years ago when it was assailed in the press for promoting ''fascist'' music. Officials closed it for ''bad hygenic conditions and excessive noise.'' In January, the club reintroduced heavy metal and is now a popular spot.
The monthly publication Prehled Kulturnich Poradu v Praze, which is available at all hotels and in most cigarette and newspaper kiosks, provides concert information for most Prague clubs. Concert tickets can also be purchased at several locations on or near Wenceslas Square: Alfa, Cerna Buze, Melantrich.
 
Warsaw. The economic crisis in Poland has almost obliterated Poland's live rock scene, which in the early 1980's was one of the most explosive in Eastern Europe. ''There are almost no bands playing in Warsaw right now,'' says the Polish rock star Zbigniew Holdys. ''Everyone is too concerned about finding money to live.''
Still, several Warsaw clubs are worth visiting. Hybrydy, until recently a leading venue for Polish punk and reggae music, still holds occasional live concerts though it relies primarily on recorded music.
Warsaw's two venerated rock clubs, Riviera-Remont, the birthplace of Poland's punk scene, and Stodola, the former club for Mr. Holdys's legendary antigovernment band Perfect, still feature occasional live performances, but now serve primarily as discotheques. Riviera-Remont is typical, an undistinguished structure with an institutional atmosphere.
The bimonthly magazine Wik, available at all kiosks, lists the names and addresses of the leading clubs as well as upcoming concert events.
 
Budapest. Once called the merry barracks of the Soviet bloc, Budapest offers the most diverse rock culture in Eastern Europe. There are hundreds of ''discotheks,'' often bars or restaurants with dance space, and an estimated 50 clubs with live bands.
''Budapest offers just about every kind of music from classic rock to punk and heavy metal,'' says Kate Lorinzci, a long-time observer of the Hungarian rock scene. According to Ms. Lorinczi, top Hungarian bands include KFT, which draws on the Beatles and Supertramp; the Hobo Blues Band, a veteran Budapest rock band that echoes the Rolling Stones, and Dolly Roll, a band renowned for its mainstream pop orientation.
According to Ivan Herskovits, a producer for Hungarian radio, Budapest's Young Artists Club is currently the city's most fashionable gathering place for rock fans and Budapest's trendy crowd. The club, which has a restaurant and a bar, features a nightly discotheque and a live rock band on the average of once a week. ''It looks like a normal rock club,'' says Mr. Herskovits, ''but you have a lot of eccentric types from the art scene, not just rockers.''
Live performances at the Young Artists Club tend to feature experimental and progressive rock; among the best bands are Sziame, re-formed from one of Budapest's legendary punk bands, Kontroll Group, and the Happy Dead Band, a group that sounds, according to Herskovits, ''like Frank Zappa and new wave.''
The rock club Lagymanyosi K.H. serves more mainstream rock tastes, showcasing the folk-rock band Barbaro as well as the Hobo Blues Band, who have put out hits since the 70's.
The Black Hole, in a working-class district, is Budapest's leading punk venue. It is a series of dim, graffiti-painted basement rooms with a gritty atmosphere, the Black Hole is open Thursday to Sunday and features live bands exclusively. Its crowd is mainly young men and women who dress largely in black and affect punkish haircuts. Three of the top groups to watch for are the Kretins, The Love and Cardinal.
P.M. (Pesti Musor) magazine, a weekly available at most hotels and newspaper kiosks, provides a full listing of concert and entertainment information.
 
CHECKING OUT THE CLUBS
These clubs, based on recommendations by Eastern European rock critics and musicians, represent a cross section of the most popular and progressive rock venues in East Berlin, Prague, Warsaw and Budapest.
 
East Berlin
Haus der Jungen Talente (68/70 Klosterstrasse; telephone 21030) is a center for youth culture center near the Alexanderplatz.
Capacity is 500. On Tuesday live rock concerts are presented; on Saturday and Sundays recorded and live music. Concerts begin at 7 or 8 P.M. The club serves wine and schnapps but no food.
Erich Franz (36/39 Schonhauser-allee; 4485567) is a popular hangout for East Berlin punks and the counterculture scene. Capacity is 400. Live rock is presented Friday and Saturdays; Sundays Wednesdays, recorded music. The club opens 7 P.M., and music begins at 9. Wine and schnapps are served, and there is a snack bar.
Jugendklubhaus (Langhannstrasse 23; 36 52 234) is a popular club for blues, heavy metal and mainstream rock. Capacity is 400. Live bands - up to four in an evening - play Monday from 7 P.M. to midnight, Friday 9 P.M. to 2 A.M. and Saturda 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. The club serves wine and schnapps, and has a snack bar.
 
Prague
Chmelnice (219 Konevova, Prague 3; 828598) is a theater that has occasional rock concerts. Capacity is 200. There is no food or drink.
KD Barikadniku (1 Saratovska; 770789) is the leading club for heavy metal bands. Its capacity is 600, and it is open weeknights from 6 to 8 P.M. A variety of music is offered on weekends. The club serves beer, wine, schnapps and it has a snack bar.
 
Warsaw
Stodola (10 Batorego; 258625), a student club that has some live concerts, holds 1,000. Open Friday 8 P.M. to 3 A.M.; Saturday 5 to 10 P.M. and 11 P.M. to 4 A.M., and Sunday 6 P.M. to midnight. The club serves beer and wine and has a snack bar.
Hybrydy (7/9 Kniewskiego; 267259), once a center for live punk and reggae bands, now presents live music only occasionally.
Capacity is 250. Hours are Friday and Saturday 6 P.M. to midnight, and Sunday 6 to 10 P.M. The club serves wine and coffee and has a snack bar.
Riviera-Remont (12 Warynskiego; 257497) also relies mainly on recorded music, though there are live concerts Friday from 6 to 9 P.M. Its total capacity, in two halls, is 600. Recorded music is played Friday and Saturday 11 P.M. to 4 A.M. and Sunday 9 P.M. to 3 A.M. It has a full bar and a snack bar.
 
Budapest
Young Artists Club (112 Nepkzarsag, Budapest VI; 1318858) attracts the city's trendy crowd. Capacity is 300. Latin music is performed Wednesday,; jazz and blues Thursday and new-wave rock Friday, all at 9 P.M. Closed Saturday and Sunday. The club serves beer, wine and liquor and has a restaurant.
Lagymanyosi KH (17 Korosi, Budapest XI; 1664627) presents mainstream rock, live and recorded, nightly 7 to midnight. Capacity is 500. Beer, snacks and sandwiches are served. Black Hole (3 Golgota, Budapest VIII; 1139488) is the city's leading venue for live punk and new wave. Capacity is 300. Music performed Thursdays to Sundays 7 P.M. to 2 A.M. It serves beer and wine and has snack bar. - T. W. R.

And Bear in Mind
 (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
MEANS OF ASCENT, The Years of Lyndon Johnson, by Robert A. Caro. (Knopf, $24.95.) The second volume of a projected four, Mr. Caro's account of Johnson's life from 1941 to 1948 - especially the "stolen election" that put him in the Senate - is the work of an indefatigable researcher and a master narrator.
DECEPTION, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A swift, elegant, disturbing novel, composed of fragments of talk (much of it about sex) between a woman and a man named Philip, whose relation to the real-life Philip Roth is as problematical as ever.
SOVIET WOMEN: Walking the Tightrope, by Francine du Plessix Gray. (Doubleday, $19.95.) Brilliant, sympathetic portraits of overworked, frustrated women whose men have neither the authority of patriarchs nor the utility of househusbands.
THE THINGS THEY CARRIED, by Tim O'Brien. (Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A collection of interrelated stories that confront the meaning of the Vietnam War, examining with insight and sensitivity the nature of courage and fear.
NOTES OF A HANGING JUDGE: Essays and Reviews, 1979-1980, by Stanley Crouch. (Oxford University, $22.95.) A bold and pitiless critic focuses his wrath cheifly on other African-American intellectuals and spokesmen whom he finds short on seriousness.
LEWIS PERCY, by Anita Brookner. (Pantheon, $18.95.) Ms. Brookner concentrates her mature novelist's intelligence on an innocent, well-meaning man who gets beat up in the sexual wars.
AT THE GATES OF THE ANIMAL KINGDOM, by Amy Hempel. (Knopf, $17.95.) Tiny stories and lots of them, bringing an almost miraculous exactitude of observation and execution to bear on men and women stuck in various poses of comedy and loss.

PUB-DATE: March 18, 1990

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1462 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS: Chicago;
World's Tallest Building Raises Questions

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

 BODY:
APPROVAL has been granted by the City Council here for the world's tallest building. But will it ever be built? And, if it is, will the sky-high rents needed to recoup construction costs make it difficult to attract tenants?
Those questions started making the rounds of the development and banking communities after Lee Miglin and Paul Beitler won approval in January to build a 125-story tower with 1.9 million gross square feet of space.
The developers, who have been partners for eight years as Miglin-Beitler, have built eight commercial projects here.
Height and scale are not unusual here. Among other formidable buildings, the city has the 110-story Sears tower, which for the time being is, at 1,468 feet, the world's tallest building. It also has the 1,105-foot, 96-story John Hancock Building and the Merchandise Mart, which, with 4.2 million square feet, was the world's largest building in floor area until the Pentagon was built. 
But the combination of a soft office market and an unusual marketing plan has led many to say the Miglin-Beitler tower cannot work.
''With the 1986 tax act, real estate investments can't be sheltered easily,'' said Robert Meers, president of Broadacre Development Company of Chicago, office and retail developers. ''Why should anybody take this kind of risk to find out nobody is there?''
The design by Cesar Pelli & Associates of New Haven calls for a tower resembling a needle rising 1,950 feet, although its rentable space - 1.4 million square feet - is more typical of a 40- to 50-story building here. Floors will range from 7,000 square feet at the top to 18,250 in the lower stories. By contrast, an average office floor in Chicago is roughly 23,000 square feet.
Construction at this height will add 20 percent to the cost, according to Mr. Beitler. The cost is being verified now, but Mr. Beitler estimates it at $400 million to $500 million, including everything from site acquisition to architects' fees, construction and permits. That puts the cost per square foot between $210 and $263.
How that can be recouped without making office rents unaffordable is a question being asked by many. Hard construction costs are expected to be $110 a square foot, compared with $80 for the average Class A downtown building.
Financing was originally to be in place this month, but Mr. Beitler now says there will be no announcement until June.
For the building to be economically viable, Mr. Beitler says, it must bring in $24 million a year in rent and other revenues. He intends to have half of that guaranteed before any office space is leased. According to his calculations, an 840-car garage at the building's base will generate $6 million a year, an observation deck will bring in $3 million, a restaurant, $1 million and the rental of broadcast transmission rights, $2 million.
But others doubt that a restaurant can operate successfully at such a rent. And the rising number of garages being built in Chicago may make it difficult for an operator to count on being able to generate $6 million from the new garage.
Five garages with spaces for a total of 5,000 cars have been built downtown since 1987 and more are under construction. One new garage, with space for 1,000 cars, is less than half a block from the tower site.
The Miglin-Beitler building occupies less than half a block of the southwest corner of Madison and Wells Streets. The site has been owned by the developer for eight years and has a parking lot on it now. Two of Miglin-Beitler's completed projects are on corners at this intersection, the 1982 Madison Plaza and the Paine Webber Tower, which formally opens next month.
The corner is at the edge of the central business area of the Loop and links to newer developement occurring a few blocks west. The elevated train that runs along Wells is both a boon and a curse at this corner, providing excellent public transportation but generating noise and casting shadows.
ALTHOUGH construction costs for the proposed tower have not yet been determined, competitive office rents for it are fixed, Mr. Beitler says: $28 a square foot in the lower stories, $34 in the mid-section and $39 at the top. The current market rate for Class A buildings in the central Loop, where office rents are highest, is $32.50.
Mr. Beitler is depending for leasing on smaller firms of lawyers and consultants that want and can afford premium space.
''I believe the marketplace has completely changed,'' he says. ''Companies are downsizing not expanding. Consulting firms and small startups have people who are used to high-end environments. They don't want a nook in a huge building.''
David Mosena, Commissioner of the city's Department of Planning, appears to agree with Mr. Beitler. ''I think the building has a better than 50-50 chance of being built,'' he said. ''There are a lot of office buildings out there looking for tenants. This may have an edge because it will be the world's tallest building and because of its appeal to small offices.''
Mr. Beitler is also counting on small firms partly because there is nothing else. Chicago's downtown building boom has left the city with a soft office market. In 1980, the downtown vacancy rate was 4.1 percent; as of January 1990 it was 11 percent. In the last three years eight buildings with more than 800,000 square feet of office space have been completed and six more are under way. Chicago now has a total of 113.1 million square feet of office space.
THE most desirable and sought-after tenants were the city's large legal firms and accounting offices, all of which have signed leases recently. Projects just being completed and older buildings with empty space are having difficulties finding tenants, and negotiated rent giveaways of more than one year are common. Sears, which is moving its offices out of its tower to a suburban site, faces the unhappy prospect of having to rent its 50,000-foot floors. Miglin-Beitler's own million-square-foot Paine Webber Tower is only 56 percent leased.
Still, in a time when most cities are overbuilt, Chicago continues to look attractive. A report for Equitable Real Estate of New York by the Real Estate Research Corporation of Chicago, in which more than 100 professionals in real estate development, lending and research were interviewed, ranked Chicago fourth, behind Los Angeles, Washington and San Francisco as a major real estate market in 1990.
Chicago may be the only city in the country where the Miglin-Beitler Tower could be built. Houston, which has no zoning and a fondness for skyscrapers, is still recovering from its economic troubles. Other cities, like Boston and San Francisco, are limiting development through tough zoning. Chicago, however, remains disposed to accommodate developers; it has, says Mr. Beitler, ''a compassionate process.''
Commissioner Mosena characterizes the city's zoning as ''lenient.'' The code was written in 1957 and has not been substantially altered since. It allows for a downtown-based floor-area ratio of 16, considered generous for a big city, although in line with New York City's central-business district densities. In New York, the centrally located midtown avenues are zoned for a floor-area ratio of 15, with bonuses available for plazas and subway improvements. A floor-area ratio of 16 means that 16 square feet of building are allowed for each square foot of land.
But a system of bonuses permits developers to trade arcades, setbacks and plazas for a greater F.A.R. Thus a developer can at times more than double the code F.A.R., as was the case for the Miglin-Beitler Tower with its floor-area ratio of 33.1 as a bonus for setbacks. Chicago is also less rigorous than either Boston or New York in requiring and evaluating sunlight and shadow studies and environmental impact studies.
Although the Miglin-Beitler tower required city approval, it did not need a zoning variance. In 1974, after the 4.5-million-square-foot Sears Tower was built within the boundaries of Chicago's code, zoning was amended to require review for any building higher than 600 feet. These planned developments, as they are called, require the developer to meet with Planning Department officials, who evaluate the project. The process usually takes no more than six months. The full City Council votes on planned developments, usually following the recommendation of the Planning Department.
Since the plan development provision was added to the zoning code, no project has been rejected because of its height.
Despite questions about the feasibility of the Miglin-Beitler tower there is no doubt the developers are serious. In late February, soil borings were being taken on the site for testing in anticipation of sinking foundations within the year.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK:FOCUS;
World's Tallest Building Raises Doubts in Chicago

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Approval has been granted by the City Council here for the world's tallest building. But will it ever be built? And, if it is, will the sky-high rents needed to recoup construction costs make it difficult to attract tenants?
Those questions started making the rounds of the development and banking communities after Lee Miglin and Paul Beitler won approval in January to build a 125-story tower with 1.9 million gross square feet of space. The developers, who have been partners for eight years as Miglin-Beitler, have built eight commercial projects here.
Height and scale are not unusual here. Among other formidable buildings, the city has the 110-story Sears tower, which for the time being is, at 1,468 feet, the world's tallest building. It also has the 1,105-foot, 96-story John Hancock Building and the Merchandise Mart, which, with 4.2 million square feet, was the world's largest building in floor area until the Pentagon was built. 
But the combination of a soft office market and an unusual marketing plan has led many to say the Miglin-Beitler tower cannot work.
''With the 1986 tax act, real estate investments can't be sheltered easily,'' said Robert Meers, president of Broadacre Development Company of Chicago, office and retail developers. ''Why should anybody take this kind of risk to find out nobody is there?''
The design by Cesar Pelli & Associates of New Haven calls for a tower resembling a needle rising 1,950 feet, although its rentable space - 1.4 million square feet - is more typical of a 40- to 50-story building here. Floors will range from 7,000 square feet at the top to 18,250 in the lower stories. By contrast, an average office floor in Chicago is roughly 23,000 square feet.
Construction at this height will add 20 percent to the cost, according to Mr. Beitler. The cost is being verified now, but Mr. Beitler estimates it at $400 million to $500 million, including everything from site acquisition to architects' fees, construction and permits. That puts the cost per square foot between $210 and $263. How that can be recouped without making office rents unaffordable is a question being asked by many. Hard construction costs are expected to be $110 a square foot, compared with $80 for the average Class A downtown building.
Financing was originally to be in place this month, but Mr. Beitler now says there will be no announcement until June.
For the building to be economically viable, Mr. Beitler says, it must bring in $24 million a year in rent and other revenues. He intends to have half of that guaranteed before any office space is leased. According to his calculations, an 840-car garage at the building's base will generate $6 million a year, an observation deck will bring in $3 million, a restaurant, $1 million and the rental of broadcast transmission rights, $2 million.
But others are dubious that a restaurant can be found that can operate successfully at such a rent. And the rising number of garages being built in Chicago may make it difficult for an operator to count on being able to generate $6 million from the new garage. Five garages with spaces for a total of 5,000 cars have been built downtown since 1987 and more are under construction. One new garage, with space for 1,000 cars, is less than half a block from the tower site.
The Miglin-Beitler building occupies less than half a block of the southwest corner of Madison and Wells Streets. The site has been owned by the developer for eight years and has a parking lot on it now. Two of Miglin-Beitler's completed projects are on corners at this intersection, the 1982 Madison Plaza and the Paine Webber Tower, which formally opens next month.
The corner is at the edge of the central business area of the Loop and links to newer developement occurring a few blocks west. The elevated train that runs along Wells is both a boon and a curse at this corner, providing excellent public transportation but generating noise and casting shadows.
Although construction costs for the proposed tower have not yet been determined, competitive office rents for it are fixed, Mr. Beitler says: $28 a square foot in the lower stories, $34 in the mid-section and $39 at the top. The current market rate for Class A buildings in the central Loop, where office rents are highest, is $32.50.
Mr. Beitler is depending for leasing on smaller firms of lawyers and consultants that want and can afford premium space.
''I believe the marketplace has completely changed,'' he says. ''Companies are downsizing not expanding. Consulting firms and small startups have people who are used to high-end environments. They don't want a nook in a huge building.''
David Mosena, Commissioner of the city's Department of Planning, appears to agree with Mr. Beitler. ''I think the building has a better than 50-50 chance of being built,'' he said. ''There are a lot of office buildings out there looking for tenants. This may have an edge because it will be the world's tallest building and because of its appeal to small offices.''
Mr. Beitler is also counting on small firms partly because there is nothing else. Chicago's downtown building boom has left the city with a soft office market. In 1980, the downtown vacancy rate was 4.1 percent; as of January 1990 it was 11 percent. In the last three years eight buildings with more than 800,000 square feet of office space have been completed and six more are under way. Chicago now has a total of 113.1 million square feet of office space.
The most desirable and sought-after tenants were the city's large legal firms and accounting offices, all of which have signed leases recently. Projects just being completed and older buildings with empty space are having difficulties finding tenants, and negotiated rent giveaways of more than one year are common. Sears, which is moving its offices out of its tower to a suburban site, faces the unhappy prospect of having to rent its 50,000-foot floors. Miglin-Beitler's own million-square-foot Paine Webber Tower is only 56 percent leased.
Still, in a time when most cities are overbuilt, Chicago continues to look attractive. A report for Equitable Real Estate of New York by the Real Estate Research Corporation of Chicago, in which more than 100 professionals in real estate development, lending and research were interviewed, ranked Chicago fourth, behind Los Angeles, Washington and San Francisco as a major real estate market in 1990.
Chicago may be the only city in the country where the Miglin-Beitler Tower could be built. Houston, which has no zoning and a fondness for skyscrapers, is still recovering from its economic troubles. Other cities, like Boston and San Francisco, are limiting development through tough zoning. Chicago, however, remains disposed to accommodate developers; it has, says Mr. Beitler, ''a compassionate process.''
Commissioner Mosena characterizes the city's zoning as ''lenient.'' The code was written in 1957 and has not been substantially altered since. It allows for a downtown-based floor-area ratio of 16, considered generous for a big city, although in line with New York City's central-business district densities. In New York, the centrally located midtown avenues are zoned for a floor-area ratio of 15, with bonuses available for plazas and subway improvements. A floor-area ratio of 16 means that 16 square feet of building are allowed for each square foot of land.
But a system of bonuses permits developers to trade arcades, setbacks and plazas for a greater F.A.R. Thus a developer can at times more than double the code F.A.R., as was the case for the Miglin-Beitler Tower with its floor-area ratio of 33.1 as a bonus for setbacks. Chicago is also less rigorous than either Boston or New York in requiring and evaluating sunlight and shadow studies and environmental impact studies. Although the Miglin-Beitler tower required city approval, it did not need a zoning variance. In 1974, after the 4.5-million-square-foot Sears Tower was built within the boundaries of Chicago's code, zoning was amended to require review for any building higher than 600 feet. These planned developments, as they are called, require the developer to meet with Planning Department officials, who evaluate the project. The process usually takes no more than six months. The full City Council votes on planned developments, usually following the recommendation of the Planning Department.
Since the plan development provision was added to the zoning code, no project has been rejected because of its height.
Despite questions about the feasibility of the Miglin-Beitler tower there is no doubt the developers are serious. In late February, soil borings were being taken on the site for testing in anticipation of sinking foundations within the year.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM WILLINGTON;
After 15 Years, Plan for I-84 Truck Stop Still Angers Residents

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN George L. Giguere drives the rural stretch of Interstate 84 between Manchester and the Massachusetts border, he sees an opportunity where other people see just trees.
The opportunity is the 32-acre tract of cleared land he owns at Exit 71 in Willington, where he has proposed a truck stop that would include a 200-seat restaurant and a motel with 60 to 70 units, a haven for weary truckers who are emerging from, or are ready to enter, the traffic jams of Hartford 25 miles to the southwest.
''I've consulted one of the top marketing experts in the country, and I've been told this will be one of the most successful travel parks in the country,'' said Mr. Giguere, of Woodbury. ''It's absolutely the perfect location.'' 
But many residents area see Mr. Giguere's dream as a nuisance and vow to fight it. They have already delayed construction for 15 years.
Penny Dionne, who lives about four miles from the planned truck stop, has been one of its most vocal critics. ''From an environmental standpoint, it's a disaster,'' she said.
She has received calls of support from people who live miles from the proposed truck stop, she said, and even from residents of neighboring Stafford.
 
'Like a Carnival'
Mrs. Dionne said she stayed at a truck stop once, near the Pennsylvania-Ohio border.
''I couldn't believe the noise,'' she said. ''And the smell of the trucks, and then the lights. It's almost like a carnival going on all the time.
''I don't think there's a town in Connecticut that would say, 'Give us a truck stop.' In fact, anyone who proposes a truck stop should be forced to live right next to it.''
First Selectman Roger W. Perry said that he had not polled residents about the truck stop and that he did not want to disclose his own feelings, particularly because the town is appealing an order by a judge in State Appellate Court that it grant the building permits for the project.
''When things are under litigation, it's not proper for me, as a town official, to be commenting on them,'' Mr. Perry said. He also said the Board of Selectmen had never taken any stand on the truck stop.
''It's not our business to take stands on issues like this,'' Mr. Perry said. ''We don't try to influence planning and zoning one way or another.''
Meg Reich, executive director of the Windham Regional Planning Agency, whose district includes Willington, said her agency had not had to vote on the truck stop, either. But she said she wondered whether the point is moot.
''The economy at this time is not the best for starting any new business,'' Ms. Reich said. She noted that a truck stop had recently closed, just over the state line in Sturbridge, Mass., about 10 minutes from Willington.
''Just how many truck stops can this world support?'' Ms. Reich asked.
 
Isolated Area
The disputed site is on Route 320, known locally as Ruby Road, one of three exits off the Interstate in Willington. It is an isolated area, with no houses nearby. The nearest neighbor is Red and Art's Service Station.
Mr. Giguere said the truck stop was proposed in 1975 by Willington Woods Associates, a partnership that renewed the building permits for two years before it began work at the site. There is now a cleared gravel lot on two levels, awaiting concrete foundations, asphalt driveways and parking lots.
No additional work was performed for several years, and in 1984 the permits were transferred to Mr. Giguere, who has won awards for another of his projects, Lakeridge in Torrington, a 475-unit condominium complex.
When the permits were renewed, though, a citizens' group sued to block the project. From 1984 to 1986, Mr. Giguere fought in Superior Court in Tolland County to defend the action of the Willington Planning and Zoning Commission that gave him the permits. But after he won the legal battle in 1987, the commission revoked the permits.
''There was no reason given,'' Mr. Giguere said. ''They just said they didn't want a truck stop there anymore. It didn't matter how many hundreds of thousands of dollars I had spent on design and engineering, they just didn't want it.''
 
Reviewing Ruling
So after years of defending the commission, Mr. Giguere took it to court. He also sued a former First Selectman for organizing the opposition, an action that has been dropped.
Mr. Giguere also sued the chairman of the zoning commission, Herbert E. Klei. ''People would be aghast if they knew the way you can be treated by these zoning boards,'' Mr. Giguere said.
He said he and his lawyers were reviewing a recent Superior Court decision in Litchfield County that held members of a zoning commission personally liable for damages for arbitrary decisions, because he does not believe the Willington board has ever given a good reason for reversing itself.
Mrs. Dionne said, however, that the board had not reversed itself but had not agreed to endless extensions of an old building permit.
 
Threat to Traffic
''We've gotten a lot smarter about environmental issues since 1975,'' Mrs. Dionne said. ''No one wants this kind of thing in town now.''
She said in addition to the pollution and noise, there would also be the danger of two or more trucks colliding and threats to traffic.
''People don't want to be fighting trucks getting on and off the highway,'' Mrs. Dionne said. ''When you have that many trucks in one area, it magnifies the possibility of an accident.''
Mrs. Dionne said neighbors were also worried about the crime that usually accompanies a truck stop.
''Prostitution is a problem at almost every truck stop in the country, along with drugs,'' Mrs. Dionne said. ''We don't have a police force. It's just a rural, country town.''
 
Security Force Promised
''And they're talking about a movie room in the plans,'' Mrs. Dionne said. ''I can just imagine what kind of movies would be shown, and I'll bet they're not Walt Disney.''
Mr. Giguere, however, said he would employ a security force, because truckers want a well-managed place to stop.
''To allow those things to go on at a modern truck stop would be the kiss of death,'' Mr. Giguere said.
''But the thing that really ticks me off is that without the truck driver, nothing happens in this country. For a town to be sitting out there and say all these people are no good and to use every method to subvert my efforts to put up a high-quality facility irritates me beyond belief.''
Mr. Giguere said that before state police patrols began rousting them, truck drivers used to pull off the side of the Interstate in Willington and sleep in their cabs. He is sure, he added, that there would be a market for the truck stop.
He said he was also sure that the ruling favoring his permit will be upheld and that he will soon begin construction.
''I'm ready to start that project on a week's notice,'' Mr. Giguere said.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: SAM GEJDENSON;
The Fallout From Military Cutbacks

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SAM GEJDENSON, the 41-year-old Bozrah Democrat who has been elected five times to Congress from Connecticut's Second District, has long been an advocate of economic diversification to make Connecticut less reliant on defense industries.
With the recent thaw in East-West relations and corresponding projections of military cutbacks, Mr. Gejdenson suddenly finds his views more popular. He is the co-author of the Economic Diversification and Defense Adjustment Act, which would appropriate up to $200 million this year to begin job retraining for dislocated defense workers and pay health insurance premiums for them while they are out of work, among other things. He has also co-sponsored bills to close some overseas bases, limit chemical and biological weapons and improve financial controls over the Pentagon.
Between town meetings around his district last week, Mr. Gejdenson agreed to answer questions about military spending. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q: You hear a lot of talk these days about the ''peace dividend.'' How would you define that? 
A: Well, if you listen to the Bush Administration, there is none. They really aren't ready to make the tough decisions in defense that need to be made. The question for this country is: Is our strength and our future protected better by spending $5.5 billion for the B-2, $2.8 billion for MX rail garrisons or $4.8 billion for Star Wars - or is it really in strengthening the economy and investing in the future, in research and development and education, as well as in economic opportunity in Eastern Europe, to make sure it's not just the West Germans and the Japanese who are the only ones to take advantage of the changes taking place there.
I think the greatest irony is while the Bush Administration is running to warm relations with China, within days of students being executed, they virtually have been unable to respond to anything Gorbachev has done.
Q: How large is the peace dividend going to be?
A: I think the defense budget this year, if we can get it down to $291 billion, we're doing very well. There's about a $15 billion difference between what the Bush Administration is calling for and what those of us who have proposed a ''Budget for a Strong America'' are calling for. The danger is if you don't stop some of these programs in the first year. We've locked into some of these expensive programs so that sometimes it costs us more to stop the program than to finish it.
Q: Why have even $291 billion if the threat is disappearing?
A: Part of it is because you just can't shut it down overnight. Part of it is you have to make sure all this establishes itself. But the biggest mistake we've made is we're not ready to pull our resources out of Western Europe and Japan. Japan has a $55 billion trade surplus with us, and we're subsidizing their defense. The Germans are dancing together under the Brandenburg Gate, and we're defending West Germans from East Germans.
Q: There's already several camps of opinion emerging concerning how the peace dividend should be spent. What are your own views?
A: We don't have that great a choice. We ought to use some of it for deficit reduction, maybe 25 percent, something like that. But you have to use the rest of it to deal with unmet needs and keep the economy growing.
If you lose workers in defense, if you bring soldiers home from Europe, you've got to put them to work somewhere, or the economy will slow down, and the deficit will go up. We ought to put those people to building housing and education programs and other programs that the country needs. If you took all the defense money and just tried to reduce the deficit, you'd have a massive recession.
Q: Why won't some people acknowledge the diminishing threat?
A: I think it's instinctive in mankind to be somewhat cautious. There have been other periods in the world when things have calmed down only to become somewhat troublesome. But I don't think we've seen as radical a change in the world situation between East and West in modern history. You have fundamental changes going on, and you can never know how it's going to end, but I think you can be certain if we simply sit on the sidelines, it will end up worse.
The best hope for Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is for the United States to help them build their democracy. That's what we're best at. That's what the Nicaraguan election proved.
Q: Will we then maneuver our defense forces to the drug war and fighting terrorism, and end up just shifting the budget?
A: No, hopefully we'll pay attention to the things we should be paying attention to, although it doesn't seem so from the Bush budget, of course. We ought to be investing in education and health care and housing and the environment. The President's proposal on the highway system is absolutely pathetic.
When you look at things like the drug war, there is a responsibility there, but we ought to help the towns by putting police on the streets and through education.
Q: You've got a heavily defense-oriented district. Do your constituents believe the talk about peace?
A: Everyone is concerned about their job, but the mind-set is there. People in this district wanted a defense cut for decades. For the whole Reagan era, they didn't think it made sense to build every weapons system the Pentagon or the defense contractors wanted.
Q: Are you concerned things in your district, like the submarine base or Electric Boat, which builds submarines, could be held hostage if you continue demands for scaling back defense?
A: No. The danger is, if we buy things we don't need we won't have money for the things we do need. Nobody's going to be able, long term, to keep things that aren't necessary. I was working with a group yesterday, we're trying to change priorities. People talk about cutting the B-1 or the MX or Star Wars and the Midgetman, but nobody talks about cutting submarines. We need them.
Q: How have you been able to maintain good relationships with defense contractors in your district despite your calls for cutbacks?
A: I think it's because I've been honest. I was called by one of the defense contractors in the northern part of the district, who brought me in front of 400 workers and said, ''Tell them why you voted against the B-1.'' I don't know if I won any votes that day, but I told them the truth. And I think history has shown it was an absolute disaster we built the B-1.
Q: Is there any model for diversification?
A: Eastern Connecticut has led the nation with Seatech, a diversification incubator; we hope to have the money in April or May to really kick off the first part of how to adjust for peace. This is the first defense-focused incubator in the country, defense-focused in the sense that it recognizes areas that need to change. When the woolen mills left, they left behind plants, facilities, workers, equipment that was outdated. The workers had been trained for technology that died a hundred years earlier, and just kind of hung on by accident. This time it's different, we have the best workers, the most modern facilities, the best equipment, and it is possible to replace imports, to start exports, to grow in non-defense areas.
Q: You started to talk about diversification 10 years ago when you were first elected. What convinced you so early?
A: I think it was the woolen mills. When I was growing up, entire communities were decimated by the fact one mill left, 5, 10, sometimes 15 years earlier. I think it sensitized all people who are in public service in eastern Connecticut, Republicans and Democrats. I had a Republican mayor in my office, from Groton, David Winkler, talking about diversification and wanting to do anything he could do. It's irresponsible to sit there in the good times and not do anything to prepare for the bad times.
Q: Are you getting more support for your views these days?
A: You know, you do it for so long, you talk about it for so long, and no one's listening, no one's responding to it. Then all of a sudden you've got so many calls on diversification you'd rather talk about anything else.
Q: Is it too late to start diversification now, without dislocation?
A: No, absolutely not. There will be some areas harder hit, but basically all the Federal programs are in place.
If you take the trade readjustment act, which provides education, health care, training, and the Small Business Administration loans, and other programs, put it all together and say communities that get a notice that their plant's being shut down because of lack of demand for defense items, they should be immediately eligible for all these programs.
We can make it work. We had Sikorsky that said it at one point looked into making light rail cars. This country now buys them from Japan. Maybe if we pushed them a little, with financing and other incentives, they'd do it for sure. That would help our trade picture and it would help the economy.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Representative Sam Gejdenson in his office on Capitol Hill (NYT/Bruce Young)

HEADLINE: Township Ties Economic Hopes to New Prison

BYLINE: By JAMES RUTHERFORD

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
WHEN New Jersey's first Federal prison opens its gates next month, officials say, it will be an example of enlightened penal philosophy - a structure without surrounding walls or guard towers. It will also be a prison that its neighbors have invited into their economically depressed rural community in the hope that it will bring development and jobs, local officials say.
Formal dedication of the medium-security Federal Correctional Institution at Fairton, in Cumberland County, is scheduled for April 24. Attending it is none of the tension that might have been expected locally. Rather, the prison is opening amid the kind of ribbon-cutting hoopla associated with new supermarkets and shopping malls.
Tomorrow the Federal Bureau of Prisons will take members of the news media on a tour of the new prison, and later in the week it will hold a ''community open house.'' Local service organizations, social clubs, even the Boy Scouts are invited - anyone curious to see a prison that more closely resembles an industrial park than a place where criminals must be kept for society's protection. 
 
'We Don't Hide Anything From Anyone'
''We've tried to reach every area of the county,'' the warden, Michael B. Cooksey, said. ''If anyone in the community is concerned, we can address those concerns. We operate an open prison. We don't hide anything from anyone.''
Mayor Kennard Hildreth, whose 44-square-mile community will be home to the prison's 1,000 male inmates for an average of six to eight years each, said: ''It's a lovely place. I've been through it.''
It is more besides. The Fairton prison, which is about 40 miles southeast of Camden, has become a locus of hope for the residents of these flat, sandy vegetable farms and sleepy saltbox houses deep in the scrub-pine woods at the southern end of New Jersey. Commercial development is virtually nonexistent here. Unemployment runs in double digits in a county whose 7.2 percent jobless rate is the highest in the state, according to the State Department of Labor.
''We feel it is going to be a tremendous asset,'' Freeholder Clair Miller said.
For the Bureau of Prisons, the $45 million institution is the latest part of a nationwide construction boom intended to provide living space for a growing prison population of more than 55,000. The system is already 67 percent over capacity and its numbers are expected to double by 1995, said Greg Bogdan, a spokesman for the bureau in Washington.
Institutions similar to Fairton have opened in the last few years in Pennsylvania, Oregon and Florida. Two more are in the planning stages, in Pennsylvania and Georgia.
The Fairton prison is tucked away from view on 250 acres, deep in a forest of oak and pine. The only evidence of human activity is Fairton Road, a deserted two-lane strand of asphalt that opens onto State Highway 49 about seven miles to the east. Occasionally visible from the roadside are a few rude wooden stands nailed to trees and left in anticipation of the deer-hunting season.
The prison was designed for 550 inmates. But overcrowding in Federal prisons has spawned a system of ''double bunking,'' which will double that number. The site will also include a security unit for people who are placed in the Federal witness protection program.
A $9.8 million detention center run by the Federal Marshal's Service will be added next year. The detention center, designed to house 150 to 200 people awaiting trial or sentencing, is expected to expand to 600. It will siphon off some of the overcrowding at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan and provide bed space for a daily average of 150 Federal inmates temporarily incarcerated under contracts with the jails in Bergen, Cape May, Gloucester, Passaic, Mercer and Somerset Counties.
Fairton's cell blocks are actually four detached two-story units. Each contains 128 cinder-block cells, each with a window, a desk, a storage cabinet, a porcelain sink, a mirror and a porcelain toilet. The cells have windowed doors of steel rather than bars. Each housing unit has a central seating and recreation area and a desk staffed by two uniformed guards.
 
An Intricate Security System
The units are linked by outdoor concrete paths that cross landscaped grounds and a copse of oak trees and converge on a complex of factories, where the inmates will work; classrooms, a library, a dining hall, a chapel, a gym, a weight room, a commissary, a hospital and administrative offices. Beyond the complex are two softball fields, outdoor basketball courts and a track.
Officials say that the pride of the entire system is a carefully planned and intricate layering of security. It operates on three separate but interconnecting levels: design, screening and strict regimentation. ''If there is such a thing as a state of the art, this is it,'' said John Weaver, spokesman for the prison.
The entire prison complex is antiseptic in appearance, constructed of tile and cinder block with generous amounts of glass, which is both pleasing to the eye and allows for nearly complete visibility from anywhere within the central complex. Interior corners are equipped with closed-circuit cameras and monitors.
The perimeter is ringed by two rows of looped razor ribbon, 12 feet high and drawing its name from the one-and-a-quarter-inch knife-shaped razors attached to it. The fences are electronically sensitive to contact, which can be pinpointed anywhere along their length from a central control room.
Beyond the wire, the prison complex is circled by a mile of road that will have two 24-hour, armed motorized patrols. Every staff member, from uniformed guards to secretaries, undergoes correctional and weapons training.
Internally, security will be maintained by population control, prison officials say. Inmates will be screened before admission according to the nature of their crimes and past criminal history.
Mr. Cooksey said most of those accepted at Fairton would be drug offenders, about 30 to 35 years old, with two to five previous arrests and at least one previous incarceration, usually a short-term one. They are not considered violent, he said, because their records do not identify shooting crimes or robberies, and none have made escape attempts.
Inmates will also be screened by a staff physician and a psychiatrist when they enter the prison. All phone calls will be monitored by computer. Every piece of mail will be opened and checked for contraband.
It is uncertain when inmates will begin arriving, mostly because the prison is awaiting approval of its well water system by the State Department of Environmental Protection.
The prisoners will find a daily routine that is strictly regimented. They will be responsible for upkeep of their cells and the bathing and dining areas. Every inmate who can function on an eighth-grade level or above will be required to take at least 90 days of schooling, which will lead to a high school equivalency diploma. All will have jobs to perform, for which they will be paid from 11 cents to $1.10 an hour, depending on the skills involved.
 
'Inmates Do All the Work'
''We learned a long time ago that we can't rehabilitate an inmate, so we train them to help us run the prison,'' Mr. Cooksey said. ''The inmates do all the work. They do the plumbing, cooking, cleaning up, the nonsensitive clerical work, the wiring and electrical work, grounds maintenance, landscaping and carpentry.''
''Everything we do,'' he added, ''is geared to keeping the inmates busy. Idleness is the worst thing in the world to a prison. You will never see an inmate idle. The facility will be kept immaculately clean. We have an overabundance of labor. We know their whereabouts every minute of the day.''
Inmates will buy all their luxuries - from postage stamps and telephone calls to toothpaste and shampoo - from their earnings.
At the heart of the system is Federal Prison Industries, known by the trade name Unicor, which will operate 41,376 square feet of factory and vocational training space at Fairton.
A division of the Bureau of Prisons, Unicor is entirely self-supporting from sales of inmate-manufactured products to the Federal Government - everything from national-park signs and mailbags to uniforms, life rafts and the furniture in Congressional offices.
Unicor bids competitively with private industry for Government contracts. Its largest customer is the Defense Department. Unicor sales last year totaled $327 million, said Dean Leech, the Fairton prison's associate warden for industries and education.
At Fairton, Unicor will be primarily engaged in the manufacture of electric cable for use in military tanks and helicopters. It will also sponsor a pilot program in which a private contractor, Unibase of Salt Lake City, will train and employ inmates in data processing.
 
A Community Relations Board
From the standpoint of the prison's new neighbors, good public relations have been achieved through the formation of a community relations board. Its 27 members include Mayor Hildreth, Freeholder Miller, Warden Cooksey and representatives of the police departments of the county, the Sheriff's Department, schools, hospitals and private businesses.
''Any opposition has more or less quieted down,'' Mr. Hildreth said. ''No one has expressed concern about escapes.'' Mr. Miller said: ''It looks like a college campus. It's secure; it's remote. I couldn't find any negatives.''
County officials hope that the prison will be a tonic for its sluggish economy and chronic unemployment.
Mr. Miller, a resident of neighboring Upper Deerfield Township who is a business professor at Cumberland County College, was largely responsible for leading the prison proposal through four years of planning and negotiations between the Bureau of Prisons and the residents and officials of Fairfield Township. He also helped obtain a $1 million state grant to buy the site and extend a county sewer line to it.
''I did it mainly from an economic development standpoint,'' he said. ''I'm an economist, and I know a lot about development. It's a clean industry. It's spawned a lot of construction and a lot of jobs.''
 
Starting With a Staff of 260
The prison will open with a staff of 260, which includes uniformed officers, administrative and clerical personnel, and skilled tradespeople, at annual salaries ranging from $14,573 to $29,891. The staff will increase by 230 jobs when the marshal's detention center is opened.
So far, 87 jobs have been filled by residents of southern New Jersey. Fifty-two are from Cumberland County and 10 from Fairfield Township, which has a jobless rate of 12.4 percent.
The financially strapped township received $255,000 last year under New Jersey's Distressed Cities Program. The State Division of Local Government Services has supervised the township budget, which has failed to balance, since July 1989.
Mr. Hildreth is guardedly optimistic in his assessment of the prison's role in Fairfield. ''I think, in the county as a whole, it's going to mean a lot of jobs,'' he said. ''In the township a few people have been hired, not a whole lot. But it could mean a lot of positive things in some areas, in terms of services for the township. I'm hoping the township will be able to take advantage of some of those things.''
What Mr. Miller and county officials point to is the $10 million to $12 million the prison will annually pump into the local economy in wages and purchases of goods and services from businesses in the region.
 
Benefits for Subcontractors
The county has already reaped some significant benefits from $12.4 million in construction awards that went to four local subcontractors. The related jobs and other benefits have been a shot in the arm, said Glenn R. Nickerson, spokesman for the county. ''We're very pleased that the Bureau of Prisons is happy with the location and how they've been received in the area,'' he said. ''We're pleased that they're looking to expand the long-range employment possibilities.''
Mr. Miller is looking ahead to a lot of secondary benefits from the prison. He said one new hotel was under construction in nearby Millville, partly to accommodate the anticipated influx of prison administrators, marshals and visitors and families of the inmates. He said two or three hotel chains were also exploring the area, possibly to build another hotel in the county seat of Bridgeton, some 10 miles to the north of Fairton.
''A prison is a negative thing in a lot of people's minds,'' he said. ''It used to be that there was community opposition. But when you think about it, there is no pollution, no traffic, no burden on the school system. Any development has negatives. Here, there are none. Now, when you look across the nation, there is actually competition for them because they are seen now as a tremendous economic value to a community.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Mandate for Unity 'as Soon as Possible'

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Monday, March 19

 BODY:
In their surprising endorsement of a conservative alliance led by the Christian Democrats, the East Germans declared loudly that, as a young voter named Susanna Frank put it, ''We should get out of this mess as soon as possible.''
The large vote for the Christian Democrats and more generally for parties backed by Bonn was in effect a death sentence for the German Democratic Republic and an endorsement of absorption, as quickly as possible, into big, rich West Germany.
Even those worried about their jobs and social benefits seemed to accept that unification was like an injection -painful, frightening, but unavoidable and so best gotten over with.
 
An Exuberant Celebration
''Every day we waste not having reunification just makes matters worse,'' declared Miss Frank, a 25-year-old East Berliner who seemed to echo the sentiment of hundreds who flocked to a discotheque in the center of the city on Sunday for an exuberant celebration by the Christian Democratic Union of a victory that no polls and no pundits had really anticipated.
Even many East Germans probably did not know for sure how they would vote in the first free election in their state. The one consistent thing polls had shown was that many voters were undecided, and in the weeks before the election the public mood seemed to lurch daily from hope to despair. 
When they went behind the voting partitions - borrowed from West Berlin - the majority of the 12 million voters decided that they saw no point in clinging to any vestiges of the system that had left them poor, shabby and suffering from pollution. More than 40 percent voted for the C.D.U., and three-quarters cast their ballots for parties backed by counterparts in West Germany.
 
Next: An All-German Ballot
The first free election in East German history, many pointed out, was likely to be its last. The next election in which East Germans vote, possibly within a year, is likely to be an all-German ballot.
In effect, the election of a Parliament dominated by West German-backed parties marks the real beginning of German unification. Whatever pace it assumes, the process can lead to only one conclusion now.
One international effect is likely to be felt at the talks between the two Germanys and the four major victors of World War II in Europe -the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France - which will soon begin in earnest. The Germanys will effectively speak with one voice.
The Soviet Union in particular has tried to slow the process toward unification and has resisted efforts to place a united Germany in the Western camp. But a pro-Western government in East Berlin will make Moscow's case harder to maintain.
Sunday's vote was a major milestone in the tumultuous but peaceful revolution that for the East Germans began last May, when East Germans began trickling west through newly opened gates in Hungary. By fall, the trickle was a flow that undermined the hard-line Communist regime of Erich Honecker and led his retreating successors to open the Berlin wall.
 
Euphoria and Dismay
 In the turbulent months that followed, the euphoria of reunion was supplanted by the dismay over revelations of East Germany's true economic plight, and even more by the despair of the East Germans as their visits to the West revealed their relative poverty.
The exact timetable for unification remains unknown. Obviously relishing a victory for which he could claim the major credit, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany declared that the East Germans had rejected socialism of any sort, and that ''the voters showed they want to go the way of unity with the Federal Republic.''
The vote in effect gave Mr. Kohl the possibility of extending considerable influence over East Germany and pursuing his goals of swift currency and economic union. But he left unclear when he expected political union.
One possible factor in his hedging was a growing resistance to hasty union in West Germany. A West German television poll showed that 66 percent in West Germany favored taking time in unifying the Germanys.
 
'Quick Path to Unity' Backed
But as Ibrahim Bohme, the chairman of the Social Democratic party in the East, acknowledged, what is clear is that in East Germany, ''the people have voted for a quick path to unity.''
Outside the C.D.U. celebration, the sentiments were more blunt. ''If I could do it, I'd have unity overnight,'' declared Hans Neubauer, 51 years old. ''A lot of us older people want to live our lives now. We've had the Reds long enough. Just look at the outcome.''
The tentative election results gave the Christian Democrats 40.9 percent of the vote and 164 of the 400 seats in the People's Chamber under the proportional representation system. Their sister party, the German Social Union, got 6.3 percent and 25 seats.
The third member party, Democratic Reawakening, gathered 0.9 percent and 4 seats.
The Social Democrats' total was 21.8 percent of the vote, which entitles them to 87 seats. The successor to the discredited Communists, the Party of Democratic Socialism, placed third with 16.3 percent of the total and 65 seats.
While West German-backed parties took 75 percent, none of the home-grown parties except the Communists managed to win any significant support. New Forum, the first movement forged in the rebellious fall, managed to garner less than 3 percent for its coalition of popular movements.
 
Grand Coalition Likely
The C.D.U. and its conservative allies are considered likely to seek a grand coalition with the Social Democratic party to achieve the two-thirds majority needed to change the Constitution and clear the way for unification.
Lothar de Maiziere, the chairman of the East German C.D.U., said coalition talks would start on Monday. ''What we need is a majority that can change the constitution,'' he said. ''That's why we need a very broad coalition, in which I don't exclude the S.P.D. or the Liberals.''
Mr. de Maiziere, 50 years old, replaced Gerhard Gotting as chairman of the C.D.U. last October. A slight man with a goatee, Mr. de Maiziere quickly tried to salvage the party, purging the old guard and committing the party to a market economy and rapid unification. He served as a Deputy Prime Minister in the caretaker coalition of Prime Minister Hans Modrow.
Mr. de Maziere joined the C.D.U. when he was 16. He played the viola in various orchestras for about 15 years, until forced to quit by an arm ailment in 1975.
He turned instead to law, and part of his practice was to defend conscientious objectors. He was born in Nordhausen on March 2, 1940, into a devout Protestant family descended from genteel Huguenot exiles from France. He is married and has three daughters.
As head of the C.D.U., Mr. de Maiziere stands to become Prime Minister of a government whose primary function will be to prepare its own absorption into the Federal Republic.
The vote was less a testament to Mr. de Maiziere than to Mr. Kohl, who in seven weeks of campaigning on a platform of rapid unity had taken the small and tainted East German C.D.U., for 40 years a tame appendage of the Communist Party, and thrust it to the front.
Until political change swept through East Germany last fall, the East German C.D.U. was one of the ''bloc parties'' maintained by the Communists as window dressing. Once the Communist old guard fell, the C.D.U. quickly unloaded its own old leadership. Mr. Gotting, the former chairman, is in prison awaiting trial on corruption charges.
That past kept Mr. Kohl away until February, when the S.P.D.'s widening lead prompted him to shape an East German alliance of the C.D.U. with two smaller conservative parties. He then threw his formidable weight behind a powerful campaign.
The only solution to East Germany's plight, Mr. Kohl argued in six rallies that drew 1.2 million East Germans, is a rapid economic and monetary union, followed by political unification. The message was spread by 2,000 other West German speakers, 20 million leaflets and half a million posters.
''The people put trust in him, who promised a lot of money,'' groused Oskar Lafontaine, the probable S.P.D. candidate in December's West German elections. ''That's Kohl. We'll be reminding him daily of his promises.''

HEADLINE: CONSERVATIVES BACKED BY KOHL TOP EAST GERMAN VOTE SOLIDLY BUT APPEAR TO NEED COALITION

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Monday, March 19

 BODY:
A group of conservative parties, led by the Christian Democrats and actively supported by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, scored a surprising victory on Sunday in the first free election in East Germany. The eastern Germans had not freely cast their ballots since Hitler abolished the Weimar Republic after coming to power in 1933.
The victory of the Alliance for Germany, which most strongly advocated reunification with West Germany, raised hopes among many East Germans that a joining of the two Germanys would come about soon. But political leaders interviewed on East and West German television declined to set timetables. 
Although the alliance finished first in the voting, it did not appear to have won enough seats in Parliament for a majority.
 
Top Finishers
Tentative final results, announced early today by the election commission, gave the three parties of the alliance 48.1 percent of the vote, which entitles them to 193 seats in the 400-member Parliament. Finishing a distant second were the Social Democrats, the early favorites in the campaign, who emerged as the election's big loser. The discredited Communists finished a surprisingly strong third. Lothar de Maiziere, the East German Christian Democratic leader, speaking to television interviewers, hinted strongly at a ''grand coalition'' of his alliance and other parties, including the Social Democrats.
Ibrahim Bohme, the chairman of the Social Democrats, also hinted that his party was interested in a coalition role.
Chancellor Kohl glowed with satisfaction at what he called the ''splendid result'' of the election. In a television round-table discussion in Bonn, he strongly urged the formation of a coalition of ''all democratic parties'' in view of the seriousness of the problems facing East Germany.
 
Effect on Kohl
The results in East Germany were expected to affect the campaign for West German elections in December in which Mr. Kohl, who campaigned vigorously here for Christian Democratic candidates, is seeking to retain power.
Although he says that he favors gradual unification of the two Germanys, his critics assert that he wants to move too fast, possibly because so many East Germans now appear to be politically conservative and therefore inclined to support his party. The conservative alliance's victory was also seen as a rejection of socialism. [In Washington, The Associated Press quoted a White House statement hailing the election as a ''historic occasion.''] In party-by-party tallies, the election commission said the Christian Democrats had received 4.69 million votes, or 40.9 percent of the total. This gave them 164 seats. A sister party, the German Social Union, received 6.3 percent of the votes and 25 seats. The third member party, Democratic Reawakening, gained 0.9 percent of the vote and 4 seats.
The Social Democrats' total was 2.5 million votes, or 21.8 percent, and 87 seats.
A further surprise on the left was the unexpectedly strong showing of the successor to the discredited Communists, the Party for Democratic Socialism. The party placed third, with 1.87 million votes, or 16.3 percent, and 65 seats.
The New Forum, the citizens' movement whose protests were pivotal in forcing the Communists from power last year, participated in the election in a coalition called Alliance 90, which also included Democracy Now and the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights. Alliance 90 received less than 3 percent of the votes.
 
Genscher Allies' Standing
The most likely coalition partner for the victorious conservatives was a grouping of liberal parties backed by the Free Democratic Party of Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, which is already the junior partner in the West's governing coalition. Its East German counterpart received 5.2 percent of the popular vote and 21 seats. The remaining seats had yet to be decided.
Electoral participation, which had been expected to be high, surpassed expectations. A total of 11.5 million, or 93.2 percent of 12.3 million eligible voters took part.
Mr. de Maiziere, whose party was once a subservient junior partner with the Communists before they were ousted last year, is the leading candidate for the post of Prime Minister. He refused in television interviews to discuss this or any other personnel question before he meets with his party's executive committee today.
In an indication of the break with earlier elections in this country, which were limited to approving candidates chosen by the Communist Party and its junior coalition partners, voters were told they must use voting booths so that ballots could be marked in secret. In the absence of competition, voters before had, for the most part, simply folded their ballots and put them in an urn. The booths used in Sunday's voting had to be imported from West Germany.
 
Currency a Top-Priority Issue
Chancellor Kohl and Mr. de Maiziere, speaking separately, proposed parallel ideas for the new government. The Chancellor listed in first place the introduction of the West German mark as East Germany's official currency.
At the same time, he said, a framework must be created for the introduction of a market economy, where supply and demand determine economic activity instead of the existing planned economy.
The Chancellor said this should be accompanied by measures to protect East Germany's citizens against resulting risks like devaluation of their old-age pensions and unemployment likely to result from the closing of inefficient enterprises.
Mr. Kohl declined to set a timetable for the completion of such measures except to say that they should be carried out ''as quickly as possible.'' He said such internal steps were a prerequisite for progress in the international negotiations on reunification, in which the two Germanys will deal with the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain.
 
A Plea to Remain in East
The Chancellor, like other East and West German leaders speaking in hours of television interviews and panel discussions through the night, urged East Germans to take heart from the election results and abandon plans that ''perhaps hundreds of thousands'' among them might have of joining the continuing exodus to West Germany.
He urged them to ''stay home'' and ''go to work'' so as to help in the economic reconstruction of their country. ''Those who come here now will be lacking there,'' he cautioned.
Mr. Bohme, the Social Democratic leader, who had said throughout the campaign that the Social Democrats were opposed to any coalition, said Sunday that he would not accept a Cabinet post.
Hans-Jochen Vogel, chairman of the West German Social Democrats, like other leaders of his party, said that the important thing was that after so many years free elections had taken place, even if he found the results unsatisfactory.
''Who would have thought a year ago that tonight there would be 80 Social Democrats in the East German Parliament?'' said former Chancellor Willy Brandt, honorary chairman of both the West and East German parties at East German Social Democratic headquarters. ''In any case, this was not the last election.''

HEADLINE: 1986 Tax Reform Act Affects U.S. Revenues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Big Shortfall in Corporate Taxes Thwarts Key Goal of 1986 Law'' (front page, March 6) cites a number of reasons corporate income tax revenues may be lower than predicted. Yet you gloss over the only reason that individual income tax revenues are higher and the central reason that corporate tax revenues are lower than Government economists predicted. 
The reason is that official revenue estimators ignore the practical fact that taxes affect the behavior of taxpayers. When corporate taxes were increased, corporate investment and doing business as a corporation became less attractive, so revenues did not reach anticipated levels.
When individual rates were reduced, the incentives were changed, individuals chose to work more, save more and move tax-sheltered investments into taxable investments.
The Chamber of Commerce predicted these effects in the debate over the 1986 tax reform and has long encouraged revenue estimators to take them into account. Perhaps you should ask the Government revenue estimators why they insist on using economic techniques that provide policy makers with erroneous revenue estimates.
 
DAVID R. BURTON
Manager, Tax Policy Center
United States Chamber of Commerce
Washington, March 7, 1990
