HEADLINE: The Japanese Are Working Themselves to Death;
Don't Hurry History

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report from Tokyo (Business Day, Feb. 26) on impediments to United States-Japanese trade talks and the exasperation of American negotiators with Japanese refusal to scrap the Large Scale Retail Stores Law. This law enables small retailers to block the introduction of large department stores and supermarkets, which can be expected to carry more imported goods than small mom-and-pop stores.
Never mind that the Japanese Government, which controls only the lower house of Parliament, could not possibly get such legislation approved. You report ''the United States has demanded that the law be scrapped.'' 
Next to this, the Business Scene column explains the plight of big-name department stores like Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue: ''The problem is that the public is rattling around in too many stores - with too much shopping space.'' Overcapacity, the column notes, is producing constant store closings and job losses, until even the giants are in danger.
Quite obviously, there are two very different systems of economic and social policy involved here: the one entirely market oriented and indifferent to waste and disruption; the other rooted in the view that guidance is a good thing.
For the United States to demand that Japan change the ways that have brought it this far, a demand the Japanese Government could not honor even if it tried to, seems arrogant. Granted, Japanese consumers would be first to benefit from wider choices and lower prices, but it would be a good deal healthier if they asked for those changes, instead of being presented with an outside demand.
In the years before Matthew Perry negotiated the first United States-Japanese trade treaty in 1854, Japanese urban ''machi,'' or sections, were communities of blocklong streets, closable at both ends by wooden gates for security, in which frontage owners had shares and decided who could move in or out, rather like the members of an exclusive co-op or condominium.
One can imagine the howls if Japanese negotiators were to demand free entry for their nationals in defiance of any restrictive agreements. That too might be a good thing, but it wouldn't be very smart. ''A wise man,'' Adlai E. Stevenson once said, ''does not try to hurry history.'' Not when there are more important things at stake and certainly not when it won't work anyway.
 
MARIUS B. JANSEN
Professor of Japanese History
Princeton University
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 28, 1990

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); JAPAN (91%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (79%); 

CITY: TOKYO, JAPAN (88%);

HEADLINE: U.S. Found Lagging in Children's Well-Being

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Children in the United States are more likely than children in 11 other industrialized countries to live in poverty, to live with only one parent or to be killed before they reach the age of 25, according to a Government report released today.
American children were also more likely to die before their first birthday than children in the other countries except for the Soviet Union, the study showed.
The study by the Census Bureau compared 57 social, economic and health indicators for children in the United States to those in Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Hungary, Italy, Japan, Norway, the Soviet Union, Sweden and West Germany.
While other studies have shown that economic and miltary strength of the United States has not guaranteed that its citizens would be at less risk for a host of social, economic and health problems, the new report is the first to compile data for children and to emphasize them. 
The report, ''Children's Well-Being: An International Comparison,'' was issued by the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families. It used a new Census Bureau compilation that includes international statistics on the well-being of children.
''The dead babies, the murders, the child poverty, are a hemorrhage on human resources and the American spirit,'' said Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who is chairman of the select committee. ''We just can't continue to have it go on. It escalates the amount of budget resources that must go in to clean up the mess.''
 
Impetus to Child Care Bill
The release of the report comes as the House Education and Labor Committee and the Ways and Means Committee are nearing an agreement on a comprehensive child care bill. The measure has been bogged down by differences between the two committees over where the money should come from and whether to create a new program or expand an existing one.
''This study will add additional steam to the child care bill,'' Mr. Miller said.
The United States lags behind every other country in the study except the Soviet Union in the number of children who die before their first birthday. In 1986, the most recent year for which figures were available, 10 American children per 1,000 births died before the age of 1, as against 5 children per 1,000 in Japan and 25 per 1,000 in the Soviet Union. The figures for the Soviet Union may be even higher, the report said, because it does not count the deaths of some born in high-risk groups.
Also in 1986, American males under 25 were five times more likely to be killed than were similar males in the other 11 countries. The murder rate for American females in is less than one-third that of American males, but it is still one and a half times that of the next highest nation.
Australia and the United States had the highest percentages of children living in poverty, 17 percent, the report said.
 
Highest Number of Divorces
The United States also had the highest number of children under 18 whose parents had divorced, the report said, as well as the highest number of families headed by a single parent.
In the United States, 10 percent of women aged 15 to 19 said they had been pregnant, as against 8 percent in Hungary, the next highest nation, and 1 percent in Japan, which had the lowest rate.
The United states did compare favorably in the amount of money spent on education and in the rates of youth suicide and youth unemployment.
''Many believe that how well we take care of our most vulnerable population is a measure of our commitment to the society over all,'' said Kay Johnson, the director of the health division of the Children's Defense Fund. ''If we do not get behind a national commitment to invest in our children, our poor relative performance can have an enormous impact on the productivity of our future.''
Copies of the report will be available from the Census Bureau in July, at a price that has not yet been determined.

HEADLINE: Spring Training Towns Lose Hopes for Baseball

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHANDLER, Ariz., March 17

 BODY:
If you arrive in this desert town in midafternoon these days, it is usually still possible to catch a few innings of major league baseball at Compadre Stadium, the immaculately manicured, 5,000-seat winter home of the Milwaukee Brewers.
Unfortunately, because of the baseball lockout all the action has been on a battered television set in a corner of the stadium souvenir shop. Over and over, the management has been playing a videotape of a 1988 exhibition game against the archrival Chicago Cubs, a glorious event that attracted nearly twice as many spectators as the stadium has seats.
The memento-crammed shop provides folding chairs, beer and authentic ballpark franks, all cheerfully dispensed by retirees like Shelby Scruggs and Ralph Rondeau, who volunteer their time every year to help out at the stadium. Lately, they have been directing most of their energies to trying to cheer up the few hundred people who stop by each day, many just to peer forlornly at the empty stadium. 
''Some of 'em come in here real angry at us,'' Mr. Rondeau said. ''But after a while, they realize that we're all victims of this thing.'' [But there was reason for hope as negotiators for the owners of major league baseball teams and players reached an agreement late Sunday night and teams began making plans to send equipment to their camps.] Toting Up Their Losses Officials in Chandler and Arizona's six other Cactus League communities say they are still toting up their losses from the monthlong lockout, which mainly involves a disagreement about when players become eligible for salary arbitration. The lockout has cut deeply into the $145 million in statewide income that is usually generated by the exhibition season. The situation is equally bleak for Florida's Grapefruit League, whose 17 spring training sites had been expected to bring in up to $330 million.
The lockout has been particularly troublesome for Plant City, Fla., a town of about 40,000 on the west coast. Three years ago, it built a new stadium for the Cincinnati Reds to use as their spring training home, and this year the new stadium has remained idle.
Mayor Bob Henderson estimated the stillborn spring training season has cost at least $170,000 in lost parking fees and ticket purchases.
Hotel bookings are down in Bradenton, a community of about 40,000 south of Plant City that is the spring training home of the Pittsburgh Pirates.
''We were expecting about a 5 percent increase this year over last, but we've had a 10 percent decrease instead,'' said Sergio Ortiz, the general manager of the Holiday Inn Riverfront in downtown Bradenton.
In Mesa, Ariz., the Cubs' winter home, eight miles up the freeway from Chandler, motel occupancy is off 7 percent. Two hundred miles away in Yuma, where the San Diego Padres and California Angels train, officials are projecting a loss of at least $8 million. In Scottsdale, the spring headquarters of the San Francisco Giants, volunteers from the local Boys Club are trying to figure out what to do with thousands of dollars worth of souvenirs they had planned to sell at games.
 
Worries About a Mortgage
And in Chandler, a farming and light-industrial center of 85,000 located 20 miles southeast of Phoenix, the businessmen who own the four-year-old Compadre Stadium, which receives no public subsidies, say they do not know where they are going to get the money to make a $193,000 mortgage payment next month.
''We're in a real bind,'' said Frank. P. Pezzorello, the 42-year-old manager and part-owner of the $2.2 million ballpark, which donates a portion of its spring training proceeds each year to local charities and community groups.
Right now, the only real money coming in, Mr. Pezzorello said glumly, is from the sale of T-shirts featuring a baseball diamond wrapped in chains and the legend ''I Was Locked Out at Spring Training 1990.''
At $12.50 apiece, the shop has sold nearly 1,000 so far, some to loyal fans in faraway Wisconsin who heard about them on local radio stations.
''Our only real hope,'' Mr. Pezzorello said, ''is that someone with a lot of money will step forward and say, 'Hey, we'll help you out - you guys have done a lot for the community.' ''
As for the rest of the spring season, Mr. Pezzorello has all but written it off, considering that the regular season is scheduled to start on April 2.
''If they settled tomorrow,'' he said, ''the Brewers would come here to practice and the fans could come to watch. But it would take 10 days for us and the Brewers to get ready to play exhibition ball, and there's just no time left for that.''
In the long run, many residents say, the real damage to spring baseball may be more spiritual than economic. Forced to find other outlets for entertainment, many dedicated fans appear to have done the unthinkable: They have begun to get used to the idea of life without baseball.
The phenomenon has been especially pronounced in Arizona lately, where Gov. Rose Mofford posed for photographs the other day holding a football after her triumphant announcement that Tempe, Ariz., had been designated as the site of the 1993 Super Bowl.
Hardly anyone mentioned that Tempe's Diablo Stadium, 14 miles north of Chandler, is where the Seattle Mariners were supposed to be training this month.
 
Super Bowl and Basketball
''Nobody around here is talking about anything but the Super Bowl and college basketball,'' said Gloria Bow, a co-owner of the Stadium Club Restaurant and Sports Lounge in Chandler. ''I think the baseball fans are really bummed out by what's happened, and that once it starts up again, it's going to take them a while to get back into it.''
Visitors to the area are busying themselves with what Steven L. Vierck, the executive director of the Chandler Chamber of Commerce, described as Arizona's ''alternative forms of entertainment'' - sightseeing, golf, buying turquoise jewelry and attending events like last week's four-day Chandler Ostrich Festival, which commemorates the period at the turn of the century when Chandler produced ostrich plumes for women's hats.
''I have a feeling,'' Mr. Vierck said with a satisfied smile, ''that a lot of people may have ended up doing more driving and spending more money than they would have watching baseball.''
Although business is off in the region, the overall effects appear to be something less than the commercial disaster many had feared. Many people planning visits to the Chandler-Mesa area, stuck with nonrefundable travel and baseball tickets, went ahead with their vacations despite the lockout.
''We've lost a little bit, but I don't think it's as bad as it could have been,'' said Red Sather, owner of the 50-room Chandler Inn, one of the town's most venerable motels.
But small concessionaires who normally supply the local stadiums are hurting, along with community groups like the Boys and Girls Club of the East Valley, which has been desperately trying to raise money selling a competitive line of lockout T-shirts.
 
Finding Other Diversions
''We were hoping to watch the Brewers play the Padres this week,'' said 65-year-old Joyce Madigan of Green Bay, Wis., as she gazed out over the desolate green expanses of Compadre Stadium, which is surrounded by dairy farms, a 27-hole golf course and freshly plowed fields of alfalfa that seem to sweep all the way to the craggy blue mountains on the horizon.
She flew here from Wisconsin the other day with two women she knows from her other favorite sport, league bowling.
''But now,'' she said, ''I think we'll be driving out to Grand Canyon instead.''
''Or Las Vegas,'' said Fern Smith, 68, of Eau Claire, Wis., who, like Mrs. Madigan and 71-year-old Florence Boehringer of Milwaukee, bought nonrefundable airline tickets months ago.
''If you must know,'' Mrs. Smith added in a confidential tone, ''we're spending money like water.''
Mike Turney of Antigo, Wis., who had stopped by the Compadre souvenir shop with three equally husky friends to buy a few extra-large lockout T-shirts, said: ''It's a real disappointment. We'd planned the trip to watch baseball, but now I think we're just going to play a lot of golf.''
''And drink,'' one of his sunburned traveling companions added cheerfully.

HEADLINE: La Crosse Journal Honoring The Wire That Won The West

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA CROSSE, Kan.

 BODY:
A couple of decades ago, La Crosse started a museum devoted to barbed wire and declared itself the Barbed Wire Capital of the World.
Signs on the highway attest to the claim and so does a sign on the Old West-style false front of the Barbed Wire Museum, the only museum dedicated solely to ''devil's rope,'' as old-time cattlemen called the wire.
Nobody since then has contested the claim, and the town has become a mecca for collectors of old wire specimens. But some people became a bit edgy recently when a group of Texans announced plans for a barbed-wire museum of their own. 
And a scholar of wire lore up in De Kalb, Ill., reminded a banker here that his city had perhaps an older claim to a place in barbed-wire history than anyplace else.
''We already had our title,'' said Brad Penka, president of the La Crosse Chamber of Commerce. ''We want to retain that if we can.'' He said word of the Texans' proposal ''sort of accelerated'' planning for a new and bigger Barbed Wire Museum.
Already, said Gary Kay, president of the Nekoma State Bank, the bank has a pledge of $12,000 in matching funds awaiting the start of construction.
Those who might wonder at so much ado about barbed wire haven't been to La Crosse, population 1,600, stretched out along U.S. 183 halfway between Oklahoma and Nebraska.
As people like Ivan Krug, former president of the Kansas Barbed Wire Collectors Association, can tell you, it was barbed wire that tamed the West; never mind the rifle and the six-shooter.
The first barbed-wire fences, in the late 1860's, were used to keep animals out. Homesteaders used the wire to protect their crops and farm ponds from nearly wild longhorned cattle at a time when the range was open and cattlemen were kings.
Legends (and movies, in the 20th century) abound: sodbusters dying for their fences, others nearly scared to death when coffins were left on their steps as warnings.
But when the wire was new, hundreds of inventors saw the chance of riches and filed for patents based on varying twists and turns of the wire. Soon the cattlemen themselves started fencing in plains and manufacturers in De Kalb began mass production of barbed wire.
And today thousands of collectors from across the country meet at annual conventions in places like La Crosse to trade, buy and sell 18-inch specimens of the wire, at prices up to $400.
They match skills at wire games. They vie with each other at stapling the wires to fence posts and cutting and splicing the strands, a ritual of the conventions held here the first weekend of May.
The La Crosse museum displays 500 specimens of barbed wire, along with dozens of tools used in fencing -for instance, cutters and and wire-stretchers - and ointments and liniments for the wounds that the barbs can inflict on farm and ranch animals.
La Crosse may have the only museum devoted solely to barbed wire and fencing, but there are institutions across the country that include wire collections, as Delbert Trew, president of the Texas Barbed Wire Collectors Association, said the other day.
Mr. Trew and his group plan to install its collections in a building at McLean, in the Texas Panhandle, Mr. Trew said. They propose a catchy title, Devil's Rope Museum, but he said they never intended to cause any uneasiness here in La Crosse.
''We're not going to try to call ourselves the world capital of anything,'' he said, ''and we'll help the folks up in La Crosse any way we can.''
De Kalb was the home of Joseph Glidden, a prolific inventor and holder of a patent once validated by the United States Supreme Court, and Jacob Haish and Isaac L. Ellwood, early manufacturers of the wire.
''We sort of think of ourselves like that, though we don't put it in those terms,'' said Gerald Brauer, director of the Ellwood House Museum in De Kalb, referring to the La Crosse assertion. ''We think of this as the birthplace of barbed wire. We even call our high school teams the Barbs.'' He said the museum's collection began near the turn of the 20th century, before most people ever heard of wire collectors.
Never mind, said Rick Weigel, head of a museum building committee; La Crosse was first to claim the title. And after all, the town is near the geographic center of the plains the old wires tamed.

HEADLINE: He's Discreet, but Poised to Unseat Thatcher

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 18

 BODY:
He has never said publicly that he is running against her, but Michael Heseltine, who walked out of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet four years ago, looks set to make a comeback as Mrs. Thatcher falters in opinion polls.
Mr. Heseltine will turn 57 on Wednesday, a day before an important by-election for a parliamentary seat in mid-Staffordshire. It is a traditionally safe Tory seat in the rural English Midlands, but one that the Conservatives risk losing for the first time in a decade, largely because of voter dissatisfaction with Mrs. Thatcher and her economic policies.
''We live in a wholly unpredictable world,'' Mr. Heseltine likes to say. 
Mr. Heseltine, whose regal bearing and silver hair attract attention wherever he goes, has hardly exchanged two words with Mrs. Thatcher since he resigned as Defense Minister in January 1986. The two split over whether a British helicopter company should be sold to an American company, as she preferred, or to a European consortium, as he advised.
 
One of Heath's Disciples
Mr. Heseltine is often described as the last disciple of Edward Heath, the former Conservative Prime Minister. He is an enthusiastic supporter of full British participation in the move toward a single European market in 1992.
But unlike Mr. Heath, Mr. Heseltine has not let his differences with Mrs. Thatcher become bitter in public. His is in a waiting game, positioning himself as the only Conservative alternative in the unlikely event that the Prime Minister resigns before the next national elections. For months now, the Conservatives have been trailing in opinion polls by as many as 19 percentage points.
But Mrs. Thatcher is also in a waiting game - waiting for her anti-inflation economic policy, with its high interest rates, to bring down mortgage rates before she has to call the elections. Conservative voters would be less likely to vote against her then than they are in midterm by-elections like mid-Staffordshire's on Thursday.
The next national election does not have to be called until June 1992, unless so many Conservatives revolt before then that Mrs. Thatcher loses her 100-seat majority in Parliament.
 
A Little Too Polite
That is almost unthinkable, so Mr. Heseltine is working the circuit, with never an unkind word for Mrs. Thatcher. She responded in kind today in an interview with The Sunday Express, describing him as a ''very able'' speaker. Between the lines, though, there's a world of difference.
If Mrs. Thatcher is popularly seen as ''anti-Europe,'' resisting British participation in the European Monetary System because it would take away the sovereign right of Parliament to decide Britain's economic policies, Mr. Heseltine tries to look as European as he can.
If Mrs. Thatcher is all gumption and why-don't-you get-up-and-go on the domestic front, Mr. Heseltine is for more compassion.
Speaking to a group in London on Friday, Mr. Heseltine credited the Government's policies with creating a record number of homeowners, with bringing prosperity to the elderly and with generating higher spending on education and health than ever before. But then he took his jabs. ''For all the things of which we can be proud, there are areas of shame,'' he said, particularly for the growing British underclass of the homeless. ''I see a sense of Tory concern historically interwoven with the success of my party.'' His message was not lost on the British press, which leaps on the least hint of dissent within party ranks.
 
Tories Trail Badly
Mr. Heseltine is therefore eager to be seen campaigning for the Conservatives, who need the help. According to a poll by Market & Opinion Research International, published today in The Sunday Times, the Tories would get only 29 percent of the vote in Thursday's by-election in mid-Staffordshire, compared with 55 percent for the Labor Party. All it took was for Mr. Heseltine to say, as he did in a profile in The Sunday Telegraph a week ago, that he had not been asked.
Charles Prior, the Conservative candidate in mid-Staffordshire, said that after reading those remarks, he called his liaison with Parliament and had an invitation telephoned to Mr. Heseltine, who was campaigning in Kings Bromley two days later. ''He is, after the Prime Minister, the best known Conservative figure in the country,'' Mr. Prior said.
Mrs. Thatcher herself is not campaigning for Mr. Prior, who said it was not customary for a sitting Prime Minister to campaign in a by-election. Mr. Prior's Labor Party opponent is Sylvia Heal, a 48-year-old judge.
 
Getting the Word Out
This weekend, there was Mr. Heseltine on the Letters to the Editor page of The Times, still the place to be noticed for Conservative opinion-makers, with a subtle mix of support and criticism for the Government in the guise of what Britain could learn from Germany and Japan.
A little less of the Thatcherite hands-off-the-economy approach seemed to be his answer.
''The first lesson is proper management of the economy to provide price stability as the essential background for industry and commerce,'' he wrote. ''That is why I argue for an independent central bank and our early membership of the exchange-rate mechanism.''
''I don't see the circumstances in which I will challenge Mrs. Thatcher,'' Mr. Heseltine said in a recent interview with Bryan Appleyard of The Independent, who observed that this remark, like the speaker's public appearances in support of Government policies, was ''deliciously ambiguous.''

HEADLINE: The Japanese Are Working Themselves to Death

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a United States citizen living in Japan, I found Anna Quindlen's ''Men at Work'' column (Feb. 18), on American men working 12-hour days, particularly frightening. In Japan, this has been carried to tragically absurd lengths.
In Japanese corporate culture, presence is productivity, loyalty to the organization is measured by time at one's desk, and employees are reluctant to be seen leaving the office, whether they are ambitious or not. The behavior resulting from these attitudes is the cause of ''karoshi,'' or death from overwork. 
Karoshi is on the rise. The Japan Times, in a December editorial ''The Pace That Kills,'' reported that in 1989, more than 1,300 families sought advice on filing claims against companies, the wives and mothers contending that the death of their spouses was caused by overwork. These were only the reported cases, with the number of unreported cases likely to be at least as high.
An article headlined ''Death Rate Due to Overwork on the Increase for Employees'' gives details about several karoshi cases. Some karoshi victims were working 50 days straight and more than 100 hours of overtime every month. One man was commuting daily between Osaka and Tokyo, and was logging 135 hours of overtime a month. His wife claimed he was getting about five hours sleep a night. In another case, an investigation into the death of a man employed at a ball-bearing factory revealed that he and his co-workers were not allowed to take any days off because they had to keep the factory's machines running 24 hours a day. Again, these are just the reported cases. Many of my friends and acquaintances work 10- and 12-hour days every day with little or no vacation.
Numerous books in recent years have purported to explain the secrets of Japanese business success and exhorted Americans to emulate them. While there may be much about Japanese business culture worth imitating, death from overwork is not. Yet Ms. Quindlen's column suggests that the ideas at the root of karoshi have appeared in the American workplace. I hope my fellow countrymen will not carry these ideas to Japanese lengths.
 
STEVEN SABOTTA
Fukuoka, Japan, Feb. 25, 1990

HEADLINE: Hungary's New Sports World

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, March 18

 BODY:
With a magnificent spring-like day as a backdrop Friday, many of Hungary's great fencers of the past honored one of their own, Aladar Gerevich, on the occasion of his 80th birthday. Between 1932 and 1960, he won seven Olympic gold medals in saber ''and probably would have won more,'' said one of the celebrators, Pal Schmitt, were it not for the cancellation of the Olympics in 1940 and 1944 because of World War II.
The festivities lasted an hour or so and seemed a temporary respite from the larger problems at hand in Hungary, where sports, like everything else, is undergoing rapid change.
Since last October, when the Communist Party began losing its grip, leading to next Sunday's elections, the first free vote in 40 years, the sports system has been totally reorganized. Power and responsibilities are vested in elected leaders of individual federations for each sport, much the way things are in the United States, rather in an individual serving as Minister of Sports. 
The federations develop their programs by working with athletes and coaches in sports clubs throughout the country. Hungary's national Olympic Committee remains in place to coordinate efforts of the federation in developing elite athletes. Who Will Pay? Despite the reorganization, however, critical aspects of sports in Hungary have not been addressed, leaving sportsmen of every stripe anxiously waiting to see how - or even if - the new government contends with them. Not surprisingly, their questions have to do with financial support.
''For the top sports in our country, there has always been enough money,'' said Schmitt, an Olympic gold medalist in 1968 and 1972, a member of the International Olympic Committee for seven years and the secretary general of the national Olympic Committee since last June.
Indeed, Hungary has ranked among the 10 leading nations in gold medals in all but one summer Olympics since 1928. Hungary was among the countries that boycotted the 1984 Los Angeles games.
''But I have seen what is beyond the shop windows,'' Schmitt added. ''It is important that the new government declare how we maintain sports as a social activity in our culture. With so little money, it has led to a neglect of sports in schools and sports for all, which has had a very very negative effect on the average health standards.''
In all of Europe, Hungary has among the highest levels of alcoholism, smoking, heart disease and suicide in addition to a life expectancy that is among the lowest.
The dichotomy of a small country's achieving success in the Olympics at the expense of sports for the masses is hardly limited to Hungary among nations once part of the Soviet bloc. A similar situation with much more dramatic differences existed in East Germany for years. Only since the demise of the East German Communist Government last fall have the interim leaders withdrawn some Government support of elite programs to satisfy citizens clamoring for better equipment and greater access to facilities.
 
Few Opportunities
In Hungary, a country of 10.5 million, a growing economic crisis, brought on by rising prices, taxes and unemployment has foreclosed the possibility of citizens' enjoying the sports of their choice. At the same time, Schmitt said, the Government has been unable to continue subsidizing physical education programs in schools and universities.
That not only contributes to the health problems, he said, but also undermines the Olympic effort, particularly for team sports like basketball, volleyball, water polo, handball and even soccer, a national passion. Hungary failed to qualify for the World Cup finals this summer for the first time in 20 years.
''This is just my opinion,'' the 47-year-old Schmitt said. ''Sports, as an activity, bears a close connection with the standard of living. If I have money, I can afford a lot of things. I can play tennis, go to the beach, go hang-gliding, wind surf, rent horses to ride. But we're in a country with much bigger problems than how to send kids to play sports. We have parents with more than one occupation, both working up to 12 hours a day, and their standards of living are very low.''
As one of the nation's senior sports officials, Schmitt worries that whichever party wins the elections its leaders will not necessarily grasp what he sees as the connection between sports programs for all citizens and higher health standards.

HEADLINE: New Bid for Protection By U.S. Textile Lobby

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Afraid that the Bush Administration will give away too much during international negotiations, the domestic textile industry is preparing another legislative push during this election year seeking import restrictions.
The drive by textile and apparel industry lobbyists and their friends in Congress is expected to be approved at a Capitol Hill strategy session on Wednesday. It raises the political stakes over comprehensive and far-reaching multilateral trade negotiations that have been going on for nearly four years.
The talks are known as the Uruguay Round, because they began in 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay. Scheduled to end in December, the talks include negotiations over how to open up trade in services, cut piracy of intellectual property, reduce investment-related trade distortions and end subsidized trade in agriculture. 
One trade issue the industrialized countries must expect to negotiate and, in all likelihood, make concessions on, is textiles.
''We can't ask developing countries to make concessions in intellectual property rights and services and then keep our markets closed in textiles,'' said Stanley Fischer, chief economist at the World Bank. ''It would show that the industrialized world is just not serious about these trade issues.''
 
Curbs on Third-World Imports
For 25 years, under the Multi-Fiber Arrangement of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the United States and other developed countries have taken special measures to curb imports of textiles and apparel from third-world countries.
To persuade developing countries to participate in the new round of talks, which are sponsored by the GATT, the countries were promised that the extensive network of bilateral textile quotas that are renegotiated every five years would be phased out by the end of the century.
For many third-world countries, where labor is in far greater supply than capital, garments are among the few products they have to sell.
In impoverished Bangladesh, for example, apparel products account for 40 percent of exports. ''We are strong in labor-intensive industries, but under the M.F.A. we cannot even use our competitive advantage,'' said Akbar Ali Khan, an economics specialist at the Bangladesh Embassy here.
Yet even with the arrangement, Bangladesh has not done badly. Over the last decade, its apparel exports have risen almost tenfold, to $450 million last year.
 
A Potential $8 Billion Boon
According to studies done by the World Bank, the phase-out of the arrangement could add $8 billion to the $43 billion in textile and clothing export sales third-world countries enjoy now.
For Uruguay Round negotiators, the critical issue is the transition period until the projected termination of the arrangement, in 10 years. Countries like Bangladesh want liberalization to begin now, with generous import growth rates built into any transitional quota system.
But the domestic textile and apparel industry, which employs two million Americans, has told the Administration that if it is to give up protection, it wants more, not fewer, restrictions now.
''There has to be a transition mechanism that would truly slow import growth to provide a more certain investment environment, so that our members can undertake investments needed to increase their competitiveness,'' said Carlos Moore, executive vice president of the American Textile Manufacturers Association, one of the principal lobbying groups.
The industry also wants to keep its tariff protection. Last lowered under the Tokyo Round in the 1970's, American tariffs are 20 percent on apparel, 15 percent on fabrics and 10 percent on yarn.
 
A Test for the Textile Industry
It is not the first time the industry has worked for more restrictive quotas. Congress passed restraint bills twice in the last five years, but after Presidential vetoes, in 1986 and 1988, could not muster the votes needed to override.
This election year may be no different. Still, the new legislative strategy could be a factor in what is likely to be a battle in Congress next year when the Administration asks Congress to approve any Uruguay Round package agreed upon in December.
George Bush's handy defeat of Bob Dole in the 1988 North Carolina primary has led some people to say the strength of the textile lobby may be overrated. Senator Dole, Republican of Kansas and the Senate minority leader, campaigned for textile quotas in a textile state and lost to a free trade advocate who became President.
Other domestic lobbying groups -for example, insurance companies and banks that would gain from liberalization of financial services and publishers and motion picture producers who would benefit from tougher copyright safeguards - are likely to push for exploration of their own political and economic trade-offs by the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and President Bush.
The textile industry says it wants quotas that would permit growth of imports by no more than 1 percent a year. But many economists believe that this level would barely meet demand for clothing in the United States and would guarantee high consumer prices.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Sharedata Slipped As Its Stock Rose

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AS 1989 ended and the new year began, Sharedata Inc. was struggling to survive after the loss of the only profitable products it ever had, computer game versions of the popular television shows ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy.'' Insiders were funneling in cash, and the company was paying interest rates of up to 30 percent to keep the doors open.
But that was not the view stock market investors seemed to have of Sharedata. Buoyed by a report from a small brokerage house that ignored the company's problems and forecast a surge in profits even as the company was predicting large losses, the share price leaped. 
From a low bid of 75 cents a share in October, the price rose to $7.625 in January, just before insiders got a long-delayed clearance from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell large parts of their holdings to the public.
Since then, the share price has settled back to $3.25, and the company faces new liquidity pressures. Some executives, on whom the company had said it was relying for a turnaround, have left, and it is far from clear whether Sharedata can come up with products to keep it operating.
The case of Sharedata provides evidence of both the strength and weakness of the current system of Federal securities regulation. The S.E.C. appears to have forced very detailed disclosure of the company's problems and to have stepped up the pressure for the company to acknowledge the risks as the stock price rose.
But these disclosures can only be found in the documents filed with the commission. Salespeople pushing stocks may have never read them, let alone told customers about them. ''Our inquiries lead us to conclude that the Sharedata Corporation is on the verge of a marked improvement in revenues and earnings from the computer software market,'' said a report dated Nov. 27 from the Princeton Financial Group, a small New Jersey broker-dealer.
That report did not even get Sharedata Inc.'s name right. And although it was published months after Sharedata filings with the S.E.C. reported that the company lost the licenses, effective Sept. 2, for the television game shows that had provided more than half of its revenues, the report listed those products as still being sold by the company.
In the quarter ended Dec. 31, Sharedata lost $519,284, or 12 cents a share, just about what the company was forecasting in late November.
Sharedata now is involved in a bitter fight with the company that licensed the games to it. That company, IJE Inc., obtained an injunction on Friday barring Sharedata from selling computer games that had been returned to it by retailers after they failed to sell in 1989. Michael S. Williams, Sharedata's president, said Friday that those returns had been greater than expected, but he said he did not know how much effect the increase in returns would have on results in the current quarter. IJE is also seeking large damages over several issues.
Last week appeared to be a crucial one for Sharedata, with $250,000 in short-term loans coming due, including one for $24,000 with a sky-high interest rate of 30 percent. Mr. Williams declined to say if any had been paid, but professed nonchalance. ''I'll call and get an extension,'' he said of one loan.
In its filings, Sharedata emphasized that its main hope for getting enough cash to stay in business was the exercise of 2.3 million warrants, each allowing the holder to buy a share for $1.25. The warrants are owned by Sheldon L. Miller, the company's chairman, who got legal clearance to exercise them and sell the shares in late January, at the same time other insiders got permission to sell shares. Mr. Miller could not be reached to comment, but Mr. Williams said none of the warrants had been exercised.
Sharedata's hope for a return to profitability rests on some office software that it has yet to market successfully, and on its newest product, introduced last week. That is a game that can be played on Nintendo machines. Mr. Williams said the company did not have Nintendo's permission to sell such games but believed it had found a way around that company's patent protections. He said Nintendo had not been formally advised of that opinion and so far had not commented on it.
One warning the S.E.C. forced Sharedata to add to its filings was that ''the existence and exercise of the warrants may have the effect of depressing the market price'' of the company's shares. Whether that was the cause or not, the share price peaked a couple of weeks before the insiders got permission to sell, but hung near that level until they were allowed to do so. It then fell sharply over the next two weeks.
How does Princeton Financial, which issued the bullish report that ignored the company's own cautions, feel about what has happened? When Anthony Pontieri, Princeton's president, was reached on Friday, he said he would not discuss the stock.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Market Place column on Monday about Sharedata Inc. misstated the month during which the company estimated a loss for the quarter that ended Dec. 31. The company made the estimate, of a loss of $500,000, in January 1990, not November 1989.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The 4A's Get A Call From Congress

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALM DESERT, Calif., March 18

 BODY:
The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee called on the advertising industry on Saturday to help sell his deficit-reduction package to the nation's business community.
In a speech at the annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Congressional committee responsible for drafting tax legislation, told more than 600 people, most of them advertising and communications company executives: ''You need a healthy economy so that people will have the money to buy the goods that you so successfully market. I need people with selling skills who can convince the American people that they'll have to make some short-term sacrifices so we can solve our shared problems.''
In a subsequent interview, Mr. Rostenkowski explained that he wanted advertising executives to ''sit down with their clients and let them know what the problem is, so that we can help solve the deficit.'' 
''You're the people who put the spin on things,'' he said. ''Join the army. Help me out.'' The object of his concern was a plan he recently put forward that he said would reduce the Federal budget deficit by $511.6 billion over the next five years. The program calls for one-year freezes in Social Security cost-of-living adjustments and other Government spending, cuts in the nation's military budget and increased taxes on personal income and gasoline.
Mr. Rostenkowski's address to the advertising trade association, whose 72d annual meeting ended Saturday, was the latest in a national tour he has been conducting to drum up support for his proposal among different interest groups.
While he avoided any direct criticism of American business in his address, Mr. Rostenkowski chided the advertising industry for influencing the nation's acceptance of budget deficits. He said, ''Our Government has embraced the very idea that your industry has sold so successfully to the American people: buy now, pay later.''
But Mr. Rostenkowski sought to allay the industry's continuing fear that advertising will become a target for legislators hungry to raise revenues, opening his talk by affirming that his committee has ''no such plans at this time.''
For at least two years, ever since Florida passed, and subsequently rescinded, a measure to tax advertising distributed in the state, the ad industry has been fearful of further state or Federal efforts to tax advertising expenditures or restrict their tax deductibility.
Still, Mr. Rostenkowski, who was instrumental in shaping the compromise between the Reagan White House and his own party that allowed passage of the 1986 income tax overhaul, refused to rule out the possibility and in a subsequent interview he acknowledged, ''It's hard for me to say yes or no'' to a Federal tax on advertising expenditures.
But he added that, to his knowledge, only one member of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Richard T. Schulze, Republican of Pennsylvania, had discussed taxation of advertising. He said the committee had not even studied the amount of revenue that could be raised through such a program.
Because it is a magnified reflection of the broad world of business, Madison Avenue has long been stereotyped as a Republican stronghold. Indeed, several executives in attendance here worked on the campaign advertising teams for Presidents Ford and Reagan. Nevertheless, Mr. Rostenkowski's message was well received by the executives, particularly his expressed willingness to link tax increases for specific purposes, like deficit reduction.
''People in that room are not interested in socialism,'' said Curtis R. Troeger, chief executive of Doremus & Company, a New York ad agency. ''If they knew where the tax money would go, it would make it easier to accept.''
Still, most of the ad executives said they would continue to oppose a tax on advertising, even if it were part of a broad plan to share the burden of deficit reduction among various constituencies.
''An income tax rise, a value-added tax, O.K.,'' said William H. Monoghan, the chief executive of Cabot Communications in Boston. ''But I think it's a mistake to tax advertising, because it's a mistake to tax anything that would diminish the creation of sales.''

HEADLINE: BIGGER BUDGET GAP IS SEEN BY DINKINS AS TAX MONEY LAGS

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that New York City faces an additional budget gap of at least $700 million for the fiscal year that starts on July 1. He ordered city agencies to prepare $500 million more in cuts that would severely trim services, and said more new taxes would be needed.
The new estimate is on top of the $1.1 billion gap that the city expected when Mr. Dinkins announced his $27.8 billion preliminary budget on Feb. 1. By law the city must have a balanced budget, so it must take actions each year to close the expected gap - the difference between its planned expenditures and its anticipated revenues. 
The new gap comes with budget prospects worsening for the state, from which the city is hoping to get some relief. Yesterday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, under severe pressure to close an estimated $1.5 billion budget gap, reversed a long-held position and proposed increasing the state's gasoline tax for the first time in 18 years. [Page B1.] 'Serious' Problems He did not suggest how high to raise the tax but said that just the fact that he was proposing an increase ''should give you some idea of how serious'' the budget problems are. Mr. Cuomo, who has frequently denounced supporters of a gas tax, estimated that a 5 cent-a-gallon increase would raise state revenues by about $200 million a year.
Mr. Dinkins said the city's new budget gap estimate was caused mostly by a $335 million projected shortfall in tax receipts and by the city's decision that it could no longer count on receiving $303 million from the sale of the old Coliseum site in time to help in the coming fiscal year. He said the Coliseum money would not be included in the budget to be issued about May 1.
 
Uncertain Revenue Source
The decision about the Coliseum seemed intended both to pressure community groups on the Upper West Side of Manhattan to settle a lawsuit that has held up the deal and to satisfy fiscal monitoring agencies that had criticized the city for including such an uncertain revenue source in the budget, a decision by the Koch administration.
At the same time, with the state's deadline for adopting its own precarious budget just weeks away, the Mayor's latest gloomy news put pressure on legislators in Albany to give the city as much aid as possible.
Mr. Dinkins, who met with his budget advisers at Gracie Mansion Sunday night, said he did not yet know just what the new cuts would be, but he said that they could range from closing firehouses to deferring hiring of police officers. The cuts already proposed call for everything from fewer sanitation and parks workers to reductions in library and cultural programs.
In response to a series of questions yesterday about whether certain items might have to be cut, Mr. Dinkins repeated, ''We may, we may, we don't know yet.''
 
'Dreams Deferred'
''It certainly is the worst of the bad news,'' the Mayor said at a news conference at City Hall. ''But it is clear that we have little option, if any. We have no option.'' Later, he added, ''Hopefully what we're talking about is dreams deferred, not dreams denied.''
The Mayor said the rest of the new $700 million gap was caused by new and revised economic projections that forecast additional tax shortfalls of $335 million, as well as an additional $70 million increase in mandated expenses. Together with hundreds of millions of dollars in cuts and other actions already announced in recent weeks, that means the city will have had to close a total gap of about $1.8 billion for the coming fiscal year.
Besides the new service cuts, Mr. Dinkins said the city would seek to close the expanded gap with $200 million more in bond refinancings and tax increases on top of the $550 million package of state and city taxes it has already proposed. He said he could not yet say what additional tax increases he would seek.
Mr. Dinkins's comments came less than a week after the State Financial Control Board said the city's budget would probably not be balanced without even deeper cuts than the Dinkins administration had proposed.
The cuts that have taken effect so far have mostly involved deferrals in hiring city workers and reductions through attrition.
 
'False Expectations'
In a letter to all agency heads yesterday asking for their recommendations for more cuts, Mr. Dinkins said he would prefer eliminating some programs entirely, rather than reducing them ''to a point where they exist in name only, something that would limit my decision-making options and present a set of false expectations'' about services.
Mr. Dinkins said the city still expected the Coliseum sale to go through eventually but could not count on it happening in time to help with next year's budget, as he had planned just six weeks ago. The sale of the site at Columbus Circle to Boston Properties, which intends to build a new skyscraper there, has been held up by litigation from community groups.
Deputy Mayor Barbara J. Fife said negotiations to settle the lawsuit had been unsuccessful but were continuing. She said that even if the suit were ended, there were some technical ''legal and financial issues left unresolved'' about the sale and that it would take ''a substantial amount of months'' to close the deal.
Faced with the prospect of severe service cuts, opponents of the deal, including some of Mr. Dinkins's political backers like State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, will undoubtedly come under greater pressure to reach a settlement.
Mr. Dinkins - who as Manhattan Borough President had opposed including the Coliseum money in the budget but said that since it was there, the city should go forward - said he had talked with the litigants ''repeatedly.''
 
'Sort of Stuck With It'
Of having the money in the budget, he said, ''We were sort of stuck with it.'' But he declined to criticize the Koch administration too harshly. ''Frankly, I think we need to dwell on resolution of the problem as opposed to fixing blame.''
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said new projections on the $335 million revenue shortfall showed that about $150 million of that would come in falloffs in corporate and commercial rent taxes, $95 million in personal income taxes and $35 million in other business or income taxes, as well as a $55 million slowdown in anticipated real-estate taxes.
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the City Council, which must approve the final budget this summer and which has the sole power to raise real-estate taxes, said it was too soon to comment on Mr. Dinkins's announcement. ''When they show us specifically what they're going to do, then we'll have something specific to say,'' she said.

HEADLINE: AT HOME ABROAD;
Wind Of Change

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
A premise of political life in all the black countries of southern Africa has suddenly been thrown into question. It is the rooted belief that South Africa menaces the life of the country.
There has been every reason for that feeling. Over the last dozen years South Africa has raided, bombed or invaded all of its black-ruled neighbors. By supporting guerrilla wars it has destabilized governments and bled societies. 
All this has been seen as an aggressive effort to maintain the power of South Africa's white minority. But now President de Klerk has unbanned the anti-apartheid political movements and released Nelson Mandela from prison. Next month in Cape Town he will meet an African National Congress delegation.
The system of white supremacy has by no means been abandoned as yet. But a process of change has begun in South Africa, and her neighbors have to know it. Already the Government has stopped its aid to guerrillas and promised that there will be no more cross-border raids. It has given up its colonial grip on Namibia, which becomes independent tomorrow.
If the menace is really fading, if there is a chance for a democratic government in Pretoria, the effect on the politics, the economics and the psychology of the region would be profound. It would be as fundamental as the dwindling of the Soviet threat is for Europeans and Americans. And as dislocating.
An ironic recent example: Zimbabwe officials have joined the A.N.C. in calling on the South African Government to end its state of emergency. But then people pointed out that Zimbabwe, too, has a state of emergency. It was renewed most recently just two months ago.
The menace of South Africa has been a justification for repressive measures in the black-ruled countries of the region. Change in South Africa might well produce pressure for liberalization elsewhere.
Something similar may be true of one-party systems. In Zambia, for instance, President Kenneth Kaunda has governed for 25 years. The country is an economic ruin. Yet last week Mr. Kaunda rejected the idea of allowing other parties than his to exist.
If South Africa moves to an open political system, there surely would be reverberations. The changes in Eastern Europe have already had their effect. Joe Slovo, General Secretary of the South African Communist Party and a member of the A.N.C. executive, has called for ''a multi-party post-apartheid democracy.''
Zimbabwe is a prosperous country and a pleasant one, the internal tensions of the past greatly eased. But opposing President Robert Mugabe is not easy.
When a newspaper exposed official corruption and a minister was convicted, President Mugabe pardoned him - and the editor was ''promoted'' out of his job. In primary elections held recently a number of prominent figures in the governing party were defeated, but the party committee voided some of those results.
In the past Mr. Mugabe has spoken of making Zimbabwe a one-party state. His intentions now are uncertain. But many Zimbabweans are against that idea, and democracy in South Africa could stiffen their resistance.
Change in South Africa would of course have great economic significance for the region. Zambia and Zimbabwe, Botswana and Mozambique all trade with South Africa now because they must, although they subscribe in theory to sanctions. The end of apartheid would encourage booming trade with the area's economic powerhouse, and have an enormous potential for growth.
The economic role of a post-apartheid South Africa might well have uncomfortable aspects, too. Local businesses may fear the competition. If South Africa avoided the folly of centralized economic controls, others could find it harder to maintain existing rigidities: the elaborate price ceilings that stifle growth in Zimbabwe, for example.
Thirty years ago Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, visiting Cape Town, said ''the wind of change'' was blowing through Africa. With Namibian independence, colonial and minority control will have ended everywhere save South Africa. If political change comes there, a fresh wind may well blow back up the continent.
The transition to a South Africa that has a respected place in the region will hardly be an easy one. But the possibilities can be glimpsed already. Many countries will have large stakes in the talks that begin in Cape Town on April 11.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 392 words

HEADLINE: A Good Deal on Prison Cells

 BODY:
With prison crowding in New York State at a critical point, Gov. Mario Cuomo and his Corrections Commissioner, Thomas Coughlin, offer an excellent deal: 3,000 prison cells for the price of 1,700, in half the time. Why do state legislators hesitate?
Last year, as part of a larger crime law package, the Legislature approved $160 million in bonding authority to build two 750-cell prisons and a 200-bed drug and alcoholism treatment center, pending approval for actual construction. But as projections for this year's prison population surged to alarming levels, Mr. Coughlin came up with a better idea. He proposes using the $160 million to expand five existing prisons by 600 cells each. 
Those 3,000 new cells could be constructed for the same money because there would be no need for new mess halls and other central facilities. Furthermore, it would take only six months to complete the 600-cell expansions, while building the new full prisons would take about a year.
There is urgent need for that kind of flexibility. Facing the most severe budget crisis in years, Albany isn't likely to come up with much new money for prisons this year. Yet prisons now are at 120 percent of capacity, and tougher sentences, combined with more aggressive police pursuit of drug dealers, promise no relief. Mr. Coughlin has already been forced to the potentially explosive practice of double-bunking inmates. Unless the 3,000-cell plan is approved soon, he asserts, the double-bunking might continue well into next year.
Why hasn't the Legislature rushed to embrace the substitute plan? At first, Assembly leaders argued that probation, drug treatment and other programs to ease the load on prisons ought to be considered along with more cells. Such services are essential to an overall corrections policy. But Assembly leaders now appear to recognize the urgency created by the budget crisis and the double-bunking problem, and seem prepared to accept the 3,000-cell plan.
The State Senate seems more reluctant, perhaps for political reasons. Two new 750-bed prisons are attractive plums to dangle before economically depressed upstate communities that vote for Republican senators.
Such preoccupation with politics is shortsighted. Viable criminal justice rests on a solid correctional system; putting it at risk, whatever the reason, is irresponsible.

LENGTH: 445 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Kohl's Divisive Appeal for Unity

 BODY:
Voting in their first free election since 1932, East Germans commendably turned out en masse to register their desire for a quick, sharp break with their Communist past. They threw their support behind right-of-center parties backed by West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who held out hope that rapid unification soon would bring economic prosperity.
But Mr. Kohl's highly partisan handling of the unification issue may come back to haunt him, Germany and Europe - unless he and other German leaders demonstrate appropriate sensitivity to European concerns, particularly about the inviolability of borders. 
Mr. Kohl and his Christian Democratic allies in East Germany took some hard shots at their main rival, the Social Democrat Party. The Social Democrats had been expected by many to be the leading party in East Germany before the campaign got under way. But the East German conservative alliance succeeded in exploiting the general revulsion against Communism. They painted the Social Democrats as ''Reds'' who harbored reservations about free markets and rapid unity.
These attacks will not be helpful when it comes to gaining Social Democratic support for the tough decisions that lie ahead on unification. Yesterday, leaders of the Social Democrats showed their displeasure by rejecting the conservative alliance's invitation to join a broad-based coalition government.
As matters stand, then, the conservative coalition of Christian Democrats and Free Democrats will be able to muster a parliamentary majority. But it will not have the two-thirds vote needed to amend the East German Constitution on critical questions.
An equally troubling concern is Mr. Kohl's management of the German border issue during the campaign. For weeks he refused to reaffirm existing boundaries between Germany and its neighbors. Then, under intense pressure from all over Europe and the United States, he relented to a degree.
It would be unfortunate if Mr. Kohl's nationalistic dance on the border question helped his conservative allies in East Germany win many votes. And it would be worse still if German leaders, East and West, now believed they had a mandate to proceed toward unification without being attentive and responsive to the rest of Europe.
Of course, Europeans and Americans rejoice with the German people in their first free election in almost 60 years. Of course, maybe everyone except the Soviets likes the idea of an all-German government prepared to remain a member of NATO in some form. But all this good will could quickly sour if Germans do not complete their march toward unification in harmony with their worried friends and neighbors.

HEADLINE: White House Resisting Further Pentagon Cuts

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The White House said today that it was not willing to accept major cuts in its proposal for the military budget in the fiscal year 1991 and that it believes it has already offered Congress adequate reductions.
The New York Times reported Sunday that the Bush Administration, under widespread pressure from Congress and elsewhere, had decided to accept cuts almost as large as those that lawmakers are urging in the 1991 Pentagon budget. The article was based on interviews with senior Administration officials.
In January, the Administration proposed a budget of about $303 billion for 1991, a cut of about $3.2 billion from what military programs would cost after accounting for inflation. The article said the Administration had decided to accept a much bigger cut, around $10 billion or $11 billion.
Asked about the article today, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ''Every number is negotiable.''
But he added: ''Our position is that we have proposed a budget that calls for something like $3.9 billion in cuts. We intend to stick with that proposal. That is our proposal. There is not a $10 billion or $12 billion cut number that we are prepared to accept.''
Still, Mr. Fitzwater said that the Pentagon had been conducting ''some very active and aggressive reviews of our defense needs'' and that in the future, if the Soviet threat continues to diminish, ''there certainly will be significant reductions in the Defense Department.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 4, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1012 words

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
Without Apology, a Defender of Deng Tells Why

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 19

 BODY:
He is ostracized by intellectuals and hailed by the leadership. He is the author of newspaper columns and recipient of death threats. The writer in question is He Xin, a social commentator and one of the best-known intellectual supporters of the present Government.
At a time when most Chinese intellectuals are still quietly seething at the Government, Mr. He goes out of his way to endorse it. For those in the West who believe that China's octogenarian leadership will inevitably be replaced by supporters of rapid liberalization, Mr. He is a rude surprise. He is a well-read, intelligent 40-year-old who sounds like Deng Xiaoping. 
''Americans care tremendously about personal freedom,'' Mr. He said in a recent interview, between puffs of a cigarette. ''But China is a country of 1.1 billion people, geographically immense but lacking in cultivatable land. If we didn't have a strong government, if we had American-style personal freedom, then China would fall into terrible chaos.''
 
A Red Guard in His Youth
A husky man with close-cropped hair just beginning to gray, Mr. He's was a lonely voice until the rise of the hard-liners last year. He does not have a university degree, for he came of age as a Red Guard when the universities were closed during the Cultural Revolution, but he has written more than a dozen books on a variety of subjects.
In his books and essays, he inveighs against rapid economic liberalization, against modern trends in literature and against the trend among intellectuals to blame China's traditional culture for the country's problems.
''Zhao Ziyang was very displeased when he saw this,'' Mr. He declared happily, waving a long essay that after much internal wrangling appeared in People's Daily a year ago. But it was the student democracy movement, which ultimately led to the dismissal of Mr. Zhao from his post as party leader, that most clearly distinguished Mr. He from other intellectuals.
The Australian Journal of Chinese Affairs recently published a copy of a confidential memorandum by Mr. He to the leadership, written on April 28, a day after one of the momentous demonstrations of the student movement. It was a remarkable call for the Government to accept the democracy movement as a serious threat.
 
Fears Decades of Disorder
''Civil war, military coups and popular uprisings in China for decades to come are now far from unthinkable,'' his memo said.
Yet the memo also warned against taking too repressive a line, for that might antagonize the population and create dissident heroes. Instead, Mr. He suggested that the leaders deal with allegations of corruption and take other steps to restore public confidence. Above all, he argued, the Government should avoid violence.
''History has taught us that in the long run those who die as a result of political repression invariably become heroes and martyrs,'' he wrote.
His arguments were not heeded, but Mr. He today does not question the eventual use of force. He says that the situation deteriorated after he wrote the memo, and that he understands the leadership's decision to use force.
 
Bloodshed Was 'a Great Pity'
''It is a great pity that there was bloodshed,'' Mr. He said. ''But the situation was getting worse and if force wasn't used it could have gotten out of hand and the consequences would have been unimaginable.''
Word of Mr. He's secret advice to the leadership spread among intellectuals, and deepened his reputation as a traitor. For while he urged restraint, he clearly came down against the democracy movement and his memo even named a few intellectuals as instigators of the unrest.
After a July television appearance in which he expressed strong support for the Government, and a few like-minded newspaper essays, Mr. He received a flood of 4,000 letters from around the nation. He says the letters alternately hailed and condemned him.
The role that Mr. He plays has no direct counterpart in the West, for nominally he is only a researcher at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. But scholars are widely respected in Chinese civilization, and they can help buttress or undermine the legitimacy of a government.
 
The Confident Communist
After the crackdown, when most intellectuals were silently disapproving, it was very important for the Government to have younger people, and especially scholars, to grant a seal of approval to the repression.
The essence of Mr. He's argument is that while democracy is a worthy goal, it takes decades or centuries to develop the educational and cultural base that can nourish a democracy.
''We all want a free environment in the end,'' Mr. He says. ''But if we tried to achieve this overnight, we would only get turmoil and disaster.''
He says he is confident that Communism will endure in China and that there will be no further popular upheavals like the one last year.
 
Says He's Faced Death Before
An economist said Mr. He attracts attention because ''it's just very hard for the leadership to find anyone his age who agrees with them.''
Mr. He acknowledges that he has received several death threats, but he says he faced death before - in the Cultural Revolution - and is not worried. While Mr. He enthusiastically joined in the Cultural Revolution, in 1970 he was accused of being a counterrevolutionary and was beaten and ''struggled against.'' His wrists still bear the scars of handcuffs, tightened as a form of torture.
Nonetheless, the experience apparently generated more a horror of chaos than of repression. Today, many intellectual antagonists of Mr. He are behind bars, accused of being ''counterrevolutionaries,'' and he is untroubled. If they merely expressed erroneous views, they would not be jailed, he suggested, while if they were behind-the-scenes organizers of the democracy movement, then it is only right that they be punished.
''They would have led our country into an abyss of misery,'' he said of those now in disgrace. ''If the student movement wasn't controlled, China could have entered several decades of turmoil.''
