SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1466 words

HEADLINE: 'Model Minority' Label Taxes Asian Youths

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Zhe Zeng, an 18-year-old junior at Seward Park High School in lower Manhattan, translates the term ''model minority'' to mean that Asian-Americans are terrific in math and science. Mr. Zeng is terrific in math and science, but he insists that his life is no model for anyone.
''My parents give a lot of pressure on me,'' said Mr. Zeng, who recently came to New York from Canton with his parents and older brother. He has found it hard to learn English and make friends at the large, fast-paced school. And since he is the only family member who speaks English, he is responsible for paying bills and handling the family's interactions with the English-speaking world.
''They work hard for me,'' he said, ''so I have to work hard for them.'' 
As New York's Asian population swells, and with many of the new immigrants coming from poorer, less-educated families, more and more Asian students are stumbling under the burden of earlier emigres' success - the myth of the model minority, the docile whiz kid with one foot already in the Ivy League. Even as they face the cultural dislocations shared by all immigrants, they must struggle with the inflated expectations of teachers and parents and resentment from some non-Asian classmates.
Some students, like Mr. Zeng, do seem to fit the academic stereotype. Many others are simply average students with average problems. But, in the view of educators and a recent Board of Education report, all are more or less victims of the myth.
''We have a significant population of Chinese kids who are not doing well,'' said Archer W. Dong, principal of Dr. Sun Yat Sen Junior High School near Chinatown, which is 83 percent Chinese. ''But I still deal with educators who tell me how great the Asian kids are. It puts an extra burden on the kid who just wants to be a normal kid.''
Perhaps the starkest evidence of the pressures these students face is the dropout rate among Asian-American students, which has risen to 15.2 percent, from 12.6 percent, in just one year, though it remains well below the 30 percent rate for the entire school system. In all, there are about 68,000 Asians in the city's schools, a little more than 7 percent of the student population.
Behind these figures, the Board of Education panel said, lies a contrary mechanism of assumed success and frequent failure. While teachers expect talent in math and science, they often overlook quiet Asian-American students who are in trouble academically.
The report also said that Asian students frequently face hostility from non-Asians who resent their perceived success. And though New York's Asian population is overwhelmingly Chinese, this resentment is fed by a feeling in society that the Japanese are usurping America's position as a world economic power. Some educators said that because they are often smaller and quieter, Asian students seem to be easy targets for harassment.
Teresa Ying Hsu, executive director of an advocacy group called Asian-American Communications and a member of the board panel, described what she called a typical exchange at a New York City school. One student might say, ''You think you're so smart,'' she said, then ''someone would hit a kid from behind and they would turn around and everyone would laugh.''
Since Asian cultures dictate stoicism, she explained, students in many cases do not openly fight back against harassment or complain about academic pressures. But though they tend to keep their pain hidden, she said, it often is expressed in ailments like headaches or stomach troubles.
 
'Acutely Sensitive'
''We have a group of youngsters who are immigrants who are acutely sensitive to things other students take in stride, like a door slamming in their face,'' said John Rodgers, principal of Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan.
Norman Thomas, whose student body is about 3 percent Asian, had two recent incidents in which Chinese students were attacked by non-Asian students. The attackers were suspended.
But tensions escalated after a group of 30 Chinese parents demanded that the principal, John Rodgers, increase security, and rumors spread that ''gangs of blacks'' were attacking Chinese. Both incidents, however, were one-on-one conflicts and neither attacker was black. In some cases, Mr. Rodgers said, Chinese students say they are attacked by blacks but that they cannot identify their attackers because all blacks look alike to them.
In response to the parents' concerns, Mr. Rodgers said, he increased security and brought in a speaker on cross-cultural conflict.
Traditionally, Asian parents have not been that outspoken, educators say. While they often place enormous pressures on their children to do well, most Asian parents tend not to get involved with the schools.
Lisa Chang, a 17-year-old senior at Seward Park - which is 48 percent Asian - recalled being one of six Asians at a predominantly black intermediate school.
''Inside the school there was no big deal,'' she said. ''I was in special classes and everyone was smart. Then I remember one day being outside in the snow and this big black boy pushed me. He called me Chink.
''Then, at home, my parents didn't want me to dress a certain way, to listen to heavy metal music,'' Ms. Chang said. When she told her dermatologist that she liked rock and roll, the doctor accused her of ''acting like a Caucasian.''
Ms. Chang and other students say there are two routes some Asian students take: they form cliques with other Asians or they play down their culture and even their intelligence in hopes of fitting in.
 
Wedged Between Two Cultures
Most Asian students are acutely aware of being wedged between two cultures. They say their parents want them to compete sucessfully with Americans but not become too American - they frown on dating and hard-rock music. There is also peer pressure not to completely assimilate. A traitor is a ''banana'' - yellow on the outside, white on the inside.
There is anger, too, over the perception that they are nerdy bookworms and easy targets for bullies. .
''A lot of kids are average, they are not what the myth says,'' said Doris Liang, 17, a junior at Seward Park. ''In math, I'm only an average student and I have to work really hard.''
Ms. Liang said she sometimes envies the school's Hispanic students.
''The Hispanic kids, in a way they are more open,'' she said. ''They're not afraid to bring their dates home. If you're Chinese and you bring your date home they ask a lot of questions. My parents only went to junior high school in China, so when we got here they wanted us to do well in school.''
Nicole Tran, a 15-year-old senior who spent the early part of her life in Oregon, said she believes her generation will be far more assertive.
''We are the minority minority,'' said Ms. Tran. Of the white majority, she said, ''We are moving too fast for them.''
Dr. Jerry Chin-Li Huang, a Seward Park guidance counselor, said he believes that Asians in New York are in part experiencing the cultural transformations common to all immigrants.
He notes that more of the new Asian immigrants - whose numbers in New York have swelled 35 to 50 percent in the past five years to about 400,000 -are coming from smaller towns and poorer, less educated families.
It was the early waves of educated, middle-class Asian immigrants whose children became the model minority, Dr. Huang said. Many of the students he sees have problems.
For one thing, Dr. Huang said many Asian parents are reluctant to admit that their children need help, even in severe cases. He said he had a schizophrenic Chinese student who began constantly wearing a coat, even on the hottest summer days. The parents were of little help.
''I have other children who run away from home because of the pressures,'' said Dr. Huang. ''I had two sisters who had to go to school then work in the factories, sewing. Their parents could not speak English so they were helping them with the bills. The girls said they barely had time to sleep.''
Dr. Huang said many non-Asian teachers come to him for his insights because they have few Asian co-workers. Asian are 1.4 percent of all school counselors; 0.8 percent of all principals, and 1.4 percent of all teachers in New York City.
Among its recommendations, the task force called for more Asian counselors and teachers.
People like Ms. Hsu, of Asian-American Communications, are optimistic that the situation for Asian students will improve as students and educators talk openly about it.
''I gave a workshop and I talked about the quotas, the Chinese exclusion act,'' said Ms. Hsu. ''Two black girls came up to me. One said: 'You know, I always thought the Chinese kids were snooty. Now after hearing what you went through I feel you're my brothers and sisters.' ''

HEADLINE: Florio Urges Taxing Rich

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 19

 BODY:
Behind the cascade of numbers released last week with Gov. Jim Florio's new budget stands a startlingly clear statement of philosophy by New Jersey's new Governor: he plans to shift money from the rich to the poor.
Beyond Mr. Florio's short-term plans to balance the next budget by cutting deeply into state programs and raising more than $1 billion in new sales taxes, he is proposing to double the income tax on the state's most affluent residents in 1992. This he sees as a long-lasting answer to some of the state's most vexing and ideologically charged problems.
The higher income tax would raise an additional $1.25 billion. That new money would go to relieve high property taxes for homeowners who earn less than $65,000 a year. It would be used to aid poor school districts. And it would help lift the cost of welfare and social services from cities and counties, a burden now borne most heavily by poor cities like Camden and Newark. 
Mr. Florio's income tax plan has helped define how he wants to be perceived as Governor. The image, politicians say, is of a lean, tough liberal.
 
Growth or Fairness as State's Goal
''He has cut expenditures radically, in the most painful and visible way,'' said George Sternleib, a professor at Rutgers University. ''But after that he has set his priorities as a very liberal Governor. It has been so long in public life since we have had a public figure who espouses and acts on these doctrines that it comes as a shock.''
For two decades the debate over the state's dependence on property taxes for revenues has raised conflicts between rich and poor, suburbs and cities, taxpayers and schools. Most of all, it has brought heated argument over whether the state government's first goal should be to encourage economic growth or to make the state a fairer place to live.
Since the 1960's critics of the tax system have said New Jersey resembles a child who continues to wear clothing that is long outgrown; its system for towns and cities, which rely almost entirely on property taxes, is a holdover from the days when New Jersey was a bucolic place of small towns and county governments that provided simple and inexpensive services.
In 1985, according to a state commission, property taxes were 41 percent of all state and local New Jersey taxes. In the the fiscal year that ended June 1988, the state raised $9.13 billion in taxes, and local governments raised $7.75 billion in property taxes.
Though the State Legislature enacted a modest income tax in 1976 -it now rises to a top tax bracket of 3.5 percent on income over $50,000 - critics continued to complain that the state's reliance on property taxes was generating a series of problems.
For one, in New Jersey as in other states, school districts raised money thorugh property taxes, meaning that children in poor districts, where schools received less financing, were deprived of the education available to children in richer districts.
 
Suit Challenges School System
A lawsuit against the state Department of Education, which is expected to be decided soon by the State Supreme Court, challenges the current school financing system as unconstitutional.
Second, urban leaders complained that the property tax system caught them in a fiscal trap: Social problems like crime meant higher taxes for more police, encouraging businesses and affluent residents to leave for lower taxes of the suburbs, which, in turn, caused city taxes to go higher.
Moreover, with many services paid for by property taxes, including the courts and welfare, property owners in almost all areas of the state saw their tax bills jump in recent years.
In July 1988, a commission reported to Gov. Thomas H. Kean on proposals to change the tax system. Among the many recommendations was raising the income tax for households with incomes of more than $50,000 from 3.5 to 4.0 percent, and raising the tax rates for incomes of more than $100,000 from 3.5 to 4.5 percent.
 
Symbol of Big Government
But to most Republicans an income tax increase remained a powerful symbol of big government and the state's attitude towards business.
''That would have been killing the goose that laid the golden egg,'' Governor Kean said later, after rejecting the commission's findings.
The budget package Mr. Florio announced last week really came in two steps. The first step would raise $1.4 billion in sales taxes, taxes on cigarettes, alcohol, and petroleum products in fiscal 1991, which begins this July 1, to balance the state's strained budget.
The income tax increase, to take effect January 1, 1992, would, in effect, adopt the philosphy of the commission report that Mr. Kean rejected. But Mr. Florio went further, raising $1.2 billion in taxes on those with incomes over $55,000, with households earning more than $100,000 paying a 7 percent tax. Seventeen states have higher income tax brackets than 7 percent.
In fact, aides to the Governor said, the 202,000 housholds that earn more than $100,000 would pay 75 percent of the income tax increase, or an average of about $4,500 more for each of those households.
The $1.25 billion raised by the income-tax increase would be used for property tax relief of up to $500 to those with incomes of less than $65,000, relieve county and municipal goverments of some welfare and social service costs, and fund a new school aid formula for adequate financing of education for students in poorer districts.
The Administration ensured that much of that money would go to to the poor, the elderly, and those living in cities and urban counties. For example, the decision to relieve local and county governments of welfare would ensure far more relief for poor urban areas. The administration decided not to take over the costs of running the courts, a Kean Administration proposal, which would have lifted a burden that is more alike for rich and poor counties.
''It was a courageous move on the part of the Governor,'' said Richard Roper, the director of the Program for New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School, who has long supported property tax revision.
Critics of the commission report in 1988 are already beginning to take aim at what they describe as a threat to business.
''It just takes my breath away,'' said Assemblyman Charles Hardwick of Union County, who bitterly opposed the commission report when he was the Republican Speaker of the Assembly. ''I see people leaving New Jersey because it will become a high-tax state.''
Florio Administration officials say, however, that they carefully considered the impact of the proposed increases on the economic climate of the state. One decision they made was not to raise corporate taxes, they said.
State Treasurer Douglas C. Berman, who oversaw the drafting of the Florio budget, said the Republicans cannot demonstrate that an increase in personal income taxes leads business executives to take their corporations out of the state. Mr. Berman described such logic as ''an argument for rich Republicans to avoid paying their fair share.''

HEADLINE: A Lucrative Crime Grows Into a Costly Epidemic

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The theft at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on Sunday is the largest and latest in what art experts and law enforcement authorities are calling an epidemic of art thefts. Spurred by soaring art prices and the increasing resourcefulness of thieves, art theft now ranks as one of the most lucrative forms of crime, they say.
Museum officials and insurers say the dramatic increase in thefts has not only heightened concern about security at museums and galleries but has also caused a spectacular rise in art-insurance costs. This rise has increased the financial burden on museums that mount major exhibitions of art on loan.
Last year, the International Foundation for Art Research, a New York organization that compiles information about stolen art, received reports of about 5,000 thefts. That was only a small fraction of the total, according to the foundation's director, Dr. Constance Lowenthal. 
Although sketchy reporting and record-keeping means there are no reliable statistics, Dr. Lowenthal estimated that art theft is now a $1 billion- to $2 billion-a-year business.
''Law-enforcement officials in much of the world see art theft as a low priority,'' she said. ''Furthermore, many smaller museums don't report thefts because they don't know a work has been stolen or have adequate information to prove that a theft has occurred.''
 
'Much More at Risk'
 The growing economic toll of art theft is partly a consequence of today's overheated art market.
''With the increase in art values, insurance premiums have gone up because there's much more at risk,'' said Harold Smith, a New York insurance adjuster who specializes in fine art. ''Add to this the fact that there's more art theft and damage. And the biggest danger to the art world is that thieves are getting much better at disposing of stolen art.''
What does become of priceless art like Vermeer's ''Concert'' or the three Rembrandts and five works by Degas, all of which were among the 12 artworks stolen on Sunday from the Gardner Museum, or Monet's famous ''Impression, Sunrise,'' still missing more than four years after it was taken from the Marmottan Museum in Paris?
''I don't know how on earth they could get back on the art market,'' said Jane Yeingst, the former art-theft analyst for the American office of Interpol in Washington. ''There might be unscrupulous collectors who'd buy them, but you'd really have to limit who they were shown to. They're either held on to, abandoned or, unfortunately, destroyed.''
A popular but unsubstantiated theory is that thefts of well-known artworks are commissioned by wealthy black-market collectors like the evil genius in Ian Fleming's novel ''Dr. No.'' ''Someone may have been behind the theft at the Gardner,'' Dr. Lowenthal said, ''but it's unlikely it was a Dr. No-type scenario, with someone wanting the paintings for their own delectation.''
 
Is the Black Market Growing?
 But Dr. Lowenthal says there may be a growing black market, particularly in Japan, for even well-known artworks. ''It's mostly speculation, but there are several elements to this 'Asian possibility,' '' she said. ''The Japanese have been spending a lot of money on art in recent years. In 1988, some paintings by Corot that were stolen in France were recovered in Japan, and we keep hearing rumors that the Monet is in Japan. And Japanese law on stolen art is not good for owners. There's only a two-year statute of limitations on recovering stolen art from a Japanese purchaser who did not know it was stolen.''
Other experts believe that thefts of major artworks often have ''quiet ransom scenarios,'' Dr. Lowenthal said. Insurance companies officially deny that they ever pay ransom, but law-enforcement officials and some insurers say that it is sometimes paid. ''Reward money is supposed to be offered for information leading to the recovery, prosecution and conviction of thieves,'' Dr. Lowenthal said, ''but I imagine that sometimes money from insurance companies is available under less stringent conditions. It's a dangerous route for insurance companies to embark on, because it's essentially blackmail and leads to more of the same.''
Huntington T. Block, a Washington art-insurance dealer, said, ''When a well-known work is stolen, generally the owner can expect a ransom call -whether months or years later - because he is the only person the thief can deal with.''
 
Many Thefts, Few Arrests
 Whatever happens to stolen masterpieces, thousands of lesser artworks vanish from museums, libraries, art galleries, private collections, churches and synagogues each year. Only about 12 percent will be recovered, Dr. Lowenthal said, and just a fraction of those recoveries will result in arrests.
''Most minor works, like prints, jewelry and decorative arts, go back on the art market,'' Ms. Yeingst said. ''They're often taken to another country to be sold, and the chances that the right person will look at them in an auction catalogue and recognize they're stolen is slim.''
Smaller museums, art dealers, collectors and churches, which rarely have elaborate security measures, are particularly vulnerable to theft, said Lieut. John Kelly, commanding officer of the New York Police Department's special frauds squad, which oversees investigations of art thefts.
 
Private Collections in Jeopardy
 Even though private collections are generally well insulated from the public, they are also major targets for thieves. In July 1988, for example, an armed thief posing as a building inspector entered a Gramercy Park apartment in Manhattan, tied up the housekeeper and the building superintendent, and stole 30 paintings and prints, including works by Picasso and Renoir.
New York's hundreds of private galleries have been victims of many thefts over the years, but the recovery record has been good, said Lieut. Joseph Pollini, who heads the New York Police Department squad that investigates major burglaries. In February 1988, Old Master paintings worth an estimated $6 million to $10 million were stolen from the Colnaghi Gallery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and have yet to be recovered. Several more recent thefts - of 15 contemporary paintings, from the Dyansen Gallery in SoHo on Feb. 13, and of a $1.4 million Alexander Calder sculpture from the Perls Gallery on Madison Avenue on Jan. 21 - were quickly solved.
 
Next Victim: the Public
 The threat of theft may plague art owners, but the most immediate danger of increased art prices, art theft and insurance costs for the public is that blockbuster exhibitions may become a thing of the past, museum officials say.
''The sudden escalation of art prices has meant that too much of your budget for special exhibitions gets chewed up by insurance,'' said Charles S. Moffett, senior curator of paintings at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
Although the Federal Government indemnifies some loans of art from abroad for up to $125 million per exhibition, ''for an exhibition of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist or classic modern paintings, it doesn't take you very far,'' he added. ''It's beginning to make it quite difficult to do certain kinds of exhibitions. Our Gauguin show in 1988 might have been a project we couldn't pursue today.''
Diane Waldman, deputy director of the Guggenheim Museum, said: ''Insurance now accounts for up to one-third of the budget for exhibitions like our 50th-anniversary show, which took place in 1987. Five years ago, it would have been 10 percent.''
''Increasing prices also affect operating budgets,'' she added, ''because museums have to keep re-insuring their collections.''
 
Insuring for the Worst Case
 Whereas private and corporate collectors generally insure each work they own for a fixed value, museums and dealers usually do not itemize their collections or insure specific works, and few museums or galleries insure their collections for their full value. ''If they did, they would have to close their doors because of the cost of premiums,'' Mr. Block said. The high cost was cited as a major reason the Gardner did not have theft insurance.
Museums and galleries typically have ''all risk'' policies for theft, vandalism and fire that cover their collections for a blanket amount. Costs depend on museum location, architecture and security measures, but annual premiums for $10 million in insurance range from $10,000 to $50,000 a year.
Museums try to calculate their maximum possible loss in a worst-case scenario like a fire or a bombing, said Axel Beyer, executive vice president of Nordstern Insurance Company of America. Thus they may insure their collections for only about 15 to 25 percent of the total value, he said.
But many museum officials agree with Phillip Babcock, director of risk management at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, that ''the primary mission of museums is to protect and preserve their collections.''
''They should use their resources to reduce the risk of loss through improved security and better identification of objects,'' he added. ''Insurance should be at the bottom of the list.''
 
Keeping Thefts in Check
 Although the United States has no central registry of significant artworks in its museums and other cultural institutions - unlike France, Belgium, Italy and Japan - several American organizations do monitor art theft.
For example, the International Foundation for Art Research has records on nearly 32,000 stolen works and updates its catalogue of stolen art 10 times a year. The F.B.I. also has a database of stolen art, with images of thousands of works, stored on laser disks.
Museum officials have even begun to overcome longstanding fears that discussing theft would scare away potential donors, Dr. Lowenthal said. ''Museum policies have changed from secrecy to openness,'' she said. ''They've realized that publicizing theft will promote recovery.''
But art theft remains a low priority among law-enforcement officials. ''Many institutions have no liaisons with police departments,'' said Katharine Leab, founder of another database, called Bookline Alert Missing Books and Manuscripts. ''So police often have no understanding of their problems.''

HEADLINE: Where Balloons Fail In Clearing Arteries, New Devices May Help

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

 BODY:
Researchers are working on more than two dozen new devices that are designed to clear heart arteries by cutting, drilling, burning or pulverizing obstructions.
The devices, which are mounted on thin tubes snaked into the heart arteries, might find wide use in correcting deficiencies and side effects of a conventional therapy that relies on tiny balloon devices to widen a channel, the researchers say.
When that technique, coronary angioplasty, is used, new obstructions develop within six months in 30 percent of the cases, and they are often as severe as the original obstruction. In up to 4 percent of cases, the vessel reseals shortly after the procedure because of the collapse of part of the obstructing material that has been pushed back by the balloon or of flaps of tissue from the artery. Often emergency bypass surgery is required. 
 
'Balloon Has Limitations'
 ''There is a lot of excitement in the field because the balloon has limitations and people see opportunity,'' said Dr. George Sopko, who administers grants for cardiovascular research from the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute.
But none of the new devices has proven successful enough to replace balloon angioplasty. ''Early on, there were limited attempts to look at devices as replacements, but now the trend is to look at things that are complementary to angioplasty,'' Dr. Sopko said.
Dr. Donald S. Baim of Harvard Medical School, who is director of invasive cardiology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, said, ''Nothing looks like an absolute replacement for angioplasty.''
Angioplasty is a common treatment when arteries carrying blood from the heart become clogged or obstructed with a sticky, yellow plaque formed from cholesterol, minerals, cell debris and other material. The blockage can lead to chest pain from restricted blood flow and sometimes heart attack.
Researchers working with the new devices hope to get part of a heart catheter market with worldwide annual sales of $500 million; the total is expected to double in five years. The precision devices generally cost $500 to $1,000 apiece, experts said, and are used only once.
Dr. Baim, who has tested several of the new devices, said: ''More than a million angioplasties have been done and we know a lot about it. It's the most tried, true and versatile technique for opening arteries and something would have to be pretty spectacular to displace it.''
Dr. Sopko said that because of its commercial potential, most of the research on alternatives to balloon angioplasty is being sponsored by the private sector, not the government.
In angioplasty, doctors run an uninflated balloon on a thin tube through an artery in the leg. Tracking the procedure by X-ray, surgeons move the balloon to a blocked area and inflate it, cracking and crushing the plaque against the arterial walls to open a channel through which blood can flow more freely. Although the plaque is pushed aside, it is not removed.
 
The Search for Alternatives
 Looking for alternatives, researchers at scores of companies and medical centers are developing mechanical devices that burrow through plaque by slicing it away, high-speed bits that drill in and pulverize the block, lasers that heat and ''weld'' back plaque compressed by a balloon, and low-heat lasers that disrupt the structure of the plaque and disintegrate it.
Cutting or shaving devices appear to be getting the most attention from developers. For example, Duke University researchers led by Dr. Richard S. Stark, working with Interventional Technologies Inc. of San Diego, Calif., are testing a catheter with a rapidly spinning, cone-shaped tip containing tiny blades. As the cone shaves pieces from the obstruction, the plaque is continuously extracted by suction.
Dr. Timothy Fischell, a Stanford University cardiologist, and his physicist father, Robert Fischell of Johns Hopkins University, are also developing cutting devices to get at tough plaque that resist balloons. They have patented bullet-shaped catheters with cutting edges on the trailing end; the devices first pierce the deposit, then slice and collect plaque as they are pulled back out of the vessel.
Coronary balloon angioplasty, first accomplished in 1977 by Dr. Andreas Gruentzig in Switzerland, became an established procedure in the early 1980's. The procedure is also widely used to open clogged vessels in the leg and kidney, but most research attention has focused on the heart.
Experts estimate that 200,000 to 300,000 of the procedures, which cost about $8,000 each for treatment and hospitalization and $2,000 more for the surgeon, will be performed this year in the United States.
Angioplasty is sometimes an alternative to much more expensive coronary bypass surgery, in which veins are transplanted to carry blood flow around clogged vessels.
 
Complications and Drawbacks
 Specialists say the procedure has major complications and drawbacks, including the sudden collapse of the artery shortly after the procedure. Surgical teams normally stand by in case the vessel cannot be reopened.
The balloon technique is not very effective when total or nearly total blockage prevents entry of the catheter, or when there are elongated or odd-shaped blockages or plaque attached more to one side of the vessel than the other. It also has difficulty dilating rigid plaques made hard by calcification or the accumulation of tough, fibrous material.
 
Preventing Re-stenosis
 The most persistent problem has been re-stenosis, or the return of narrowing deposits to some vessels, which occurs within six months in 30 percent of coronary arteries and more than 40 percent of leg vessels opened by balloons.
Re-stenosis is believed to be a result of injury to the vessel caused by insertion of the tube and expansion of the balloon, which stretches and tears the artery wall. For unknown reasons, the rate of this type of closure is even higher, 45 to 50 percent, in bypass graft vessels, and balloon angioplasty sometimes is used to clear them.
''When you think of what the balloon does to the artery, it's very crude,'' said Dr. Timothy A. Sanborn, director of the cardiovascular research program at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City. ''It cracks and stresses the vessel and doesn't really remove the plaque, just compresses it. We're trying to find kinder, gentler ways of doing this.''
Some researchers are optimistic that the restenosis problem might be helped by physically bracing the artery against collapse.
For example, Johnson & Johnson Interventional Systems of Warren, N.J., is testing a collapsible scaffolding or stent that is carried into an blocked vessel around a balloon catheter. When the balloon inflates and depresses the plaque deposit, the mesh-like metal device, called the Palmaz-Schatz stent, expands to form a supporting structure inside the vessel wall. Researchers said tests of the Johnson & Johnson product in hundreds of patients indicate it could stop acute closure when properly inserted.
Another method that shows promise for fighting the re-stenosis and abrupt closure problems is the excimer, or cold, laser. With this approach, pulsed ultraviolet light energy photochemically shatters plaque, but releases little heat.
The excimer laser system being developed by Advanced Interventional Systems of Irvine, Calif., is undergoing clinical tests at several hospitals. It delivers laser energy through bundles of optical fibers at the end of a catheter.
Excimer systems, Dr. Sanborn said, appear to produce a smoother channel through plaque and to seal off flaps of tissue that can suddenly close a vessel. ''With patience and more time I think some of the devices might end up superior'' to angioplasty, Dr. Sanborn said.
Some new research also focuses on modifying and improving the classic balloon method. Dr. J. Richard Spears of Wayne State University in Detroit has combined an inflatable balloon with a laser heat source to create a ''hot balloon'' catheter that is being widely tested. The device heats the wall of the artery to the boiling point of water while inflating the balloon under pressure, a procedure that Dr. Spears says creates a larger, smoother channel while welding back the plaque deposit.
The researchers at Duke are also testing what they call an autoperfusion balloon catheter, which allows blood to flow through a tube in the center of the balloon while it is inflated. Preliminary tests indicate that this approach, which does not totally block the vessel, will allow gradual, more prolonged periods of balloon inflation that may improve outcomes.
Dr. Robert Ginsburg, head of the vascular therapy center at Stanford University Medical Center, said many of the devices being tested would probably end up having a role in treating clogged arteries.
''But none of these devices will be perfect for all occasions, all patients,'' Dr. Ginsburg said. ''I envision having several available on the instrument tray of an operating room and the surgeon picking different ones, depending on the peculiarities of the case, like a golfer selecting different clubs from his golf bag depending on the shot he wants to make.''
 
IMPROVING BALLOON ANGIOPLASTY AND REPLACING IT
 
In balloon angioplasty, arteries clogged by plaque are opened with an expanding balloon, snaked to a blocked area, often a coronary artery. The technique has been used more than a million times; new techniques are being tried to supplement it.
 
Problems and Side Effects
Balloons work poorly when blockage is nearly total or when plaque deposits are long, awkwardly positioned or hardened. The vessel may reseal immediately after the procedure or later.
 
Cold laser energy carried through bundles of optical fibers shatters plaque, makes a smoother channel and seals off flaps of the artery wall.
 
A laser heats the artery wall while the balloon is being inflated to make a large, smooth channel and weld back the plaque.
 
Other Devices
A motorized device uses a tube with a rapidly spinning cone-shaped tip containing tiny blades. It shaves pieces from the plaque blocking the artery; suction carries the debris through the tube and out of the body.
 
When the balloon inflates and depresses the plaque, it can stress and weaken the artery. A collapsible mesh scaffolding carried along with the balloon expands to brace the artery against collapse. (Sources: Wayne State University; Advanced Interventional Systems; Duke University and Interventional Technologies Inc.;; Johnson & Johnson Interventional Systems)

HEADLINE: Japan Loan Rate Lifted Sharply

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, March 20

 BODY:
Under heavy pressure from the turmoil in the stock market and a weak yen, the Bank of Japan ended weeks of speculation by announcing here at midday that it was raising its official discount rate a steep one percentage point, to 5.25 percent, its highest level since 1981.
The announcement calmed some of the uncertainty that had plagued the market every since talk of a rate increase began more than a month ago. But many had felt it had come too late and thus had contributed to a growing sense of despair over the downward spiral in the financial markets here.
Although the move was intended in part to bolster the yen, its impact was momentary at best. The dollar fell to slightly less than 153 yen after the news of the central bank's decision raced through Tokyo trading rooms. The dollar, however, quickly rebounded to 153.60, shrugging off both the discount rate increase and continued intervention by the Bank of Japan. 
 
'Great Disappointment'
''There was great disappointment by the lack of reaction in the foreign exchange market,'' said Jeffrey Guy, an analyst at Yamaichi Securities. ''It was not a very bright day.'' Japan has been at pains to prevent the yen from declining further because a weaker currency would tend to widen the country's already huge trade surplus. A weak currency makes exports cheaper to foreign buyers and makes imports dearer. There has been concern here that the falling currency could aggravate the already strained relations between Japan and the United States.
The discount rate announcement came against the backdrop of a plunge in the Tokyo stock market on Monday and a further decline on Tuesday.
 
Slide Continues
In the shaken Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 4.1 percent Monday as it continued its worst slide since the worldwide stock market crash in October 1987 and tumbled another 1.5 percent today.
In New York on Monday, the investors shrugged off the news from Tokyo, and the Dow Jones industrial average managed a gain of 14.41 points, to 2,755.63. [Page D10.] In Japan today, the market seesawed throghout the morning and then was pushed lower in the afternoon, with the Nikkei tumbling a further 456.05, to 30,807.19.
The increase also carried great significance for Japanese corporations and the economy. It reinforced the view that the era of ultra-low interest rates, which made a large contribution to the international competitiveness of Japanese companies, had ended.
The discount rate, which is charged commercial banks on certain short-term loans and which acts as a benchmark for other interest rates, has been increased four times and more than doubled since last May, when it stood at 2.5 percent. It was last increased on last Christmas Day in a futile attempt to arrest the decline of the yen against the dollar.
On Monday, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 600 points in the morning, and the drop accelerated in the afternoon, with the index closing down 1,353.20 at 31,263.24. Trading volume was a remarkably thin 400 million shares, about half the level of a moderately active day.
The plunge left the market down by 4.1 percent for the day and 19.6 percent for the year, erasing most of the gains of last year. It was the second time this year that prices have plummeted more than 4 percent in a single day.
The same pattern of recent weeks was repeated Monday: selling pressure was not heavy, but there was almost a total absence of buyers, which put share prices in something close to free fall in the afternoon. Large institutions, which so often in the past have acted as a backstop for tumbling prices, have been conspicuous by their absence this time, adding to the despair of Japanese investors.
 
Pessimism Abounds
''I don't want to say that it's the end of the world, but everyone's mind is set, they interpret everything pessimistically,'' said Masa Nakamura, head of international equities trading at Goldman, Sachs & Company's Tokyo office. ''Nobody has the guts to put in a bid'' to buy shares, he added.
''What's been happening has severely damaged confidence,'' said Nick Akers, a senior analyst at James Capel Pacific Limited. ''I just don't see the big institutions coming back in a hurry.''
A further psychological blow to the market was a steep plunge in the shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the telecommunications giant. Its shares fell 20,000 yen, or about $130, to close at 1,180,000, the first time the issue had fallen below its initial offering price of 1,197,000 in 1987. In addition to NTT being hit by the general worries in the market, the Government is considering forcing a breakup of the company.
 
Officials Are Perplexed
Even senior Government officials are beginning to show how perplexed they are, not just by the steepness of the slide, but by its persistence in the face of what is still a generally healthy Japanese economy.
For instance, at a briefing for reporters on Monday, a senior Bank of Japan official commented: ''We expected some correction this year, but I admit it's larger than we thought. It's extremely difficult to explain by economic terms.''
A number of factors are contributing to the growing pessimism, without any single influence dominating, analysts said.
Foremost in the minds of many here is the falling yen and the Japanese Government's inability to arrest the slide. The dollar has risen a little more than 7 percent against the yen this year. The Bank of Japan has spent more than $10 billion buying yen and selling dollars to try to reverse the trend, but its efforts have had no impact.
 
Celebrating Spring
Wednesday is a national holiday in Japan, to celebrate the first day of spring, and there was speculation that the central bank would increase its discount rate today in advance of that break, as happened.
By creating the expectation of higher rates, the weak yen had contributed to a big decline in the bond market, where rates have jumped to their highest level in nearly six years.

HEADLINE: Getting Burned By the Frying Pan

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Kentucky Fried Chicken's middle name is beginning to spell trouble.
Concerned about fat and cholesterol, which seem to fairly ooze out of the company's namesake, more and more Americans are turning to chicken that is grilled or baked or broiled - anything but fried. No matter that some studies show many of these have nearly as much fat and almost as many calories per serving as the fried version.
The shift has caught Kentucky Fried Chicken and other established purveyors in the $5 billion-a-year industry with offerings, both old and new, that are still almost always fried.
''Increasing health concerns among consumers are inhibiting the growth of Kentucky Fried Chicken,'' said Elden Chang, a restaurant analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. 
Last month, Kentucky Fried Chicken reported that its fourth-quarter earnings declined 12 percent, to $28.5 million, on a sales gain of 3 percent, to $420.9 million, compared with the period a year earlier. The chain's parent company, Pepsico, tersely attributed the decline to ''lower customer counts.'' Higher prices and more restaurants accounted for the meager sales growth.
 
A New Chain Tastes Success
Picking up on the consumer mood, new entrants like a fast-rising Southwestern chain called El Pollo Loco, and poachers from the hamburger business, like Burger King, are prospering from sales of non-fried chicken. El Pollo Loco, based in Irvine, Calif., has become the nation's fastest-growing major chicken chain. And Burger King's ''BK Broiler,'' a broiled-chicken sandwich introduced last month, is already selling at a rate of a million a day. That compares with the two million Whopper hamburgers that it sells each day.
As the warm-weather months approach, when most fast-food chicken is sold, Kentucky Fried Chicken's fried-food onus is not its only problem. It is also hurt by high chicken prices and rising competition from what many analysts see as a near-saturation of fast-food outlets.
Kentucky Fried Chicken, based in Louisville, Ky., is the largest and weakest link in the strong restaurant chains of Pepsico. By contrast, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell are performing vigorously.
To try to move the chicken chain ahead, Pepsico has installed new management. John Cranor 3d, a longtime Pepsico executive, replaced Richard Mayer as chairman of the chicken division when Mr. Mayer left last year to join Philip Morris's General Foods U.S.A. Just last week, the president of Kentucky Fried Chicken-USA, Steven Fellingham, resigned and was replaced by Kyle Craig, an assistant to Pepsico's chairman, D. Wayne Calloway. Pepsico also brought in William McDonald, a Pizza Hut executive, to direct marketing, Under the new management, Kentucky Fried Chicken has started test-marketing grilled chicken. It is also tightening operations and broadening its fried menu. ''K.F.C. doesn't have the best reputation for cleanliness and service,'' Mr. Cranor has told securities analysts. He has reorganized field operations, revamped training and is conducting more frequent inspections of franchisees. A new fried-chicken sandwich and other new products, like spicy chicken wings, are being added to attract more lunch-time business. Most of the chain's sales are at dinner time.
The $5 billion that Americans spent last year on fast-food chicken was more than triple the $1.4 billion spent in 1980, according to the National Broiler Council, a Washington trade group for chicken producers. Ninety percent of the fast-food chicken was deep-fried.
 
First Fundamental Menu Change
But the 10 percent of the market that was not is expected to grow quickly. ''Over the next two or three years, the proportion of chicken grilled, baked or broiled could easily double,'' said William P. Roenigk, an economist with the broiler council. ''There are a lot of people out there -nobody knows how many - who say, 'I love chicken, but I just won't eat it fried.' ''
Grilled chicken would be Kentucky Fried Chicken's first fundamental menu change since the company's founding in 1955 by Harland Sanders, known as the Colonel. But the chain says it will not be available nationally soon, even though results in Louisville, Las Vegas, Nev., and Canberra, Australia, are promising.
The company is still tinkering with the grilling equipment to determine how to incorporate grills in the already cramped kitchens of the chain. The national introduction of grilled chicken will be sometime next year, said Richard M. Detwiler, a company spokesman.
The only national fast-food chicken company, Kentucky Fried Chicken is by far the market leader, with a 67.6 percent share, according to estimates by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, based on figures from Nation's Restaurant News, a trade magazine.
 
Popeye's Is Climbing
Popeye's, the growing No. 2 chain, with 13.3 percent of the market, recently acquired third-ranked Church's, with an 8.1 percent share. Popeye's is converting the faltering Church's outlets to its Cajun fried-chicken format. Fourth-ranked Chick-Fil-A, a fried chicken chain with a 6 percent share, is steadily increasing its share by concentrating on its base in the South, where people still love their chicken fried.
But the rising star is fifth-ranked El Pollo Loco (The Crazy Chicken in Spanish). The company has prospered partly by promoting its broiled chicken as a ''delicious and healthy fast food'' prepared in accordance with American Heart Association recommendations.
With sales per store of about $1.1 million in 1989, El Pollo Loco ranks at the top of the industry, Donaldson Lufkin said. That is nearly double the sales level of it competitors.
Moreover, El Pollo Loco's total sales grew by 27.2 percent in 1989, again at the top of the industry. That compares with Kentucky Fried Chicken's 3.5 percent. El Pollo Loco, a unit of TW Services, a privately held food service company in Paramus, N.J., does not disclose full-year sales or profits.
 
A Rapid Rise
El Pollo Loco had only 17 outlets in Southern California in 1983 and now has 203 restaurants in California, Arizona, Nevada and New Mexico.
Although the chain plans to concentrate its growth in the Southwest for now, said R. Neil Croak, franchisee marketing manager, ''this is a concept viable across America.''
While El Pollo Loco uses ''healthy fast food'' to its advantage in its ads, the fat and calorie content of grilled chicken, marinated in fruit juices and herbs, is similar to that of fried chicken.
The Center for Science in the Public Interest, a health advocacy organization in Washington, compared company-provided data for typical portions of Kentucky Fried Chicken and El Pollo Loco chicken. As a percentage of calories derived from fat, a widely used nutritional index, Kentucky Fried's chicken scored better at 49 percent, compared with El Pollo Loco's 52 percent.
Kentucky Fried Chicken was indeed 39.5 percent higher in cholesterol and 75.3 percent higher in sodium, ounce for ounce. But it was only 9.5 percent higher in calories and a scant 2 percent higher in fat.
''That is very interesting,'' Mr. Detwiler, the Kentucky Fried Chicken spokesman, said of the nutritional analysis. ''I suspect most people don't know that. I certainly didn't.''
El Pollo Loco attributes the mixed nutritional picture to the fact that its data were based on an average of the white-meat breast and dark-meat wings and thighs. ''Dark meat is typically 20 percent higher in fat than white meat,'' said Gayle A. De Brosse, the company's director of research and development.
 
Costs Shoot Up
Mainly because of increased demand for chicken at supermarkets and restaurants, Kentucky Fried Chicken has seen its raw material costs rise by 19 percent, to $500 million, from $420 million in 1987. Mr. Chang, the Donaldson, Lufkin analyst, said chicken prices were still near their peak of 70 cents a pound.
Perhaps the largest external pressure on Kentucky Fried Chicken is the sheer number of fast-food outlets of all kinds competing for customers.
Analysts estimate the number of American restaurants in the 100 leading chains - serving burgers, chicken, pizza, seafood and steaks -increased nearly 19 percent in just the last three years. That is a total of 119,161 major restaurants, or one fast-food place for every 2,100 people.
Such intense competition is at the heart of the dispute between Kentucky Fried Chicken's management and its franchisees, who own more than 70 percent of the chain's nearly 5,000 outlets in the United States. (There are also more than 3,000 international restaurants, from Beijing to Barbados.) The company wants to change the franchisee contract to allow more outlets in the few areas that have fast-growing markets.
The Association of Kentucky Fried Chicken Franchisees filed suit to block the move, fearing that new stores could be placed too near existing ones and sap their sales. Management and the franchisee group are now negotiating the contract.

An article in Business Day yesterday about Kentucky Fried Chicken and rival chains misidentified the parent company of El Pollo Loco, a fast-food chain. It is TW Holdings Inc., a publicly traded holding company based in Spartanburg, S.C.

HEADLINE: Soviets Seek Bond Advice in U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Soviet Union, struggling to invigorate its economy, is turning to American financial experts for advice on raising money to build much-needed projects, from hospitals to factories.
With the approval of senior Soviet officials, an American team is developing ways of borrowing similar to those used by more than 40,000 local governments in the United States. Several of the proposals are to be presented in early April when the Americans visit the Soviet Union.
Important to the American group's proposals is showing how a relatively small amount of money can be stretched to finance projects that would greatly benefit the Soviet economy. That technique is widely used by local governments in the United States, which borrow money by selling bonds to pay for construction of large projects, then repay the bonds over years or decades. In the Soviet Union, bond financing is unknown, and projects are financed on a ''pay as you go'' basis, with no long-term borrowing. 
 
A Daunting Task
But while the pool of savings in the Soviet Union is large, persuading citizens and enterprises to invest in bonds to finance new projects will be a daunting task. Bond purchases mandated during the Stalin years were later repudiated. And with inflation estimated at 10 percent for consumer goods whose prices are not controlled, many savers are more interested in buying gold, rugs and artwork. New financial instruments will require some salesmanship to overcome the suspicion that the investments may not hold their value.
Nevertheless, Sergei Plekhanov, a deputy director of the Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada, a research organization that is part of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and is working with the American team, said from Moscow in a phone interview that the program ''has the full-scale support of the Soviet Government.'' The supporters include Deputy Prime Minister Leonid I. Abalkin, chief economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and officials of the Commission on Economic Reform, a state agency.
 
Idea 'a Breakthrough'
''The budget is really tight, and the prospect of raising funds through the state for many necessary projects is not very good,'' Mr. Plekhanov said. ''But there are huge amounts of funds that are just lying out there not being used, and the idea of using new financing mechanisms to channel them to public health looks like a breakthrough.''
Soviet officials are tentatively planning to apply the new financing techniques to construction of a 300-bed AIDS hospital in Moscow, one that would not be state-owned. Soviet supporters of the American team expect this project to be popular enough to make the public and Government officials accept the novel financing techniques more quickly. Other projects envisioned are buildings for six regional financial exchanges and a factory that would produce an as yet unidentified product now being imported.
 
Small-Scale Application
''What we are doing is coming up with ideas that might be applied now on a very small scale, but which might serve as a template for many larger projects in the future,'' said Jeffrey A. Sachs, a New York financial consultant who made connections with Soviet officials and assembled the American financial team.
The financing plans come at a time when the Soviet Government is experimenting with many economic changes to strengthen private enterprise and loosen the reins of state control over the economy.
While bond sales require governments to pay interest, they have the advantage of spreading the cost of major projects over many years, so that small governments can afford large projects and still have money for other essential purposes. Stretching out repayments also allows governments to pass the cost on to citizens who use the project over many years.
 
Absorbing 'Ruble Overhang'
Another objective of the financial proposals is to absorb some of the ''ruble overhang,'' the vast store of money that Soviet citizens and enterprises have accumulated but have no place to spend or invest. Economists worry that the supply of rubles, combined with the pent-up demand for consumer goods, could lead to extemely high inflation if price controls were loosened.
''The investment alternatives now in the Soviet Union are extremely limited,'' said Eric Stubbs, a professor at the Harriman School of Management and Policy at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I. Mr. Stubbs, a member of the American team that will travel to Moscow in April, said Soviet officials were eager for financial innovations that might absorb some of the 600 billion of rubles held in low-interest savings accounts or in savings outside the banking system.
 
Supported by Officials
The idea of using new financing techniques to develop local projects has the support of Andrei V. Orlov, deputy chairman of the Commission on Economic Reform, and Georgi A. Arbatov, a member of the Soviet Parliament and director of the Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada. ''Many of our economists are looking at ways to apply bond financing to various capital needs in both public-purpose and private-sector projects,'' Mr. Arbatov said in a letter to Mr. Sachs last year.
The two officials signed an agreement authorizing Mr. Sachs to proceed with development of various financing proposals. In that letter, the Soviet officials agreed that ''the development of a system of public finance in the Soviet Union is a critical component of economic reform.''
The officials promised to arrange the cooperation of various agencies in the Soviet Government whose policies and laws must be changed to proceed with demonstration projects.
 
Local Decision-Making
Besides the economic benefits of the various projects, participants in the program expect it will help Soviet officials develop the habit of economic decision-making at the local level rather than by planners in the national Government.
While the cooperation of central planners is essential, the new financing arrangements mean they would lose some of their control over the nation's economic activity. For example, an enterprise that invests in bonds would receive interest in rubles that could be used to buy equipment needed for expansion - without obtaining prior approval for expansion from Government central planners.
''I am sure we will have to overcome the resistance of various bureaucracies, but the opportunities are good and the financing mechanisms are important,'' Mr. Plekhanov said.
 
Two New Strategies
Mr. Arbatov said that the inability of Soviet citizens and enterprises to freely exchange their rubles for Western currencies or goods within the Soviet Union was a major difficulty facing any financier trying to raise large sums by borrowing. To attract buyers for the bonds needed to finance local projects, Mr. Sachs and his associates have so far developed two strategies new to the Soviet Union.
One idea is to issue bonds that pay interest in certificates convertible into Western currencies. Because Western currencies are needed to pay for many high-technology imports, the bonds might appeal to Soviet enterprises that have excess rubles but do not have Government authority to spend on Western goods.
To encourage Government officials to part with some of the scarce Western currency needed for interest payments, the bonds might be used to pay for a factory producing something that is currently imported and that must be paid for with hard currency. For example, bonds might be used to pay for a factory making high-quality scissors, eliminating or reducing the need to spend Deutsche marks on scissors imported from West Germany.
 
Some Type of Savings Bond
A second proposal is some type of Soviet savings bond, or allocation bond, with proceeds of the sale earmarked for particular local projects. These bonds could pay interest in what the American financiers call ''allocated'' rubles. The allocated rubles would be given priority when presented to Government agencies that control the sale of scarce materials and equipment.
''There are many Soviet enterprises that have accumulated large amounts of rubles which are all but useless because they do not have Government allocations to buy needed supplies,'' Mr. Sachs said. By investing their rubles in the new allocation bonds, those enterprises could put their rubles to work and gain access to materials they seek.
J. Chester Johnson, a member of Mr. Sachs's team and president of Government Finance Associates, a Princeton, N.J., financial adviser to local governments, said the American team did not want to encourage unwise use of bond financing. ''We want to make sure that everybody understands that bonds are good for capital projects, but not as a means to pay for day-to-day operations,'' he added.
Mr. Sachs made his first connections in the Soviet Government last summer, at a rock and roll concert that attracted 100,000 fans to Lenin Stadium in Moscow. Acting as liaison between the concert promoters and the Soviet Government, the 37-year-old Mr. Sachs met Stas Namin, a well-known Russian rock performer and impresario and also the well-connected grandson of Anastas I. Mikoyan, for decades a top Soviet official and diplomat.
 
Housing Experience Cited
Exploiting his new-found connections, Mr. Sachs talked with Mr. Arbatov about his experiences in New York as a co-founder with Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, of HELP, a nonprofit organization that develops housing for the homeless, and as a developer of community residences for mental patients once confined in hospitals.
After a second trip to the Soviet Union in November, he returned to the United States with a written agreement authorizing him to assemble a team to propose and help evaluate financing proposals that Soviet officials might put into effect. For now, Mr. Sachs said, the team was working without pay.
''The big banks and investment houses have spent millions of dollars trying to develop business in the Soviet Union, but they have to realize that the economy is run by a Government bureaucracy, not other businessmen doing deals American-style,'' Mr. Sachs said. ''The people I have brought together all have a background in public finance, so when it comes to talking and negotiating with government officials they are like fish in water.''

HEADLINE: Oil Industry Is Criticized on Safety

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Some environmental and safety officials say the recent rash of oil spills and accidents at petrochemical plants may be traceable to financial pressures on the petroleum industry in the 1980's that led companies to reduce skilled technicians and put an emphasis on cost cutting rather than flawless performance.
The industry vigorously denies that it cut corners as well as costs.
''First and foremost, the industry's abiding concern is the safety of its workers,'' the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's principal trade group, said. ''Secondly, there is an obvious economic incentive for avoiding accidents and thereby preventing worker injury, and loss of equipment and product.'' 
Lee Raymond, the president of the Exxon Corporation, said, for instance, that the issue of whether cost reductions hurt the company's ability to operate its plants safely is a legitimate question; his conclusion, not surprisingly, is that they did not.
 
'Soul Searching'
''We have done a lot of soul searching about this and we do not think so,'' he said in an interview.
But the Occupational Health and Safety Administration, a Federal agency, is conducting a special investigation of recent petrochemical plant explosions, and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union made safety an issue in recent contract talks.
The 1980's were a difficult decade for the industry. Some companies were taken over, others were threatened by raiders, and as prices fell all companies came under pressure to improve profits by cutting costs. The American Petroleum Institute says the number of refinery workers in this country declined to 122,000 in 1988 from 162,000 in 1980.
Last year, the industry has been rocked by a series of highly publicized accidents, including the 11-million-gallon oil spill in Alaska by the Exxon Valdez, an explosion at Phillips Petroleum Company's petrochemical plant in Pasadena, Tex., that killed 23 people and left 125 injured and the leak of more than 500,000 gallons of home heating oil into the Arthur Kill waterway between New Jersey and Staten Island. Two more people were killed in a blast at an Exxon chemical plant in Louisiana on Dec. 24.
 
No Industry Statistics
The industry says it does not keep statistics on accidents and injuries at its refining and chemical processing operations. But the Occupational Health and Safety Administration reacted to the Phillips blast by ordering a special study of petrochemical plants, with particular emphasis on the role of contract workers. ''We want to take a good close look to find out what caused these accidents,'' said Stanley Elliott, deputy director for field operations at the Federal agency.
Joseph Kinney, director of the National Safe Work Place Institute, an advocacy group, asserted recently: ''There is a clear relationship between the incidents of explosions and the downsizing of the petrochemical industry. Some of the so-called corporate fat that was cut was maintenance engineers and industrial hygienists.''
A spokesman for Phillips said the company had 13 full-time safety specialists at the Pasadena complex at the time of the explosion, compared with five in 1984. But he said the company did not know how many were involved in maintenance compared with previous years, because much of that work was now performed by outside contractors.
 
Contract Workers
The issue of contract workers is a volatile one to the refinery workers' union, whose membership declined 20 percent in 10 years as the companies replaced full-time workers with those hired by contractors. The companies save money this way by avoiding union rates.
Union officials asssert that plant managers, under pressure to improve financial performance, have also pushed experienced managers into early retirement and entrusted key maintenance jobs to contractors.
''The 80's saw profit centers shift downward,'' said Richard Leonard, director of special projects for the union. ''First-line supervisors were put on cost accounting and they are all trying to look good by saving money. So you have people with no appreciation of risk taking great risks to save money.''
Mr. Leonard said early retirement programs offered by many companies to reduce their white-collar work forces had reduced the technical expertise needed to run highly complex refineries and chemical plants. ''They stripped out a lot of seasoned managers,'' he said.
 
Union's Point of View
The union asserts that more than 60 workers have been killed and more than 200 seriously injured in petrochemical plant explosions in the last five years. The union says there were just 18 fatalities in the previous five years.
In contract negotiations earlier this year, the union pressed for the appointment of special environmental monitors in plants, whose job it would be to try to spot unauthorized emissions or potentially unsafe practices. But it dropped the issue in return for higher pay and benefits. Union officials say they will continue to raise environmental and safey issues in informational campaigns.
Environmental advocates and industry watchers say they see some of the same factors behind the oil spills.
''The spill clearly relates to cost cutting,'' John Adams, director of the Natural Resources Defense Council said, speaking of the Arthur Kill incident. ''Remember, they cut the crews on the ships before the Alaska accident. With 15 million people living around New York harbor, they should have put in redundant systems so they would not worry about shutting a pipeline for a few hours or days.''
 
Exxon's Budget Problem
Meeting with New Jersey state officials shortly after the spill in early January, Exxon executives said a budget problem had prevented them from replacing a balky warning system that had been sending false signals for years. Plant operators accustomed to ignoring the signal made the spill worse by continuing to pump oil after the alarm sounded.
''During the 1980's both the oil industry and government agencies reduced funding and personnel for oil spill response,'' said Richard Golob, publisher of Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin in Cambridge, Mass. ''Exxon alone lost 10 senior environmental people, so when the Valdez grounding occurred, they did not have the expertise they had in the 1970's.''
Mr. Raymond, Exxon's president, said that eliminating layers of management had speeded communications, permitting faster responses to troubles as they arise. Still, one of the company's responses to the Arthur Kill spill and a chemical plant explosion in Louisiana on Dec. 24 was to add a layer of management. Exxon has appointed a corporate vice president for safety and environment, reversing the policy of managing these matters within operating divisions.

HEADLINE: Interest Rate Drop Is Seen

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Interest rates have peaked and should start falling this spring, a group of private economists predicted today.
Members of the Shadow Open Market Committee said they believed a variety of consumer and business loans would decline in coming months, reflecting a sluggish economy and declining inflationary pressures. 
The economists forecast that banks' prime lending rate, the benchmark for many business and consumer loans, should drop from 10 percent to 9 1/2 percent or perhaps as low as 9 percent by summer.
Fixed-rate mortgages, which are about 10.25 percent, will fall to 9.8 percent by midyear and remain below 10 percent for the rest of 1990, the outlook predicted.
Jerry Jordan, a senior economist at First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, who compiled the group's forecast, said that weakness in the economy would encourage the Federal Reserve to loosen its grip on credit in coming months.
The panel forecast that the Federal funds rate, an indication of the Fed's intentions about interest rates, would dip from 8.25 percent down to 7.5 percent by midyear.
The shadow committee meets twice a year to assess actions of the Federal Reserve whose chief policy-setting body, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet next week.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Moody's Reduces Ratings On Massachusetts Debts

 BODY:
The rating on $9.09 billion in Massachusetts general obligation debt and debt issued by state agencies with backing by the state, was lowered to Baa, from Baa-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.
The lower rating is still considered investment grade, but any drop in grade means that the state may have to pay higher interest rates on the money it borrows in the bond market. 
Moody's said the rating change was the result of the failure of Massachusetts to resolve its growing fiscal problems. The rating agency said that the state, whose debt is now the lowest rated, had the ability to service the debt but lacked the willingness. The rating change more than anything reflects the state's lack of action in meeting and containing an annual deficit that is expected to increase to $700 million by the end of the current fiscal year on June 30, Moody's said.
The rating agency reduced the state's general-obligation debt in November 1989, to Baa-1 from A, indicating that Moody's was concerned about the state's fiscal problems. Continued inaction, Moody's said, has reduced confidence that responsible action will be taken to control the situation.
Among the agencies whose debt was downgraded yesterday were the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, various university building authorities, various regional transit authorities, the Convention Center Authority, the Government Loan Bank and various local housing authorities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Elections in East Germany Lift Mark Against Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance against other major currencies yesterday in trading dominated by the West German mark.
Currency dealers said the support for conservative parties in Sunday's general election in East Germany spurred the buying of West German marks and drove down the dollar. As trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6860 marks, down from 1.6980 marks Friday. 
The new East German Government, backed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, was considered likely to take quick steps toward monetary union, free-market reforms and unification of Germany.
 
Gains Against Yen
The dollar gained against the Japanese yen, however, as dealers grew impatient waiting for Tokyo to raise the country's key interest rates. A Japanese news report that increases could be enacted today, which came late in yesterday's United States trading session, failed to have much impact.
Confidence in the yen was also shaken by the stock selloff in Tokyo, which reduced the value of the Nikkei stock average by 4.1 percent.
One dollar bought 153.05 yen late in New York, more than the 152.65 yen late on Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.55 yen, up from 152.50. In London late yesterday, the dollar also closed at 153.55 yen.
The British pound declined on the eve of today's national budget speech by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, who is not expected to present measures that can revive Britain's economy. Dealers reported the Bank of England sold dollars and bought pounds to defend the pound's value.
A pound bought $1.6135 late in New York, weaker than the $1.6190 on Friday. Earlier in London, a pound cost $1.6110, compared with Friday's $1.6235.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Friday, included: 1.5085 Swiss francs, down from 1.5095; 5.7025 French francs, down from 5.7360; 1,246.75 Italian lire, down from 1,253.00, and 1.18225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18285.
 
Gold Up Slightly
In the precious metals market, gold prices posted minor gains in domestic and overseas dealings. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $400.70 an ounce, $1.10 higher than Friday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $400.80 for an ounce of gold late yesterday, 80 cents more than Friday's late bid.
In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.101 an ounce, up from Friday's $5.093.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Soybean Prices Up Sharply On Developments in Brazil

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 19

 BODY:
Prices of soybean futures rose sharply today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk of lower-than-expected Brazilian soybean yields and diminishing fears that Brazil's economic reforms will lead to a flood of soybean marketings.
On other commodity markets, coffee, sugar and cocoa futures fell sharply, and petroleum futures were mixed.
Soybean futures settled 6 cents to 8 1/4 cents higher, with March at $5.90 a bushel. Wheat, corn and oats futures were also higher. 
The soybean market opened lower on expectations that sweeping economic reforms announced last week in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, would stimulate the country's farmers to sell soybeans.
 
Currency Devaluation Feared
Of greatest concern was a plan to replace Brazil's currency, the cruzado novo, with a new currency, the cruzeiro, which would feature free-floating foreign exchange rates. Many experts believe the cruzeiro will be sharply devalued, which would prompt farmers to sell soybeans to obtain dollars or other hard currency.
But analysts saw no significant increase in Brazilian sales over the weekend or yesterday, said Steve Freed, a grain market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Meanwhile, analysts said Memphis-based Sparks Commodities Inc. released an estimate of the Brazilian soybean crop that put production at 19.5 million metric tons instead of the 20.5 million projected last month by the Agriculture Department.
Sparks would not confirm the number, but analysts said indications of lower-than-expected Brazilian soybean yields - the harvest began about two weeks ago - had prompted much speculation that the crop would be smaller than the Agriculture Department's estimate.
Selling associated with the Brazilian economic reforms dominated the coffee, cocoa and sugar markets. Brazil is a major producer of all three commodities.
On New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, coffee futures finished 1.5 cents to 2.67 cents lower, with March at 87 cents a pound; sugar settled 0.02 cent to 0.26 cent lower, with May at 15.87 cents a pound; cocoa futures settled $20 to $36 lower, with March at $1,095 a ton.
Near-month crude-oil futures edged lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns about high OPEC production. Gasoline futures also fell while heating oil firmed on indications of tight near-term availability.
