HEADLINE: O'Neill Decides He Won't Run For a Third Term in Connecticut

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 20

 BODY:
Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would not seek a third full term in office, citing the ''political realities'' facing him and saying he had no taste for the negative campaign tactics he believed necessary to win re-election.
Mr. O'Neill, a Democrat who governed the nation's most affluent state throughout the 1980's, suffered a sharp drop in popularity last year after pushing nearly $1 billion in tax increases through the General Assembly to counter a decline in revenue caused by the economic slowdown in the Northeast.
His decision not to seek re-election comes as other Northeastern governors and mayors are grappling with similar budget problems. In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio, at the start of a four-year term, has proposed $1.4 billion in tax increases and sharp cutbacks in spending. In New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins has proposed additional taxes to close a widening budget gap in the next fiscal year. 
 
A Daunting Issue
For officials facing re-election this year, the issue of raising taxes has been especially daunting. In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo only this week began discussing possible tax moves, including a rise in the gasoline tax. In fiscally troubled Massachusetts, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis announced last year that he would not run again.
In Connecticut, politicians say the tax issue was only one factor for Mr. O'Neill.
''I also think people just got tired of him,'' the state Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley, said today.
Mr. O'Neill, had maintained for months that he would run. His withdrawal leaves Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden as the only Democrat with an organized campaign, further muddling a race already complicated by the entry of former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a liberal Republican, as an independent candidate. The leading Republican contender is Representative John G. Rowland, a conservative from Waterbury.
At a news conference at the Governor's mansion, Mr. O'Neill said, ''I have decided that I can best serve the people of Connecticut, who twice have elected me their Governor, by completing this term of office unfettered and unimpaired by the demands of a campaign for re-election.''
Mr. O'Neill a 59-year-old former bar owner from rural East Hampton, has spent the last year battling the economic slowdown that has struck New England, New York and New Jersey.
 
Increase in Sales Tax
Last year he acted much sooner than many other governors by imposing the largest tax increase in Connecticut's history, including raising the sales tax to 8 percent, the nation's highest. The state does not have an income tax.
This February he proposed a budget that eliminated 2,000 workers and cut $600 million in spending and he warned that more cuts were possible if the state's revenues did not improve. But his proposed budget does not call for further tax increases, and it is balanced by taking hundreds of millions in dollars from special reserve accounts.
He also showed that he had some political fight left in him when he vetoed fare increases in Connecticut for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad over the objections of the railroad's governing body in New York.
''I firmly believe I could win this re-election,'' Mr. O'Neill said.
 
Open-Heart Surgery
Shortly after taking office, Mr. O'Neill had open-heart surgery. He also had polyps, one cancerous, removed from his colon several times during the last three years.
His announcement today came just hours before his party began the selection of convention delegates at the local level. Many delegates now are expected to remain uncommitted until the delegate primaries on May 15.
Besides Mr. Morrison, State Representative William J. Cibes Jr. of New London announced his candidacy at the State Capitol today, two hours after Mr. O'Neill's speech.
Other possible candidates include the Senate President pro tempore, John B. Larson of East Hartford, and Mayor Christopher Droney of West Hartford, who is the brother of the state Democratic Party chairman, John F. Droney Jr. The Democrat long considered Mr. O'Neill's heir apparent, Representative Barbara Kennelly of Hartford, who has said she would not be a candidate, repeated that position today.
Like most politicians in both major political parties, Mr. Morrison, a liberal who has been urging Mr. O'Neill not to run for re-election for several months, was gracious upon hearing Mr. O'Neill's announcement. ''I want to thank Mr. O'Neill for making the decision he has at the beginning of the delegate selection process,'' he said.
He also stepped up criticism of Mr. Weicker, painting him as a Republican running as an independent. Besides Mr. Rowland, other Republican candidates include the Senate minority leader, Reginald J. Smith of New Hartford; Joel Schiavone of New Haven, and Joseph McGee, a Fairfield banker.
The co-chairman of the Weicker independent candidacy, Thomas D'Amore Jr., a former state Republican chairman, said Mr. O'Neill's decision had little direct impact on Mr. Weicker's bid. ''We wish him well,'' he said. ''He was always a good man.''
As for the effect on the Democratic Party, the state's dominant party for the last 20 years, Mr. D'Amore said: ''It certainly makes things very dynamic and fluid. I don't know what's going to happen on the other side.''
Mr. O'Neill took office on Dec. 31, 1980, after Gov. Ella T. Grasso resigned in failing health. ''We walked in with humility and pride, and we walk out with humility and pride,'' said Governor O'Neill, flanked at the news conference by his wife, Nikki.
During his current term, he often responded to questions about a 1990 re-election race by saying he would run barring serious health problems. At his news conference, he said no such problems existed. ''The modern process of campaigning is a rigorous one,'' he said. ''It exacts a toll on the body and the spirit which, at this point in my career, I do not choose to pay.''
''It would be a very, very difficult campaign,'' he added later. ''I think it would have to be a negative campaign, and I'm not sure that at this point in my life I wanted to start competing in that type of operation.''

HEADLINE: VENEZUELA AGREES TO DEBT PROPOSAL

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Giving a lift to the Bush Administration's debt policy, Venezuela and its bankers announced agreement yesterday on the basic terms of a plan for debt reduction and new loans.
The proposal, which covers about $20 billion in outstanding loans, offers banks that have loans to Venezuela a variety of plans to chose from. One option would reduce a loan by 30 percent and offer guarantees on principal and interest payments. This is just under the 35 percent level set in last year's deal with Mexico, the first agreement reached under the Brady plan, named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. 
Another option provides for the Venezuelan Government to buy back existing loans at a deeper discount, expected to be 60 percent to 65 percent, to allow banks to choose to remove Venezuelan loans from their books if they are willing to take the loss.
 
Less Administration Pressure
The goal of the Administration's debt strategy, announced a year ago, is to resolve the third world's $1.3 trillion debt problem with an emphasis on reducing existing debt rather than just making new loans. The Administration put pressure on banks to reach an agreement with Mexico but had a less central role in the Venezuela talks.
Miguel Rodriguez, Venezuela's Minister of Planning, said at a news conference in New York that the agreement was a ''crucial aspect'' of the economic plan President Carlos Andres Perez announced last year to fight inflation and open the economy to international trade and investment.
That program, including an increase in gasoline prices, set off riots in February 1989 in which more than 300 were killed. In response, Mr. Brady named Venezuela as a top candidate for the new debt strategy, although many bankers contended that Venezuela had created many of its own economic problems and had the resources, in oil and elsewhere, to recover economically without a substantial reduction of its debt.
The proposal for Venezuela's debt is the fourth initial agreement completed under the Brady plan, and it includes several new twists that show how each deal has been tailored to the country's problems and the bankers' desires. Final details of a deal for Philippines are thought to be nearly complete, and a deal is expected to be completed for Costa Rica, although talks have been delayed.
The Treasury officially welcomed the announcement. ''I think it's significant that in no more than nine months we've had four major deals,'' said Treasury Under Secretary David Mulford.
 
A New Idea
One new idea in the Venezuelan proposal is an option for temporary - but very large - interest-rate reductions on existing debt. For two years, interest rates can be cut to 5 percent, almost half current levels. They would then rise gradually, reflecting the contention of many bankers that Venezuela faces a much less severe long-term economic crisis than Mexico does.
Another proposal, also reflecting this theme, will give banks that accept the 30 percent permanent debt reduction option the ability to get additional payments from the Venezuelan Government after six years if oil prices rise beyond a set level, expected to be near $26 a barrel.
Venezuela also hopes to attract a substantial block of new loans from its bankers, something Mexico was unable to do in its deal.
Unlike the Mexican deal, the bankers have more options to choose from and are not basically being forcing to pick debt reduction or new loans.
M. Peter McPherson, executive vice president at the Bank of America, a member of the Bank Advisory Committee and a former Treasury Department official, said in an interview that the Venezuelan deal showed that ''the Brady plan clearly has got life in it.''
 
Moving Too Slowly
Critics of the Brady plan, announced in March 1989, have argued that it has not moved fast enough. Others have argued that the debt reduction, in the case of Mexico, was not enough.
A final deal with Venezuela will take the fourth-largest debtor in the world off the negotiating list, with Mexico, the second largest, already gone. Brazil, the largest, remains, but there is hope now that the country's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, will make the economic reforms needed to open the way to debt talks. But the situation in Argentina, where there was similar hope last year with the election of Carlos Saul Menem, has deteriorated.
''We are confident that with the implementation of the plan, our economy will begin to show the substantial benefits of our adjustment efforts,'' Mr. Rodriguez said.
Venezuelan officials and the 16-bank advisory committee, headed by Chase Manhattan Bank, will now work on the final details of the plan to be sent to its more than 300 creditor banks around the world. This process is expected to take several months.
The impact on Venezuela will not be clear until the banks choose among the options.
 
Two Main Options
There are two main debt-reduction options. One is for a 30 percent reduction, combined with guarantees on principal and interest that will be paid for by Venezuela, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and several countries, including Japan and Spain. The amount of these guarantees was not announced, and it could be a difficult issue.
Under this option, the banks can choose to reduce the face value of their existing loans and be paid interest at the rate of the London Interbank rate plus 13/16 of a percentage point. The London Interbank rate is now 8.75 percent.
Banks can also keep the face value of their loans, but accept a cut in the current interest rate to a fixed level of 6.75 percent.
In both cases, the banks would get special security that would guarantee the additional payments from the Venezuelan Government if Venezuela's crude oil price passes a set rate, adjusted for inflation, after six years. The additional payments would be made each six months for 24 years, the remaining life in the 30-year bonds, when the oil price is over the threshold. These certificates can be traded separately from the debt reduction bonds, which a banker said adds to their attractiveness.
 
At a Deep Discount
The other debt reduction option is a debt buyback under which the Venezuelan Government would offer to buy back existing loans based on a discount set by the Government, expected to be around 60 to 65 percent.
Under the temporary debt reduction proposal, the banks would accept an interest rate cut to 5 percent in the first two years, 6 percent in the third and fourth years, and 7 percent in the fifth year. For the remaining 12 years of the bond, the interest would be the London Interbank rate plus 7/8ths of a percentage point.
For the five years of the lower interest rates, Venezuela will provide a fund that will guarantee the interest.
As part of the deal, Venezuela also agreed to pay all of its back interest on existing loans by the end of March. The country announced yesterday a $400 million loan from the Bank for International Settlements to help make this interest payment.

HEADLINE: South Africa Seen as Ready to Sign Nuclear Pact

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 17-

 BODY:
After talks here in 1988 and last year, officials of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union say they believe that South Africa is poised to sign the 1970 treaty limiting the spread of nuclear weapons.
At the last talks in December, officials said, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa left the representatives of the three Governments with the clear impression that his Government would agree to adhere to the treaty at another meeting in Vienna this spring.
South Africa is one of a small group of countries that have refused to give up the option of acquiring nuclear weapons by signing the treaty. Some of the nations may already have such weapons or be able to produce them. In August 1988, Mr. Botha said South Africa has the ability to produce a nuclear bomb ''should we want to.'' Asked if South Africa already had nuclear weapons, he said he would not elaborate on his statement. 
There was no immediate comment from South Africa.
A total of 137 countries now adhere to the treaty. Those that do not include Israel, Pakistan and India. In 1987, South Africa said it was considering signing the treaty, a move that helped Western countries block an African drive to expel it from the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Vienna-based organization that inspects plants of countries that have signed the treaty to insure that they are used only for peaceful purposes.
South Africa then asked for discussions about signing the treaty with the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union, the three countries that can, under the accord, keep nuclear weapons in return for a pledge to work for disarmament and a ban on testing.
The development that appears to have swung South Africa around in favor of signing the treaty, officials say, was an assurance from the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union that for procedural reasons the International Atomic Energy Agency would not be in a position to start inspecting South Africa's plants for about two years after it signed.
Britain also assured South Africa that if it signed the treaty, European countries were likely to lift their ban on nuclear cooperation with South Africa.
Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader who was freed from prison last month, has been urging the West to maintain economic sanctions until South Africa's white-dominated Government carries out its promise to abolish apartheid.
During the discussions, officials say, South Africa sought assurances that if it signed the treaty it would gain access to Western technology, be able to take part fully in the scientific work of the atomic energy agency and benefit from the help it gives its members.
Although the agency's African members have been trying to expel South Africa from the agency since 1987, their drive has been successfully blocked so far by the United States, the Soviet Union and their allies, who want as large a membership as possible.
The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union told South Africa that the three would not agree to any further talks on any topic related to the treaty because it cannot be changed in any way to accommodate new members.
They said they would meet with South Africa again only to accept its adherence to the agreement.
The international agency now inspects South Africa's two nuclear power reactors at Koeberg near Cape Town at the insistence of France, which supplied them. It also inspects the small Safari research reactor.
But the South African authorities never allowed any outside inspection of their pilot uranium enrichment plant, which could be used for military ends. South Africa may also have other nuclear plants as well.
Diplomats say they have evidence that South Africa has never tried seriously to develop nuclear arms.
Agency officials say South Africa sees itself as a growing industrial power in Africa and has expressed interest in expanding its nuclear generating capacity to cope with demand.
Although South Africa has much coal, there is concern about reliance on coal-fired generating capacity alone.

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS TO ASK FOREIGN AID SHIFT

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
In their first formal challenge to the Administration's foreign-aid priorities, Senate Democrats plan to propose that more than half of the $800 million in emergency aid that President Bush has requested for Panama and Nicaragua be redirected to assist the new democracies in Eastern Europe.
The Administration had sought $500 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua as part of a supplemental foreign-aid bill for fiscal 1990. But Congressional officials said the Democratic plan, which will be offered later this week, would allocate only $300 million for the two Central American nations and earmark the remaining $500 million for an Eastern European ''emerging democracies fund.''
The fund's money would not be designated for any particular Eastern European country but would be available to finance various economic development and technical assistance projects as needs arise. 
 
Help for Israel in Limbo
President Bush did not request any supplemental spending for Eastern Europe in 1990, though his 1991 budget seeks $300 million. The supplemental spending bill includes items to be added to the budget for the current fiscal year, 1990.
As part of the 1990 supplemental package, lawmakers had hoped to include $400 million in loan guarantees to help the Israeli Government resettle Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union.
But after Administration testimony today, it appeared that the loan guarantee legislation would remain in limbo as Congress awaits clarification of the Administration's position on new settlements in the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Questioned on that point at a Senate subcommittee hearing today, the Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, told Senators that the loan-guarantee legislation ''would have our support on the assumption that we can obtain adequate assurances from the Government of Israel on the use of these funds.''
Lawmakers said that Mr. Eagleburger's comment left them in the dark as to the Administration's position on the issue in the wake of statements several weeks ago by President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Mr. Baker appeared to suggest that all aid to Israel be contingent on a pledge that no new settlements be opened in the occupied territories.
While the longstanding United States position has been that American assistance to Israel cannot be used in the occupied areas, Washington has not previously tried to tie the aid to the broader issue of new settlements.
 
Silence on 'Assurances'
President Bush then added to the confusion by saying the United States did not believe ''there should be new settlements in the West Bank or East Jerusalem.'' After a series of moves over plans for Middle East peace, including some related to the inclusion of negotiators with links to East Jerusalem, Israel's coalition government collapsed.
Under questioning today by members of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Mr. Eagleburger declined to specify what ''assurances'' the United States was seeking from Israel, and Senators on the panel said they would need to know more before the loan guarantee legislation could move forward.
But the primary focus of Mr. Eagleburger's appearance on Capitol Hill today was Central America, not Israel. Although there is broad, support from both Republicans and Democrats in Congress for assistance to Panama and Nicaragua, Mr. Bush's proposal has run into stiff opposition from Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, and Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the full Appropriations Committee, Mr. Leahy and Mr. Byrd have been working for several weeks on the plan to change the distribution of the aid to Eastern Europe and Central America, and at a White House meeting with the President this morning, Senate Republicans as well as Democrats warned Mr. Bush that his aid request was in trouble. ''There is a lot of confusion, that was evident from the meeting,'' said Senator Bob Kasten of Wisconsin, the senior Republican on the foreign operations panel.
 
Military Cuts Opposed
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said Senators in both parties told the President that they object to the Administration's plans to pay for the additional aid for Panama and Nicaragua by taking money out of the military budget. One Republican Senator, who asked not to be identified, told the President that some of the Pentagon deletions the Administration has suggested amount to line-item vetoes of provisions in the 1990 military budget.
But the hearing in Mr. Leahy's subcommittee, which followed the White House meeting, offered a preview of the larger foreign-aid battle to come. Mr. Leahy told Mr. Eagleburger that the $800 million the Administration has requested for Panama and Nicaragua is ''simply too much money'' for ''two countries of slight economic, security and foreign policy importance to U.S. national interests.''
Mr. Leahy raised particular objections to the part of the Administration aid package intended to help Panama repay its overdue loans to the World Bank and other international development banks, calling it ''a crazy scheme.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Neutral-Germany Stand By Soviets Is Softening

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Soviet foreign policy experts have indicated that Moscow might eventually compromise on its demand that a united Germany be a neutral nation outside NATO.
Noting the new signals, Bush Administration officials said today that the Soviets would revise their position if their security concerns could be satisfied through other means, perhaps including limits on the number and location of German and foreign troops in a united Germany.
In an interview on West German television March 8, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev flatly rejected the idea that a united Germany could be a member of NATO. ''We will not agree to that,'' he said. ''This is absolutely ruled out.'' 
On Monday, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, reaffirmed that a united Germany ''should not be a member of NATO.''
But Nikolai S. Portugalov, the adviser on German affairs to the Communist Party Central Committee, hedged his position. He said on Monday that NATO membership for a united Germany is unacceptable right now, but added that this is only Moscow's ''starting position in the negotiations'' on German unification.
Vyacheslav I. Dashichev, who works at the main Soviet research institute dealing with Eastern Europe, went one step further in an interview in today's issue of the West German newspaper Die Welt.
''You have to bind a united Germany into the framework of NATO,'' said Mr. Dashichev, an official at the Institute of the Economics of the World Socialist System, in Moscow. ''There is the image of a cannon not being fixed to the deck of a ship, and some people compare a neutral Germany to such a cannon.''
American experts on Soviet-German relations predicted that Moscow would accept NATO membership for a united Germany as long as it is a temporary status, pending creation of new security arrangements for Europe.
Arnold L. Horelick, an expert on Soviet foreign policy at the Rand Corporation research center, said:
''The Soviets will press for a neutral Germany, but they are realists. They understand that the alternative to agreeing to some form of German membership in NATO would be to restore a confrontational environment in Europe, which would set them at odds with the West and a united Germany. At the moment, their ability to pursue such a confrontation is weaker than ever. In the end, they will probably be obliged to accept some form of German membership in NATO.''
Mr. Horelick, who served as the chief Soviet analyst at the Central Intelligence Agency from 1977 through 1980, said the Soviets would use their insistence on German neutrality as a device to win concessions that ''encumber and attenuate German membership in NATO.''
For example, he said, the Soviets might seek assurances limiting the size of the armed forces of a united Germany, restricting the deployment of NATO troops in Germany and prohibiting nuclear weapons on German soil.
The Soviet Union wants to see Germany locked into a new security arrangement under the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
American officials say they would welcome a larger role for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in protecting human rights, promoting democracy and encouraging free-market economic policies in Eastern Europe. But they do not see it as the foundation of a new security regime.

HEADLINE: Fayston Journal;
Inviting Vermont To Learn How to Ski

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FAYSTON, Vt.

 BODY:
Her legs still wobbling from her maiden voyage down the Easy Street trail, Debra Maloney-Evans finds she is actually enjoying herself. For Mrs. Maloney-Evans, this slushy Sunday at Sugarbush's Mount Ellen Ski Area is her first outing on Alpine skis in nearly 20 years, and she admits to having had her doubts.
''I've never been this close to the mountain to know whether or not I could ski it,'' said the 36-year-old nurse, who grew up one mountain range away in Northfield. ''From a distance, the mountain looks so intimidating. I wondered what people would be wearing. Growing up, you had the sense it was kind of snobbish.'' 
She, her husband, Peter Evans, and their three children were on skis courtesy of a program called Let's Get Vermont Skiing, run by the Vermont Ski Areas Association. The association's 17 members all offer free beginner lessons, lift tickets and rental equipment to Vermonters on most Sunday afternoons.
Contrary to the common perception outside New England that skiing is second nature to Vermonters, many of them don't ski. State residents represent about 20 percent of the skier-day volume in the state, said Tom Meyers, the association's spokesman, The purpose of the free skiing program is ''to expand the market,'' he explained, adding that since it began six years ago, about 15,000 Vermonters have taken advantage of it.
''It's also to give local people an opportunity they might not otherwise have,'' he said. ''There's a sense that skiing has become very expensive, and in some cases it has.''
But many say the price of a lift ticket - more than $35 for a one-day ticket on the weekend at many areas - is not the reason many Vermonters don't ski. They point to economic and cultural tensions between ski areas and the local populations.
In 1965, the year David Munford stopped Alpine skiing, Vermont ranked 41st in the nation in terms of per capita income. At the same time, the ski industry was booming, with affluent weekend skiers flocking up the newly opened interstate highways from states like Connecticut (first in per capita income), New York (fourth) and Massachusetts (12th).
''When I was growing up in Middlebury, about half of my friends skied,'' said Mr. Munford, a graduate student in education who is a part-time lift operator at the Middlebury College Snow Bowl, a small ski area. ''The reason several of us quit permanently was that equipment was becoming a status issue. You were made to feel inferior if you didn't have the right equipment. It turned me off. I felt out of place in my own home.''
Mr. Munford says the tensions have been aggravated by the explosion of the number of second homes built here by out-of-staters, largely around the ski areas, and what he calls the ''neo-Colonialist attitude'' of resort owners toward the service workers, most of whom are local.
''There's a split between the haves and have-nots, and it's becoming more obvious,'' he said. ''The average income of skiers is being displayed in more and more high-tech equipment, and it creates resentment. Vermonters are expected to stay away from their vacation homes except to mow the lawns.''
Peter Evans, an elementary school principal, is typical of the Vermonters who sign up for the Let's Get Vermont Skiing program. By the end of the first hour, he had mastered the wedge, which was known as the snowplow when he used to ski back in grade school and junior high.
''They're supposed to be beginners, but we can tell that most of them have been on something that slides,'' said Chip Nicholas, assistant director of the Sugarbush Ski School. ''We find that they learn very fast.''
Mr. Evans has adopted more of a live-and-let-live attitude toward ski resorts than he used to have. ''It used to be that we just never came here,'' said Mr. Evans. ''We felt that it wasn't really Vermont, that it was something that had been sold out.''
But at the age of 37, with three school-age children, he has come to appreciate Alpine skiing as a family activity.
''I'm still concerned about the valley,'' he said, ''but what's being done here in terms of development is being done well. There was a time I wouldn't have come here because I didn't like what was going on. Now, I'm taking the attitude we should enjoy the resources we have.''

HEADLINE: What Multinationals Do Isn't Tax Cheating;
Weak Evidence

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I write to flesh out your Feb. 18 front-page article on tax cheating by United States subsidiaries of foreign corporations. You quote an unnamed Internal Revenue Service official as saying that ''suspected underpayments amount to at least $12 billion.'' The alleged cheating was ascribed to subsidiaries of foreign companies paying their parent corporations too much for goods and services. The main suspects are United States distributors of products made in Japan. 
The article was widely reported, is affecting events and has triggered at least one Congressional investigation. The allegations have also been taken up by protectionists who see the cheating as an unfair subsidy to foreign imports. I cannot evaluate the allegations, but some of the circumstantial evidence of cheating presented by the Internal Revenue Service is less compelling when it is explained.
I.R.S. statistics, you report, show that over a decade (presumably ending in about 1987), although foreign assets in the United States more than tripled and the United States gross income of foreign-owned companies more than doubled, the total taxes that these companies paid hardly changed.
I have three observations: (1) Foreign investment in recent years has been heavy in commercial real estate, which has been a disaster in many parts of the United States. Thus taxes in this area have not kept pace with assets. (2) Gross income for United States corporate tax purposes means sales (or other revenues) less cost of sales. Any manipulation of the purchase price of goods bought from a foreign parent would increase cost of sales and decrease gross income. Since gross income has more than doubled in the decade, that tax revenues are about the same cannot be attributed to pricing manipulation. (3) During the decade in question, the United States corporate tax rate was reduced more than 29 percent (from 48 percent to 34 percent). For corporations as a whole, the rate reduction was offset by other changes, most significantly reduced depreciation write-offs and elimination of the investment credit. But these offsets had little effect on importers, distributors and retailers because those taxpayers did not have large investments in plant and equipment. Everything else being equal, the reduced tax rates meant lower taxes.
Increased interest payments are probably the main reason tax collections remained flat while gross income doubled. But there is no allegation of cheating in this area. The I.R.S. has no trouble getting information from United States subsidiaries of foreign companies about interest expense. And it has plenty of power to adjust interest deductions where interest rates on loans from related parties are higher than the going rate. Prospectively, beginning in 1990, there are new interest stripping rules that substantially limit the interest United States subsidiaries can deduct on loans from related foreign companies.
 
RICHARD M. HAMMER
New York, March 2, 1990
 The writer is national director of international tax services for the Price Waterhouse accounting organization.

HEADLINE: Out of the Pits: Why P.S. 182 Can Read

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Public School 182 in the East Bronx learned yesterday that it had made a phenomenal comeback - the educational equivalent of moving from the league cellar into pennant contention.
One year ago the school, whose pupils are largely Hispanic and black from poor and lower middle-class homes, was near the bottom third of the New York City school system. It ranked 404th among 616 elementary schools in the citywide reading scores.
Only 36 percent of its children could read at or above a level considered appropriate for their grade. 
 
'Everything Clicked for Us'
Yesterday, when the latest rankings were published, the school finished among the top third of the schools, placing 169th on the list, with 60.4 percent of the children reading at or above grade level.
''Everything clicked for us last year,'' said the principal of P.S. 182, Jeanne LoCascio. ''But we've been working on this for a long time.''
She attributed the turnaround mainly to a daily after-school tutoring program.
More than 370,000 children in Grades 3 to 9 took the Degrees of Reading Power examination in May 1989. The results were released last fall, but yesterday the 618 elementary schools and 180 junior high schools were ranked by the proportions of children reading at or above grade level. Overall 47.4 percent of the city's students read at or above grade level, a measure derived from the average performance of national samplings of students at each grade.
As they do every year, schools in economically comfortable neighborhoods in northern Queens, Staten Island, Riverdale in the Bronx and the East Side of Manhattan topped the rankings. But many educators were impressed more by the progress of schools like P.S. 182.
P.S. 182's gain of 24.4 percentage points, the third largest of any city school, is no mystery to Mrs. LoCascio, who has been the principal for five years. Last year the school was able to get money to provide after-school tutoring for its poorest readers five days a week.
Four seasoned teachers, assisted by honor students from nearby Adlai Stevenson High School, worked with 60 children for two hours each day, teaching them how to break up an unfamiliar word into its component sounds and how the meaning of a word might depend on its context. They also had the children practice reading the kinds of paragraphs that appear on the citywide reading test.
 
Practice Avoids 'Freeze Up'
''They practiced the format of the test, so when they sat down, they weren't stunned by it,'' Mrs. LoCascio said. ''Some children who are really capable in reading freeze up during the test and don't really show us what they know.''
At P.S. 182, which is in a sparsely populated, frontier-like section of the Bronx known as Clason Point, an emphasis on reading has permeated the school for several years.
Lorraine Shirley, the school's librarian, can be seen planting herself into a snug rocking chair in a corner of of the library and reading an Italian folk tale to third graders sitting cross-legged on carpets before her.
When a visitor asks fourth graders to describe the books they are reading, Brian Carr, a slender youngster with an engaging gap in his front teeth, delights in spinning the tale of ''James and the Giant Peach.''
Brian breathlessly describes how James's parents are eaten by an escaped rhinoceros, how James meets up with green things, witches, centipedes and ladybugs and finally how James ends up inside a giant peach that is rolling down a hill.
''I read books on dinosaurs,'' says a classmate of James, Russell Johnson. ''Most dinosaurs died because an asteroid hit where they lived and no more plants could grow and that's what dinosaurs eat, so they died.''
 
Reading in Every Class
Every class, from science to social studies, is used as an opportunity to get children to read and think about what they are reading. Claire Harris, the school's remedial-reading teacher, works individually with children from poor families under the federally financed program known as Chapter 1.
Even the school's parents join in. They are asked to read to their children for at least 15 minutes every night. Children whose parents fill out a calendar charting the reading sessions are rewarded at a school assembly.
Also last year, the first beneficiaries of an I.B.M.-sponsored ''Writing to Read'' program, in which children write stories on computers, finally took the third-grade reading test, the earliest grade counted in the citywide rankings. Mrs. LoCascio believes many children who may worry about their penmanship find computers less intimidating than paper.
At P.S. 182, classes are grouped according to competency in reading. Teachers say that such ''tracking'' allows them to focus their lessons to a discrete audience. ''It's very hard to individualize 28 reading levels,'' says Sheila Rubin, who teaches the top second-grade class.
 
A Welcome Atmosphere
More basic still, the school is orderly and quiet, and its floors and yellow-and-gold tiled walls have a welcoming shine. A colorful sign near the entrance tells visitors, ''A Teacher Affects Eternity.'' The school is small - only 580 children from kindergarten through fourth grade - and Mrs. LoCascio knows almost every child and much about their families.
''When I walk into the building every day,'' she said, tears welling in her eyes, ''I say, 'God, how wonderful it is.' Being a principal or teacher right now is a very hard job. It really is. But I love it.''
There are some anomalous fluctuations in school reading scores from year to year, but Mrs. LoCascio, who has worked in New York City schools since 1957, feels her school's progress is genuine. She worries that the school's rankings next year may not be as high as this year's. The after-school tutoring program has been cut back to two days from five each week because it did not receive the same grant it did last year.
 
Coaching of Pupils Defended
Although some educators criticize schools that spend class time preparing children for the reading test, Mrs. LoCascio and some of her teachers disagree. Such coaching, Ms. Rubin said, still offers children skills they need to read.
Mrs. LoCascio's husband, Vincent, is a principal in an adjoining Bronx district, and his school ranked 423d, with only 37.6 percent of its children reading at or above grade level.
But Mrs. LoCascio thinks there's a broad lesson to be learned in the disparity between the schools that may explain why other schools do not make as much progress as hers. Her husband's school is badly overcrowded, with 1,600 children in a building meant for 1,000.
''He tells me I run a country-club school,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Education;
Great Expectations Hobble Black Superintendents

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
When summer returns to the oak-shaded streets of Jackson, Miss., Benjamin O. Canada hopes to be settling into his job as Superintendent of that city's public schools.
As the newly named chief of Mississippi's largest school district, he will face a formidable challenge: the education of 33,000 students, 78 percent of whom are black and disproportionately threatened by drug and alcohol abuse, teen-age pregnancy and economic disadvantage.
But Dr. Canada and his administration may face a more insidious set of problems as well. He is Jackson's first black Superintendent.
For the last 20 years, blacks have made significant gains in securing superintendent positions across the United States. At the same time, many have also seen their tenures grow troubled and end prematurely. 
In many instances, black superintendents, who make up about 3 percent of the nation's superintendents, seem to have become lightning rods for all that is wrong in urban public schools. They usually preside over schools that have crumbling walls and tax bases and are producing too many high school graduates who read at only grade-school levels.
And they increasingly find themselves under fire. Sought after most often by school districts in ruin, yet held to what they see as a higher standard than their white predecessors, they face double-edged criticism, from whites who raise questions about their authority and from blacks who are impatient for radical improvements.
''There is a double standard at play,'' said Charles D. Moody Sr., vice provost at the University of Michigan and founder of the National Alliance of Black School Educators. ''There is a conflict in expectations. The black superintendent is expected to be able to do more with less, and undo overnight years and years of things.''
 
Expecting and Demanding More
It is a double standard, many black superintendents note, that is held not just by whites but also by black constituents, who tend to look to the black superintendent as miracle worker.
''Blacks expect more and demand more,'' said Hugh J. Scott, dean for programs in education at Hunter College in New York City and author of the 1980 book ''The Black Superintendent: Messiah or Scapegoat?''
On Feb. 13, the Boston school board voted to dismiss the district's Superintendent, Laval S. Wilson, whose contract was to expire in June 1991. Dr. Wilson accepted a $260,000 buyout of his contract on March 13, said the board president, Daniel R. Burke.
About eight weeks before the Boston board's action, the six white members of the 11-member school board in Selma, Ala., voted not to renew the contract of its school superintendent, Norward Roussell. The contract expires in June.
The two dismissals drew national attention to the problems of black superintendents, especially those in racially mixed districts. They also renewed racial tensions in Boston and Selma, stirring allegations of racism by frustrated black parents and students.
 
Clashes Over Management
School officials said race had played no part in either dismissal; disagreements between the superintendents and their boards over management styles were cited instead.
''The basis for the renegotiation, buying out Dr. Wilson's contract, had no basis in race whatsoever,'' Mr. Burke said. ''It became an issue for some people both in the community and in the school department.''
Mr. Burke said Dr. Wilson was dismissed because the board and the district's needs had changed. He said times required a more decentralized leadership, something that Mr. Burke said was antithetical to Dr. Wilson's style.
Whether leadership or race was the ultimate issue in Dr. Wilson's case, educators and civil rights leaders maintain that race often adversely affects the relationships between black superintendents and the boards, teachers, parents and students with whom they must work.
''Being a superintendent is a tough job anywhere in the country today,'' regardless of color or race, said Milton Bins, deputy director of the Council of Great City Schools, a Washington-based education advocacy group. ''It's one of the most pressurized of situations.'' But when blacks assume the top posts, he said, ''all of a sudden they are expected to be the great deliverer.''
 
When a Black Is Sought
Complicating the issue, Mr. Bins added, is the tendency for blacks to be sought by school systems gripped by crisis or teetering on its edge. Education experts and former black superintendents say blacks are not usually seriously considered for a top post in education unless the district's student body is predominantly black or Hispanic. They also say a black superintendent is more likely to be hired by a district where students' achievement scores are faltering badly and financial resources are eroding.
Some notable exceptions have been Kenneth Burnley in Fairbanks, Alaska; Matthew Prophet in Portland, Ore.; Percy Clark in Lawrence Township, Ind.; and the late Richard R. Green, who headed the public schools in Minneapolis for eight years before he briefly took charge of the New York City school system, the largest in the country, in 1988.
Dr. Moody, who conducted surveys in 1970 and 1985, said the number of black superintendents rose to 125, from 16, among the country's 16,000 school districts in those 15 years.
Hispanic superintendents are also rare; 97 percent of the country's superintendents are white, according to a 1988 study by the Washington-based Center for Education Information.
Dr. Moody found in 1985 that 78 percent of black superintendents were in their first superintendency. He found, too, that 80 percent of them worked in districts where the majority of students were non-white and that most of those districts were overseen by predominantly non-white boards.
But Dr. Scott of Hunter College said a black superintendent who answers to a majority black board could no more count on solid support than could a white superintendent who must answer to a white-controlled board. Further, he said, the administrative staff and middle managers whom the black superintendent inherits are usually white and sometimes resistant to the new superintendent's authority.
 
Tough for a Trailblazer
Mr. Bins of the Council on Great City Schools said blacks in positions of high leadership, like superintendents, generally found themselves confronting racially based scrutiny, one way or the other. He said this occurred partly because blacks were still relatively new to such roles and often the first to hold such jobs in their districts.
''The first black anywhere catches hell,'' said Dr. Scott, who was Washington's first black Superintendent, serving from 1970 to 1973. ''The expectations for Richard Green were enormous.''
''You have to convince them that you are going to turn around the system without tearing it up and doing them in,'' Dr. Scott said of whites who may be leery of blacks' motives and abilities. ''At the same time you have to be a solid educator. I'm not so certain that there are enough people who combine all those skills to make it.''
The black superintendents in Boston and Selma were each the city's first.
 
Difference in Atlanta
''My situation is different,'' said Jerome Harris, a black who is Superintendent in Atlanta, whose school and political leadership is mostly black. ''We are educationally bankrupt. I have to make change, and change is painful.''
Critics of Dr. Harris, a former community district superintendent in Brooklyn, say he has moved too forcefully in making policy and personnel changes, upsetting local blacks who are trying to retain their school jobs, the jobs of friends and the way things have been done in Atlanta schools for years.
Yet Dr. Harris, who has been Superintendent for almost two years, said he did not plan to alter his approach, because he was trying to make teachers and administrators forge a more emotional attachment to their jobs and to the students.
''They come to work with a job,'' he said. ''I come to the job with a mission.''
Dr. Roussell, the Superintendent leaving in Selma, said he, too, particularly wanted to improve the educational effort shown to black students by the school system, in which they are in a vast majority.
''In the predominantly white schools the facilities were better and better maintained,'' Dr. Roussell said, noting that many of those schools had computer laboratories while no predominantly black schools did. ''In the predominantly black schools there was furniture that was 30 to 35 years old, maps way outdated and books in short supply.''
Almost immediately, Dr. Roussell said, he began challenging these inequities. One of his most controversial moves included making college preparatory courses more available to blacks. He said he believed that black students were being unfairly denied entry into the schools' advanced-study programs.
''I don't think kids ought to be educated for obsolescence,'' Dr. Roussell said. ''So anything that did not give young people a challenge to further their development, I tried to deal with that.''
''It cost me my job,'' he said, because many whites believed that the change threatened to dilute a privilege their children were enjoying.
Jamie Wallace, the executive vice president of the Selma-Dallas County Chamber of Commerce, disagreed. A close observer of the situation that led to the board's refusal to renew Dr. Roussell's contract, Mr. Wallace said the Superintendent's style of management ''was not agreeable with the majority of the board.'' He said it was ''unfortunate'' that people viewed the dispute as racially motivated.
 
Evidence of a Pattern
Sar Levitan, director of the Center for Social Policy at George Washington University in Washington, said the resistance that black superintendents faced was part of a historic pattern. When blacks assume non-traditional jobs, he said, the few who make the early breakthroughs usually clear the way for new generations of blacks who find greater acceptance.
Dr. Levitan said the history of black elected officials provided an excellent example. David N. Dinkins as Mayor of New York and L. Douglas Wilder as Governor of Virginia were both placed in office by predominantly non-black electorates, whereas black public officials in the past were usually elected by black majorities.
''It's too early to judge,'' Dr. Levitan said, ''but maybe we are finally divesting ourselves of racial prejudice and are judging people on the basis of ability.''
Dr. Canada, who will take over in Jackson this summer, hopes so.
''I'm saying up front that I'm coming in as a Superintendent, not as a black Superintendent,'' said Dr. Canada, who is leaving a predominantly white district in Tucson, Ariz., where he was a Deputy Superintendent. ''It is up to the community to give me the same opportunities it would give anyone.''

HEADLINE: Fleurian Beats Fog-Bound Becker

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 20

 BODY:
While Boris Becker gave too convincing an imitation of a noontime somnambulist, Jean Fleurian, an eccentric Parisian wearing his last pair of sneakers and shorts too new, too large and held up by a safety pin, was wide awake.
So fearful was he of being stuck in the stomach by the pin, said Fleurian, who played the match with a plane ticket back to Paris in his pocket, that he kept his body language to a minimum and stuck to economical winners.
Because he also was afraid of ''waking up'' his opponent, Fleurian relied on passing shots that allowed the No. 2 player in the world to remain in his own private haze. The histrionics that prompted his Davis Cup teammates to label Fleurian a Rambo earlier this year were curtailed for a day in order to help Becker doze. 
 
'Completely Different'
''He was a completely different player today, very slow to react, and that was my chance,'' Fleurian said of his unanticipated straight-set upset at the Lipton Championships today. ''I knew I could do something and I knew it was the day to do it.''
Becker's inattention to what turned out to be a tiger of an opponent produced a 7-6, 6-1 victory for the 24-year-old Fleurian, whose career hit a crescendo in the second set, revealing the West German in his poorest performance against an underdog in nearly two years.
As he had two weeks ago after a straight-set loss to Andre Agassi in the semifinals at Indian Wells, Calif., the 22-year-old Becker blamed his demise on an inadequate supply of concentration. Along with blistered toes and an aching back, Becker has been bothered by a chronic acquiescence to distraction. When he ought to be applying tunnel vision to his game, his mind is meandering, especially if his ferocious cannonball serve happens to be sputtering.
Like a sleepwalker, Becker had strolled onto the court for the completion of his fourth-round match with the unheralded Fleurian, a match twice interrupted by rain on Monday. The match resumed today with Becker up by 3-1 in the first set, but when he came back to complete it, he did so minus a sound strategy or the desire to officially wrestle away Ivan Lendl's No. 1 computer ranking.
 
An Absent Mind
''My mind was not really on the court,'' said Becker, who didn't bother to hide the fact that the loss had stunned him. ''It was, I don't know where, and I have to find it sometime this day. Am I disappointed? Yes.''
Becker, who took a wild card into this tournament at the last minute last week after deciding not to play in the Davis Cup for West Germany, had been in typical form when the match began on Monday. Fleurian admitted he was outclassed and, after canceling his Monday night flight when the match was left unfinished, promptly booked the same flight for tonight because he was so certain his career-high ranking of 46 didn't pose a threat to Becker.
But from the start today, Fleurian noticed the blank look on Becker's face and the holes in his game. Becker held four set points in the first set and fumbled them all, committing an emblematic double-fault on the fourth, then falling, 7 points to 3, in the tie breaker to the revitalized Frenchman.
''After the first set, where I had many chances, he started to tee off almost immediately,'' Becker said. ''Everything went in. He didn't give me any chance to come back.''
 
Gimpy Becker Serves
Fleurian cranked out winners on every gimpy serve sent his way, and after breaking Becker and holding serve with a forehand winner, he claimed a 3-1 advantage in the second set. He then broke Becker again in the fifth game when, after the West German fought his way to deuce, Fleurian followed a sprawling backhand volley winner with a blistering forehand return on a serve that by all rights was a winner itself.
Fleurian, a sun worshiper who spent the last five years tuning his game and a tan in Florida, held serve for 5-1 and then broke Becker for the match, assisted by another double-fault and a backhand that veered out of bounds after the befuddled West German mislaunched it.
''I am the sort of player who goes through stages in a year, and right now I have a low,'' said Becker. He said he could live with his valley of a performance here, where he briefly reigned as the second seeded player, so long as he peaks in time for the French Open and Wimbledon.
''That's basically the bottom line,'' Becker said of his penchant for reserving his nonpareil play for the Grand Slam tournaments.

HEADLINE: New Generations Bring New Vision To Food Business

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
THE food business in America came of age over the last decade. In some families involved in the industry, members of a younger generation were also coming of age. Today many of them are in charge.
These sons and daughters, members of a second and, sometimes, a third generation in a family food or wine business, are often innovators, introducing new products, creating new images and cultivating new markets. They want to make their mark, but they also have enormous respect for their parents' and grandparents' accomplishments and the traditions the businesses represent.
The current social and gastronomic attitude that has given prestige to being a chef, a meat purveyor or a baker has made it exciting for the younger generation to work in their parents' food businesses. The children or grandchildren are frequently college educated and well traveled, unlike the older generation, which was often forced to go right to work because of economic necessity. 
In 1975, Seth Greenberg began working full time at William Greenberg Jr. Desserts, Inc., the retail pastry company his father, now 65 years old, started in 1946 in Manhattan. He was also attending New York University at night, but left after three years. ''The hands-on experience of working in the business became more relevant than studying it in school,'' the son said.
The company, which has several stores, is best known for its simple but rich chocolate cake, butter cookies and sticky buns. The son, now 32, said he has earned the respect of employees and customers for innovations like computerization, expanded mail-order business and cholesterol-free cakes. ''I'm no longer regarded simply as my father's son,'' he said. He also does about half the cake decorating, formerly his father's exclusive domain. Customers usually do not know the difference.
In Cambridge, Mass., Ronnie Savenor, 32, and his brother, Alan, 40, have been running Savenor's, the 60-year-old butcher shop and market that is best known as the place where Julia Child shops, since their father, Jack, retired four years ago. ''It was a trauma to turn it over to them, but I'm happy they're doing it with such style,'' their father said.
Last summer the shop, now in its third generation of Savenors, was completely remodeled and the emblem changed with the legend ''The Culinary Edge'' added. ''We decided the place needed to be brightened up,'' said Ronnie Savenor.
The brothers also placed more emphasis on the fish counter, relocating it more prominently. ''My dad was less interested in fish, and it's very important today,'' he said. He said the market would still offer traditional, personalized service. ''I could have done anything with my life, but I was given a gift horse and I'm lucky I enjoy what I do,'' he said.
Abram Orwasher was practicing law five years ago when he joined the 74-year-old bread bakery started by his grandfather, Abraham, and run by his father, Louis, now in his 70's, on New York's Upper East Side.
''This business and its reputation for quality means a lot to our family and I want to see it have a future,'' the 39-year-old son said. ''Fortunately there is a demand for quality today.'' Abram Orwasher has introduced some new products, like muffins and pumpkin and cranberry breads for Thanksgiving, and is thinking about expanding. ''I've done some automation on the business side, but today the real challenge is to keep the traditional side going, not to modernize the brick ovens. Someone who is not a member of the family may not understand that.''
Longstanding family food businesses like these are commonplace in Europe. There are fewer of them in America because the second generation is often still in diapers. In the instances where the children have grown up in the business and finally chosen it as a career, they have usually come with a broader perspective.
In 1974, after his father, Joe Czarnecky, now 79, suffered a heart attack, Jack Czarnecky, who had a degree in bacteriology from the University of California at Davis, came back to Joe's, the family restaurant founded in 1916 in Reading, Pa., to help out.
''I never thought I'd wind up in this business,'' he said. ''My dad would have had to sell the restaurant if I had not come back. But I'm here because this is where I want to be.''
The younger Mr. Czarnecky, 39, with his wife, Heidi, changed the focus of the restaurant, which has long been famous for serving exotic mushrooms in dozens of preparations, from continental to American. He added an extensive list of American wines and gained a nationwide reputation with his cookbook, ''Joe's Book of Mushroom Cookery'' (Atheneum, 1986).
''He's taken it way beyond what we could ever do,'' his father, Joe, said. ''He has the same philosophy, the respect for quality, but his vision is greater.''
Five years ago when N. Lee Comisar retired, his sons Marc and Michael E. Comisar, now both in their late 30's, began running Maisonette the premier French restaurant in Cincinatti. It was founded by their grandparents in 1949.
The sons, who acquired experience on the West Coast and in Europe, keep trying new menu items, have modernized the color scheme from red and lime green to salmon pink and are aggressively pursuing clients for business functions.
Transitions like this one can be made smoothly with years of planning, sometimes circumstances make them more abrupt and the changes seem even more dramatic.
When Joyce Chen, 73, who pioneered cookware products like polyethylene cutting slabs and owned a northern Chinese restaurant in Cambridge, began suffering from Alzheimer's disease and had to retire three years ago, her children, Helen, 43, Henry, 44, and Stephen, 47, took over the business, the Joyce Chen companies, which their mother founded in 1958. Not only have they have added a second Chinese restaurant in Boston, Joyce Chen's Cityplace, expanded the mail-order business, and hired a publicist, they have introduced new cookware and prepared foods, some of which their mother might not have endorsed.
''I began looking at what the market wanted, not just what pleased me, the way my mother did,'' her daughter said. She has added a wok with a nonstick coating to the cookware line. ''My mother did not believe the traditional wok, which had to be seasoned and stabilized on a ring, was suitable for American kitchens,'' she said.
Mrs. Chen sold what she called a Peking pan, a deep skillet with sloping sides. ''But the stores that carried the Joyce Chen line were selling other people's woks so it seemed silly,'' Helen Chen said.
''People sometimes call me Joyce,'' she added, ''but it doesn't bother me because I'm doing my own thing as well.''
Joy Sterling, 36, who left a successful career as assignment manager for ABC News in Los Angeles five years ago, is now in charge of sales and marketing for Iron Horse Vineyards in Sonoma County, Calif., the highly respected winery her parents founded.
''When you join a family business, the outside world looks upon it by saying, 'Isn't that cute; she's obviously retarded and her parents gave her a job,' or they think you've been handed life on a silver spoon,'' she said. ''I had to know that I could work for strangers, but I finally decided I wanted a different life, so I came back to the winery.''
She sees her joining the business ''as a validation of what my parents did when they bought Iron Horse Vineyards in 1974,'' Ms. Sterling said. ''It proves that it's more than a hobby and it won't end. Now it's up to me to make sure that Iron Horse will continue to be enticing and economically viable for the next generation.''

HEADLINE: Banks Balk at Costs of Japan

SERIES: Struggling in Japan: U.S. Companies That Pull Back - First of two articles.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 20

 BODY:
United States trade negotiators have been hammering away for years to open Japanese markets, yet many American companies, even giants like Citibank, the nation's largest bank, find Japan a daunting challenge. They have discovered that the real problem is not so much governmental or cultural barriers, but that doing business here is too costly and competitive to justify a major effort.
Several American companies have recently been selling operations in Japan, because of the enormous prices an established company can command, or they are scaling back because the competition is so fierce. Still others, unable to crack the market by themselves, are forming alliances with Japanese companies.
The sobering experience of American commercial banks in Japan provides a vivid illustration. Tokyo has eased restrictions on foreign banks operating here in the last couple of years, yet there has been no real payoff for American banks. Citibank is alone in trying to establish a beachhead in Japan's large consumer banking market. But even it is straining because of the enormous cost of building a business. Japan Banks Surge in U.S. Indeed, most American banks have been cutting back in Japan even as Japanese banks have made large acquisitions in the United States and are aggressively expanding in the American market. 
The Japanese are better able to afford costly expansion at home and abroad mainly because the value of their shares and other assets have soared in the last decade along with the stock and real estate markets in Tokyo. In addition, those assets are worth more in terms of the dollar, because the yen has strengthened considerably since 1985.
Japanese-owned banks now control more than a quarter of California's rich banking market and are amply represented in other big American urban centers. In contrast, all of the 82 foreign banks operating in Japan make just 1.66 percent of the loans, a rate that has declined for two years.
American banks have been forced to write off billions of dollars for bad loans to third-world countries and domestic real estate developers, leaving them short of capital and much less willing to make big investments that do not produce quick returns.
The Chase Manhattan Bank has slashed its Japanese loan portfolio to about $200 million, from some $4 billion several years ago, and has closed a branch. Chemical Bank is focusing on businesses that require little capital and little risk, like acting as a foreign-exchange broker for clients. The Bank of America, which has been in Japan for decades, plans to move its Asian headquarters to Hong Kong next month because of the very high cost of doing business in Japan.
 
'Who Can Afford It?'
''It is very, very hard here for a foreign bank to make a buck, and it is getting even harder,'' said M. L. Greenberg, head of Asian operations for the Bank of America. ''No American bank owns even a part of a Japanese bank, but who can afford it?''
Even an American powerhouse like Citicorp, the holding company for Citibank, is far smaller than the Japanese giants that dominate this market. It has scaled back its expectations as it has adopted a new strategy to crack the retail market. Yet it is sticking with its effort because it is the only United States banking company committed to building a worldwide consumer business.
Because of Japanese resistance and, more important, the extraordinary price it would have to pay, Citibank has abandoned efforts to acquire a Japanese bank with a branch system.
 
Very High Prices
Since Japan's stock prices soared in the 1980's, banks here sell for as much as 60 times their earnings - five to six times the price an American institution would command. And the high prices act as another barrier to entry by foreigners.
''If you look at the economics of a bank acquisition in this country, it just cannot be justified,'' said Masamoto Yashiro, head of Citibank's consumer banking operations here since January 1989. ''An acquisition becomes attractive only if prices are not out of this world - but they are.''
Just a few years ago, Citibank tried to buy an ailing Japanese institution, the Heiwa Sogo Bank, for its extensive branch system. After they were outbid by Sumitomo Bank, some Citibank executives complained that Japanese bankers would not permit the acquisition of a Japanese bank by an American company. But Mr. Yashiro conceded that the issue was less one of outright barriers than of price.
More recently, John S. Reed, the chairman of Citibank, said it would be willing to acquire branches that might be sold off by Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank, which plan to merge next month. But it seems unlikely that any operations will be sold, at least not at a price Citibank would find acceptable.
 
Expensive Plan to Expand
Instead, Citibank has opted to build a network branch by branch and brick by brick. At its current rate of growth - by four or five new branches a year - it will take nearly five years for the bank's Japanese retail system to match its presence in Hong Kong, a market only one twenty-fourth as big.
''It's quite a difficult strategy because of the overhead you have to take on,'' said James E. Russell, a banking analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan. In Japan, he explained, the market requires a network of branches staffed with bank tellers, whereas in the United States most customers are accustomed to dealing with the more efficient automatic teller machines.
Citibank began to reassess its retail strategy in Japan when Mr. Yashiro joined it after a career as a marketing executive with Exxon, from which he had retired at age 60. He was given a mandate to analyze Japan's consumer banking market and figure out how Citibank might penetrate it. He recalled that he did not need to spend a lot of time at the task before a realization came to him.
''The answer was clear,'' he said. ''With the kind of crazy multiples we would have to pay to make an acquisition, there's no way we could make it work.
''Corporations hardly need banks any longer in Japan, and the competition in retail banking is heating up.''
 
Old Customs and Work Rules
A key problem was not just the cost of rent, which is astronomical in Tokyo, but what Mr. Yashiro described as the unusually high cost of staff and a number of inefficiencies built into the system by old customs and work rules.
''Japanese manufacturing is supposed to be so efficient, but when it comes to the actual involvement of people, it becomes terribly inefficient,'' Mr. Yashiro complained. ''Every time people touch something in this country, it becomes very expensive.''
As a result, he said, Citibank had to lower its sights considerably or risk throwing money away. ''We have to start off as a niche player,'' Mr. Yashiro explained.
What that means in practice is that Citibank will not move quickly to add to its nine retail branches in Japan. At its deliberate pace of expansion, it will not start to reap economies of scale and any big increases in profits until 1995, Mr. Yashiro said.
Citibank's consumer business here includes the retail branch system, a credit card operation that issues Visa and a card affiliated with Mastercard, and a consumer finance operation.
 
Shying Away From Lending
Leery of the narrow margins and high borrowing costs faced by foreign banks here, Citibank is not emphasizing loans, a staple of Japanese retail banks. Instead, it will merely try to offer services for which it can charge high fees and take deposits, which are classified as liabilities since they involve, in effect, a loan to the bank.
''We've been focusing on the liability side because lending is a cutthroat business in Japan,'' Mr. Yashiro acknowledged. ''It's just too competitive.''
The bank's principal consumer product is a multi-currency account that permits the holder to move money easily from one currency to another and to make remittances overseas. The popularity of the account is a tribute to the worldwide business dealings of the Japanese, the frequency of their overseas travel, and the education of young Japanese in foreign countries.
 
Impasse Over Teller Network
One of the few real roadblocks Citibank ran into came when it tried to join a huge network connecting the automatic teller machines of the big Japanese banks. Citibank was in an unusual position to benefit from acceptance in the network; it would bring just 20 automated machines to the system, but its customers would instantly have access to about 18,000 machines at the Japanese banks.
For four years, the talks went nowhere. Citibank never received a flat no; the talks just ambled in no particular direction.
''I must admit, there is a frustrating side to this country,'' Mr. Yashiro said. ''Sometimes you don't even know what the problem is, it's so amorphous.''
But that logjam was recently broken. Mr. Yashiro says that there has been progress and that the Japanese banks have been cooperative and receptive to Citibank's efforts. The American bank may be plugged into the system early next year, he said.
That would be a coup, but how much it alters the fundamental economics of this difficult market remains to be seen. ''The fact is, progress is going to be slow,'' Mr. Yashiro said.
 
Next: Selling out and going home.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Japan's Yen Strategy May Weaken Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
When a country has two problems, sometimes it must choose to fight only one of them.
Japan yesterday sought to support its falling yen by once again pushing up interest rates, and in the process it may have made its plunging stock market even more vulnerable to further declines.
''The Japanese stock market has never been more at risk than it is now,'' said George Noble, manager of the Fidelity Overseas Fund, which has reduced its holdings of Japanese stocks since late last year.
That growing bearishness comes as Japan, whose stock market led the way up for most of the 1980's, plunged again. The Nikkei 225, down 1.5 percent yesterday, has dropped 21 percent this year, before adjusting for currency fluctuations. In dollar terms, the index is down 26 percent. 
By pushing up interest rates, the Japanese Government hopes to stem the slide of the yen, which has been the weakest of the world's leading currencies for most of the last year. But even bigger rate increases may be needed, since the latest Japanese move only partly catches up with rate rises in West Germany, whose currency has been the strongest. Despite the Japanese move, the dollar rose 1.15 yen yesterday, to 154.20.
For years, Japanese stocks have looked expensive relative to stocks in Europe or America, measured by traditional indicators like price-earnings ratios or their dividend yields. For most of that time the Japanese kept buying their own stocks, and prices kept rising.
But the key fact about recent interest-rate rises is that they have made Japanese share prices overvalued by traditional Japanese measurements as well. Charles Elliott, a Goldman, Sachs analyst in Tokyo, noted that in 1984, the last time Japanese long-term bond rates were around 7 percent, as they are now, the stock market traded at less than 30 times earnings. Even with the latest falls, the current prices are about 50 times profits.
 
Higher Yields in Bonds
Looked at another way, yields on Japanese long-term bonds are close to 13 times higher than the dividend yield on the typical Japanese stock. At the peak of that ratio a few weeks ago, the figure was 14. The only other time that ratio climbed to 13 was a few weeks before the 1987 crash, Mr. Noble of Fidelity noted. After the 1987 crash, as interest rates fell sharply around the world, the ratio fell to as low as 7.
The fall of the yen has been brought on by a series of problems that include the fact that interest rates rose faster in Germany than in Japan, making German investments more attractive. But Japan is also facing the fact that money may not continue to roll in as it has. In January, for the first time since 1982, Japan reported a current-account deficit. The current account includes trade, but also ''invisibles,'' like the money that Japanese tourists spend overseas.
The deficit was widely deemed to be a fluke, and there was a surplus after making seasonal adjustments. But the trend is unmistakeable: the Japanese trade surplus has been falling everywhere. The United States reported yesterday that its trade deficit with Japan fell to $2.9 billion in January, the lowest monthly figure since 1984.
 
Reversal of Trends
A few years ago, the Japanese stock market took off under the benevolent conditions of the ''triple merits'' - falling oil prices, falling interest rates and a rising yen. Now the talk is of ''triple demerits,'' with all those trends running the wrong way for Japan.
The result is that in the Japanese blue chips represented by the Nikkei 225, prices have fallen to the levels of early 1989. Adjusted for the effect of the rising dollar, the Japanese stock market is now at its lowest level since early 1988.
On the Japanese stock market through the 1980's, any weakness was a buying opportunity. But so far this year, the Japanese have instead shown a new willingness to buy assets and stocks in other countries that looked cheap by Japanese standards.
Until the last few days, advocates of Japanese stocks could reassure themselves that the recent weakness was largely a blue-chip affair. The average of the Tokyo stock exchange's second section, generally smaller stocks with shorter histories, managed to rise in both January and February, while the larger stocks were falling. But in the last week, that index, too, has begun to sag, down 4.6 percent since Friday, almost as much as the 5.5 percent fall in the Nikkei 225.
For now, it appears that buying interest in Tokyo is not likely to be rekindled until both the yen and Japanese interest rates stabilize. Neither looks to be on the immediate horizon.
