HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up By 0.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Consumer prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent last month as a surge in the cost of clothing more than offset a record decline in the price of fuel oil, the Labor Department said today.
The February increase, though less than half as large as January's 1.1 percent jump, was nevertheless more than most analysts expected and prompted some to assert that the Federal Reserve would have to consider tightening credit when its main policy-making body meets next Tuesday to plot the nation's monetary course for the following seven weeks.
''The Fed is getting behind the eight ball on inflation,'' said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist at Carroll, McEntee & McGinley Inc. ''It's creeping higher.''
 
Hopes for Lower Rates Dim
For much of the fall and winter the expectation was that the Fed's next move would be to trim interest rates to head off a possible recession. But in recent weeks these hopes have been gradually abandoned as the economy seemed to be rebounding from a very sluggish fourth quarter in which growth dwindled to a rate of less than 1 percent. 
The concern about inflation raised by the price report led to an early-morning selloff in stocks and bonds. But the stock market then seesawed through the rest of the day before ending lower, while bond prices quickly turned up as talk about big Japanese purchases began to develop. [Pages D8 and D17.] At the White House, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said: ''We must remain vigilant against any increase in inflation. But the inflation level has been relatively steady for some time in spite of the weather-related and energy-related surges. Over all, we continue to believe that inflation is low and under control.''
Still, a close examination of today's price data left room for doubt that fresh anti-inflation measures are required. The jump in clothing prices, which the Government attributed largely to early introduction of spring lines, by itself accounted for 42 percent of the overall increase in the Consumer Price Index and some of this reflected a change in the way the numbers are collected. Without clothing, the rise would have been the expected three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Fuel Prices Off Sharply
After sharp increases in December and January, fuel oil prices tumbled 19 percent in February with the onset of warmer-than-usual weather. The decline was the largest one-month drop since 1935, when the Government first began tracking the price.
Patrick C. Jackman, a senior Department official, suggested that more moderate increases lie ahead because the prices of some goods that have been rising rapidly, including gasoline and tomatoes, have already turned down.
''There doesn't appear to be much that is going to hurt us'' when the C.P.I. for March is reported next month, he said.
Some analysts noted that prices received by producers of finished goods were reported last Friday to have been unchanged for February and that prices for goods at the intermediate stage of production had declined.
Prices at the producer level tend to flow through eventually to consumers but with various time lags. Unlike the Consumer Price Index, the producer indexes do not include services.
 
Apparel Up 3.3%
The rise in the February Consumer Price Index was dominated by a 3.3 percent surge in the apparel and upkeep category, the biggest on a seasonally adjusted basis since records began to be kept in 1947. The Department attributed this to exceptionally early introductions of new spring and summer clothing lines with women's and girls' apparel up 5 percent and infants' and toddlers' apparel up more than 10 percent.
Besides the early warm-weather lines, the jump in this component of the Consumer Price Index - accounting for about 6 percent of the total index - also reflected the department's reversion to its pre-1987 practice of immediately reporting the price impact of new lines rather than spreading it over more than one month.
Mr. Jackman said that the phasing-in process of the last few years meant that some clothing was being discounted before original prices could be reported.
Apparel and medical care, which rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, were the only big categories to show more rapid inflation last month than in January. Food, housing, transportation, entertainment and ''other'' goods and services rose more slowly in price.
The Consumer Price Index climbed by the same five-tenths of 1 percent when its volatile food and energy items are excluded, about the same pace as in December and January. Over all, commodities climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, and services rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
Food prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent following a 1.8 percent burst in January, with tomatoes soaring another 30 percent after doubling in January, and beef, pork, poultry and seafood all rising substantially. Egg prices, however, dropped 9 percent after rising 15 percent during the preceding three months, while fruits and vegetables rose only 1 percent after a 10 percent January surge.
Housing prices, which account for 42 percent of the Consumer Price Index, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in February as household fuels and other utilities eased six-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Higher Cost of Cable TV
The cost of cable television continued to rise sharply, with a 1.8 percent rise bringing the three-month total to 4.8 percent.
In transportation, where prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, motor fuels rose scarcely at all while new cars, used cars and finance charges all declined. Insurance and public transportation, the latter mainly because of a 2.5 percent increase in airline fares, both posted large increases.
''Inflation concerns are still around and they should still be on the mind of the Federal Reserve,'' said Michael P. Daly, an economist for the Cigna Corporation. ''It's not abating - but it's not accelerating either.''
Among the five major metropolitan areas for which price information is collected monthly, the least inflation was a one-tenth of 1 percent increase for New York, where apparel data were not included because of the timing of the survey, while the worse was a 1.1 percent increase for Los Angeles. The rise for Chicago was nine-tenths; for Philadelphia, eight-tenths, and for San Francisco, five-tenths.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Widened by Oil Imports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The trade deficit widened to $9.3 billion in January as oil imports surged to refill stocks depleted during December's record cold, the Commerce Department reported today. In December, the trade deficit totaled a revised $7.7 billion.
Exports were also higher, climbing 4 percent above December to an all-time high of $32.1 billion. But the increase in both the volume of oil imports and their price once again pointed up an ominous dependence on foreign oil. Many economists believe that dependence will only increase as the decade progresses, further intensifying trade pressures. 
Imports of petroleum products totaled $5.9 billion, which was $1.8 billion greater than in December.
 
Monthly Oil Record
The volume of imported oil, at 291 million barrels, set a monthly record, topping a previous high set only last August. The average price per barrel of oil in January was $20.13, or $2.16 higher than the December average.
The gain in exports, while broad-based, was particularly robust in the capital goods sector. But it was overwhelmed by a 7.3 percent rise in imports, to $41.3 billion, most of which was accounted for by oil, the trade report showed.
''Our long-term trade outlook is relatively pessimistic,'' said Brian R. Horrigan, director of long-term forecasting for the WEFA Group of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., ''because we expect increasing oil dependency on a permanent basis.''
The American Petroleum Institute has reported that foreign oil accounted for a record 54 percent of consumption in January, as domestic production fell to its lowest level in a quarter century.
Still, many economists said, the unusually warm weather after December could buy some short-term improvement in the trade accounts in coming months. Oil companies have had less of a need to replenish inventories, and prices have tended to weaken since December.
The White House and Administration officials voiced little concern at the January deterioration, especially because it followed a dramatic improvement in December, when the trade imbalance was the lowest in five years, even when revised slightly upward to $7.7 billion, from $7.5 billion. ''Everyone seemed to realize they couldn't maintain that low level, and it was expected there would be an increase in January,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman.
 
Fluctuations Cited
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said he was ''encouraged'' by the record exports, but noted that the data are subject to wide monthly fluctuations and that totals over longer periods should be used to understand fundamental trends.
In contrast to the experience with most other countries, the deficit with Japan fell in January. Much of the improvement reflected weakness in the American automobile market, which led to a decline in automobile imports from Japan.
From $3.5 billion in December, the deficit with Japan, still the largest with any country, shrank to $2.9 billion, the lowest in five years. Annualized, the $2.9 billion would mean $34 billion, compared with the $49 billion deficit in Japanese trade that the United States chalked up in 1989.
 
'The Right Direction'
''Clearly the deficit with Japan is going in the right direction,'' said Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, in an interview. She faces a series of negotiating deadlines in coming weeks over efforts to pry open the Japanese markets for more American wood products, satellites, supercomputers and other exports.
To David Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI/McGraw Hill, the decline in the Japanese deficit, which came despite a strengthening of the dollar versus the yen, ''suggests that we're still competitive in the world market and can hold our own.''
While the deficit fell with Japan, it rose with most other countries, including the European Community and such newly industrialized areas as Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.
With Taiwan, the deficit topped $1 billion, the second highest after Japan. With all developing countries, the deficit doubled to $5.9 billion, from $2.9 billion.
 
Doubling for China Deficit
Practically doubling was the deficit with China, which jumped to $841 million in January, from $498 million in December.
While oil was the main factor behind the higher trade deficit, the high propensity of the nation to consume imports affected all manufactured goods. Manufactured imports totaled $30.4 billion, up $400 million from December.
Among categories of manufactured goods, clothing and footwear, organic and inorganic chemicals, iron and steel mill products and specialized industrial machinery showed the most striking gains.
Imports of clothing were up 31 percent, to $3.1 billion, and are likely to add fuel to what is expected to be a renewed effort by the domestic textile industry to seek protection from Congress.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
An Old Trade Idea Wins New Favor

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
THE latest round of trade negotiations between the United States and Japan is provoking rancor but few results. The Japanese have charged that America does not invest enough in education and research and development, while the United States contends that Japan's distribution network remains closed.
Although there may be elements of truth in the charges of both sides, they remain outside the realm of the talks, which are supposed to focus on the reported discrimination against American exports to Japan of satellites, forest products, telecommunications equipment and supercomputers.
Some policy makers and critics - discouraged by the slow pace of negotiations and America's big annual deficits - have begun to voice new support for an old idea. Articles have appeared in academic journals, including the Harvard Business Review, and the ideas have been discussed by some Congressional staff members. 
''We need more than short-term bilateral talks on trade,'' said Walter Russell Mead, an economist and author who completed a study of the postwar international economic system published in the summer and winter issues of World Policy Journal. ''We need a reform of the postwar international economic system so that it recognizes how integrated our national economies have become.''
John Maynard Keynes first advocated the idea that is gaining favor today when, representing Britain at the Bretton Woods, N.H., conferences following World War II, he proposed creating an ''international trade organization,'' with responsiblity over long-term trade matters. ''After World War II, Keynes pushed for creating the World Bank, to stimulate global economic growth, and the International Monetary Fund, to make short-term balance-of-payment loans,'' Mr. Mead said, as well as an international trade organization to solve long-term trade problems, but it ''died in the cradle.''
The trade organization, as Lord Keynes envisioned it, would have had an independent secretariat with an international staff and would have served as a forum where countries could discuss trade issues on a neutral turf.
''The secretariat would have been at least able to develop a data base so that during trade negotiations apples could be compared to apples; we don't have that now,'' said Clyde Prestowitz, a former trade negotiator in the Reagan Adminstration and a critic of the Bush Administration's policy toward Japan. Supporting the idea of creating a new trade organization, he added that the aim of the organization ''was simple - to bring surplus and deficit countries into balance in a nonpejorative way.''
The trade organization would be able to impose - and collect - tariffs and surcharges on the exports of countries with chronic trade surpluses, like Japan and West Germany, with the tariffs going into a fund for balance-of-payment loans. It would also be able to prompt countries with chronic deficits into devaluing their currencies to make their exports more attractive.
William Diebold, who was with the State Department during the trade organization negotiations and is now a senior fellow emeritus at the Council on Foreign Relations, said: ''A lot of myths have recently been developed about the international trade organization, giving it more power than it was to have had. But had it been created, it probably would have been a place where domestic business practices, like Japan's distribution system, could be discussed in the context of trade so that over the long run specific rules could emerge.''
Congress opposed the organization, largely out of concerns that it would impinge upon American sovereignty, and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, with less authority, was accepted instead. ''But the GATT's rules are too vague and its secretariat is too weak to do anything but serve as a place to discuss tariffs and trade barriers,'' Mr. Mead said. ''These are no longer the important issues dividing Japan and the United States.''
The proponents of a new trade group argue that it needs research capabilities to allow it to forecast problems like those between Japan and the United States and sufficient authority to deal with world trade problems. Jeffery E. Garten, an investment banker who served in the Ford and Carter Administrations and who supports a new trade organization, said that ''at the next economic summit, the leaders ought to finally acknowledge that the current system is inadequate for dealing with trade'' and appoint a group to report back in a year on how to change the system.
Mr. Mead said that ''as long as trade expands, we can expect more conflicts.'' For that reason, he argues, the functions of an international trade organization should be put somewhere - even in GATT.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Continental Air and Denver Sign Lease on New Airport

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
Ending a yearlong stalemate, Continental Airlines said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Denver officials to lease space at the city's new $2.3 billion airport.
The agreement eliminates a major hurdle facing the airport, which will be the world's largest when completed in late 1993. Continental, the second-largest carrier at Denver, had opposed construction of the new airport, which will replace Stapleton International Airport. The largest carrier, United Airlines, has yet to reach such an agreement with the city. 
The new airport, 18 miles northeast of the city, will be the first major one to be built in this country since 1974. It will be financed with Federal money, airport bonds that will be repaid through various charges to the airlines, and proceeds from the development of land at Stapleton, which will be closed.
City officials hope the new airport, which is expected to generate more than 100,000 jobs, will help lift Denver from its economic slump.
 
Millions in Interest Savings
As part of the agreement, the city will redesign a terminal to satisfy Continental and will finance $100 million worth of support equipment for Continental, saving the airline millions of dollars in interest payments.
Federico Pena, the Mayor of Denver, said he recently met with a board member of United Airlines and hopes to reach an agreement with the carrier in a few weeks. But he said the success of the project does not depend on United's support. ''This ship has left the dock,'' he said.
A spokesman for United declined to comment.
Critics had said that the two airlines opposed the new and bigger airport because they would lose their dominant position in the city. Together, United and Continental control more than 80 percent of the market at Denver. But Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, parent of Continental, said yesterday that the airline had opposed the new airport because of its high cost, not to protect market share.

HEADLINE: House Tax Bill Aims At Foreign Concerns

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders today introduced legislation intended to help the Government collect taxes owed by United States subsidiaries of foreign-owned companies.
The measure was prompted by recent reports that some subsidiaries had consistently underpaid their taxes, and thereby gained a competitive edge against American-owned companies that paid the taxes they owed. It was reported last month that Federal tax officials were investigating many American subsidiaries of Japanese companies on the suspicion that they had underpaid corporate income taxes by billions of dollars.
The bill would also tax the stock gains of some foreign individuals and corporations, in an effort to provide more equitable treatment for foreign and domestic investors. But this provision would not apply to nations, like Japan and Canada, in which such a tax is barred by treaties with the United States. 
 
Curb on Investment Feared
Critics of the bill said it was a politically inspired way to raise revenues without offending American taxpayers. They warned that it would discourage foreigners from investing in the United States, where total foreign investment approaches $2 trillion.
Supporters of the bill cited Internal Revenue Service reports that in 1986 foreign-owned companies reported a negative tax liability of more than $1 billion, while also reporting more than $500 billion in gross income. The I.R.S. found that of the 36,800 foreign-owned companies filing returns in 1986, more than half reported no taxable income.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Illinois Democrat and chairman of the House Ways and Means committee, said, ''It is critical that we insure that foreign-owned companies are not underpaying their taxes, thereby gaining a competitive advantage over American companies that are paying their fair share.''
To that end, the bill would extend to all pending tax cases the I.R.S. authority, provided by a 1989 law, to examine a foreign company's books and records, and take testimony concerning any transaction. Under current law, the I.R.S. is subject to a three-year statute of limitations, which can be waived by the taxpayer.
 
Broad Underpayments Seen
The Ways and Means panel estimates that the measure would produce $1 billion in revenues over five years. But an I.R.S. official said suspected underpayments, in returns now under review, amounted to at least $12 billion.
Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said the measure was intended to end ''a U.S. tax holiday for foreign competitors.''
The Missouri Democrat said foreign auto makers in the United States paid a total of $12 million in taxes on $7.7 billion in total receipts in 1986.
A Treasury Department spokesman said that ''our attorneys and economists are looking at the bill,'' and that the agency had no comment.
Bradley Larschan, secretary of the Association for International Investment, which represents 25 American subsidiaries of foreign companies, called the proposed bill ''discriminatory against foreign investors.''
''We don't think it's clear that foreign investors don't pay their taxes,'' he said. ''These responses are not based on thorough or detailed studies, and would discourage foreigners from investing in the U.S. at a time when the U.S. needs to continue to attract foreign investment.''
Michael Patton, a tax lawyer who represents foreign clients, said: ''What is really harsh about this provision is that a case could be 10 years old, and a company could have had no notice about what kind of records it should keep. Companies shouldn't be penalized for not keeping records that they weren't told they should have kept in the first place.''
An aide to the Ways and Means Committee said that a foreign company would not be penalized for failing to have a document it was not previously required to have, but that the I.R.S. would have access to all available documents.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
The Search for a Cleaner Way to Make Steel

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
For years, steel industry executives have voiced a need for a way to produce steel without using air-polluting ovens that convert coal into the fuel known as coke to heat the blast furnaces. But the issue has taken on new urgency now that Senate leaders and the White House have agreed, in clean-air legislation, to retain a deadline of 1995 for steelmakers to install stringent anti-pollution technology.
Steel companies in the United States and abroad are taking different tacks in developing processes that are not only cleaner but also more energy-efficient.
Steel is currently made in an energy-intensive, three-step process. First, coal is heated in a tall, narrow oven sealed to keep out oxygen. The process drives out a variety of chemical byproducts in coal, primarily benzene, and produces red-hot coke, nearly all carbon, that burns more efficiently and at a far higher temperature than coal. 
Then the coke is fed into a blast furnace in which iron ore is reduced to almost pure molten iron. In the third step, the iron is dumped into an oxygen furnace and combined with a small portion of scrap steel. Oxygen is injected to raise the temperature to burn out unwanted elements, producing molten steel.
The major environmental problem in the steelmaking process comes from gases - primarily benzene and ammonia - that escape during the coke-making process and when the doors to the coke ovens are opened. (Most of the gases are trapped and the chemicals are recovered for other uses.) The problem worsens as coke ovens age and the seals around the doors wear down.
The American Iron and Steel Institute, an association of the nation's major steel companies, in conjunction with the Department of Energy, is researching and developing a ''direct'' steelmaking process that would combine the functions of the three-step process into one and eliminate the dirty coke-making step by using coal as the basic fuel. In the process being developed, iron ore and coal would be heated in a single vessel into which oxygen would be blown. Out of that would flow liquid iron. Sulfur and carbon would then be removed from the iron ore, producing steel.
The experimental process would be cleaner and more energy efficient because the process of converting coal into coke would be eliminated.
But the process faces a number of problems. Foremost is the corrosive liquids produced in a one-step process.
''The major challenge is to produce refractory materials that will withstand the attack from the corrosive liquids,'' said Brian E. Aranha, a manufacturing and technology fellow with the American Iron and Steel Institute. ''It's never been tried before.''
Moreover, steel executives said, it will be a long time before the system can produce steel on a large scale. ''Coke is an essential ingredient to integrated steelmaking and coke will be needed well into the next century,'' said Walter F. Williams, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
 
Feasibility Being Determined
Steel industry engineers are now determining the economic feasibility of the process. ''If we get full success out of the pilot process, we would move to a semi-commercial production by 1996 and a finished product by 2004,'' said Ian F. Hughes, vice president of technology for the Inland Steel Company. ''If we succeed at that, we would be doing brilliantly.''
Steel company executives therefore complain that the present clean-air legislation is too harsh and would result in a shutdown of more than 80 percent of the nation's coke ovens. (A small minority are new enough and far enough from populated areas to meet the requirements.) Meanwhile, 44 alternative processes are being studied around the world to reduce dependence on coke ovens, according to a study by the University of Salford in England. The processes fall largely into two categories: those based on burning coal rather than converting coal to coke and burning the coke, and those that use significant amounts of electricity to create heat for the steelmaking process.
One gaining attention internationally is a two-step process called Corex now being demonstrated in South Africa by a consortium of steel companies led by Voest Alpine of Austria. Under this system, no coke is used. Instead, a blast furnace fueled by coal melts iron ore, producing molten iron. The molten iron then goes through a process similar to the oxygen furnace in conventional steel plants.
 
'Operating Very Well'
The plant ''is operating very well so far,'' said a spokesman for Voest Alpine. It has a capacity of 300,000 tons and has begun production. The spokesman said annual capacity could be increased to 500,000 tons. The plant is not only cleaner but also consumes less energy than a conventional steel plant, he said.
Other systems based on use of coal rather than coke are being developed by Krupp & Klockner of West Germany, Kobe Steel of Japan and British Steel.
Also being studied are several electricity-based processes that use coal for the initial reduction of iron ore and then electricity to provide the heat for the final melting. Many experts consider those projects less efficient on a large scale because of the large amount of power they require.
Many steel industry experts say processes like the two-step Corex technique would be easier to perfect over the short term than the one being studied by the American team. ''The Americans are just not serious players at this stage,'' said Jonathan Aylen, a professor of economics at the University of Salford. ''There are processes that already are working on a pilot scale.''
The problem of emissions is more serious in the United States, Mr. Aylen said, because the average coke oven is older than those in most other countries.
''The typical coke oven in South Korea was built in the 1980's,'' Mr. Aylen said. ''The typical coke oven in Japan dates from the 1970's. And in Europe it dates from the late 1960's. The typical American blast furnace, we don't know, because they are so old. Many are Second World War construction.''
Mr. Williams of Bethlehem Steel said that the average coke oven in the United States was about 30 years old and that coke ovens had frequently been refurbished to reduce emissions.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Up Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices moved sharply higher in a volatile session yesterday, as traders gave more weight to rumors of significant Japanese purchases of zero-coupon Treasury bonds than to economic reports that suggested inflation was still a problem.
The Government reports on consumer prices and merchandise trade were not in line with market expectations, and traders reacted by selling securities early in the session.
But the selling stopped abruptly after talk about big Japanese purchases began to develop.
Talk about the Japanese centered on rumors that in the run-up to March 31, the end of their fiscal year, big Japanese institutions have been selling out money-losing positions in Japanese government bonds and offsetting those losses by purchasing large quantities of zero-coupon Treasury bonds. There were also rumors that a big Japanese institution had reallocated assets out of Japanese stocks into Treasury bonds. 
Because zero-coupon bonds do not pay periodic interest, the issues trade at a deep discount. They are redeemed at 100, or par, when held to maturity.
By selling the Japanese bonds, which have tumbled in value since the start of the year, and buying the zero-coupon issues, Japanese institutions are ''taking a loss but not showing it,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc., because they would avoid having to report the loss in the Japanese securities on their year-end balance sheets.
''Much to my chagrin, we have done none of that business,'' Mr. Brachfeld added. ''But I know that an enormous amount of zeros have been sold to Japan in the last month or so.''
 
Japanese Financial Markets
Japanese financial markets were fairly stable yesterday after the Bank of Japan raised its discount rate by a full percentage point, to 5.25 percent.
The move, which had been widely forecast, did not provide much immediate support for the Japanese yen, which remained weak against the dollar yesterday.
Indeed, some credit market participants said the dollar's strength provided additional underpinning for the bond market yesterday.
A strong dollar helps to blunt inflationary pressures. Because inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities, it is reviled in the bond market.
However, a more direct inflation indicator, the Consumer Price Index, was less encouraging. It showed prices rose by half a percent in February, well down from the energy and food-related spurt of 1.1 percent in January.
 
Jump in Apparel Prices
A big jump in apparel prices had much to do with last month's increase, but a number of analysts said they were not encouraged.
The inflation report was ''basically bearish for the credit markets,'' said Rudolf Thunberg, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn.
Excluding food and energy prices, ''consumer prices have risen at an annual rate of close to 7 percent over the past two months,'' Mr. Thunberg added.
''That is excessive by any standards and is higher than the first two months of last year,'' he said. ''It is not imminent, but if these trends continue, I would expect the next move in monetary policy by the Fed to be towards tightening.''
That possibility was seen only briefly in the bond market yesterday.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100 17/32, up 7/8 point, to yield 8.45 percent, down from 8.53 the day before. The late price was a full 1 1/2 points above the bellwether issue's low price for the day.
Price movement among Treasury note issues was considerably more subdued.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 26/32, up 1/4 point, to yield 8.52 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 18/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.59 percent.
Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.94 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills were unchanged at an offered rate of 7.90 percent.
Elsewhere, new issue activity in the corporate bond market remained strong yesterday. On Monday four issuers priced just over $1 billion worth of securities.
Among the issuers yesterday was the McDonald's Corporation, which priced $100 million worth of seven-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 3/8 percent notes, which mature March 15, 1997, were priced at $99.918, to yield 9.39 percent, 75 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 percent Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for five years, is rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Prudential-Bache Securities acted as lead manager for a Bank of New York offering of $100 million worth of floating rate deposit notes.
The notes, which mature Aug. 27, 1991, were priced at 100. The interest rate on the notes, which floats weekly, will be the bond-equivalent yield on three-month Treasury bills plus 82 basis points. The first rate will be set on March 27.
The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Despite the recent flood of new issues, participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that demand for securities had been picking up. Prices of most intermediate issues rose by about 3/8 point, while long-term bonds were up by as much as 7/8 point.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds was less robust. Traders said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/4 point on the day.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Central Banks' Intervention Fails to Halt Soaring Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar soared higher in heavy trading yesterday, helped by profit taking in West German marks and in the Japanese yen.
Intervention by several central banks aimed at shoring up the sagging yen failed to alter the dollar's course. The banks reportedly sold dollars on world foreign exchange markets and bought yen. 
Speculation that United States interest rates would not decline soon, which grew when the Government reported an unexpectedly strong inflation rate for February, also encouraged dollar buying.
Currency dealers in the United States described trading in dollars as brisk. They said the Federal Reserve sold dollars against the yen after similar moves by its counterparts in Europe.
''We had a nice rally in the dollar,'' said John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York.
 
Momentum From Marks
Mr. McCarthy said most of the momentum for the dollar's broad advance came from sales of marks to collect profits amassed during the currency's recent climb.
Traders had scrambled to buy marks before Sunday's East German elections and bought more on Monday when the results indicated a faster move toward a unified Germany. But as the euphoria eased over the outcome of the voting, traders lightened their mark holdings.
As trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.7048 marks, up from 1.6860 late Monday.
The Japanese yen suffered despite an increase in a key lending rate. Dealers said the one percentage point rise in Japan's discount rate, to 5.25 percent, failed to evoke a favorable response because the move had been widely anticipated.
One dollar bought 154.20 yen late in New York, compared with 153.05 yen late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 153.65 yen, from 153.55 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 153.85 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Monday, included: 1.5225 Swiss francs, up from 1.5085; 5.7575 French francs, up from 5.7025; 1,258.00 Italian lire, up from 1,246.75, and 1.17765 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18225.
Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday's late levels, were: 1.6965 West German marks, up from 1.6829; 1.5157 Swiss francs, up from 1.5085; 5.7340 French francs, up from 5.6895; 1.9107 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8970; 1,253.50 Italian lire, up from 1,244.25, and 1.1792 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1836.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Fall, With Gold Leading the Way

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Precious metal prices plunged yesterday as the dollar advanced against most leading foreign currencies. A sharp rise in Japanese interest rates also made platinum, gold and silver more expensive to buy in that nation, which has become a major consumer as well as dealer in precious metals.
Gold prices opened weaker in Japan and Europe, but the heaviest selling came later in New York. At the close of the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot March gold delivery settled at $392.20 an ounce, down $8.50 on the day. Comex spot silver lost 5.8 cents an ounce, at $5.043. 
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the spot March platinum contract settled at $490.80 an ounce, down $8.50.
 
Japanese Didn't Sell, Didn't Buy
The strength of the dollar more than anything else knocked gold down, and the silver and platinum markets followed suit,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''While the Japanese did not sell metal in response to the one-point rise in their discount rate to 5.25 percent, the continued weakness of their stock market and the yen, they didn't buy, either.''
One reason, she said, was that the Japanese fiscal year ends March 31. Toward the end of March Japanese investment managers tend to be less aggressive in the marketplace and more preoccupied with balancing accounts and planning for the coming fiscal year.
With the value of the yen falling and interest rates rising, it is now more expensive for Japanese consumers to buy precious metals, or for dealers to import metal and finance inventories, Ms. Raptopoulos noted.
Precious metals are traded in dollars. Thus foreign buyers must first acquire dollars to buy bullion. The recent rise in the dollar's value against the yen and most other currencies has raised costs substantially for Japanese and other foreign metals importers.
Frederick R. Demler, minerals economist at Paine Webber Inc., said: ''The rise in Japanese interest rates could benefit the precious metals market globally if it caused similar moves in domestic interest rates, but we don't see this happening at this time. Investors in precious metals are also unsettled by the recent drop in oil prices, which were supposed to rise and help reignite inflation.''

HEADLINE: Even as U.S. Fights for Entry, Some Companies Quit Japan

SERIES: Struggling in Japan; U.S. Companies That Pull Back - Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 21

 BODY:
For nearly two decades Avon Products Inc. was one of America's biggest success stories here, a company that spent years tailoring its products for Japanese women and learning how to outsmart a distribution system that has defeated many foreign companies. It paid off: Last year Avon reaped a quarter of its corporate profits in Japan, even though the country accounts for less than a tenth of its sales.
But last year was also Avon's last in Japan. A few weeks ago, worried about takeover rumors and a $1.1 billion debt at home, the company sold its Japanese subsidiary to a little-known Japanese company for $408 million, in the midst of a Japanese consumer spending binge.
Avon is only the latest, if the most dramatic, instance of American companies that are cashing in their Japanese holdings. At a time when the United States is complaining that it is still far too difficult for American companies to crack the Japanese market, a steady stream of those already here are abandoning or reducing their stakes. 
Like Avon, many of them have succeeded here, making a profit or obtaining technology from Japanese partners. But almost all of them are in need of quick cash. And even after the recent fall in the Tokyo stock market, they view selling their Japanese holdings as a quick solution. The decision to pull back is also often influenced by the high cost of trying to expand their business in Japan.
 
An Extensive Roster
The list of such companies now extends to Chrysler, General Motors, CBS, Honeywell and Shaklee, among others. As in Avon's case, the sale of their assets or stakes in Japanese joint ventures was often greeted warmly on Wall Street.
But what makes sense to American investors is often read very differently in Japan, where such sales seem to speak of a lack of corporate commitment. Many Japanese business leaders say the sales prove that American companies are not really dedicated to becoming powerful forces in the world's second-largest economy and that they will often opt for a short-term profit over the long-term benefits of having an established business here.
American trade negotiators say the accelerating pace of the selloffs is beginning to undermine the United States' efforts to encourage Japan to let foreigners in at a faster pace. That fight has been forcefully pressed by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman and financier, who has become the largest shareholder in a Japanese maker of auto parts, the Koito Manufacturing Company, but so far has not been granted a seat on its board.
The American selloffs come at a bad time for Washington. ''How am I supposed to explain this to the Japanese?'' an American official involved in the trade negotiating process asked the other day. ''Am I supposed to simply say that Akio Morita is right?'' Mr. Morita, the chairman of the Sony Corporation, has been a leading critic of American business managers, saying they ''can only see 10 minutes ahead.''
No exact figures are available on the sale of American stakes in subsidiaries or joint ventures in Japan, though investment bankers and others estimate that in the last year more than $2 billion in assets other than real estate have been sold, often to Japanese partners.
 
Foreign Investment Growing
Moreover, the pullback from Japan comes as American companies are generally increasing their investment abroad. The amount of foreign direct investment worldwide by American manufacturing companies increased 20 percent last year, according to a survey by the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research group.
To be sure, Japan remains a lucrative market for many American companies and the United States remains the largest foreign investor in Japan. For their part, European companies have been investing heavily, beginning a large number of joint ventures or setting up retailing networks in Japan.
If the American experience holds, making those ventures profitable may take anywhere from 5 to 10 years. But once they are established, according to figures collected by the Ministry of Trade and Industry, foreign companies here are often more profitable than their parents or their Japanese competitors. Nonetheless, the expense of gaining additional market share in Japan, combined with the value of land assets here, often make a sale irresistible.
''You can make a very good financial argument for leaving,'' said John Colby, the Japan-based partner for the Blackstone Group, a New York investment banking firm. ''There is a time to take profits. But from a national policy point of view, it is exceptionally shortsighted.''
 
Cutback by Chrysler
One of the largest sales so far was done last year by the Chrysler Corporation, which sold half of its 24 percent holding in its Japanese partner, Mitsubishi Motors Company, in time to bolster Chrysler's third-quarter earnings. Officially, both companies say the sale had no effect on their relationship. Mitsubishi still supplies Chrysler with engines and with Mitsubishi-made cars that are sold under the Chrysler label. The companies also produce automobiles together at Diamond-Star Motors, a joint-venture plant in the United States.
But inside Mitsubishi's headquarters here, visitors are left with the clear impression that Chrysler's sale will not be quickly forgiven. ''It was not a totally welcomed thing,'' Toyoo Tate, the chairman of Mitsubishi Motors, said in an interview.
Chrysler, Mr. Tate said, ''has been doing its best to stay above water, and we have high hopes that the effort will succeed.''
''I don't like to think that they would reduce their stake any more,'' he said, ''and they have not brought the subject up.''
Analysts, however, have been continually speculating about the sale of Chrysler's remaining shares, especially if Chrysler's financial difficulties worsen.
Mitsubishi executives say the stock sale, together with Chrysler's halting efforts to sell its own cars here - it sold fewer than 1,000 vehicles in Japan last year - has convinced them that Chrysler is not the right partner. That may help explain Mitsubishi's eagerness to join with Daimler-Benz, maker of the Mercedes-Benz, as part of a broader arrangement between the top four Mitsubishi companies and Daimler announced earlier this month.
 
G.M. Trims Its Stake
Soon after Chrysler's sale, General Motors sold some of its shares in Isuzu Motors, reducing its stake from 40 percent, to 38 percent. But G.M. says the move was not intended as a signal. ''I'm quite sure it doesn't mean anything,'' said Richard R. Johnson, general manager of the Japan branch of General Motors Overseas Corporation. G.M., he said, still relies on Isuzu for research.
Automobile analysts, however, note that Isuzu is losing strength in the Japanese market and speculate openly about whether G.M. will further reduce its stake.
But typically it is problems at home, not in Tokyo, that cause American companies to sell their stake. The Shaklee Corporation, a direct-sales distributor of vitamins, cosmetics and household products, sold its Japanese unit to Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical Company when Shaklee was trying to forestall a takeover. When that strategy appeared doomed, the American parent company agreed to be bought by Yamanouchi.
In some cases, the sale of a stake in Japan has deprived an American company of huge profits later on. CBS sold its stake in CBS/Sony, a joint venture to produce compact disks and records for the Japanese market, when Sony purchased the American-based CBS Records. Since then, sales of CBS/Sony, along with those of CBS Records, have soared, riding a boom in consumer spending, especially among young Japanese women.
 
Profits for Avon
Some analysts and cosmetics industry executives predict that the same may happen to Avon. In 1989, Avon Japan posted $285 million in sales, giving it about 4 percent of the Japanese cosmetics market. But the high price of cosmetics here - and Avon's use of Japanese ''office ladies'' and housewives to create a direct-sales network that circumvented the country's expensive and multi-layered distributors - generated $15.3 million in profits.
At a meeting with analysts recently, James E. Preston, Avon's chairman and chief executive, insisted that despite the profits, the Japanese market was now mature and it was time to move on. The company, he said, had three choices: ''We could invest heavily to try to increase share in the face of some tough competition, we could make no new investment there and face erosion in both market share and profit margins, or we could sell to a Japanese company that could make the investments.''
Avon chose to sell, and after a flurry of bids from Japanese companies eager for access to a nationwide network of Avon sales representatives, the winner was the Friends of Freesia Company, a direct-mail company that plans to offer its own household products along with cosmetics.
Avon will continue to receive royalties from the sale of its products. But the long-term cost of its departure, many business experts here believe, will be high. The company will no longer pit its best cosmetics research directly against that of Shiseido and Kanebo, the giant Japanese cosmetics makers that are quickly expanding abroad.
 
Mature Market Is Seen
And with more and more Japanese consumers buying through direct mail and freelance salespeople, Avon may be cutting itself out of a market on the verge of explosion.

HEADLINE: Bamboo Coaxed to Flower in Lab; Global Impact on the Crop Is Seen

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
In a significant advance for the cultivation of one of the world's most important timber and fodder crops, scientists say they have coaxed bamboo plants to flower in the laboratory, a feat never before managed. Bamboo in the field can take more than a century to flower and produce seeds.
The new technique will allow botanists to breed a better version of a plant that has undergirded the economies and cultures of Asia and many tropical nations for hundreds or even thousands of years. And it should allow faster replacement of depleted bamboo forests that are vitally needed. 
''This is a spectacular success for the breeding of bamboo,'' said David Hanke, a botanist at the University of Cambridge and the author of an editorial that accompanied the report being published today in the journal Nature. ''It's a breakthrough that could have real significance for a quarter of the world's population.''
 
A Construction Staple
In many Western nations, bamboo is viewed largely as ornamental foliage. But in China, India, Japan, Malaysia, parts of Latin America and other regions where bamboo is abundant, it provides a vital source of lightweight, rot-resistant wood for houses, smaller public buildings, furniture and even the scaffolding that is used in the building of skyscrapers and supertankers.
Bamboo reeds are crafted into musical instruments, artists' tools, baskets and domestic goods of all kinds. They are pulverized for paper pulp. With four times the protein of other fodder grasses, bamboo hay is a dietary staple for livestock.
''In those regions where bamboo is common, the plant is a godsend,'' said Beecher Crampton, professor emeritus of agronomy at the University of California at Davis. ''It's hard to overstate its importance.''
The new technique should allow botanists to fashion novel hybrids of bamboo that will grow faster, resist diseases and yield a stronger, more versatile wood. Botanists say the technique could allow rapid reforestation of regions where bamboo stands have been depleted or devastated, either through human encroachment or as a result of the natural mass dying cycle that all bamboo forests undergo.
 
More Panda Food
Beyond its economic value, botanists say, the ability to hasten forest regeneration may benefit the endangered giant panda, which feeds on the reedy plant in the fast-diminishing bamboo wilderness of northeast China.
Scientists estimate that there are more than 500 species of bamboo in the warmer regions of the world. The most spectacular examples of the plant, a member of the grass family, are found at the southern and southeastern edges of Asia, where lush yet delicate canopies of bamboo reach heights of 130 feet.
But the quirks of bamboo reproduction have made the plant almost impossible to cultivate or to improve selectively. Most species flower and produce seeds only once in their lifetimes, after growing between 12 and 120 years, the longest generation time over all in the plant kingdom. A forest of bamboo usually flowers simultaneously, a phenomenon called masting. And shortly after flowering, the forest dies en masse, often within a single season. Left behind is a blanket of seeds that can be 20 to 30 inches deep, setting the stage for new forest growth.
Before flowering and perishing, a bamboo tree can also reproduce asexually, by sending up underground shoots, known as rhizomes, which are genetic clones of itself. Many bamboo forests consist largely of trees born of such shoots, and in China, rhizomes are planted to produce bamboo stands that can be harvested.
 
Plants Outlast Researchers
But neither of the bamboo's reproductive methods allows for standard agricultural manipulations. Because the normal seed generation time is so long, botanists in the past have been unable to mix together the genes of different plants and to cull superior offspring; a researcher may reach retirement age long before the bamboo in the lab has reached its moment of flowering. Nor can the seedless clonal rhizomes be used to breed new hybrids.
To solve the problem, A. F. Mascarenhas and two colleagues at the National Chemical Laboratory in Pune, India, devised a test-tube cocktail that spurs young bamboo plants to flower prematurely. The researchers suspended tiny cuttings of two species of bamboo, Bambusa arundinacea and Dendrocalamus brandisii, in a test tube, and added a culture medium enriched with plant growth hormones, coconut milk and other nutrients. After several weeks and two more applications of the broth, the bamboo slips, measuring only a few inches in length, began sprouting flowers half an inch or so in diameter, the size of adult blossoms.
Under natural conditions, botanists said, the two bamboo species in the experiment would not flower until they were about 30 years of age and 30 to 60 feet tall.
''It's very impressive that they've gotten the shoots to flower before they have any vegetative body to speak of,'' said Richard Howard, vice president for botanical science at the New York Botanical Garden.
 
A Little Luck
It is not yet clear why the brew of hormones and milk encouraged precocious blooming. In the past, coconut milk has been found to have powerful and diverse effects on other plants. ''It's like cookery,'' said Dr. Hanke. ''There's a great deal of empiricism and blind luck in this business.''
So well did the technique work that 60 percent of the approximately 200 coddled shoots propagated healthy-looking seeds about two weeks later, a success rate that botanists say is astonishing. The seeds have yet to be planted in soil and allowed to grow, but experts expect them to be viable.
With the method, the botanists can begin trying to cross the two bamboo species to see what new hybrid appears. Should the crossings succeed, the scientists expect to cultivate other bamboo species in the lab and try more combinations.
They can also begin inserting foreign genes, like genes for disease resistance, into bamboo cells, thereby ushering the versatile bamboo, among the most venerable of plants, into the horticultural future.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Journal;
Is the Skyscraper Looking Daggers at Neighbors?

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 21

 BODY:
The Bank of China moved this week into its new Hong Kong headquarters, a spectacular glass tower designed by I. M. Pei and already heralded as one of the most distinctive buildings in the world.
But Chinese officials here marked the occasion with nothing more than a small newspaper advertisement that announced the move and declared, ''No ceremony will be performed.''
For a building fraught with symbolism for both Hong Kong and China, the soaring skyscraper has opened ''with just a whisper,'' as a foreign diplomat here noted, Paradoxically, the glittering glass tower Mr. Pei built to capture the spirit of the new liberalism of China has been completed just as that country is undertaking a forced march back to old-style orthodox Communism.
 
A Metaphor for Bamboo
''The building was meant to celebrate the modernization of China, and to me it still does,'' Mr. Pei said in an interview here on Tuesday. 
The Canton-born American architect, here to receive an honorary degree from Hong Kong University, said the sectioned building, which tapers as it rises, is a metaphor for bamboo. ''In China, there is a saying that like a bamboo you advance with every stage of growth, meaning you rise to meet challenges.''
The 70-story, 1,209-foot tower, the tallest building in the world outside the United States, rises from the central business district, dominating the skyline in much the way China is expected to dominate life here when it resumes control of this British colony in 1997.
From the beginning in 1982, when the British sold China's state bank a prime building site for millions less than its market value, the tower project has been the focus of fear and speculation. Labor shortages, a problem with the foundation and material difficulties delayed the completion of the $130 million building by more than a year.
 
Some Startling Rumors
At one point, Hong Kong was abuzz with rumors that the tower was sinking and that to accommodate its weak foundation several stories would have to be lopped off.
''The rumors about the building sinking were very strong,'' said Jeffrey Q. Finney, of Knight Frank Kan & Baillieu , which leases space in the tower. ''Then of course there were the rumors about the two poles on the top of the building being special towers to broadcast propaganda or secret spy messages. They aren't.''
Mr. Pei said the poles were simply a finishing flourish to mark the end of the building.
If residents worried about the poles, they have worried even more that the triangles that give the building its distinctive design are bad ''fung shui.''
Hong Kong Chinese are serious about fung shui, the ancient art of arranging buildings and other objects so they are in harmony with nature and bring good luck. Many fung shui experts say the sharp angles of the tower are like dangerous daggers pointed at businesses and homes in the area. Small mirrors have been placed in the windows of surrounding buildings to deflect the evil that is supposed to emanate from the bank.
 
The Angles Explained
Neither the bank nor Mr. Pei consulted a fung shui expert, but Mr. Finney said every business that has moved in has brought in its own experts. ''We're hearing that the overall fung shui inside the building is good,'' he said. ''It's just the people outside the building who have to worry.''
Mr. Pei explained his controversial angles, saying that ''the three-dimentional triangulation in the building has never been done before, and by using this design we transfer all vertical stress to the four corners of the building, making it very stable and wind resistant.''
Rents in the Bank of China are 10 to 20 percent below market price, and other property managers said one reason, aside from fierce competition in a sagging property market, is that the floors inside are strangely shaped, ending in points and angles. ''It looks grand on the outside, but it's hopeless inside,'' an agent said.
Mr. Pei said that while the floors were irregular, ''in an office building what you really rent are windows, and this building has windows and views everywhere.''
He said he designed such a tall structure because building up on the small piece of land was the only way to maximize the space available. But, he said with a grin, ''The second reason the building got higher is that anything less would not be seen.''
 
A Run on the Bank
In Hong Kong, business always takes precedence over pleasure and politics. And Mr. Finney said that companies did not shy away from China's bank building, even when China shocked the world by using guns and tanks on peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing last June, an event Mr. Pei called ''an absolute tragedy.''
''We had three tenants back out after June 4, but for business, not political reasons,'' Mr. Finney said. ''Here it's a question of value for money and what's makes business sense.''
Emotions were high last June, and Hong Kong Chinese, stunned and angered by the military crackdown, staged a run on Bank of China offices in the colony, emptying the cash machines in hours and then lining up to withdraw their money. Liberal political leaders here were finally forced to ask residents to stop their withdrawals as the entire colonial banking system was in danger.
There has been speculation that China may now be a bit embarrassed by this quintessentially Western skyscraper commissioned in the mid-1980's when the country was eagerly embarking upon economic and political changes.
Robert Broadfoot, director of the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy, does not agree. ''The building is big and tall,'' he said. ''It dominates; it declares China's sovereignty. I think they love it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Bank of China headquarters in Hong Kong, at 1,209 feet, is the tallest building in the world outside the United States. The I. M. Pei design has been heralded as one of the most distinctive in the world. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Taiwan President Re-elected; He Meets Protesters

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 21

 BODY:
President Lee Teng-hui was re-elected today by an overwhelming majority of Taiwan's National Assembly delegates, some escorted to the ballot boxes in wheelchairs, and then promptly met with student demonstrators to discuss their demands for greater democracy.
The 67-year-old, American-educated Mr. Lee is the first native Taiwanese to be elected President. Mr. Lee, previously Vice President, automatically became President two years ago upon the death of his predecessor, Chiang Ching-kuo, the son of the former Nationalist leader, Chiang Kai-shek.
In recent weeks there was intensive jockeying for power in the National Assembly, which elects the President, but Mr. Lee's only challenger withdrew a few days ago. Thus, running unopposed, he received 641 votes, about 95 percent of those cast. The remaining ballots were invalid or blank. 
While Taiwan has taken steps toward democracy in recent years, and held multiparty legislative elections in December, the President is still chosen by the 752-member National Assembly.
Most of the Assembly members are in their 80's and 90's and were chosen on the China mainland before fleeing to Taiwan with Chiang Kai-shek. These aged delegates, some of whom were too frail to vote, have been at the center of one of the island's most highly charged debates over the election process.
The overwhelming vote for re-election by the National Assembly appeared to be a sign of unity among the elderly delegates who had until recently appeared divided in their support of Mr. Lee.
''I think he will become more powerful,'' said Chang Chungtung, a professor at National Taiwan University. ''He can do more with this new mandate to reduce pressure from other areas.''
Thousands of student demonstrators and a small number of hunger strikers continued their protests in Chiang Kai-shek Square in central Taipei today and pressed their demands for broader and faster changes in Taiwan's political system.
Mr. Lee pledged in a statement to work for constitutional democracy, economic progress, social order and stability.
This evening, he met for about an hour with 50 student representatives at the presidential palace and appeared to agree to their demands, students said.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Lee announced that he would convene a conference in the end of June that would enable opposition party members, scholars, legislators and business people to discuss national issues like constitutional changes and policy toward the Chinese mainland. This was one of the demands of the students.
One topic of the conference is likely to be the dissolution of the National Assembly and the growing demand for the presidency to be directly elected by the population at large.
As university students danced in the rain and huddled together under plastic ponchos late into the night, representatives were divided on whether to retreat from the square or to remain longer, students said. Although Mr. Lee agreed to do his best to fulfill their requests, some of their demands will be difficult to meet any time soon because they would involve modifications to the Constitution.
Students and members of the opposition party, the Democratic Progressive Party, denounced the election, saying it did not represent the wishes of the people.
''This election was ridiculous,'' said Qi Weinen, a 24-year-old student representative from Furen University. ''We want the old representatives to retire as soon as possible. We can't put up with them any longer.''
At dawn today, about 200 members of the Democratic Progressive Party and their supporters gathered to protest the election, but they were prevented by riot policemen from approaching the National Assembly voting hall. Instead, they confronted elderly delegates on their way to the hall, and smashed the car windows of two delegates.
The 11 opposition members in the National Assembly were barred from voting because they refused to pledge allegiance to the Nationalist Goverment.

HEADLINE: El Salvador and Rebels Reportedly Agree to Talks

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, March 21

 BODY:
The Salvadoran Government and the leftist guerrillas have agreed to begin talks and to a tentative time frame for signing a peace treaty, senior Government officials said today.
An official said the ''continuous and uninterrupted'' talks are to begin next month and are expected to lead to an agreement by the fall under which the guerrillas would start incorporating themselves into the political process.
''We're very optimistic,'' said a senior official, who was speaking with the direct authorization of President Alfredo Cristiani. ''This is a major breakthrough.'' Officials said that in a major concession to the rebels, Mr. Cristiani himself would lead the Government negotiating team. 
In a news conference late this afternoon, the Minister of Information, Mauricio Sandoval, announced what he described as major progress in behind-the-scenes negotiations intended to lead to the first direct talks since the rebels staged a nationwide offensive last November.
''The Government is ready to immediately reinitiate the dialogue without any precondition,'' he said. He added that the Cristiani administration hoped the rebels would ''respond to the Salvadoran people, who are clamoring for the reinitiation of the dialogue process.''
But Mr. Sandoval stopped short of formally declaring an agreement to resume negotiations, apparently to avoid breaking an understanding under which Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General of the United Nations, will announce the renewal of talks, Cristiani administration officials said.
The leaders of the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front were not at their Mexico City offices and were not available to comment on the Government's announcement. But in recent days they have repeatedly suggested that they are ready to make more concessions and close to completing arrangements for negotiations.
An aide to President Cristiani said the two sides had not agreed on a date or a location for the negotiations. But he said that that was not a major issue and that the talks would be held in a nearby Latin American capital, apparently a concession by the rebels, who wanted to hold them in New York.
Presidential aides said the talks were intended to enable the guerrillas to take part in municipal and legislative elections next March. The Government, the aides said, has set September as the deadline for concluding a treaty to give the rebels time to transform their army and civilian network into a political operation able to enter the electoral process next January. Concessions have been made on both sides to reach what appears to be the broadest and most complete agreement since the beginning of the civil war.
The talks will have an open agenda, presidential aides said. They said that unlike previous meetings, which were intermittent and little more than a forum for exchanging views, the new negotiations would be ''continuous'' and intended, for the first time, to reach an agreement.
The revival of talks in large part stems from growing pressure by the United States, the financier of the Salvadoran Government, the country's economic desperation and a nationwide longing for peace. The decision to renew talks also reflects a realization by a number of leaders on both sides that neither the Government nor the guerrillas can win an outright military victory.
Government officials said President Cristiani was convinced he had the political capital to overcome any opposition to negotiations among hard-liners in the military and in the governing party, which was founded a decade ago as a paramilitary group dedicated to fighting Communism.
Many right-wing extremists have sharpened their opposition to talks, saying that the defeat of the rebels' Sandinista allies in Nicaraguan elections last month will inevitably lead to the guerrillas' demise. But the President, an aide said, recognizes the guerrillas' strong base here and their ability to survive as an insurgent army even without Nicaraguan Government support.

HEADLINE: Mandela Chides Baker on Talking With de Klerk, but Praises U.S.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINDHOEK, Namibia, March 21

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela scolded Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today for scheduling a meeting with President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa on Thursday, saying that such an encounter would only enhance Mr. de Klerk's stature before he had done anything serious to dismantle apartheid.
With Mr. Baker standing by his side, Mr. Mandela cushioned his public criticism with warm praise for American efforts to combat white minority rule in South Africa, emphasizing that he regarded ''Mr. Baker, the American Government, the Congress and the people of America as true friends.''
The 35-minute meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr. Mandela today was the first high-level contact ever between a United States official and the black nationalist leader, who was freed last month after 27 1/2 years in prison.
 
From Very Different Worlds
While there were obvious disagreements over how to bring about nonracial democracy in South Africa, both sides seemed anxious that their first meeting be seen to succeed. Each man seemed to take the other's measure and walk away from the session relieved that it went off without serious acrimony and convinced that they can and will do business together in the future. 
Mr. Baker, scion of a Texas banking family, and Mr. Mandela, a lifelong fighter for black majority rule in South Africa, could not come from more different worlds. From the moment the two men shook hands, Mr. Mandela, who is 72 years old, seemed to be in command of the whole scene. But then he has dominated the whole Namibian independence celebration, garnering far more press attention than Namibia's new President, Sam Nujoma.
After the two men met, Mr. Mandela was asked for his views on Mr. Baker's decision to visit Cape Town on Thursday to meet with President de Klerk. Mr. Mandela himself refused to meet Mr. Baker on South African soil.
 
'Regrettable.' He Says
Mr. Mandela said: ''I will tell you. We do not think that there has been any fundamental change in the policy of the national Government. There is nothing which Mr. de Klerk has done up to now which would require a change of strategy on the part of the international community.
''And the fact that the foreign secretary of a superpower now visits Mr. de Klerk creates a great deal of confusion - specifically that the national Government has done something which requires a change of attitude on the part of the international community. We regard that as regrettable.''
The important thing to bear in mind, Mr. Mandela quickly added, ''and I hope this is what you will concentrate upon, is the fact that our discussions were dominated by the spirit of friendship that exists between the African National Congress and the American people.''
''The differences themselves will always be there,'' he said. ''Although we don't agree with the Secretary of State, we understand his position.''
Mr. Baker listened with a blank expression, but had a response that gently suggested that Mr. Mandela was playing to his domestic audience.
Mr. Baker observed that while Mr. Mandela and his colleagues in the African National Congress opposed Mr. Baker's visit with Mr. de Klerk, they were nevertheless cooperating by allowing their supporters in South Africa to meet with the Secretary of State and receive him in the black township of Soweto. As long as Mr. de Klerk continues moving forward on negotiations for a nonracial democracy in South Africa, Mr. Baker said, the Bush Administration feels it is important to encourage him directly.
''Let me simply say,'' Mr. Baker said, ''that Mr. Mandela and his colleagues here have been very generous in seeing to it that we can see their colleagues when we go to South Africa, and for that we are very grateful. We understand the position that he has just articulated.''
 
Efforts 'in Good Faith'
Mr. Baker said the Administration felt that the de Klerk Government was making efforts ''in good faith to move the process forward in South Africa.''
''We believe that it is important to try to encourage that process to move forward,'' he said.
Last month Mr. de Klerk announced a package of changes, including Mr. Mandela's release from prison and the legalization of the African National Congress and other banned organizations.
The meeting today was originally scheduled to take place at the American Ambassador's residence in Windhoek. Five minutes before the start of the talks, an American official emerged and told reporters gathered there that Mr. Mandela had called and asked if Mr. Baker could go to his house because he had ''a very busy schedule.'' Although protocol required Mr. Mandela to come to the Secretary of State, Mr. Baker went, arriving at Mr. Mandela's villa minutes after Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union ended a session with the black leader.
 
Advice, Offered Delicately
After the meeting, a senior State Department official said Mr. Baker, as expected, brought up with Mr. Mandela his feelings that the African National Copngress leader would be well advised to abandon some of his socialist economic principles. But it was clear that he offered this advice delicately.
Mr. Baker, the official said, observed to Mr. Mandela that ''of course we are very biased, and with all of my biases and prejudices hanging out as a former Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, we think the free market model works, and we think it can work for South Africa.''
Mr. Mandela, the official said, brought up the question of American economic aid for the African National Congress. Many of the group's top leaders also attended the meeting today, including Thabo Mbeki, who is in charge of foreign affairs; Alfred Nzo, the General Secretary; Joe Slovo, the head of the South African Communist Party, and Mr. Mandela's wife, Winnie. Only Mr. Mandela spoke.
The official quoted Mr. Mandela as having said that when he goes to the United States some time in the next few months, he will be looking for money to build houses for exiled African National Congress members who are returning to South Africa. Mr. Baker did not make any promises, officials said, but he told Mr. Mandela that the Bush Administration was considering asking the National Endowment for Democracy to channel money to South Africa to support voting registration and general democratic education programs for blacks.

Mr. Mandela and Mr. Baker chatted after the meeting in Namibia, the first high-level contact between a United States official and Mr. Mandela. (Reuters)
