HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
In a Pact, Poland Opens Doors to U.S. Business

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
President Bush and the Prime Minister of Poland signed a treaty today to increase American investment in Poland. It was the first such United States agreement with one of the newly emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.
In the arrival ceremony for the Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Mr. Bush affirmed support for Poland's security, saying the Polish people had a ''fundamental right'' to live secure within their current borders. He said Poland ''must have a voice'' in any decisions affecting its future. 
Mr. Bush's statement was intended to calm Polish fears that the unification of Germany might lead to German claims on territory ceded to Poland after World War II.
''We want to see the nation of Poland achieve its full measure of democracy and independence,'' Mr. Bush declared. ''In any decisions affecting the fate of Poland, Poland must have a voice.''
 
Opening Doors to U.S. Business
Moreover, Mr. Bush said, ''We see a new Europe in which the security of all European states, and their fundamental right to exist secure within their present borders, is totally assured.''
The treaty the two leaders signed today will gradually eliminate Polish laws that restrict the ability of American businesses to transfer profits from Poland to the United States.
''We can now take this treaty to the U.S. business community and say, 'This is why you should invest in Poland,' '' Mr. Bush said.
Poland looks to private industry and foreign investment as the hope for the future of its economy, which was in ruins after decades of control by Communist officials.
The treaty gives American businesses new incentives to invest in Poland: protection against expropriation, copyright protection for computer software and guarantees that license applications will be swiftly approved. #19-Gun Salute Mr. Mazowiecki was welcomed at the White House today with a 19-gun salute, a trumpet fanfare and music by the United States Army Fife and Drum Corps.
At a signing ceremony in the Rose Garden of the White House, Mr. Bush said: ''This treaty is very important, important not only in its content but what it says about where Poland is going. It says that Poland wants U.S. investment because this investment is good for the Polish people and vital to the growth and development of the Polish economy.''
''In this treaty,'' he said, ''Poland is taking a number of very substantial steps, steps that will orient the Polish economy toward the Western economic system and toward global markets. These are courageous steps, and we applaud them.''
 
Seeking Courageous People
Mr. Mazowiecki, who was interned for a year after the martial law crackdown in 1981, took office last August as Poland's first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early years after World War II.
He said today that Poland was perhaps not prepared in every respect for the surge of economic growth that it wants and needs.
''Our telephones do not work as they should, and we have many other problems,'' he said. ''But people should not be discouraged by the problems, which are typical of this first phase. We look forward to seeing courageous people who will be willing to come and to move through this half-year of problems.''
A summary of the treaty issued by the White House said that under the agreement ''U.S. investors in Poland will be treated the same as Polish nationals or investors from other countries, whichever is more favorable.''
East and West Germany and the four major Allies of World War II - Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States - agreed in February on a framework for negotiating the unification of Germany. On March 14, the six countries agreed that Poland could have a seat at the table in any discussions of the German-Polish border.
In talks today at the White House and the State Department, Mr. Mazowiecki said that Poland should have a say on other issues affecting its security, Administration officials reported.
Raymond G. H. Seitz, the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, said it ''would really quite overstate things'' to say that there is still ''some disagreement'' between Poland and the United States about Warsaw's role in talks on the future of Germany.
Without giving details, Mr. Seitz said, ''We understand Polish concerns, and we will listen to Polish concerns and we will respond to Polish concerns in a variety of ways and in a variety of places.''

LENGTH: 505 words

HEADLINE: Budget Minuet in Albany

 BODY:
New Yorkers, confronted with a deficit-ridden state budget and a declining economy, need answers. Instead they're getting piecemeal proposals from their Governor, and little but evasion from Albany's Republican leaders.
Gov. Mario Cuomo has at last broken his frustrating silence and is dribbling out some sketchy plans for dealing with a budget deficit that's grown $1.5 billion in two months. That's far more than can be said for the Republicans. Led by Ralph Marino of Long Island, Senate Republicans don't even acknowledge the problem. 
They turn a blind eye to evidence that New York's economy suffers from the downswing that's attacking the entire Northeast. They ignore the warnings of their own State Comptroller, Edward Regan, also a Republican, and have nothing to say about the queasiness of bond rating agencies. Mr. Marino says he'll consider only spending cuts, without saying what to cut. He'd prefer to let the Democrats make the case for higher taxes, so Republicans can bash Mr. Cuomo in the coming elections. That's what passes for good politics nowadays. Mr. Cuomo has put something on the table but not everything. He says he has a complete plan but can't disclose it while he's negotiating with lawmakers. His call for an increase in the gasoline tax looks sensible. The rest of his tax menu includes extending the sales tax to cover items like nonprescription drugs, a higher corporate tax rate and a new personal property tax on automobiles. Maybe those ideas make sense and maybe they do not. Right now, it's impossible to judge Mr. Cuomo's trial balloons until he turns them into tangible proposals with price tags and consequences attached.
As the Governor acknowledges, the state's fiscal woes go beyond coping with one sizable deficit. The region's economic downswing would fall more softly on New York if the state hadn't got into bad habits. In recent years it borrowed heavily and accumulated an unprecedented $5 billion debt, repeatedly rolled one year's deficit into the next and relied on fiscal gimmicks.
That's why it's troubling that Mr. Cuomo wants to use some of the same tactics to plug budget holes - including the use of one-shot revenues like borrowing from reserve funds. Quick fixes have become all too common in New York.
Mr. Cuomo says he has a three-year program that addresses the state's long-term fiscal problems. He wants to convert $2 billion in short-term borrowing into long-term bonds, impose a spending cap and reduce state borrowing. That's a start, but the public has to hear a lot more.
New Yorkers are shrewd enough to see through the tactics of the Republicans, whose strategy is to sit, wait and pounce on anyone willing to embrace unpopular positions - like taxing and cutting. But New Yorkers need someone to make the hard choices. If the Governor is waiting for the most propitious moment to make public a comprehensive plan, instead of trickling out bits and pieces, that moment has arrived: the deadline for a new state budget is only 10 days away.

HEADLINE: Converting to Peace

 BODY:
Shareholders in Fortress America aren't waiting for Washington to convert from cold war defense to a diversified economic offense. If ''peace dividend'' is the political phrase of the moment, the next one is ''conversion.'' Paying attention to retooling of defense industries from military to consumer production is good sense. As people in California have found, it is also good politics. 
Economic conversion was once anathema to the military-industrial complex of Southern California, notably in conservative Orange County, where nearly 100,000 workers depend on defense-related jobs. But recently in Orange County, defense contractors, unions, community leaders and the director of the Pentagon Office of Economic Adjustment met to discuss how to survive, diversify and thrive in the post-cold-war era.
Contractors want to get ahead of the defense-cut curve and plan for new civilian contracts. Labor wants to protect laid-off defense workers. The business community wants to build a diversified economic base. And Larry Agran, the Mayor of Irvine, wants to show President Bush the potential political dividend of the peace dividend. ''It doesn't take a rocket scientist to realize there's a great public benefit'' from investing it in health care, transportation, housing and the environment, he says. Though a liberal Democrat, Mr. Agran thrives as a maverick in Republican territory. Environmentally conscious conservatives applaud when he says that the Federal Government shouldn't spend ''billions to put guided nuclear missiles on rail cars; what we need is to put thousands of commuters on rail cars.''
Orange County is growing out of dependence on military contracts. But other, older areas face layoffs as bases and plants close. Conversion takes on a wholly different meaning in the Rust Belt than the Sun Belt. If anything, it is more needed in aging cities than in new suburbs.
Conversion efforts have sprung up in Ohio, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Long Island. ''This is where the solution happens, in communities,'' says the Pentagon adjustment director, Dr. Robert Rauner.
Political leaders will be reluctant to cut Pentagon spending, even where they believe cuts to be wise, until they're confident their communities won't face economic ruin. What Mayor Agran demonstrates with his Orange County conference is that the problems of conversion can be attacked successfully without being attacked by the Stealth bomber. Washington might usefully hold its own national conversion conference.

HEADLINE: TV Debates Need Third Party Candidates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Timothy J. Russert of NBC News hits the nail on the head in ''For '92, the Networks Have to Do Better'' (Op-Ed, March 4) when he observes that ''no one was satisfied with the 1988 coverage.''
Half the people qualified to vote in the 1988 election failed to do so because issues were never dealt with. But the debate format suggested by Mr. Russert, which could end up with a monologue and an empty chair, confirms serious misunderstanding of the nature of this problem. 
A debate means nothing when it's between two individuals who endorse one philosophy of government. Most Americans realize that, regardless of the party in power, nothing ever changes. The deficits continue to rise, even with Republicans in charge; and attacks on our civil liberties persist even with Democrats in charge. Foreign meddling is never seriously challenged by either party.
Economic interventionism, inflationism, worldwide police activity and obsession about drugs with disregard for civil liberties, are endorsed by Democrats and Republicans alike. Mild variations of these beliefs offer nothing to 50 percent of the American people, who have come to see politics as a joke and have been denied alternative views by the media.
The Libertarian Party and the New Alliance Party were on virtually every ballot in the country in 1988, a major undertaking considering the horrendous obstacles placed in the way. Yet, these two new parties representing clear alternatives were ignored by 95 percent of all media outlets. The Libertarians, with their principled stand on liberty, and the New Alliance Party, with its principled stand for a socialist agenda, have a lot to offer to spice up the debate and arouse the American people's interest.
If any party can achieve enough ballot status to win the election, theoretically, its candidate deserves a spot in the debates. I can guarantee there would then be no boring debates and no need to have a monologue with an empty chair.
 
RON PAUL
Lake Jackson, Tex., March 6, 1990
 The writer was Libertarian Party Presidential candidate in 1988 and a member of Congress, 1976-84.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Rockefeller Plea: Turn From Greed To Public Service

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
It might strike cynics as paradoxical to hear David Rockefeller complain about capitalistic greed, but with communism - and New York City's streets - disintegrating, he wondered, what kind of example are Americans and New Yorkers setting for the rest of the world?
''I'm distressed,'' he said, ''by the fact that the institutions that are associated with our society have not been setting a very good example.''
Specifically, he complained about corporate shortsightedness and selfishness. ''Unless the coming generation of leaders in our society sets a good example and not one that people are repulsed by,'' he said, ''we won't be copied and I don't know what will happen.'' 
Mr. Rockefeller was addressing six potential leaders who hope to emulate his success in public service, at least. They are finishing their year as the first David Rockefeller Fellows, a program created by the New York City Partnership to instill in the next generation of local executives the same commitment to corporate citizenship and a stake in the city's future that New York officials tapped during the fiscal crisis in the 1970's.
Mr. Rockefeller recalled the significance of that commitment as he expressed concern about the impact of crime and crumbling streets on the city's future.
''There's hardly anyone I know who hasn't themselves or haven't had close friends who have been mugged, robbed or what not and it doesn't even attract attention,'' he said. ''Even if you have a car you may break an axle.''
 
He cautioned that
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who he said comes from the same background as people who have been disadvantaged and correctly feel they deserve more, will be tempted to do more ''and the only way he can do it is to take measures that will undermine the economic base.'' So far, he said, the Dinkins administration has responded responsibly.
''I don't envy Mayor Dinkins his job,'' Mr. Rockefeller said.
The Partnership was established by Mr. Rockefeller in 1979 to apply the expertise of private industry to public problems. The fellows are being exposed to those problems and potential solutions in education and economic development.
When the program was announced last year, the first applications were all from public or nonprofit agencies - not the companies from among which the Partnership had hoped to recruit. But all six finalists were from private industry. Recruiting for the second class of fellows is to start next month.
It is difficult to measure whether the chill on Wall Street has increased the appeal of volunteer or even full-time public service, but, by some accounts, it has, modestly.
''The 80's were not a great period for schools of public policy,'' said Matthew P. Drennan, director of the public administration program at New York University's Robert F. Wagner School of Public Service. ''But, more and more, students don't see spending their lives increasing a corporation's market share of soap or selling bonds as what they'd like to do.''
He said 124 students have applied for next September's class, compared with 100 the year before. Forty-eight have applied for the school's urban planning program, compared with 36 in 1989.
''The public sector gives young people responsibility far beyond their experience,'' Mitchell Moss, director of the school's Urban Research Center, said.
The partnership's program, in which the fellows volunteer their time, has introduced its participants to ''a new vision of corporate citizenship,'' in the words of Jan C. Childress, coordinator of area development for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company. He said he had already received broad exposure to the city through his full-time job.
''Above and below ground,'' Mr. Rockefeller said.
Several fellows said they were discouraged in their initial attempts at volunteer work. Mr. Rockefeller recalled that he fared better in his first efforts after college, serving as secretary to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia - the first of a series of quasi-public posts as he rose to become chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank.
One was his appointment by President Lyndon B. Johnson as the first chairman of the White House Fellows program. His record, Mr. Rockefeller recalled, was mixed. Among the applicants who were rejected was Elizabeth H. Dole, who is now the United States Secretary of Labor. Among those accepted was David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs.
His public service, Mr. Rockefeller said, enhanced his life and benefitted his career. Some critics complained that he spent too much time away from the bank, he said, but ''I don't feel particularly apologetic.''

LENGTH: 962 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins's 2-Pronged Budget Strategy

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In revealing a new gap in New York City's budget for the coming fiscal year, Mayor David N. Dinkins on Monday not only put pressure on the Governor, legislators and other politicians to help him now, but may also have made it easier for himself in deciding how to spend money later.
Like a company that reports bad news in one quarter to clear the books in the hope of better days ahead, Mr. Dinkins announced the new $700 million gap to get his bad news out of the way quickly. The addition is on top of the $1.1 billion gap that the city said it was expecting six weeks ago.
On Monday, the Mayor attributed almost half the new gap to revised projections showing an additional $335 million shortfall in tax revenues. 
But the Mayor effectively decided to further widen the gap by declaring that the city could no longer count on receiving $303 million from the sale of the old site of the New York Coliseum in time to help in the fiscal year that starts on July 1. In doing so, he pleased fiscal monitors, who had criticized him for counting on the money in the first place.
By law the city has to balance the budget each year by closing any gap between planned spending and expected revenues. By removing the Coliseum money now and vowing to balance his budget anyway, Mr. Dinkins put pressure on the opponents of the Coliseum deal, including some Upper West Side politicians who support him, to reach an agreement that would allow the sale to proceed.
He also virtually guaranteed that if the money becomes available later and is put back into the budget, he would decide how to spend it and then be able to take credit for doing so.
 
Change in Jobs, Change in Stance
Mayor Edward I. Koch had originally included the Coliseum money in the operating budget to support a host of programs, but the deal to sell the parcel on Columbus Circle has been held up by lawsuits and revisions in the design of a skyscraper proposed for the site.
As Manhattan Borough President in the Koch administration, Mr. Dinkins had opposed putting the money in the budget. But as Mayor, he said that because the city was depending on it, it had no choice, and he included it in his preliminary budget of $27.8 billion issued on Feb. 1.
Since he won office on a platform of liberal change, Mr. Dinkins has been hemmed in by the city's worsening fiscal condition and by spending for programs under way. He has been forced to defer major plans and to include just a few small, mostly symbolic, social-service initiatives.
In a stern memo to his commissioners on Monday, Mr. Dinkins said he preferred that they eliminate some programs outright rather than keep them barely operating. That is the surest way to trim the budget, and that would give him more flexibility if money becomes available. Then, with those programs no longer even nominally on the books, Mr. Dinkins could propose new programs more easily.
 
'Gruesome Things in There'
In the meantime, of course, the Mayor faces the prospect of no immediate improvement in the economy, and he has to contend with the pain of the new cuts, which could range from delaying the hiring of police officers to closing firehouses to further cutting the number of street sweepers. ''None of it is good,'' he said on Tuesday.
To hammer home his threat, he warned that $500 million more in service cuts, on top of hundreds of millions already made or announced since last fall, would be needed to close the new gap. On Tuesday, Budget Director Philip R. Michael said virtually all agencies had been asked to prepare cuts amounting to 4 percent of their budgets. ''There will be gruesome things in there,'' he said.
But by taking the Coliseum money out of the budget now, Mr. Dinkins forces the City Council, which will vote on the budget in the summer, to share the burden of balancing the spending plan. If Mr. Dinkins kept the money in the budget and it fell through later, he alone would have to shoulder the responsibility for cutting programs.
 
Postponement of Hearing
''It took a lot of guts and it was a good move, and I think it will serve him well,'' said one state official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The Mayor also said on Tuesday that his administration was considering asking the Council to postpone the date for submitting the budget, from April 26 to early May, in part to have more time to assess the effects of the state budget due to be adopted next month.
Because of Mr. Dinkins's announcement, the Council said it would delay hearings on the preliminary budget that were to have begun yesterday. That in turn lets the Mayor keep his options open a bit longer.
Several mayoral aides said on Tuesday that the main reason for Mr. Dinkins's latest pronouncement was the continuing bleak prospects for tax revenues. The aides added that he also wanted to remind the state, which is struggling with its own huge budget gaps, that the city needs help and to warn the opponents of the Coliseum deal of the consequences of their actions.
Moreover, by removing the Coliseum money now, the aides said, the Mayor risks relatively little political capital. He appears fiscally responsible and could fault others if the new cuts have to be made. Even if the city does not reap the money from the deal for two or three years, Mr. Dinkins would be able to claim credit for getting it.
The executive director of the State Financial Control Board, Allen J. Proctor, who last week criticized the administration for counting on the Coliseum deal and not cutting the budget enough, praised the Mayor's move.
''We welcome the city's announcement,'' he said. ''Our evaluation of the budget pointed to a number of areas of concern, and the city's steps have substantially reduced the amount of risk.''

HEADLINE: 3 Officers Acquitted in Fatal Struggle With Disturbed Brooklyn Man

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
As dozens of fellow police officers cheered, three officers were acquitted yesterday of assaulting an emotionally disturbed 40-year-old who died shortly after a struggle with the officers two years ago in Brooklyn.
The three officers went to the home of the man, Juan Rodriguez, an unemployed electrician, in response to complaints by neighbors that he was acting violently. Mr. Rodriguez collapsed in the subsequent struggle. An autopsy indicated that he had suffered head injuries and died of a heart attack. 
''I believe that the police officers in this case were confronted with an extremely difficult situation,'' Judge Alan Marrus said in Criminal Court in Brooklyn. He described Mr. Rodriguez as a disturbed man who had broken two doors in his apartment building and terrorized his neighbors.
Supporters of the three officers broke into long, loud cheering when Judge Marrus, who tried the case without a jury, announced the verdict.
The officers are Thomas Mascia, Christopher Rising and Joseph Tripp. They are on modified duty pending the outcome of a departmental investigation, a police spokesman said.
 
Standard of Reasonable Doubt
In announcing the verdict, Judge Marrus said, ''The evidence has not established beyond a reasonable doubt that these officers recklessly or negligently caused physical injury to Mr. Juan Rodriguez.'' Noting that the prosecutor had contended that the officers had treated Mr. Rodriguez as ''a subhuman being'' and would have treated a middle-class person differently, the judge said the contention was ''entirely speculation.''
The judge said officers responding to difficult situations ''should not be second-guessed into a guilty verdict for a crime based on speculation.'' If there was any failure by the authorities, he added, it was ''a lack of sensitivity to the Rodriguez family.'' He observed that when Mrs. Rodriguez had frantically inquired about her husband's condition, she had received a ''cold shoulder from the authorities.''
''I want to express publicly my sympathy to Mrs. Rodriguez and her family for the tragic loss that they have suffered,'' the judge said. ''But I cannot base a verdict on sympathy. I have to base it on evidence.''
The prosecutor, Steven Schwartz, argued in his summation that the officers had assaulted Mr. Rodriguez because he was a poor disturbed Hispanic man. Defense lawyers said the officers had acted properly in restraining someone acting violently.
District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said after the verdict that he had ''allocated the full resources of this office'' to prosecute the case.
''The death of Juan Rodriguez was a tragic incident,'' he added. ''I offer my condolences to his family.''

HEADLINE: Counting the Homeless: A Lonely, Iffy, Wary Job

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Under a steady drizzle, Edward Diaz and Elizabeth Cruz walked briskly along deserted streets and pathways on the Lower East Side of Manhattan shortly after midnight yesterday, two lonely figures in search of a third.
They looked in the lobbies and ground-floor areas of staircases in residential buildings. They looked across playgrounds and parking lots. Frustrated, they even strayed from preassigned sites to check rooftops. 
''Normally there are about a hundred homeless people in this area,'' said Ms. Cruz, who lives in the neighborhood. ''Where are they? Good question.''
 
Rain Hampers the Count
For one full night, thousands of people with a permanent roof over their heads set out to count those without one, trying to back up with numbers the faces they see every day in street doorways, on subway cars and in park benches.
For New Yorkers like Ms. Cruz and Mr. Diaz, two in a nationwide contingent of 15,000 workers who carried out the Census Bureau's count of homeless people, the night ended in disappointment as rain drove many of the homeless away from their regular sleeping quarters.
Other counters contended with danger. The Census Bureau's director, Barbara E. Bryant, said yesterday that no worker was injured on the job. But in Austin, Tex., three enumerators had their car windshield smashed in a wooded area where homeless people camp, and at 2:15 A.M. in Coney Island another team scattered when it heard shots while surveying an abandoned building.
But for many, the experience was a revelation, dispelling preconceived notions about a population they barely knew. And it drove home the seriousness of the homelessness problem. Some counters said they were moved to offer pocket money or a cup of coffee to the most destitute.
A few were horrified to find people sleeping across armrests on benches or exposed to the rain and cold with hardly a shirt on.
 
Teen-Ager at Penn Station
''Can you believe a 15-year old lives at Penn Station?'' said Alex Fernandez, 19, who counted people at transit stations and who was stunned by what he found. ''That is not sad. That is neglect.'' Marty Wolf, 51, an Upper East Side resident, said she used to think people were homeless because ''they were lazy people who don't want to work.'' She said her perceptions changed when she saw shelter residents leaving for work or coming back from work.
''The majority were simply normal people who don't have a place to live,'' she said.
The census-takers had a wide range of backgrounds. They included a Transit Authority bus driver, an unemployed construction foreman, a State Department of Taxation compliance agent and a recently arrived Russian Jewish emigre, homemakers and students. They also included the homeless, most of them recruited at shelters.
The workers were paid $8 an hour for work done in shifts, mostly between 6 P.M. Tuesday and 11 A.M. Wednesday. They also received night differential pay and a $50 bonus for completing their assignment.
 
Some Refuse to Be Counted
Although money was an incentive, many of the workers said they had applied for the job out of curiosity or because they strongly believed in the importance of the count. Most found that they were welcomed, although some encountered grumbling and sometimes outright antagonism.
At the Bellevue Men's Shelter in Manhattan, with a population of nearly 1,000, Barbara Remington, a 60-year-old artist, approached as many as 20 residents who refused to be interviewed.
''I think it's going to be pretty meaningless,'' she said of the demographic count.
Inna Orel, 36, who arrived in New York City barely three months ago, said her overtures to those she tried to count at Pennsylvania Station were often met with a shout to go away. But she enjoyed the overall experience.
''To see New York, to get acquainted with this side of life that usually I don't have a possibility to see, it was a great experience,'' she said.
Carmen M. Luna, 39, a widow and mother of two teen-age daughters, said that whatever apprehensions she had about participating in the count vanished as compassion overtook her.
 
Danger Discounted
Ms. Luna said she had been prompted to apply for the job because ''I feel that there are so many Hispanics that are homeless that need to be counted, so they can get the proper amount of benefits.''
''My parents were terrified, because they thought it was too dangerous,'' she said, ''but I figure if we all take that attitude, we won't solve anything. ''
Dwayne Mayes, 27, who lives in a shelter in Manhattan and worked as both an enumerator, said he supported the count despite criticism by those who feared an undercount would jeopardize financing of programs for the homeless.
''Hopefully it will make people realize that there's a population of homeless people who are not dehumanized and that still maintains self-respect,'' he said. ''Being counted means social services will be provided. We are here, and we are counted now.''

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Schwinn Is Building Bikes The U.S. Way in Hungary

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
''A friend of mine came into this factory the other day and said, 'Boy, it's changed; it's hardly recognizable,' '' said Laszlo Nogradi, general manager of the Schwinn Bicycle Company's 14-month-old joint venture in Hungary.
Since arriving in Hungary, Schwinn has put sophisticated welding and painting machines in the crowded, bustling, high-ceilinged factory in Budapest. The Chicago-based company has also accelerated the pace of two 100-foot-long assembly lines where shiny bicycle frames move past, as workers attach wheels, chains, pedals, gears and brakes.
For Schwinn, the joint venture seems to be a perfect marriage, and company officials are delighted with their move into Eastern Europe. ''We came to Hungary because we made a decision that we needed to become a more global company,'' said Steven M. Bina, director of Schwinn's European operations. ''We wouldn't be here if there wasn't money to be made.'' 
Schwinn is one of some 100 American companies that have set up joint ventures in Hungary, and its experience is typical. With modest investments in modernization and the introduction of some Western personnel management techniques, they have created far more efficient and profitable factories, although cramped conditions and 19th-century layouts remain.
American investors are swarming to do deals in Hungary, thanks to its attractive joint venture laws, tax breaks for Western investors, and liberal rules allowing foreign investors who create jobs here to repatriate their profits. There are big joint ventures like General Electric's $150 million investment to buy a majority stake in Tungsram, Eastern Europe's largest light bulb company, and smaller ones like Levi Strauss & Company's $1 million investment in a jeans factory.
In late 1988, Schwinn wanted to expand its presence on the Continent and was looking for a low-cost way to do that. At the same time, Csepel Bicycle, Hungary's largest bike manufacturer, with annual production of 200,000, was seeking a wealthy Western partner to help upgrade its operation.
With a new age dawning in Eastern Europe, Csepel officials knew that their heavy bikes with a clunky design and dull paint could not compete.
''We wanted to improve the quality of our bikes, and we wanted someone with expertise to help us do that,'' said Mr. Nogradi, who wears a blue work uniform around the factory.
Schwinn, a family-owned company that controls 51 percent of the joint venture, has pumped millions of dollars into improving the Hungarian plant. It will not say just how much it has spent, but a new high-temperature welding system cost several hundred thousand dollars and the ''electrostatic'' painting system cost more than $1 million.
Schwinn has changed the order of production so that all metal-cutting is finished before, not after, a fine, even spray of peacock blue or ruby red paint is put onto electrically charged bike frames.
''We've tried to liven things up.'' from the dull colors of Communist days, said Mr. Bina, a tall, athletic native of Iowa with a brown mustache.
The most significant change, however, is in personnel management. The joint venture is producing as many bikes as the old Csepel plant, but with 15 percent fewer employees, thanks to a new American-style incentive-based wage system.
Workers can get bonuses of up to 40 percent of their base pay if their work exceeds a management-set goal. To win the loyalty of the 380 workers, the Schwinn-Csepel venture has pegged its average wages - about $210 a month - some 30 percent higher than the national average, but it prohibits its employees from holding the second and third jobs that many Hungarians work.
Schwinn did extensive testing of the work force it inherited, demoting some people and promoting others. It put most of the employees on probation for three months while evaluating them.
''We didn't have to drag anyone kicking and screaming,'' Mr. Bina said, adding that by and large Hungarians seemed eager for change, even if it entailed some pain at first.
Before the joint venture was formed, the plant managers earned just 15 percent more than the average workers. Now the differential is several times that, and Schwinn offers sizable wage increases to workers capable of taking on more responsiblity.

HEADLINE: Volatility Jolts Stocks In Tokyo

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, March 22

 BODY:
The deeply troubled Tokyo stock market went through its most volatile day ever today as the plummeting value of the yen and Government efforts to strengthen it set share prices swinging wildly and left investors and market professionals stunned.
Those gyrations left the closely watched Nikkei 225-stock average down 963.85 points, at 29,843.34. The 3.1 percent decline was the Tokyo market's 10th-worst percentage drop.
The Tokyo Stock Exchange went into a nose dive this morning and declined 6 percent by its midday break, in spite of the fact that only half the shares could open for trading because of huge imbalances of sell orders. By itself, that would have represented the second-largest decline in the market's history, and it followed a string of steep dives in the last two months that have turned what had been virtually the world's most stable major market into its shakiest. 
 
Government Actions
But shortly after the lunch hour both the Bank of Japan and the United States Federal Reserve were reported to have begun large-scale interventions to strengthen the yen. The Japanese central bank spent more than $1 billion, currency traders said, buying yen and selling dollars, while the Fed intervened heavily in Singapore.
In addition, Government officials leaked word that Finance Ministry officials had contacted leading Japanese corporations and financial institutions and encouraged them not to sell yen and buy dollars.
The Japanese Government also confirmed American reports that Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Minister of Finance, would leave Friday for Washington, where he would discuss the exchange rate situation with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and other top American officials. By repeating these reports, the ministry's actions were taken as a hint that there may be further coordinated intervention to stabilize the markets.
 
Dollar as High as 155.40 Yen
Along with the intervention, those reports knocked the dollar back from a peak of 155.40 yen - it's highest point against the yen in three years -down to 154.70 yen, still its highest level in more than a year.
In a chain reaction, that move caused Japanese bond prices to strengthen, which caused a rebound in share prices of more than 1,000 points at one time. In effect, the market went through its second-steepest decline and its second-sharpest upward jump, both in the same day.
It was the first time since December 1988 that the index had fallen below 30,000. The 3.1 percent decline today left the market down a steep 8.5 percent this week.
At midday, the index had fallen 1,836 points, spurring the Government action to avoid having the rout turn into a crash.
Analysts, traders and economists said that buying support had all but dried up, paralyzing the market. In addition to the number of individual shares that could not open this morning because of the wave of sell orders, the stock-index futures market was unable to trade because of the pressure.
''It is getting panicky,'' said Toyoharu Tsutsui, a managing director in the equity department of CS First Boston (Japan), said of the morning session. ''It is an ugly situation. There are no buyers at all. None.''
A senior securities executive said of the morning plunge, ''There is a total loss of confidence, period.''
The latest blow came in the reaction to the move by the Bank of Japan on Tuesday to raise the official discount rate a full percentage point, to 5.25 percent. It was the fourth increase in that benchmark short-term rate in the last 10 months. The rate has now more than doubled since May. The increases, the central bank has said, have been intended to nip inflationary pressures in the bud and to bolster the sagging yen.
The Fed's action in Singapore was said to have been effective in turning the dollar around - temporarily. Many market experts said they still expect further declines in the yen and the Tokyo stock market.
''We don't see this thing turning around quickly,'' added Kermit Schoenholtz, an economist with Salomon Brothers Asia. ''The authorities have taken insufficient measures.''

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japanese to Meet on Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that a meeting Friday between Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and his Japanese counterpart is intended to head off major trade disputes this summer and to consider moves to check the recent fall of the yen.
The five-hour talks in Los Angeles between Mr. Brady and the Japanese Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, come as the United States and Japan move into a critical phase of their economic relationship. The talks, disclosed by Secretary Brady on Tuesday before he testified to the Senate Appropriations Committee, follow by less than three weeks a hastily arranged meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif.
At that meeting, Mr. Kaifu promised to make reduction of trade tensions a top priority of his Government, but questions remain about whether the verbal commitments will be turned into significant market-opening moves. 
 
Proposals From Tokyo
Makoto Utsumi, the deputy minister for international affairs of the Japanese Finance Ministry, was in Washington this week to help prepare for the Los Angeles talks. American officials said that he brought with him a series of preliminary proposals - prepared in Tokyo after Mr. Kaifu's meeting with Mr. Bush - that are aimed at defusing some of the major trade problems.
Mr. Utsumi and American trade and Treasury officials discussed the proposals Tuesday at a northern Virginia conference retreat named Airlie House. Among the Japanese concessions discussed were stiffening penalties for antitrust violations, relaxing restrictions on opening large retail stores, increasing spending on public works, abolishing tax breaks that could bring down the price of urban land and encouraging buying of American super computers and satellites.
 
Part of Previous Effort
The concessions discussed, execpt for those involving supercomputers and satellites and some others, were among those already being sought by the United States under the negotiations known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, an effort begun last summer in Japan that is intended to open Japanese markets and make industry in both countries more competitive.
But one American official said that Mr. Utsumi was told that the Japanese proposals he outlined Tuesday at the Airlie House were still inadequate.
''We have had some progress in the discussions,'' said one Administration official in Los Angeles. ''But it's clearly been insufficient and we are looking to have an in-depth exchange on the trade issues.''
At the same time, the official stressed that the meeting was not intended for ''any great deal-making'' but rather for ''advancing the dialogue on these critical trade issues at a very important time.''
Treasury officials also said they doubted there would be ''any new policy approaches'' to the problems of the sinking yen. As one official put it: ''The meeting was called simply to touch base and have an exchange of views.''
 
Statement to Be Sought
''At this stage,'' the official said, he did not see the need for any formal statement from the Los Angeles meeting to try to influence the markets to halt the slide of the yen. Japanese officials have said, however, that Mr. Hashimoto is likely to seek such a statement from the Treasury Secretary.
The yen, now trading at around 154 to the dollar, is at its lowest level against the dollar in more than three years and has also dropped against other leading currencies.
The Los Angeles meeting is preliminary to a broader gathering on April 7 in Paris of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven nations -the United States, Japan, France, Britain, West Germany, Canada and Italy.
The Group of Seven meets several times a year to try to coordinate international economic policies. The April meeting was called chiefly to take stock of German unification and its impact on world economies.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Are Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up for the week that ended yesterday.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund increased by 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.96 percent. The 30-day average yield rose by a basis point, to 7.94 percent. 
The assets of taxable funds rose by $629 million for the week, to a total of $384.3 billion, with institutional assets down by $221 million, to $80.4 billion, and consumer assets up by $850 million, to $303.9 billion. Analysts at Donoghue's said that amount of money going into consumer funds was considered normal.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased by a day, to 44. The analysts noted that the number maturity days was at a high level not seen for some time. The fund managers, they say, are not concerned about a rise in short-term rates and have been increasing the days to take advantage of current yields.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, Donoghue's found that the Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I., remained on top, where it has been for five weeks. The fund reported a return of 8.83 percent, up from 8.79 percent last week.
 
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
The yields of tax-exempt funds were also up for the week.
Assets increased by $256 million, to $77.9 billion, with the average seven-day compounded yield up by 14 basis points, to 5.42 percent. The sharp increase in yields, some analysts at Donoghue's said, reflects yields in the tax-exempt market trying to catch up with the rest of fixed-income market.
For investors seeking a comparable return in taxable securities, the equivalent return for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket is 7.52 percent, with 8.60 percent being the equivalent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
Donoghue's said the top-performing tax-free fund this week was the Spartan Pennsylvania Municipal Money Market Portfolio, distributed by the Fidelity Distributors Corporation in Boston. The return was 6.07 percent, about 65 basis points higher than the average.
By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed that yields on bank money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit were unchanged at 6.25 percent and 7.88 percent, respectively. The C.D.'s with longer maturities were up modestly, with a one-year certificate up by 4 basis points, to 8.01 percent, and a two-and-a-half-year up by 5 basis points, to 8.01 percent. The average yield on five-year certificates rose by 3 basis points, to 8.06 percent.

HEADLINE: World Trade Grew in 1989

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 21

 BODY:
International trade volume could slow slightly this year, with inflation and rising interest rates in industrialized nations hampering expansion, the world's main trade forum reported today.
Experts at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade also reported that the value of international merchandise trade exceeded $3 trillion for the first time in 1989. 
GATT experts predicted the volume of goods traded internationally would grow by 5 percent to 6 percent in 1990, the eighth straight year of expansion. The value of goods traded on world markets last year rose by 7.5 percent from 1988, to $3.1 trillion, the report stated.
In 1989 the United States regained its position as the world's leading exporter after three years in second place behind West Germany, the report said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Off in Light Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell in light trading yesterday, as dealers took profits after Tuesday's rally.
In part, activity was more subdued than in recent sessions because Japanese financial markets were closed yesterday. Rumors that large Japanese institutions have been big buyers of zero-coupon Treasury bonds were instrumental in fueling the run-up in prices on Tuesday.
Even with the price dip, traders said that market psychology has shifted slightly over the last few days. 
''The market is kind of fun right now,'' one government bond trader said. ''People have come back into the market and are trading again. Every day there have been buyers, and that is making for better trading.''
That attitude could change over the next few weeks, since the Treasury is expected to be a heavy seller of new securities.
The auctions will begin next week, and yesterday the Treasury announced it will sell $10 billion worth of new two-year notes on Tuesday and $8 billion of four-year notes on Wednesday.
Following the announcement the two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.66 percent, and the four-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.70 percent.
 
Traders Increasingly Optimistic
With note yields at current levels, traders said demand for the new issues should be strong. And some economists, citing an increase in the nation's savings rate, are becoming increasingly optimistic that the Federal budget deficit, which is running at an annual rate of about $150 billion, could possibly be financed without the help of foreign investors.
''The budget deficit is easily financed, and increasingly the money will come from internal savings,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
Mr. Yardeni said that personal savings amounted to $206 billion last year, compared with $102 billion in 1987.
''I expect the savings rate will continue to rise this year, and that is one of the reasons I like bonds,'' Mr. Yardeni said. ''Also, the economic fundamentals are not as bearish as many investors have concluded.''
That view was not manifested in Treasury bond prices yesterday, which gave ground after several days of strong gains.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100 1/8, down 3/8 point, to yield 8.48 percent. #10-Year Note Issues Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 19/ 32, down 7/32, to yield 8.56 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 13/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.63 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were flat.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.94 percent, unchanged on the day. And six-month bills were unchanged at a late offered rate of 7.90 percent.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a $1.4 billion asset-backed financing for Citicorp.
The issue consists of four parts, including $750 million of three-year securities and $500 million of seven-year securities.
The 9.30 percent three-year securities were priced at $99.859 to yield 9.342 percent, 70 basis points, or hundredths of a point, over the prevailing yield on the 8 3/8 percent three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The 9 1/2 percent seven-year notes were priced at $99.406, to yield 9.57 percent, 95 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 percent seven-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Those two issues carry AAA ratings from both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction.
An underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers priced a $100 million offering of two-year notes for the Union Camp Corporation.
The 9 1/2 percent notes were priced at 100, or par, 97 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent two-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most issues in the secondary market dipped by about 1/8 point.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was very lethargic, according to participants. Prices of most issues were unchanged to down 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises Modestly; Gold Declines a Bit in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved up modestly against most major currencies, including the yen, the pound and the West German mark, in slow trading yesterday, as traders sought a safe investment haven. Gold prices posted minor declines in domestic dealings after much larger losses overseas.
One reason that investors sought safety was increasing tensions in Lithuania, which declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ordered Lithuanians yesterday to turn in their weapons, a day after the Baltic republic's Government demanded an end to Soviet military maneuvers. 
Despite Japan's one percentage point increase in a key interest rate on Monday, the dollar rose to 154.37 Japanese yen late in New York, from 154.20 yen late Tuesday. Tokyo markets were closed for Japan's national holiday on the vernal equinox.
 
Effect of Uncertainties in Britain
Also contributing to interest in the dollar was the uncertain outlook for Britain's governing Conservatives, because of rising prices, high interest rates, the deterioration of the Government-run health service and a new tax on every adult to finance municipal services.
The British pound slipped to $1.5955 late in New York, a weakening from late Tuesday's $1.6005. The pound closed yesterday in London at $1.5965, down from Tuesday's $1.6105. It stood at $1.7145 on Feb. 22.
Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Bank in Chicago, said activity in the dollar was subdued, lacking significant corporate or interbank trading. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Tuesday, included: 1.7100 West German marks, up from 1.7048; 1.5225 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.768 French francs, up from 5.7575; 1,259.75 Italian lire, up from 1,258.00, and 1.17875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17765.
Selected rates for the dollar late in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's levels, were: 1.7070 West German marks, up from 1.6965; 1.5192 Swiss francs, up from 1.5157; 5.7575 French francs, up from 5.7340; 1.9230 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9107; 1,257.25 Italian lire, up from 1,253.50, and 1.1769 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1792.
Gold bullion prices fell back after traders took profits on the metal, which had crept above $400 an ounce on Monday.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $391.80 an ounce, 40 cents lower than Tuesday. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $391.90 for an ounce of gold, 50 cents lower than Tuesday's late bid.
Gold closed in London, the major foreign market, at a bid of $391.75 an ounce, down from $398. Silver was mixed. In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.055 an ounce, up from Tuesday's settlement of $5.043. Silver bullion traded late in London at $5.06, down from Tuesday's late bid of $5.09.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1219 words

HEADLINE: Nunn Opens a Double Attack In Military Spending Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee sharply criticized the Defense Department today for spending plans that he said were based on outdated assumptions about the military threats facing the United States.
But he also assailed some of his fellow Democrats on Capitol Hill, saying that the deep cuts in Pentagon spending they were seeking could bring disruptive problems for the military.
The Armed Services chairman, Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat whose views on military issues are influential among his Democratic colleagues, intensified the debate over Pentagon spending with a speech on the Senate floor. He said the Defense Department had failed to develop a new military strategy in response to changes in the Soviet Union and Europe. 
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney rejected Mr. Nunn's criticism. In a luncheon address at the National Press Club, Mr. Cheney defended his spending requests and said he had given the services guidance for planning the military budget through 1997 that assumes continued political change in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and new arms control agreements between Moscow and Washington.
In a broad rebuttal to recent Congressional criticism, Mr. Cheney complained in his address that lawmakers were offering ''complaints instead of solutions.''
Mr. Cheney noted that his speech was prepared before Mr. Nunn spoke. ''But obviously, if the shoe fits, wear it, Sam,'' Mr. Cheney added.
Mr. Nunn's speech was his first important address on military policy since the Pentagon's budget request for the 1991 fiscal year was submitted to Congress in January. He emphasized that neither the Pentagon nor his fellow Democrats on Capitol Hill who have called for deep reductions in military spending had made the systematic, thoughtful analysis needed to reassess the nation's security needs and to begin an orderly reduction of military forces.
The Pentagon has proposed a 1991 budget of $295 billion, a 2.6 percent decrease from the 1990 level once the effects of inflation are taken into account. That does not include about $11 billion in spending for nuclear weapons program by the Department of Energy. The New York Times has reported that Administration officials have suggested that President Bush would be willing to reduce military expenditures for the 1991 fiscal year by $7 billion. But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, and the chief Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, have denied that Mr. Bush has agreed to this.
In his speech today, Mr. Nunn specifically assailed proposals by fellow Democrats to make cuts of up to $20 billion.
 
Comments Aimed at Sasser
In comments clearly aimed at Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Nunn said reductions of that magnitude would place too much emphasis on achieving immediate cuts and would force large and disruptive layoffs of military personnel, creating serious morale problems and hampering the United States' ability to respond to future threats.
Mr. Nunn did not outline his own proposals for reshaping military strategy and spending, saying he would address that in future speeches. But implicit in his remarks today was a view that both the Pentagon and its critics had focused too much on the short-term issue of identifying savings in the 1991 budget instead of rethinking fundamental military issues and developing a long-term approach.
''With threat, strategy and program assumptions that are, at a minimum, two years out of date, we are left with very important blanks in the fiscal 1991 defense budget,'' Senator Nunn said of the Pentagon's budget proposal.
''I am constantly being asked for a bottom-line defense number,'' Mr. Nunn said. ''I don't know of any logical way to arrive at such a figure without analyzing the threat; without determining what changes in our strategy should be made in light of the changes in the threat; and then determing what force structure and weapons programs we need to carry out this revised strategy.
 
No Clear Consensus
''To decide on the size of the defense budget without first going through this process would be little better than pulling a number out of the air.''
The differences between Mr. Nunn and Mr. Cheney, and Mr. Nunn and Mr. Sasser, reflect the absence of any clear consensus in the capital about how to respond to the changes in Europe.
Senator Sasser rejected Mr. Nunn's charge that his proposed cuts would severely disrupt the military.
''Certainly it is true that there will be disruptions as we move from a wartime buildup to a peacetime economy. There are always disruptions when Government reduces spending,'' Senator Sasser said.
''The issue is whether spending $300 billion annually for defense is justified in a post-cold war world. I think Senator Nunn has laid out a compelling case that it is not,'' he added.
 
Cheney Calls His Budget Prudent
Defense Secretary Cheney said today that his budget proposals were a prudent response to political changes in Moscow and Europe and that deep cuts would be risky.
But Mr. Nunn said that Mr. Cheney's 1991 budget and his five-year military spending plan for the fiscl years 1991 through 1995 contained ''five big blanks.''
Mr. Nunn said the Pentagon's assessment of the military threat ''is rooted in the past.'' Pentagon officials have said that 1991 is a transitional year, asserting that changes will be made in the assessments of foreign threats once reviews are completed of issues like how much warning the United States might have a Soviet attack.
''The development of a new military strategy that responds to the changes in the threat has not yet occurred,'' Senator Nunn added, dismissing arguments by Mr. Cheney that the Pentagon has made adequate adjustments for the political changes in Europe by preparing plans to reduce American troops in central Europe to 195,000.
Mr. Nunn also complained that the Pentagon's five-year spending plan is incomplete because it has identified only $70 billion of the $167 billion in budget cuts needed to meet its own projected spending requests. The Pentagon acknowledges that it is still preparing a detailed five-year plan. But Mr. Nunn said, ''I am certain that more programs will have to be terminated than the Defense Department has recommended so far.''
Mr. Nunn also complained that the Pentagon has not told Congress what the size and structure of the military will be over the next five years and has not completed important reviews of major weapons systems.
In response to this criticism, Pentagon officials note that the Defense Department has proposed eliminating 5 of the Army's 28 active and reserve divisions and doing away with 5 tactical air wings, among other cuts. But many Pentagon officials concede that further cuts in the size of the military are likely to be needed.
Those officials also acknowledge that they are still conducting reviews of some major weapons programs, asserting that it takes time to adjust American weapons programs to a changing world.
''I hope these blanks will be filled in by the Defense Department, but the Congress will have to act if the Defense Department doesn't,'' Senator Nunn warned. ''At this time, we have no indication of when or if this information will be provided.''

HEADLINE: Baker Reports a Pledge by de Klerk

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, March 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa had told him that his Government was on an irreversible course toward creating a nonracial democracy.
Addressing reporters in Cape Town after a one-hour meeting with Mr. de Klerk, Mr. Baker gestured toward the South African President and said: ''May I repeat what you told me at the conclusion of our meeting? 'That we are engaged here in South Africa in an irreversible process that we will follow to its logical conclusion.' ''
Mr. de Klerk's use of the word ''irreversible'' was clearly not accidental. Leading American proponents of continued economic sanctions against South Africa like Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, have repeatedly said that these punitive measures must not be ended until apartheid is on an irreversible track toward dissolution. South Africans said that only lately has Mr. de Klerk begun to use this expression in his public statements. 
 
Baker Deeply Impressed
After the talks in Cape Town today -Mr. Baker also met with black opposition leaders and with Foreign Minister R. F. Botha - reporters traveling on Mr. Baker's plane were told that the Secretary of State was deeply impressed by Mr. de Klerk's stated commitment to end in the very near future the state of emergency declared in 1986.
As impressed as Mr. Baker was Wednesday by the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, he was said to be no less taken with Mr. de Klerk in their first meeting.
The reporters were told that Mr. Baker, a novice in African diplomacy, might be somewhat naive in his assessment, but nevertheless felt that Mr. de Klerk was ''absolutely serious.''
The reporters were told that in the view of those aboard the plane the South Africans are committed. and that changes that were taking place in other parts of the world were likely to be repeated in South Africa.
 
Two Sides Still Far Apart
On April 11, Mr. de Klerk and the African National Congress will begin talks on removing obstacles to formal negotiations on power sharing - obstacles like the state of emergency and the continued confinement of political prisoners. Both sides have been making conciliatory statements, but they remain far apart on what a ''new South Africa'' should look like.
Mr. Baker's visit was the first by an American Secretary of State to South Africa since Cyrus R. Vance came in 1978. Mr. Baker left reporters with the impression that the visit signaled the beginning of a new relationship, on a much higher level, between the Bush Administration and South Africa provided that Mr. de Klerk continues moving forward. Mr. Baker and Mr. de Klerk discussed a date for his proposed visit to Washington. The final announcement will be made after consultations with the White House.
Mr. Baker was understood to have told aides that when Foreign Minister Botha told him at a meeting in Rome in February 1989 that a de Klerk Government would be committed to ending apartheid and instituting majority rule, he did did not believe the South African. Reporters were told today that Mr. Baker ''believes them totally now when they say they have made a commitment and will follow through on it.''
Mr. Baker was said to have told Mr. de Klerk that the South African's moves - releasing Mr. Mandela, legalizing the African National Congress and agreeing to open talks with the it -were ''courageous in light of the obvious political pressures he is subject to.''
Earlier today, after talks with leaders of the African National Congress, Mr. Baker held an impromptu news conference accompanied by the black nationalists. A senior official of the congress, Govan Mbeki, used the opportunity to criticize the Secretary of State for meeting Mr. de Klerk on South African soil, echoing criticisms made by Mr. Mandela on Wednesday in Windhoek.
''We are not happy that he has come here to consult with the South African Government,'' Mr. Mbeki said, adding that such a move would only ease pressures on Mr. de Klerk before he has made any real changes in the system of apartheid.
Mr. Mbeki said that the African National Congress's message to Mr. Baker, the American Government and the American people was that they ''should continue to impose the pressures which they have been on the South African Government and not relax them at all until such times that positions will have been made clear.''

HEADLINE: In Namibia, South African Is Center of Attention

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINDHOEK, Namibia, March 22

 BODY:
President F. W. de Klerk has used the celebration of Namibian independence to engage in perhaps the most extensive and varied international diplomacy that a South African leader has undertaken since apartheid was ushered in 42 years ago.
Mr. de Klerk came here officially to surrender South Africa's stewardship over Namibia. But he stayed on to score a series of diplomatic coups, as heads of state and foreign ministers all but queued up to inquire what he was doing at home.
President de Klerk had discussions here with the Presidents of Egypt, Mozambique, Angola, Nigeria, Mali, Zambia and Yugoslavia, and the Prime Minister of Cape Verde. He had met previously with the leaders of Mozambique and Zambia, but met the others for the first time. 
He also held first meetings with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Ireland, Finland, West Germany, Sweden and Spain, as well as other officials from France, Italy and Norway. And he spent an hour with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations, which has supervised Namibia's transition to independence.
 
Mandela Draws Spotlight
The only other visitor to Namibia enjoying such attention was Nelson Mandela, who held meetings in which he put across the views of the African National Congress, which has fought to end white minority rule in South Africa. In recent statements, Mr. Mandela has called for the continued isolation of South Africa to speed political change there.
A South African diplomat said Mr. de Klerk's talks, which took place over little more than two days, entailed the most concentrated diplomatic activity by a leader of his Government since before South Africa quit the Commonwealth under pressure in 1961.
But a South African journalist said he believed that such exposure was last accorded to Prime Minister Jan Smuts, who was defeated in 1948 by the National Party, which established apartheid and remains in power.
Mr. de Klerk saw Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who represented the United States at Namibia's independence celebration, back in South Africa today.
Before the two took separate flights to Cape Town this morning, Mr. de Klerk suggested at a news conference here that South Africa was breaking out of its isolation in the world because he had undertaken the gradual dismantling of apartheid.
 
'We Mean What We Say'
His meetings, he said, showed that ''the international community now accepts that drastic change is going to take place in South Africa, that we mean what we say when we say that we want to negotiate.''
''From that acceptance flows a much more constructive and positive approach by the international community,'' Mr. de Klerk said.
In virtually all of his meetings, Mr. de Klerk was asked to explain the changes he was instituting in South Africa. This afforded him an opportunity to explain that he wanted to negotiate with all leaders of the country's black majority and not only representatives of the African National Congress, who are scheduled to meet him April 11.
The South African President also emphasized that South Africa was essential to the economic development of southern Africa, which includes Namibia.
He reminded some black leaders that it was in their interest to cooperate with South Africa, now that the concern of the West was turning to other areas like Eastern Europe.
 
United Front Suggested
''The nations of southern Africa are in danger of becoming marginalized internationally unless they present a united front and benefit from the resources of the region as a whole,'' Mr. de Klerk said in a statement today summing up his meetings.
His contacts were significant more for their variety than their contents. Only one black African country, Malawi, has diplomatic relations with South Africa. But Mr. de Klerk had talks with seven black heads of state or government, including Namibia's new President, Sam Nujoma.
He also met with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, the current chairman of the Organization of African Unity, which has excluded South Africa from membership because of its racial policies.
The most interesting meeting, a South African official said, was the two-hour meeting that Mr. de Klerk had with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, during which they compared notes on the changes set in motion in their two countries. Mr. de Klerk today described his talks with Mr. Shevardnadze as ''enlightening and informative''.
 
A Meeting With Nujoma
The Soviet Union broke off diplomatic ties with South Africa in 1956, and Moscow became a political and financial patron of the African National Congress. The two countries recently renewed contacts at lower level in connection with the political settlement in southern Africa that linked Namibia's independence to the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola.
Mr. de Klerk also said he had a short but rewarding meeting with President Nujoma, whose South-West Africa People's Organization fought a guerrilla war against South African rule in Namibia for 23 years. The South African President said it was clear from Mr. Nujoma's side that their countries ''should remain good friends.''
Namibia has not established diplomatic relations with South Africa, but its economy remains tied to its neighbor. The two countries look likely to exchange trade missions that will function unofficially as legations.
South Africa has such trade missions with Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Swaziland and Lesotho.
''Having been involved in every sphere of life in Namibia, the fact that we are no longer here leaves a sort of a vacuum,'' Mr. de Klerk told reporters.
''There are many spheres where we have an involvement, where we have an interface with Namibia and it is necessary to structure our cooperation.''

HEADLINE: Bush Position on Art Group Evokes Protests From Right

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The refusal by the Bush Administration to endorse restrictions on the content of Federally financed arts programs sparked fierce protests from the social and religious right today in what may turn out to be the first major test of the President's ability to keep ardent conservatives as happy members of his party.
Already edgy that the Republican Party is softening its opposition to abortion, social and religious conservatives responded angrily today to Mr. Bush's announcement Wednesday that the Administration would not support their call for legislation to deal with what they consider objectionable art.
The White House switchboard was deluged with telephone calls from around the country protesting the Administration position, the first time that Mr. Bush has directly defied the wishes of the social conservatives who were a crucial element of Ronald Reagan's coalition but have been feeling increasingly isolated of late.
Legislation to control the content of Federally financed art work is favored by standard-bearers of the moral and religious right like Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and the Rev. Pat Robertson. 
 
Conservatives Press on Issue
In speeches, fund-raising letters and on Mr. Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network, conservatives have been pressing the case that the National Endowment for the Arts has been giving taxpayer money to support art that, in their view, is obscene, promotes homosexuality or is in other ways objectionable.
Some conservatives said they would fight the White House, while others, like the Rev. Louis Sheldon, head of the Traditional Values Coalition, an evangelical lobbying group in Anaheim, Calif., said they could not believe that Mr. Bush knew what members of his Administration were saying in his name or that he had seen the sort of art being financed by the Government.
''If I found out he had approved it, I would ask him to retract it,'' Mr. Sheldon said today about the statements from both White House spokesmen and from John E. Frohnmayer, head of the National Endowment for the Arts.
In the face of the protest, Mr. Frohnmayer issued a statement today emphasizing that he was just as opposed to obscenity as the conservatives who were demanding legislation.
''I will be diligent that obscenity will not be funded by the endowment,'' he said.
 
Criticism From Robertson
On his 700 Club television program today, Mr. Robertson avoided any mention of Mr. Bush, but attacked both the endowment and the Democratic chairman of the subcommittee considering arts legislation, Representative Pat Williams of Montana. Both Mr. Williams and Mr. Frohnmayer had criticized Mr. Robertson on Wednesday.
Mr. Williams praised Mr. Bush for a ''very courageous'' decision that ''isolates a small minority of right-wing religious zealots.''
Mr. Robertson, who ran against Mr. Bush in the 1988 Republican primaries, bridled at that characterization and said his information came from mainstream publications.
Politicians say the brewing fight between the White House and the right on the arts issue illustrates a much larger strain in the Republican coalition as candidates from Pennsylvania to California secure their conservative credentials by tough stands against crime and taxes while then moving to the middle on social issues like abortion.
The President and his handpicked party chairman, Lee Atwater, have been encouraging this move with speeches about how the Republican Party is a ''big tent'' with room for all positions.
 
Broad Position Is Defended
''It's the price of becoming a majority party,'' said Otto Boss, campaign director for Senator Pete Wilson's Republican bid for Governor of California. Senator Wilson has been attacked by some conservatives for his stand in favor of a woman's right to abortion and his acceptance of at least some rights for homosexuals.
''If we're going to be a majority party, we're going to have to have some breadth,'' Mr. Boss added. ''We are essentially in California a conservative party and we have a conservative heading it in Pete Wilson. But then there'll be various shades of gray along the way.''
That attitude is clearly shared at the White House and Republican headquarters, but Mr. Bush, who was always viewed with suspicion from the right, has managed, nevertheless, to stay on good terms with the religious right, which helped elect him.
But now the confrontation is more direct, and the cultural schism Mr. Bush so successfully overcame in his 1988 election drive has again become manifest.
''I think it's a disgrace,'' said Michael Schwartz, a resident fellow at Paul M. Weyrich's Free Congress Foundation, a conservative research group, speaking about the Administration's decision. ''I think George Bush keeps the wrong company. The social set in which he customarily travels would look on someone like Jesse Helms as an ignorant redneck and someone like Robert Mapplethorpe as a great creative spirit. They're entitled to their opinion, but they have no right to take public funds and subsidize this kind of stuff.''
It was an exhibition of the late Mr. Mapplethorp's photographs, which include pictures of naked men and children, that has helped stir the furor directed at the National Endowment for the Arts. The endowment helped pay for the Mapplethorpe exhibition.
Many political analysts saw the Administration's stand on the arts as part of a larger effort to appeal to a crucial generation of voters, what Linda Divall, the Republican pollster, described as the ''emerging coalition of baby boomers who have an interest in more than just the economy and foreign policy.''
Mr. Schwartz said that he understood this appeal but that he thought the party was making a mistake. ''It's very alienating to people like me,'' he said. Mr. Schwartz, a Democrat, said he voted Republican in the last three Presidential elections because of the party's stand on cultural issues. ''I don't have to vote in the next Presidential election.''
