HEADLINE: Marathon Oil to Sell a Cleaner-Burning Gasoline

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 22

 BODY:
The Marathon Oil Company, in an effort to popularize a cleaner-burning gasoline, says it will begin selling in limited quantities the first reformulated unleaded gasolines that can be burned by virtually all car engines.
Two previously announced efforts to sell reformulated fuel have been more limited in scope. In California ARCO offers a reformulated leaded gasoline that can be used by cars made before catalytic converters were required equipment. Conoco and Phillips Petroleum have been selling a reformulated unleaded gasoline in Denver, but only in the regular or lowest octane grade. 
 
Available on Monday
Marathon, a subsidiary of the USX Corporation, said on Wednesday that it would begin selling what it calls ''Amaraclean'' gasoline in regular (87 octane), midgrade (89 octane) and premium (92 octane) at 161 service stations in the Detroit area starting Monday. Marathon said it would absorb the additional cost of producing the new gasoline for the time being, but later consumers would inevitably pay extra for the fuel if it was widely accepted.
''People might think that because this is reformulated they will have less performance - that isn't true,'' said Richard White, Marathon vice president of marketing. ''We want to make sure people want clean air and will try our gasoline.''
While Congress debates a clean-air bill, some legislators favor a provision that would force the auto industry to produce vehicles that could burn methanol or some other cleaner-burning fuel to reduce pollution. The petroleum and auto industries oppose such a measure, contending that cleaning up gasoline can accomplish the same thing at far less cost and trouble.
Emissions from engines using Marathon's fuel will be lower in carbon monoxide and in unburned hydrocarbons that cause the formation of ozone, a prime component of smog. Marathon said the new gasoline would result in a 20 percent reduction in unburned hydrocarbon emissions and a 14 percent reduction in carbon monoxide.
 
Three Improvements
The Marathon gasoline makes three improvements in clean-air technology. By adding methyl tertiary butyl ether, the fuel contains more oxygen and burns more completely, thus reducing carbon monoxide emissions. The fuel also contains less butane, which evaporates easily and contributes to the production of smog. Some hydrocarbons that do not burn well, like benzene and toluene, are reduced, according to Ed Ledico, a technical specialist for Marathon.
Marathon gasoline is sold at about 4,500 service stations nationwide but the company is currently limiting sales of the new fuel to the Detroit area because of its limited capacity to produce methyl tertiary butyl ether.
Donald R. Buist, director of the Ford Motor Company's environmental and fuel economy office, said, ''We are pleased that Marathon has taken a very positive step to develop a fuel that is cleaner burning than those used today.'' He added that a group of Big Three auto makers and 14 oil companies was studying various cleaner gasolines and alternate fuels on different types of engines and expects to report the findings of its research later this year.

HEADLINE: A Warning From Argentina

 BODY:
In the best of times, Argentine politics tends toward melodrama. In the worst, it tends toward military coups. Eight months into President Carlos Saul Menem's term, times are getting very bad. It is in the U.S. interest to help Mr. Menem master his gathering problems. But the main responsibility is necessarily his alone. 
Six months ago Mr. Menem seemed a savior. Taking office amid hyperinflationary chaos, he boldly pledged to shrink a bloated public sector and free protected markets. A Peronist, he built a Peron-like coalition of labor, business and military backers. His popularity hit 70 percent.
Today that support has crumbled, as has Government credibility, following repeated shifts in policy and personnel. There have been three Economy Ministers, four central bank presidents, three emergency economic plans. Inflation again rockets out of control. The middle class fears ruin. Business has withdrawn its confidence. Labor threatens defiance. Poverty and hunger stalk a fertile land.
It could be worse, as an article on today's Op-Ed page suggests.
The author, Ernesto Barreiro, sparked a military mutiny in 1987 by refusing to report for trial. He had been charged with torturing detainees at an interrogation center he commanded during military rule. The mutiny won Major Barreiro, and other military defendants beneath the rank of general, immunity from human rights prosecution.
The major and like-minded junior officers staged two further revolts. From the war paint smeared on their faces during these uprisings, they took the name ''carapintadas,'' meaning painted faces. They endorsed Mr. Menem's candidacy, and were rewarded with an amnesty covering all crimes during military rule.
Mr. Menem also ordered carapintada leaders retired from active duty. That left them more time to agitate politically. As the Op-Ed article suggests, they do not seek direct military rule. Their hope is to exercise power informally from within a figurehead Menem regime.
That's unacceptable for most Argentines, who blame the military for the disasters of the 70's and 80's. The carapintadas seek to deflect blame elsewhere - to the generals, to former President Alfonsin, to interests resisting the Menem reforms.
Meanwhile, Mr. Menem himself feeds military fantasies. Last month he authorized the armed forces to take responsibility for internal security in case economic problems spark social unrest. A similar decree by the previous Peronist Government opened the door to the 1976 coup.
Remilitarization of Argentina's Government still seems unlikely. But desperation grows daily. The U.S. and governments across Latin America have every interest in Mr. Menem's quickly regaining his political balance and serving out his full elected term. On economic questions, there is scope for Washington to help. But the survival of constitutional government in Argentina depends on Mr. Menem's supplying the bold and imaginative leadership he promised at the start of his term.

HEADLINE: Facing Facts in Connecticut

 BODY:
Gov. William O'Neill of Connecticut has decided not to run for re-election, with good reason. His mishandling of the state's budget crisis last year, highlighted by a billion-dollar increase in taxes, sent his popularity into a nosedive. Foreseeing a mud-slinging campaign for which he has no stomach, he wisely opts for honorable retirement. His successor will have to pick up the pieces.
Mr. O'Neill succeeded Ella Grasso upon her death in 1981; he was her Lieutenant Governor. He grew in the job, and Connecticut grew in his time. Twice re-elected, he oversaw a marked improvement in the state's school system and critical road and bridge repair. But when the Northeast's economy softened he failed to anticipate the consequences and offered no leadership in reshaping state finances. More than ever, conditions demanded a personal income tax. Mr. O'Neill offered instead an unpopular miscellany of higher taxes.
The Governor recently sought to repair his fallen image with a blitz of campaign-style advertising. But when Lowell Weicker, the maverick Republican ex-Senator, said he would run as an independent candidate and immediately shot to the top of the popularity charts, Mr. O'Neill got out.
Regrettably, his delay discouraged some strong Democrats who might have run if he had decided earlier. Only Representative Bruce Morrison was brave enough to challenge Mr. O'Neill head-on. He now emerges as the Democrats' front-runner, but the list of contenders grows daily. Among them, only William Cibes, a professor at Connecticut College, campaigns openly for tax reform. On the Republican side, Representative John Rowland leads at this stage, but he may be challenged, too.
In the end it will be a three-way race. Connecticut will be best served by candidates who face up to the fiscal facts.

HEADLINE: AT HOME ABROAD;
Promise at Midnight

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: WINDHOEK, Namibia

 BODY:
It was a scene of amiable chaos.
Hosni Mubarak and Nelson Mandela and Yasir Arafat trying to find their seats in the jammed V.I.P. section of the stadium. Herero women walking by in their long Victorian dresses and bonnets. Ululating cries from the distant stands. 
The schedule slipped. It was well past the appointed hour of midnight when the South African flag was lowered and the new blue, red, green and gold of Namibia raised. But it happened.
After 70 years under South African control, after guerrilla war and torture and exile, Namibians had their own country. And the symbol of the South African flag going down let emotion loose in that stadium: not just happiness, I thought, but a kind of amazement that the struggle and international diplomacy and politics had finally worked.
Bience Gawanas, who spent 12 years in exile, tried to explain what she felt. ''It was just nice to see that flag coming down. It was the difference between what I was and what I am.''
But why should the world care all that much? Namibia is a remote country, with only about 1.3 million people in a mostly desert land twice the size of California.
The answer is that several factors give Namibia's independence significance beyond the usual power calculations. One is the role of the South African Government.
For decades South Africa resisted international efforts to make it disgorge Namibia, which it had taken over from Germany after World War I. When South Africa finally accepted a plan for elections supervised by the United Nations and leading to freedom, it stalled and evaded on carrying out the plan.
But last April Pretoria finally said yes. It held to that through crises in the election process. And President F. W. de Klerk came here for the ceremony. He spoke just before the South African flag was lowered.
It was not an easy moment for Mr. de Klerk. The crowd, impatient to see the flag go down, had begun to chant ''Down, down.'' But he spoke graciously, and he won his audience over. At the end there was more than routine applause.
Mr. de Klerk said the road to Namibia's independence had been ''long and arduous.'' Many had died in the process, ''and it is fitting that we should remember them tonight.'' He clearly meant people on both sides. The audience responded to that acknowledgment of history.
Namibian independence showed that South Africa would keep its commitments, Mr. de Klerk said. The statement was a little hard to take after all the years of obstruction. But Mr. de Klerk was really making a point about the process of negotiation that is about to start in South Africa itself. He was saying: You can trust me.
Another factor of note in the Namibian story is the role of the international community, including the United Nations. The United States had an important part in the diplomacy of the last dozen years, as did other Western powers. U.N. forces have been a great success here over the last year: very possibly an example for other difficult political transitions.
Finally, there is the part played here by the idea of a written Constitution enforced by judges: that very American idea. It is not too much to say that constitutionalism made possible agreement among Namibians.
The small population of this country is made up of 11 ethnic groups, divided by race, language, culture, politics. The largest party, Swapo, has most of its support among the Ovambo people of northern Namibia. It won the election for a constituent assembly that drafted the Constitution. But approval needed a two-thirds vote, and Swapo fell short of that.
''Not getting two-thirds was the luckiest thing that ever happened to us,'' a Swapo lawyer said. He meant that the drafters of the Constitution had to get a consensus. In the end the assembly approved it unanimously.
The key element, the reassuring one, was the inclusion of a bill of rights. Many of its guarantees are familiar to Americans: freedom of speech, press, religion, association, the right to just compensation for property taken by the state.
That last provision was reassuring to the 100,000 whites, a small but economically dominant group. But the Constitution also prohibits discrimination by race or sex, whether done by the state or private parties, and it explicitly allows affirmative action. It prohibits capital punishment. Constitutions can be just pieces of paper. But this one has strong provisions for enforcement by judges. There is a recent tradition of judicial intervention on behalf of human rights, and all parties seem to feel safer on that ground.
Here again Namibia could have a larger meaning. If the Constitution works, if peace holds in this divided country, South Africa could look for a similar path.

HEADLINE: Terrain Turns Bumpy in Connecticut Race

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
Connecticut's political terrain has undergone two profound changes this month with former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s return from retirement to run for governor as an independent and Gov. William A. O'Neill's abrupt announcement that he would not seek re-election.
The withdrawal on Tuesday of Mr. O'Neill, who had indicated as recently as five days earlier that he would ''absolutely'' run, left the Democratic Party in disarray. It now has no groomed successor, consensus on a leading candidate, or even a contender with statewide recognition.
Mr. Weicker, meanwhile, a maverick liberal Republican who is now a candidate without a party, is seen by several polls as the front-running candidate, even though he has just started organizing a campaign and has been attacked by figures in both major political parties. 
''This is very strange,'' said State Representative Jonathan Pelto of Storrs, the political director of the Connecticut Democratic Party. ''You have to go back to the Senate race in 1970 to find something like this or, in a gubernatorial race, back to 1939 when the Socialist Mayor of Bridgeport ran.''
This week both parties are selecting delegates to their July conventions. Among Republicans, Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury, a 32-year-old conservative, appears to be the leading candidate.
Others include the Senate minority leader, Reginald J. Smith of New Hartford; Joel Schiavone, a wealthy developer from New Haven, and Joseph McGee, a Fairfield banker. Among Democrats, a primary appears to be all but certain. Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, a liberal who announced his candidacy in January, was the only Democrat prepared to challenge Mr. O'Neill.
The Governor would have been seeking a third full term in office.
State Representative Willian J. Cibes Jr. of New London formally entered the Democratic race on Tuesday.
Mr. O'Neill's withdrawal also left several people who would have been seriously interested in launching a campaign months ago pondering whether there was time and support to begin now.
They include Mayor Christopher F. Droney of West Hartford, the brother of the state Democratic chairman, John F. Droney Jr., and the Senate president pro tempore, John B. Larson of East Hartford, a moderate who, with Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Hartford, was considered a likely heir to Mr. O'Neill. Ms. Kennelly said she would not be a candidate.
''Everyone is saying, 'Hold your breath and wait to see what the fallout is after everything shakes down,' '' said the Mayor of Hartford, Carrie Perry Saxon, a Democrat who would have supported Mr. O'Neill or Ms. Kennelly but is now firmly uncommitted.
But the press secretary for Mr. Morrison's campaign seemed to delight in the party's turmoil. ''I seem to remember an old Chinese saying,'' said the press secretary, Paul Donnelly. ''There is great disorder under heaven, and the situation is extremely favorable.''
 
'Win-Win Proposition'
Republicans had mixed emotions about Mr. O'Neill's withdrawal. Many thought he would have been an easy candidate to defeat, considering that recent polls gave him the most negative ratings of his nine years.
''It looks like a win-win proposition to us, either Bill O'Neill remained in the race or there is the chaos that results from his withdrawal,'' said Mr. Rowland's press secretary, Jack R. Goldberg. ''Bill O'Neill would have been a good target for us to run against, but the discontent with him also spills over to the Democrats as a party. They have to run on his record.''
Mr. O'Neill, 59 years old, cited two principal reasons for his withdrawal: a distaste for negative campaign tactics and ''political realities,'' a euphemism for his recent decline in popularity, which is widely seen as linked with nearly $1 billion in tax increases that he approved last summer, the state's slowing economy and voters' desire for a change.
His backers said his decision was made so late largely because of a split between the Governor's supporters and aides, who were divided about his prospects for re-election. ''This was the only time I've disagreed with the Governor since I've been chairman,'' said John Droney, a staunch supporter.
 
'Far More Exciting Race'
Mr. O'Neill, who has not endorsed any Democrat, also said that Mr. Weicker's campaign was not a factor in his withdrawal.
''It made it a far more exciting race, and I'm sure it still will be,'' the Governor told reporters on Tuesday. ''It would have been a spirited campaign, and I would have loved to have debated Lowell Weicker.''
Mr. Weicker, a three-term Senator who vowed to leave politics after losing his seat in 1988 to the State Attorney General, Joseph I. Lieberman, is expected to pick his party name and a running mate within the next month.
Already he has been painted by Mr. Morrison as a Republican running as an independent and by Mr. Rowland as a liberal running as an independent. Republicans believe Mr. Weicker will split the Democratic vote to the advantage of their candidate. Democrats believe Mr. Weicker will draw support from both parties.
''He's got to be considered the leading candidate for governor,'' Mr. Pelto said.
The co-chairman of the Weicker independent candidacy, Thomas J. D'Amore Jr., a former Republican state chairman, said Mr. O'Neill's decision left the Democratic leadership confused. ''There is no bench - no depth,'' he said.
He cautioned, though, that it is early in the campaign and the Democrats have won every gubernatorial race since 1970. There are about 700,000 registered Democrats in Connecticut, 550,000 unaffiliated voters and 450,000 Republicans.
''It's a formidable organization,'' he said. ''We'll have to wait and see what comes out of all this.''

HEADLINE: LAW: At the Bar

BYLINE: By David Margolick

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
When J. Willard Hurst attended Harvard Law School in the 1930's, the study of legal history was nonexistent. Oh, yes, some professors had studied obscure legal doctrines and there was one superannuated scholar studying history, but it was Roman history, and he stalked Langdell Hall like a ghost.
Why this dearth, given the inherent overlap between law and history? The explanation came a century ago from Christopher Columbus Langdell, Harvard Law School's intellectual architect: The law was a self-contained science and the law library its laboratory. One need not study how law actually affected people or how legal institutions evolved; all wisdom could be gleaned from appellate decisions. This approach not only gave law professors a shot at omniscience but also spared them from having to learn other disciplines, set foot in a courtroom or state legislature, or even step outside. 
From the moment he arrived here at the University of Wisconsin Law School 53 years ago, and was mandated to bridge the gap between law and society by studying how laws were enacted and applied, Professor Hurst changed all that. By his intellect and example, he is universally credited with legitimizing legal history. Even in retirement he remains one of the few legal scholars whose work can be measured in shelf feet -and shelf feet of bona fide research rather than of cut-and-pasted cases and comments. In an era when academia, like sports, has been watered down through expansion, he is an old-fashioned towering figure.
In some ways, he is also an anachronism. He is the one of the last disciples of Louis D. Brandeis (whom he once served as law clerk), having inherited Brandeis's interest in grass-roots democracy. He is a disciple of the LaFollettes, who charged Wisconsin's academics to view the state as their campus and their laboratory. He is the last of the Legal Realists, the Depression-era scholars who tried to place law in a larger social context.
Mr. Hurst is one of those rare figures in academia who is as well-known for his modesty as for his scholarship. And even as he approaches 80, he still casts his long shadow over the field. ''You're either a Hurstian or a reviser of Hurst,'' said Lawrence M. Friedman of Stanford Law School, one of a generation of legal historians either tought or influenced by Professor Hurst.
Mr. Hurst had the academic pedigree to do whatever he wished. He graduated at the top of his class at Harvard, edited its Law Review, served as research assistant to Felix Frankfurter before clerking for Brandeis in 1936.
It was Brandeis who urged Mr. Hurst to head for Wisconsin and study its democratic institutions. While there Lloyd Garrison, then the school's dean, urged him to create a program in ''law and society,'' investigating how the state's legal system and economy cross-pollinated.
The spectacle of law professors doing social research was rare and at times ridiculous, like the Yale scholar who once charted parking-meter use in New Haven. Mr. Hurst focused on the lumber industry in Wisconsin, all to determine how industry both used and molded the laws of contracts, property and other areas. Mr. Hurst discovered Chippewa Falls long before Woody Allen found Annie Hall there; the work of the courts there was, to him, more interesting, less abstract and certainly less pawed over than that of the United States Supreme Court.
Mr. Hurst's was a largely uncharted route to respectability. Once, when he told a leading law dean he was working on ''legal economic history,'' the dean harrumphed: ''You'd never get away with it at my place!'' But rather than feel excluded from the mainstream, Mr. Hurst simply created his own.
''For me personally, he was an incredible inspiration,'' Morton Horwitz of Harvard said. Robert Gordon of Stanford added: ''Every scholar needs heroes, and Willard is one of the few authentic heroes of our field.''
As his studies continued and broadened, recognition came. Three times he turned down the deanship of Yale Law School, as well as a chair at Harvard. ''I guess I was just too pleasure-loving,'' he recalled. ''I was having too good a time in Wisconsin.''
Mr. Hurst is one of those people who, beneath a deceptively elderly exterior, retain all the fire, impatience and curiosity of youth.
He still goes into his office, still sifts through piles of manuscripts, still grumbles over all the issues -political action committees, Ralph Nader, antitrust laws - younger legal historians are still neglecting.
He takes great pride in his students - which all younger legal historians necessarily are - even when they criticize him. ''Part of your function as a teacher is to send out people who've done more than you,'' he said.
That may be the only scholarly endeavor in which Willard Hurst has fallen short.

HEADLINE: James H. R. Cromwell Dies at 93; Married 'Richest Girl in World'

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
James H. R. Cromwell, a wealthy businessman who was briefly a politician and diplomat and best known in the 1930's and 40's as the husband of ''the richest girl in the world,'' Doris Duke, died of a pulmonary ailment on Monday at the Marin Terrace retirement home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 93 years old.
Mr. Cromwell was connected to three of the greatest fortunes in America through two of his marriages and one of his mother's. While Jimmy, as Mr. Cromwell was known, was in his teens, his mother, Lucretia, married E. T. Stotesbury, a Philadelphia multimillionaire and banking partner of J. P. Morgan. 
Mr. Cromwell's first marriage, in 1920, was to Delphine Dodge, the daughter of Horace T. Dodge, the automobile magnate. The two were divorced in 1928. Marriage to Doris Duke Miss Duke, who became his second wife in 1935, inherited a tobacco fortune from her father, James Buchanan Duke, the founder of Duke University.
Mr. Cromwell was in the public eye steadily before and during World War II while he was married to Miss Duke. Unlike the vast majority of their peers in the Social Register, they were fervent supporters of Franklin D. Roosevelt and his New Deal.
In 1933 Mr. Cromwell published a book, ''Voice of Young America,'' in which he advocated measures like guaranteed bank deposits, abandonment of the gold standard, compulsory unemployment insurance and Federally aided public works, all of which came to pass under Roosevelt.
Four years later, in a treatise, ''In Defense of Capitalism,'' he shocked business leaders by advocating tight control of money by the Federal Reserve System.
In 1940 Roosevelt appointed Mr. Cromwell Minister to Canada, an ambassadorship at a time when the only Ambassador to a country in the British Commonwealth was the one accredited to the Court of St. James's.
 
A Bid for U.S. Senate
Mr. Cromwell resigned the post after five months to run for the United States Senate from New Jersey; he and Miss Duke lived in a mansion in Somerset County. His only bid for elective office ended in decisive defeat.
The Cromwells separated soon afterward and in 1943 became involved in acrimonious divorce proceedings that went on for five years. Miss Duke, asserting that her husband wanted a $7 million ''endowment,'' won a decree in Reno, but it was voided by a court in New Jersey. Mr. Cromwell then obtained a divorce that became final in 1948.
That year he was married for a third time, to Maxine MacFetridge, the daughter of a cement company manager. She died in 1968. In 1971 he married Germaine Benjamin, the widow of a financier. She died in 1987.
Mr. Cromwell was born in Manhattan, the son of Oliver Eaton Cromwell, a member of an old New York family. He went to Lawrenceville School and spent two years at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Cromwell, an athletic man, piloted racing boats, played tennis with Bill Tilden and was a talented amateur boxer, once staying three rounds with Tommy Loughran, later the world light-heavyweight champion. Mr. Cromwell served in the Marine Corps in World War I. Mr. Cromwell's Career Mr. Cromwell began his business career with Drexel & Co. in Philadelphia. While married to Miss Dodge, he started an automobile finance company, Cromwell-Dodge. In the 1950's he was involved in oil and gas production in the West and in Canada; he retired in the early 1980's.
He lived for many years in Southampton, L. I., before moving to the West Coast two years ago.
Mr. Cromwell is survived by a daughter from his marriage to Miss MacFetridge, Hope Hampton of Belvedere, Calif., and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
The Brooklyn dining scene is often noted for its diversity, economy and lack of pretension, but rarely for its romance. Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights are fine for a week-night dalliance, but with few exceptions, Manhattan still has the patent on the Big Date. Adele, an alluring little restaurant in a former carriage house in Park Slope, is striving to offer a romantic neighborhood alternative.
This year-and-a-half-old venture is the creation of John Sielski, an experienced restaurant manager who started at Huberts when it was still in Brooklyn (it is now on Park Avenue in Manhattan), and Jim Dozmati, who was a garden designer by profession. Their 19th-century carriage house - a blacksmith and carpenter were still toiling there when they took over - seats 40 with room to spare under the high pressed-tin ceiling. A crackling fireplace, candlelight, flower-patterned wallpaper and classical music contribute to the amorous mood. 
The eclectic American fare has become more impassioned and confident in recent months compared with visits last year. The chef, Melicia Phillips, who came from a three-year-stint at Chanterelle, turns out a wisely limited but diverse menu with Italian and French accents. Starters can be as simple as blood-warming duck consomme with al dente julienne of vegetables, or as urbane as a velvety and well-seasoned foie gras-and-avocado terrine. Soups are taken seriously here. Cream of leek, squash and carrot is lusty and delicate at the same time; cream of mussel soup is on the rich side, but so scintillating with saffron that it is hard to be temperate. The menu is getting a spring cleaning, so some of the dishes I sampled in the last six weeks may be in storage by now. If the squab salad with a compote of butternut squash and apples is available, go for it. The lightly bound terrine of lobster and shrimp is another good starter. Wild mushroom cannelloni has double-barreled flavor, boosted by its mushroom broth. And for two-fisted eaters, there is a pancakelike fritter of potato and bacon set over a sweet-sharp abundance of red cabbage, a harmonious combination.
For a small, relatively new restaurant, Adele has a varied and uncommon wine list. Among whites to consider are the 1988 Saint-Aubin, Les Remilly, Domaine Aime Langoureau ($22); the 1988 Silverado sauvignon blanc from Napa ($15), and the 1988 Kendall-Jackson chardonnay, vintners reserve ($18). In reds, there are a light but ripe 1983 Givry from Domaine Chenard for $22 and a slightly headier 1977 Gigondas at $18.
Entrees have a clean and unfussy appeal. Roasted guinea hen, meatier and more flavorful than so-called free-range chicken, is paired with cabbage, green beans and carrots. Shell steak has a deep-aged flavor and comes out nicely blackened yet moist under a slab of garlicky herb butter. Braised venison with spatzle and Brussels sprouts had a wonderfully mellow red-wine sauce, but the meat was on the dry side. Roast duck was better in its faintly sweet apple-cider sauce, accompanied by sauteed watercress and gratin of turnip.
Sea scallops arrive under an avalanche of deep-fried leeks and are ringed with a pleasantly sour-edged sorrel sauce. Salmon is nicely broiled, but the sauce of cucumber juice and fish stock tasted about as pallid as it sounds. On another visit, a leek and butter sauce did the fillet justice.
Don't expect ginger ice cream here to be like the lean, palate-cleansing scoops doled out at Japanese restaurants. If it weren't for the ginger, this could be spread on toast at breakfast. Brandy-soaked cherries nestled in pastry cream over puff pastry is a less cloying winner, as are cinnamon-dusted apple fritters with a prune-and-currant compote. Among the lightest offerings are a lovely millefeuille of strawberries with strawberry puree, and pear poached in red wine with cinnamon.
Adele may not pose a threat to the Rainbow Room or the River Cafe as a destination for major-league wooing. But it's a fine place to build up to it.
 
Adele

HEADLINE: A Home for a Bustling Borough's Memorabilia

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
How do you tell the 350-year-long story of New York's most populous and arguably most colorful borough in a small gallery with a relatively minuscule budget?
That was the challenge facing the Brooklyn Historical Society, which opened a compact museum of Brooklyn history last fall on the ground floor of its landmark Brooklyn Heights building. The 4,000-square-foot Shellens Gallery, at 128 Pierrepont Street (at Clinton Street), is at once an imaginative compendium of old Coney Island waxworks, Brooklyn Dodgers memorabilia, props from ''The Honeymooners'' and about 1,000 other objects, and a scholarly, social-historical exploration of how Brooklynites have lived, worked and played.
''We wanted to find things that are familiar, fun and interesting - like the Dodgers, the Brooklyn Bridge and the Navy Yard - and use them as wedges to be able to talk about broader issues like work, industry and transportation,'' said Ellen Marie Snyder-Grenier, a curator who planned the exhibition with David M. Kahn, the society's executive director. Consequently, the gallery's exhibits are organized around five of the borough's most recognizable aspects - the Brooklyn Bridge, Coney Island, the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the people of Brooklyn. 
 
A 7-Foot Zinc Eagle
At the entrance to the exhibition area looms a seven-foot zinc eagle that once perched near Washington and Johnson Streets at The Daily Eagle, the Brooklyn newspaper that was published from 1841 to 1955. A nearby model of the Brooklyn Bridge arches leads to displays about the 107-year-old bridge and other aspects of the history of transportation and residential development in Brooklyn. A case full of bridge souvenirs (including a popular Italian chewing gum called Brooklyn) stands beside bucolic 19th-century paintings of the Fulton Ferry and historic maps and promotional brochures for neighborhoods, then new, like Park Slope and Brownsville.
The long, illustrious and ultimately sad tale of Brooklyn's former industrial might is told in an exhibition area that vaguely resembles the hull of a battleship. Photos, mortar shells, lunch pails and other artifacts chronicle the life of the Navy Yard, the sprawling shipbuilding complex that operated on the East River from 1801 to 1966 and employed 70,000 people during World War II. Exhibits about the local labor movement and early pollution are complemented by a display overflowing with beer bottles, pharmaceuticals, shoes, clocks, pencils, clothing and other objects made in Brooklyn.
A third of a century after the final out of their final inning at Ebbets Field, the Brooklyn Dodgers still have a mystique that is evoked in another corner of the museum. Die-hard fans will find autographed baseballs, baseball cards, photos and banners, as well as a base, a brick and seats taken from Ebbets Field before it was demolished in 1960 to make way for an apartment building.
 
Essence and Counteressence
To many people, the quintessential Brooklynite was (and is) Ralph Kramden in Jackie Gleason's television series ''The Honeymooners.'' Despite the presence of a stage set lent by a ''Honeymooners'' fan club, the purpose of the next exhibition area is to debunk stereotypes about Brooklyn residents and present an overview of the borough's remarkable ethnic diversity. A make-believe newsstand with a dozen contemporary ethnic newspapers makes the point. Cultural artifacts relating to Brooklyn's Jewish, black, Italian, German, Irish, Polish, Dutch, Scandinavian, West Indian, Hispanic, Asian and Soviet communities are also on view.
Just beyond a giant pink-and-silver costume from Brooklyn's annual West Indian Day Parade, scaffolding suggestive of the Cyclone roller coaster signals the beginning of the Coney Island display. This section on Brooklyn amusements includes lithographs of elegant 19th-century beach-front hotels, a carousel horse and other souvenirs from turn-of-the-century amusement parks, several ghoulish heads from the defunct World in Wax museum at Coney Island and Playbills from long-gone theaters.
One of the most elaborately festive of New York's many festivals is the subject of a temporary exhibition called ''The Giglio: Brooklyn's Dancing Tower.'' The show, on view through May 15, explores the customs associated with the annual feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel and St. Paulinus in the Italian community of the Williamsburg section. It culminates with 125 people carrying a 3,000-pound tower called a giglio.
 
The Next Show
This changing-exhibition area will be used for shows on 19th-century portraiture (opening May 25); the borough's many Hispanic communities and Brooklyn's role in the manufacture of penicillin.
The society, which was founded in 1863 as the Long Island Historical Society, long had exhibitions relating to world and natural history, but in 1926 its gallery was converted into commercial space because of economic problems. During the next half century or so, the society functioned largely as a research institution, and its elegant 150,000-volume library remains a leading repository of Brooklyn history.
Although a few temporary shows were mounted in the early 1980's after Mr. Kahn became director, it was not until the society's name change in 1985 that planning began for the history museum. The project cost $1.8 million, with $400,000 coming from the estate of Ruth Ann Shellens, a Brooklyn businesswoman and real-estate investor. The society plans to expand the exhibition area by the turn of the century, Mr. Kahn said, contingent on the success of a $5 million capital campaign slated to begin this fall.
The society also presents about 80 lectures, tours and other public programs a year. Gallery hours are noon to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Admission is $2.50; $1 for children, and free on Tuesdays. Lectures are free with admission, and most walking tours are $8. Information: (718) 624-0890.

HEADLINE: Concern Over Tokyo Stocks Sends the Dow 32.31 Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday amid widening concern over the plunging stock market in Japan and new fears that the American economy could be heading into a recession.
Heavy computerized program selling helped bring down the market, traders said.
At shortly after 2:15 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average had slid 50 points and then recovered somewhat to close at 2,695.72, down 32.21.
Volume amounted to 175.9 million shares, up from 131 million the day before, but with 1,200 stocks down and only 368 ahead. 
Just 10 issues managed to reach new highs, while 73 touched new lows.
A wave of program trading lifted the Tokyo stock market toward the end of trading today although the market remained shaky and volatile.
The Nikkei index closed at 30,372.16, for a gain of 528.82, or 1.8 percent. [Page D6.] Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Hutton, said a big factor in the American selling wave was a front-page article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday raising the possibility that banks may make credit much harder to get and thereby push an already weak economy into recession.
''Traders are getting a little nervous,'' he said, ''and these days it doesn't take much volume to move the market.''
The selloff in Japan raised new fears that because of the exceptionally close financial ties between the United States and Japan, far more drastic corrective measures there could make problems here far worse - and then push down the stock market even more.
In an analysis of the mounting inflationary crisis in Japan, Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said, ''What's wrong is that interest rates in Japan are rising.''
He also noted that money growth in February was higher than in January and the yen was ''weak and getting weaker,'' all of which, he said, add to inflation.
''That means,'' he said, ''that to beat back inflationary pressures, the Bank of Japan has to raise rates again. And if it does, the outlook will darken the economy further and their economy will affect ours.''
Noting that the Japanese market had plunged 23 percent on the Nikkei index this year, he remarked, ''Investors are very concerned about Japan when their market decline is as disorderly and volatile as it is; it makes investors nervous that something is fundamentally wrong, that there is some serious fundamental problem in the Japanese economy.''
 
Japan Effect on U.S. Economy
Echoing the old saying that when the United States sneezes, other countries catch a cold, he said, ''Serious problems in the Japanese economy could affect the United States economy.''
Computerized program selling played a major role in bringing down the market, said Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm that tracks such movements.
At first glance, he said, it did not appear that the programs were that important, but he subsequently revised his view, maintaining that the duration and intensity of the selling represented ''real selling.''
In what Wall Street has come to accept as just a market phenomenon, traders set up either buy or sell programs to take advantage of a price spread between, say, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index and the S.&P. 500 futures.
Mr. Birinyi said he spotted two ''buy'' programs lasting 11 minutes and 14 minutes, one before 10 A.M. and the other before 3 P.M. He said he also traced six ''sell'' programs, including one of 20 minutes before 1:30 P.M. that brought down the market 10.59 points. Another 13-minute program sent the market tumbling by 13.51 points.
People on Wall Street said that traders change the programs from ''buy'' to ''sell'' almost instantly because they watch the screen on their quotation machines and touch off one or the other program as the market shifts.
In a reflection of the market weakness, the Dow industrials all declined, except for Boeing, which rose 1/8, to 71 1/4. The plane maker said it would add four million square feet of space in Everett, Wash., to meet the demand for new 747's and 767's.
Among the industrials, Coca-Cola fell 1 1/2, to 72 1/2, in heavy trading; Goodyear fell 1 1/4, to 37, and American Express fell 1 1/8, to 26 5/8, on 2.3 million shares, the third-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Dow Transportation Stocks
The Dow transportation stocks slid 13.16, to 1,158.78, with Delta Air Lines down 1 5/8, at 71 1/4; UAL down 1, at 152; USAir down 1, at 29 3/4, and Federal Express down 1 3/8, at 53 7/8.
Among other weak stocks, Genuine Parts fell 1 3/4, to 37 3/4, and Wells Fargo 2 1/2, at 69 5/8, in heavy trading, on the possibility of new problem loans and speculators selling short.
J.P. Morgan, the banking company, topped the Big Board list of most-active stocks, falling 3/8, to 34 3/8, with 6.1 million shares changing hands. But traders said the selling was dividend-related.
Walt Disney shares slid 3, to 111 7/8, in heavy trading amid talk that Disney, which has a big following in Japan because of major operations there, could face Japanese selling if Japanese investors needed money to meet margin calls.
With gold advancing slightly, gold stocks also advanced. ASA, with interests in South Africa, rose 1 1/4, to 55 1/2 and Newmont Gold rose 5/8, to 49 1/2. Computer stocks weakened, with Compaq off 2 5/8, at 97 5/8, and Microsoft off 2, at 111 1/4.
Other indexes also declined. The S.&P. 500 fell 4.05, to 335.69; the Amex market-value index 2.67, to 360.48, and the Nasdaq 4.79, to 434.51.

HEADLINE: Ingersoll Scrambles to Avoid Default

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 22

 BODY:
After successfully expanding his newspaper empire through much of the 1980's, Ralph Ingersoll 2d was scrambling today to avoid a default on some of his company's high-yield ''junk bonds.''
The bonds, issued by Mr. Ingersoll's Community Newspapers Inc. in connection with its 1987 acquisition of four Ohio newspapers and a shopper's newspaper on Long Island called The Pennysaver, trade at deep discounts from their face amounts.
The discount reflects investors' belief that the acquired newspapers are not meeting their financial targets and that Community Newspapers, as a result, might not be able to pay its debts. The publisher also started a daily newspaper in St. Louis to compete against The Post-Dispatch. 
''Community Newspapers cannot meet its debt-service obligations,'' said Stephen Unterhalter, a senior analyst at R. D. Smith & Company, a New York-based dealer in distressed securities. ''It is not in default yet, but it is obvious that it is about to be.''
That conclusion stems from a so-called reset feature on some of the bonds. By requiring Community Newspapers to pay much higher interest beginning on June 30, it would almost surely lead to a missed payment. Apparently to avoid such a default, Mr. Ingersoll said on Wednesday that Community Newspapers would seek to buy back the bonds at 25 cents to 55 cents on the dollar.
Asked about the buyback plan, Mr. Ingersoll said in a telephone interview today from his office in Princeton, N.J., that it was partly to avoid the default that would almost surely result if the interest rate were reset. Bondholders had also asked to be bought out, he said.
''They started calling us directly, seeking to sell bonds, so we said, 'Maybe it would make good sense for everybody if we got a loan and went out and bought back some of those bonds,' '' Mr. Ingersoll said.
Mr. Unterhalter said he understood that financial difficulties were being experienced by Community Newspaper's Ohio properties - The Lake County News-Herald in Willoughby, outside Cleveland; The Lorain Journal, also outside Cleveland; The Mansfield News-Journal, between Cleveland and Columbus, and The Dover-New Philadelphia Times-Reporter, near Canton.
The company is a unit of Ingersoll Publications Inc., which owns more than 25 daily newspapers and 150 weekly newspapers in the United States. Ingersoll publishes papers like The Glendale (Calif.) News Press, The New Haven (Conn.) Journal-Courier and The Trentonian in New Jersey.
''The basic problem is that the projections Mr. Ingersoll gave the banks for cash-flow growth were far greater than has actually materialized,'' Mr. Unterhalter said of Community Newspapers, noting that in 1988 the company lost $43.6 million and that its results for the first nine months of 1989 were lower than 1988's comparable figures.
Another high-yield bond analyst, who asked not to be identified, said that the Ohio acquisitions ''were a very aggressive plan to begin with, and they just have not increased cash flow in Ohio nearly as much as they had anticipated.''
But in the interview, Mr. Ingersoll attributed his problems to The Pennysaver, the shoppers' newspaper on Long Island. He said that he had spent millions to convert The Pennysaver from an advertising circular to full-fledged weekly community newspaper, but that the outlays had not brought sufficiently higher revenues.
''We have had some significant operating disappointments on Long Island,'' Mr. Ingersoll said. ''The expenses went up, and the economy on Long Island collapsed.''
While Mr. Ingersoll has experienced setbacks on Long Island, securities analysts suspected a negotiating ploy to drive down the price that bondholders may ultimately be willing to accept for their securities. Mr. Unterhalter said that he had valued Community Newspapers on a liquidation basis and had concluded that its senior bonds were worth about 80 cents on the dollars - roughly 50 percent more than Mr. Ingersoll and Warburg, Pincus Capital Partners, a New York-based investment firm that is a partner, were offering.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Transition In East Germany

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Berlin wall, built to keep East Germans from fleeing to the West, now stands as a powerful symbol of the coming unification of the two Germanys.
Every day, thousands of East Germans, West Germans and foreigners trek to the wall to read the graffiti, chisel out or purchase chunks of the wall, and feel the miraculous historic change that is still taking place here.
The graffiti have preserved both the euphoria and the anger that burst forth last Nov. 9 when the borders with West Germany were opened to the East Germans. Some of the writings declare the Germans' contempt for the former Communist leader, many in English. ''Honecker pea brain,'' says one. Other writings are simply the traditional markings of visitors in a strange place: ''Goldberg USA'' and ''Scotty Joe was here.'' And some offer short editorials: ''How do you spell freedom? USA.'' But in the wake of the victory of the conservative alliance in East Germany's election this week, euphoria has given way once again to anxiety over how to stanch the flow of East Germans to the West, and how to meld the two economies. 
The German Democratic Republic, the somewhat euphemistic title for East Germany, seems likely to become the first Communist country to make the complete journey to a market economy. It may provide some important lessons for other Communist countries on how to do it.
Many tricky problems will need to be solved. The first is to turn disordered currencies into hard currencies. That is easier for the East Germans with their West German brothers.
Although the initial view among German economists was that it would have been wiser to postpone currency reform until the economic and political institutions of a free nation were in place, most of those economists are now moving to support Chancellor Helmut Kohl's decision to merge the two currencies by July 1. They see the conversion to the strong German mark as a means of quickly setting East Germany on the course to self-propelled economic growth. The strong currency is also likely to attract greater West German and other foreign investment to East Germany.
There is also a powerful political reason for speeding up currency reform: It is seen as a means of slowing the migration that has been playing havoc with the East German economy and disturbing many West Germans who have begun worrying that the new arrivals are putting excessive burdens on their labor market, housing and budget. The phrase heard often in West Germany today is: ''The boat is full.''
Last year, an estimated 344,000 East Germans crossed to the West. So far this year an additional 150,000 have left, at a rate of about 2,000 a day.
Chancellor Kohl, having won his decisive victory in the East German election, is now swinging to solidify his political support in West Germany. That support will depend not only on his slowing the influx of East Germans but also in preventing inflation and a weakening of the German mark.
The West German mark will be exchanged for the East mark at a 1 to 1 ratio, but only for a limited amount of marks held by East Germans. This policy will be aimed at preventing an inflationary flooding of the economy of the merged Germanys with the overhang of hundreds of billions of East marks. There is also the aim of not rewarding those speculators who have acquired masses of East marks in the black market in hopes of making a killing by converting them into West German marks at a higher official rate.
A way to avoid this is to permit the conversion only of East marks held in savings deposits in East German banks on Nov. 8, the day before the borders were opened and the Berlin wall was breached. Additional East marks are likely to be exchanged at a lower rate than 1 to 1 sometime in the future for permitted amounts of currency and for use in investment, to help the East German economy.
Along with the dash to currency union by July 1, there is also likely to be widespread price decontrol in East Germany soon afterward. This decontrol will probably not be complete. Price controls and state subsidies seem bound to remain for a while on bread, milk and some other necessities. Well-informed West German officials believe that rent controls and subsidized subway fares will also continue for a long time. Such controls and subsidies would be used as a means of keeping the East Germans where they are.
''Stay home,'' Mr. Kohl told them after the election, thereby provoking harsh criticism from his Social Democratic challenger in West Germany, Oskar Lafontaine, who declared that Mr. Kohl had ''betrayed'' the population of East Germany.
The conservative Government of West Germany, nevertheless, seems certain to be generous, within budgetary constraints, toward the East Germans, although it hopes that other foreign countries and corporations will also provide aid and investment capital in the East.
The East German case is likely to be not only the first but also the easiest transition from Communism to capitalism. For, as Kurt Richebaecher, a leading German economist, puts it: ''There is a big brother, West Germany, who brings tremendous assets to the task - a strong currency, the biggest trade surplus in the world, a vast pool of surplus savings to draw upon, as well as technical and managerial know-how.''

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Rise in Japan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, March 23

 BODY:
The stock market remained shaky and volatile early today after Thursday's wild swings, but a wave of program trading late in the day lifted prices for the day.
This afternoon, a sudden surge of buying related to the stock index futures market sent the Nikkei 225-stock index up 528.82 points, or 1.8 percent, to close at 30,372.16. Earlier, at the opening, the index rose sharply initially, then fell as much as 630 points before recovering to close the morning session at 29,798.15, down 45.19 points. 
On Thursday, the index had plunged 963.85 points.
''It would have been listless if not for the program trading,'' said Liam Newberg, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. ''That created the illusion of a recovery, but we don't see an end to the declines yet.''
The market also benefited from some bargain-hunting for blue-chip shares by foreign investors, an inflow of money from a few Japanese mutual funds and a slight decline in short-term interest rates, analysts said.
Analysts generally described the market as having achieved an uneasy and possibly temporary peace after the turmoil of recent weeks. Prices have fallen more than 20 percent this year.
Another closely watched factor was the foreign exchange market, where the dollar's steep rise has abated, at least for the time being.
In addition to intervening heavily in the foreign exchange market to try to stabilize the sagging yen, the Bank of Japan has been injecting money into the money market. That has eased short-term interest rates slightly, causing a rebound in bond prices and taking some of the selling pressure off stock prices.
The market has also grown quiet in advance of Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's visit to the United States later today, where he is expected to meet with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to discuss ways of shoring up the falling yen.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Loses 'Biggest' Title

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Tokyo Stock Exchange, battered by weeks of selling, lost its title yesterday as the world's biggest stock market. 
Economists at Nikko Securities International estimated the dollar value of all stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell yesterday to $2.9 trillion, while the New York Stock Exchange opened the day with a value of $2.92 trillion.
But as American trading began, the newly proclaimed world's largest market also began to crumble.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a loss of 32.21 points, at 2,695.72.
The New York Stock Exchange lost its longstanding title as the world's largest stock exchange when the market crashed in October 1987.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Rise on Rumors

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher again yesterday, as traders were buffeted by rumors throughout the session.
For the first time in many days, short- to intermediate-term notes outperformed bonds.
Dealers said that note issues were helped by rumors that Japanese and American monetary authorities had reached an agreement to lower the value of the dollar, and that the Federal Reserve would ease monetary policy to achieve the objective.
Bond prices, which were sharply higher early yesterday, retreated later after news reports that a column of Soviet armored personnel carriers had driven through Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania. 
 
No 'Flight to Quality'
''You might think that would have prompted a flight to quality,'' one government bond trader said, since news of military unrest in the past has often caused investors to seek safe haven in Treasury securities.
''But it prompted the reverse instead, on the thinking that problems there would threaten the general warming trend between East and West, and that cuts in defense spending might not be as big as the market has come to look for.''
Yesterday's rumors were merely the latest in a week that has been dominated by mostly loose talk.
''The market has traded up this week, but in an unsettled fashion,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Traders have been saying all week that the rise in prices has been backed by increased interest from retail investors. But Mr. Sullivan said the heightened demand might be more imagined than real.
''All in all, you have to think that some securities have left the Street, but we don't think the buying has been as powerful as some have assumed,'' he said. ''We are in contact with retail accounts who are skeptical that the market can improve much from here, and are sort of sitting on their hands.''
 
Stability Falters
The rise in Treasury note prices yesterday ended a sustained period of stability among short- to intermediate-term securities. And it helped to flatten somewhat what had become a steep differential between yields on bonds and notes.
Because of the higher risk of owning a long-term security, the yields on bonds are generally higher than those offered on notes. But recently, bond yields have fallen well below those offered on note issues.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 99 26/32, up by 5/32, to yield 8.60 percent. Meanwhile, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 23/32, up by 1/4 point, to yield 8.55 percent.
Bond prices also rose, but the gains lagged behind those in the note sector.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at 100 6/ 32, up by 2/32, to yield 8.48 percent. Short-term Treasury bill rates fell. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.89 percent in late trading, down by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.82 percent. One-year bills were offered at 7.71 percent, also down by 8 basis points.
 
Corporate Issues Up
Issues of new investment-grade corporate bonds were strong again yesterday, continuing a trend that has been in place all week.
Among the companies that priced new issues was E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which offered $150 million in floating-rate notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The underwriting is the first Merrill Lynch has handled for Du Pont.
The rates on the notes, which float weekly and pay monthly, will be set at 75 basis points above the bond equivalent yield on three-month Treasury bills. They mature on April 3, 1994, and are noncallable for two years. The first rate will be set on April 2.
The notes are rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. $150 Million Offering Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as the lead manager for a $150 million offering of 10-year subordinated notes from the Household Finance Corporation.
The 9.55 percent notes, which mature on April 1, 2000, are noncallable for life. They were priced at $99.716, to yield 9.595 percent, or 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, the traders said that prices of most issues rose by about a quarter of a point.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was quiet yesterday, according to participants. The prices of most issues rose by an eighth to a quarter of a point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended on March 12. The report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply After Labor Disputes End

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of copper futures fell from five-month highs on New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday in response to an easing of labor tensions in Canada and Peru and a sharp drop in stock prices.
Copper futures settled 1.5 cents to 3.5 cents lower, with the contract for spot delivery at $1.291 a pound.
On other commodity markets, precious metals advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; cocoa futures surged; sugar retreated; energy futures fell, and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. 
Copper futures had surged as much as 4.6 cents Wednesday on speculation that union workers at a Noranda Inc. copper smelter in Quebec would reject management's final contract offer, setting the stage for a strike.
But workers approved the contract by a narrow margin, and reports of the results early yesterday morning gave the copper market its initial downward shove.
 
Settlement in Peru
Later in the morning, the port workers' union in Peru announced it had ended a nationwide strike after two days, freeing Peruvian copper exports to move again.
A miners' strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corporation, the country's largest producer, continued into its 11th day but analysts said the company had copper stockpiled. The strike is threatening to spread, though, with a national miners' work stoppage set for Monday.
Yesterday's 32-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial stock average prompted further selling. Because copper is used heavily in construction and industrial production, copper prices are extremely sensitive to economic signals.
Soybean futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade on strength in the soybean-meal market. Wheat futures retreated while corn advanced.
The markets displayed only slight interest in news that United States and Soviet negotiators had reached tentative agreement on a new five-year grain pact.
Wheat futures settled 1/2 cent to 1 1/2 cents lower, with May at $3.58 3/4 a bushel; corn was 1/2 cent to 1 1/2 cents higher, with May at $2.58 3/4 a bushel; oats were 3/4 cent to 1 cent higher, with May at $1.49 3/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 1/2 cent lower to 2 3/4 cents higher, with May at $6.05 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Korea, U.S. In Beef Pact

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, March 22

 BODY:
South Korea has resolved a dispute with the United States over beef imports, averting possible trade sanctions, trade ministry officials said today.
Under an agreement reached on Wednesday in Washington, Seoul will increase its beef import quota to 58,000 metric tons this year from 50,000 last year, the officials said. The quota will rise to 62,000 metric tons in 1991 and 66,000 in 1992.
''U.S. negotiators originally asked us to submit a schedule for total liberalization of beef imports, but later agreed to accept our offer to increase the annual quota,'' a ministry official said.
He said Seoul and Washington would hold talks before July 1992 to discuss the removal of South Korea's beef import barriers. Washington had threatened to impose a ban on some South Korean imports unless Seoul opened its markets to more American beef.
After a ban from May 1985 to August 1988, Seoul agreed to allow in 14,200 metric tons of beef imports in the remainder of 1988 and 50,000 metric tons last year. The bulk of Korea's beef imports come from the United States and Australia.
A panel for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ruled last year that South Korea unfairly discriminated against beef imports.

HEADLINE: U.S. AND JAPANESE IN COMPUTER PACT

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The United States and Japan said today that they had reached preliminary agreement on measures that would significantly open the Japanese market to the most powerful American-made computers.
The agreement will make it easier for American companies to sell such supercomputers to the Japanese Government and public universities in Japan, trade officials from both nations said.
The agreement should eliminate what has become, in effect, a requirement that companies doing business with the Japanese Government offer deep discounts on supercomputer prices. The Japanese budget for supercomputers is so low that successful bidders have had to offer discounts of up to 80 percent of the list price. 
The United States is continuing to try to persuade Japan to buy American-made commercial satellites and to open up the Japanese market to American wood products, two other areas in which Washington has accused Tokyo of unfair trade practices. The satellite talks are reportedly stalled and the talks on wood products may resume next month.
The agreement on supercomputers, reached here late Thursday night and announced today, has not been signed and is subject to review and approval in Tokyo and Washington.
Supercomputers are used by scientists and engineers to forecast the weather, to design aircraft and automobiles, to explore for oil and to predict the behavior of the economy and financial markets, among other tasks.
American computer companies like Cray Research Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation cautiously welcomed the agreement but said they did not know whether it would result in additional sales, as the American negotiators intended.
Members of Congress also welcomed the agreement, but said they wanted to see results.
 
Empty Promises
''Japan must recognize that promises without performance are simply unacceptable,'' said Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Commerce Committee.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Finance subcommittee on trade, said that in the past ''American trade negotiators have fallen in the trap of declaring success too soon.''
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, looked on the positive side: ''American supercomputer manufacturers already compete successfully in the Japanese private sector. The real test of this agreement, therefore, will be the actual success of our companies in the Government procurement market.''
The new agreement ''should give us full and effective access to that market,'' Mrs. Hills said.
 
Four Purchases Planned
The pact does not require Japan to buy a specific number of machines from the United States. But the Japanese Government plans to buy four supercomputers this year, an American trade official said. Such machines cost $7 million to $30 million each, he said.
The agreement appears to be one of the first fruits of meetings in California three weeks ago between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, trade negotiators said. The talks were prompted by a sense of alarm among officials in both countries that a continued impasse in trade negotiations would permanently damage their alliance.
An American trade official said the Japanese negotiators came to the talks on supercomputers, held here Wednesday and Thursday, ''with instructions to make a deal.'' As a result of high-level political pressure, he said, the Japanese showed a more forthcoming attitude.
 
Meeting Called Helpful
The Bush-Kaifu meeting definitely helped, he said. The Japanese negotiators ''said O.K. more often.''
A 1987 agreement between the United States and Japan called for an open, ''nondiscriminatory procurement process.'' Nevertheless, in May 1989, President Bush charged that Japan was maintaining an array of unfair trade barriers, and supercomputers were one of three areas chosen for special investigation. Japan faced the prospect of retaliatory trade sanctions, including high tariffs, if it did not relax the retrictions identified by the United States.
Mrs. Hills said it was ''too early to say'' whether the pact would resolve the case against Japan, filed last year under the so-called Super 301 section of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988.
Dennis McGrath, a spokesman for Cray, said: ''We haven't had a chance to study the initial draft of the agreement. We just hope it will contain the provisions we need to open up the Japanese market.''
 
'The Real Test'
''The real test,'' he said, ''is whether this agreement, unlike the one signed in 1987, actually results in true competitive equity. By that, we mean actual sales and market-share increases for the American supercomputer industry.''
Mr. McGrath said Cray had 80 percent of the world supercomputer market outside Japan but only 66 percent when the Japanese market is included.
In 1988, 31 supercomputers were sold in Japan, 26 by Japanese manufacturers and 5 by American companies, according to Dataquest Inc., a market research concern in San Jose, Calif.
American companies supplied only 6 percent of the supercomputers bought by the Japanese Government and publicly financed universities in Japan, the United States trade representative's office said.
Under the agreement, the Japanese Government accepted the American contention that it should buy supercomputers on the basis of a combined assessment of price and value. In the past, American officials said, Japan bought the cheapest supercomputer that met its specifications, turning down superior American machines that were slightly more expensive. The main Japanese computer manufacturers, which all produce supercomputers, are Fujitsu Ltd., Hitachi Ltd. and the NEC Corporation.
 
Bursts of High Speeds
In addition, an American trade official said, Japan agreed that it would no longer use ''theoretical peak performance'' as a factor in buying supercomputers. Japanese companies have designed computers to meet such standards; as a result, some Japanese supercomputers can reach extremely high speeds, but only for a fraction of a second.
American negotiators argued that supercomputers should instead be judged by their overall performance in solving practical problems.
Under the agreement, the Japanese Government is supposed to throw out ''excessively low bids.'' These are below-cost bids sometimes offered by Japanese companies that hope the deals will give them prestige and influence, and perhaps access to new software. Japan is to publicize the names of companies that submit such bids. American trade officials said such publicity would embarrass Japanese companies by indicating that they had engaged in unfair trade practices. The agreement, however, does not define excessively low bids.
American companies can file complaints with an ombudsman in the Prime Minister's office if they think they have been shut out of the market as a result of excessively low bids.
The American delegation in the talks was led by William Piez, a deputy assistant trade representative, who had been an economic officer at the American Embassy in Tokyo. The Japanese delegation was led by Mitoji Yabunaka, an official at the Foreign Ministry. I.B.M.
