HEADLINE: Mountain of Nuclear Waste Splits St. Louis and Suburbs 888>

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Nearly half a century after a company here began processing fuel for nuclear weapons, St. Louis and several western suburbs are battling over a new disposal plan for millions of cubic yards of dirt contaminated with uranium, thorium, radium, actinium and other radioactive elements that are polluting the water, soil and air.
Not even in Denver, where plutonium particles escaped from the nearby Rocky Flats Plant, or in Salt Lake City, where a pile of uranium wastes was recently moved from the city to the desert, has a major metropolitan area contended with radioactive wastes on the scale facing St. Louis.
 
'Oldest Radioactive Waste'
''We have a million cubic yards of radioactive waste on this side of the Missouri River, a million and a half on the other side, and they don't know where to put the first cupful,'' said Kay Drey, a nuclear opponent here who is providing technical assistance to several suburban leaders. ''This is the oldest radioactive waste of the atomic age, and there still is no safe place to put the stuff.'' 
The Federal Government, which has spent a decade and $75 million studying the extent of the contamination, has not settled on a solution, but officials are leaning toward a plan that they say can accommodate half the waste: consolidating debris from a former uranium processing plant downtown and a handful of other sites onto 82 acres just north of Lambert International Airport in the suburb of Berkeley.
The City of St. Louis owns the land, which is divided into a site where some waste is already stored and an adjoining park that was closed in 1988 because of radiation in the soil.
Showing support for the Energy Department plan, St. Louis's Board of Aldermen has voted to transfer ownership of the land to the department. But the Mayor of Berkeley, William Miller, wants all the wastes removed from the area; he is leading a campaign to collect signatures from 15,000 St. Louis voters and repeal the board's decision.
''It makes no sense at all to have this much hot dirt around so many people and so many businesses,'' Mr. Miller said in an interview. ''Ultimately, we're going to have the responsibility to watch this site. But we have no say in what's done here.''
Mr. Miller's campaign has drawn support from the St. Louis County Municipal League, which represents more than 90 municipalities, and the mayors of Bridgeton, Hazelwood and eight other cities.
 
'A Potential Health Hazard'
The Energy Department's response to such concerns has hardly been reassuring. It has displayed a new candor about the risks that residents face, describing in a January report the extent of contamination around the metropolitan area, with special attention paid to the problem in Berkeley.
The radioactive waste near the airport, along the Berkeley-Hazelwood border, ''represents a potential health hazard to the general public,'' the the report said. ''There is no control of off-site contamination to prevent further spread of this material. The problem is magnified by the extensive commercial development in this area.''
The situation here is one of the most graphic illustrations of the enduring costs paid by an American community for its participation in the cold war. For 24 years, St. Louis was a vital link in the chain of production for atomic weapons because of a chemical process that the Mallinckrodt Chemical Works developed for purifying large quantities of uranium.
The company, one of the city's oldest industrial concerns, produced the uranium used at the University of Chicago on Dec. 2, 1942, to sustain the world's first nuclear chain reaction and for the atomic bombs that destroyed Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August 1945.
 
Government Approved Dumping
Until 1966, Mallinckrodt processed uranium for nuclear weapons at its main plant along the Mississippi River in downtown St. Louis and in Weldon Spring, 25 miles to the west.
Under the cover of national security secrecy, the Government authorized the company to dump radioactive wastes quietly in the suburbs, including a 21-acre Berkeley field owned by St. Louis. It is that field and the 61-acre park across the street that the Government is considering for a permanent storage site.
David R. Bohm, an assistant city counselor for St. Louis, said the transfer of the land to the Government was subject to conditions. ''For the Department of Energy to gain control of the land,'' he said, ''they must agree that they will not charge the city for the cost of the cleanup. They must also agree not to put any other radioactive wastes there except those from three specific sites in the region.''
The Energy Department has spent $75 million since 1977 to assess the extent of contamination here and to build several small projects at Weldon Spring to reduce water pollution. In the meantime, the estimated cost of cleaning up Mallinckrodt's two plants and controlling the wastes at the site abutting the airport has reached $1.4 billion.
And the department also acknowledges that even though it has settled on a possible solution, new estimates of the size of the problem, inevitable court challenges and an array of other political hurdles mean that it is no closer to a permanent answer than it was when work began in the region 13 years ago. In 1981 the department estimated that there were 556,000 cubic yards of radioactive wastes in the St. Louis metropolitan area, roughly a fifth the current estimate.
''It's the most frustrating part of my life as a public official,'' said Mr. Miller, the 43-year-old Berkeley Mayor. ''People are retiring on the money they're making off this. It's a multimillion-dollar wait-and-see.''
 
Danger Denied in 1946
The wastes became an issue briefly in 1946, when reporters here asked questions about the trucks that were hauling dirt from the plant to land bordering the airport. The concerns disappeared after the Government and Mallinckrodt said the wastes were ''not radioactive or otherwise dangerous.''
From 1946 to 1957, Mallinckrodt hauled wastes from its downtown processing plant and dumped them in shallow pits north of the airport. In some places in Berkeley and Hazelwood, along roads where waste spilled from trucks, the Energy Department has found radiation levels seven times normal. Uranium, thorium and radium have also been found in sediments in Cold Water Creek, which drains the Berkeley park and then flows to the Missouri River.
The park, where children and adults played softball for decades, was closed in 1988 because of the high radiation levels found in the soil. The Energy Department hopes to use the park as the site for a permanent bunker to store the wastes.
While the Government favors this plan as the most economic cleanup method, it is studying a variety of options and says it will not make a decision until 1994 or 1995.
 
Problems Across the River
The problem is not Berkeley's alone. In 1957 Mallinckrodt transferred uranium processing to a new Government-owned plant across the Missouri River in Weldon Spring, and began dumping radioactive wastes into a quarry on the site. Uranium processing was halted in 1966, but the wastes remain. Cleaning them up is now expected to cost $594 million. In 1979 the Energy Department estimated the Weldon Spring cleanup cost at $3.6 million.
And in downtown St. Louis, just south of the McKinley Bridge, the department found radiation levels in excess of Federal health guidelines inside 14 buildings at the Mallinckrodt chemical plant that are still in use.
A fourth contaminated site, the West Lake landfill, has been found about 10 miles west of Berkeley in Bridgeton.
Keith F. Pickett, a spokesman for the company, now called Mallinckrodt Inc. and owned by the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, says the hazard to the company's workers is negligible because most of the contamination is confined to small spots. ''The Department of Energy has assured us and our employees that there is no real risk,'' he said.
 
Excessive Deaths From Cancer
But some workers are worried. In 1980 a study by epidemiologists under contract to the Energy Department found an excessive number of deaths from cancer of the esophagus and leukemia among 2,731 white males who processed uranium for Mallinckrodt from 1942 to 1966. The researchers did not identify a cause of the cancers.
Scientists have long known that high levels of radiation, far above the levels at which the Mallinckrodt workers have been exposed, can lead to malignancies of the blood, bones and organs. At low levels the effect is less certain, although a recent study by the National Academy of Sciences said low doses of radiation were more dangerous than was thought five years ago.
''My concern is that we're getting doses that are bad and nobody wants to tell us,'' said Kathy Collins, a 38-year-old chemical operator at the plant. ''The company doesn't want to talk about this because it's a skeleton in their closet. They hide behind the Energy Department, which tells them there is no problem.''

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS WARM TO MOYNIHAN PLAN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, March 23

 BODY:
The top leaders of the Democratic National Committee, led by the party's chairman, Ronald H. Brown, today strongly endorsed a plan to cut Social Security taxes, despite opposition among the Democratic leadership in Congress.
The endorsement, as well as a similar statement of support from a group of conservative Democrats meeting in New Orleans, breathed new political life into the proposal, offered last December by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York.
But it also dramatized the schism in the party between its political wing, which yearns for issues to help it recapture the White House, and its governing wing, which already holds power in Congress and worries about the impact on the Federal deficit of a substantial tax cut.
Mr. Brown, the party's chief political figure, called the Moynihan plan a ''political stroke of genius'' that would help Democrats re-establish themselves as the party of working people, while Republicans pushed a capital gains tax cut that would benefit the wealthy. 
 
Support for Brown Stand
Mr. Brown was joined in support of the tax cut today by both the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee, meeting here, and by the top officers of the Democratic Leadership Council, a caucus of the party's more conservative wing, meeting in New Orleans. The party executive committee unanimously approved a resolution, offered by New York's state chairman, John Marino, urging Congress to adopt a plan cutting Social Security taxes.
The resolution portrayed the Social Security tax as ''a regressive tax which falls most heavily on low- and middle-income workers.'' Rolling it back would produce ''a tax cut for working people and small businesses,'' the resolution said.
Mr. Moynihan's proposal would slash Social Security taxes by $62 billion over two years, thus eliminating a retirement fund surplus that has been used to help offset the Federal budget deficit. His proposal was intended to be something of an economics lesson to show how in the last decade the burden of taxation shifted from income taxes to the Social Security tax and to show how the retirement funds were being used to mask the Government's operating deficit. The proposal offers no suggestions for how to reduce the enlarged deficit that the loss of Social Security funds would cause.
Asked about the concerns that Democrats in Congress have about the deficit, Mr. Brown replied: ''We think the matters of principle have to be decided first.''
 
Bentsen Reasserts Opposition
A leader of the Congressional Democrats, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, quickly reasserted his opposition to cutting Social Security taxes.
''I don't want to get in a bidding war with the Republicans on cutting taxes because I don't know where that one stops,'' said Mr. Bentsen, his party's 1988 candidate for Vice President, ''and we have a responsibiity to get this deficit down.''
Mr. Bentsen said that Democrats would be at a disadvantage in a bidding war with the Republicans because, ''they don't care how far they'll go.''
Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland said it was only natural that the party's political operatives would see the Moynihan plan differently from the Congressional leaders.
''They don't have to implement it,'' he said. The party leaders were fulfilling their job, Mr. Hoyer said, by pushing a politically attractive tax cut. But he added: ''What do you do next? How do you meet that shortfall.''
The Leadership Council has often been at odds with the more liberal party members who control the official party structure. But spokesmen for both groups said it was a foul-up in scheduling, not an illustration of disunity, that the party and its often dissident right wing had held separate meetings in separate cities on the same day.
To drive home that point, Mr. Brown boarded a plane and flew from here to New Orleans this morning to speak to the Leadership Council.
''It just makes sense for us Democrats to be on the side of cutting payroll taxes for working people,'' Mr. Brown told the group. ''The Social Security tax is one of the most regressive we have, and Senator Moynihan has touched a real nerve by daring the Adminsitration to come clean and admit to what they've been up to.''
 
Moynihan Presents Case
Mr. Moynihan himself spoke to the council and presented his case that increases over recent years in the Social Security tax, which is deducted from payrolls, was being used to mask the true size of the Federal deficit.
''Ought we to allow it to go on?'' he asked. ''They have been looting these funds.''
The Leadership Council, as part of an ''agenda for the 1990's'' it distributed in New Orleans, said: ''The payroll tax burden on average American families needs to be reduced and progressivity restored to the overall tax structure so Americans are taxed according to their ability to pay.''
The resolution endorsed here by the party executive committee noted that during the Reagan Administration the percentage of Federal revenues coming from the Social Security tax increased while the percentage coming from the more progressive personal and corporate income taxes had declined.
Representative Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, has been trying to fashion a consensus on the tax issue, so far to no avail. Mr. Gephardt said he thought the debate within the party was good and that the eventual outcome would be a plan that embraced the themes being voiced today.

HEADLINE: Review/Film Festival;
Hard Labor on the Plantation, Updated

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
As black workers cut sugar cane in the 1940's, a narrator notes that these happy laborers are following the ''hereditary urge to go back to the plantation.'' That archival clip, included in Stephanie Black's ''H-2 Worker,'' suggests how little the plantation mentality has changed in nearly 50 years, though today the sugar-cane growers rely on Jamaicans imported to Florida for six months every year.
Ms. Black's documentary follows the men who arrive on H-2 visas, temporary permits that allow foreigners to take jobs for which employers cannot find Americans. According to the film, each year 10,000 Jamaicans respond to the promise of more money than they can make at home, and become virtual prisoners, crowded into dormitories that resemble army barracks, paid at most $5 an hour -minus transportation and housing fees - for grueling field work. 
Though Ms. Black's sympathy with the laborers is manifest, ''H-2 Worker'' is that rare hybrid that succeeds as both film and advocacy. The documentary's look and form is smooth and sophisticated, combining reggae music, voice-overs of letters between the Jamaicans and their families at home, interviews with the workers and with a sugar industry representative, and archival material that sets the current situation in historical context. Ms. Black is not artistically innovative, but she has mastered some fundamental rules of effective documentary film-making. She assumes a calm, objective tone, allowing the visual images and interviews to speak for themselves. She lures viewers to her point of view rather than bludgeoning them.
Maryse Alberti's cinematography is a major element of the film's convincing realism. Ms. Alberti creates rich images of the men in the fields, bending to cut cane that stands taller than they do; even a glimpse suggests the strain on one's back. The dormitory, with laundry strung between the bunks, looks stark and demoralizing, but not exaggeratedly gruesome. Most important, the film never looks picturesque or condescending.
The workers are quietly angry, dignified and often resigned as they describe their thwarted expectations. Some say they were not told of the restrictions: workers cannot leave the camp for more than 24 hours, and cannot go more than 30 miles away. But one man has been returning to Florida for 14 years, suggesting the dilemma facing poor people with limited opportunities. When the workers stage a stoppage to complain about low wages, the police are brought in to remove them from the camp; within a week 300 replacement workers are flown in from Jamaica.
''H-2 Worker'' will be shown tonight at 9 and tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the Museum of Modern Art as part of the New Directors/New Films series. It does not pretend to offer any answers, but it solidly frames issues about the economy, employment and the treatment of workers who seem just steps away from slavery.
 
SO THAT PEOPLE CAN SAVOR SUGAR
 
H-2 WORKER, directed and produced by Stephanie Black; photography by Maryse Alberti; edited by John Mullen. At the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater, 11 West 53d Street, as part of the New Directors/New Films series of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Department of Film of the Museum of Modern Art. Running time: 70 minutes. This film has no rating
 
Letters to and from workers read by Homer Heron, Oliver Stephenson, Jervis Anderson, George Cesvette, Delroy Hunter, King David and Belinda Goffe

HEADLINE: As Scores Drop, Schools Look for Lessons

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
At Public School 153 in Co-op City in the Bronx, there was the delicious feeling last year that they had beaten the odds. Test scores showed that almost 95 percent of the students read at grade level or above, raising the school's rank to 9th from 328th among the city's 616 elementary schools.
But after the latest test, which used a new, tougher standard, that rank dropped to 115th out of 618 schools, and delight gave way to bafflement.
''I can't give a reason for the change,'' said the principal, Beverly Taylor. 
Hers is not the only school puzzled by sharp drops in reading scores. When the 1989 scores and school-by-school rankings were released this week, 13 percent of New York City's 618 elementary schools were shown to have had changes - up or down -of 10 percentage points or more from the 1988 scores. Only four of the 180 intermediate and junior high schools showed such wide fluctuations.
On the face of it, at least part of the reason for the decline would appear to be the tougher standards. But school officials eliminated that as a factor by recalculating the 1988 scores using the 1989 standards.
Under that recalculation, P.S. 153's score of 94 percent in 1988 would have been 78.8 percent by 1989's standards. But the 1989 score still fell far short, to 66.5 percent, reflecting a loss of 12.3 percentage points.
''Until I analyze the data I won't know if there were any weaknesses,'' said the principal, Ms. Taylor, who often walks the beige and orange halls of the school chatting with teachers and admiring students' art. ''The feeling here is we're doing fine because the teachers work very hard and our focus is not so much on test scores as it is on total education.''
Nevertheless, principals like Ms. Taylor and other school officials are trying to understand the declines by looking at many possible factors.
 
Measuring Beyond Numbers
One is student turnover. In one school with a sharp drop in scores, more than half the student body changed from one year to the next. In two other schools there was an influx of students from a low-income housing project who had much lower reading levels than the students who were already en-rolled. School officials are also searching for ways to measure themselves beyond using only numbers.
The Board of Education wants principals and teachers to look at other school characteristics and use the reading scores as just an additional piece of information about their school. When it released its reading-achievement rankings this year, the Board for the first time took note of other factors, like school attendance, teacher experience, proficiency in English and the percentage of students eligible for free lunch, a measure of poverty levels in the schools.
Board officials also routinely caution that standardized tests are imperfect and that scores are only one indicator of achievement.
''Let's face it; this is one day in May when we sit all the kids down and take a test,'' said Robin Willner, the Board of Education's executive director for strategic planning and research development. ''Though these tests have been reviewed and revalidated, they measure a narrow band of skills. We say if a youngster can read this paragraph and answer these questions they can read at a certain grade level. It still doesn't tell us a lot about a kid's analytical ability. It's not about analysis; it's not about creativity.''
Even so, principals acknowledge that the scores are viewed as an enormous reflection of the school's image as good, bad or improving.
 
'Of Course It Bothers Me'
''Everyone wants to be in the 95th percentile,'' said Joseph L. Cugini, the principal at Public School 46 in South Beach, S.I. Scores released last year showed that 64.5 of his students read at or above grade level, compared with the 43.6 percent indicated by the scores released Tuesday.
''Of course it bothers me,'' Mr. Cugini said.
The new standards caused an overall decline in scores systemwide for the 370,000 students in Grades 3 to 9 who took the test in May: 47.4 percent read at or above grade level, compared with 66.9 percent in 1988, when the old standards were used.
''One less correct answer equals several percentage points,'' Mr. Cugini said. ''We have only 245 students in kindergarten through fifth grade and if one child goes down, the percentile goes down.''
Mr. Cugini said his school's high mobility rate might have affected its scores. He said more children are coming to the school from other boroughs and that more come from home without books or where their parents do not speak English.
The test standards were recalculated at a higher level to reflect an improvement in reading nationwide that has taken place since the last national standard was set in 1982. The norms are intended to represent average reading levels based on national samplings of students in each grade. Thus, students would need to perform better to receive the same score and even students who performed about the same would register a decrease in their score.
Mary F. Kelly, an adjunct assistant psychology and education professor at Columbia University's Teachers College, said double-digit reading level changes from one year to the next are unusual. And, she said, lower scores can be demoralizing to parents, teachers and students because the tests are not sophisticated enough to pick up the real gains that also occur.
''Tests are helpful for looking at a kid's progress over time, and they are good, objective measures because you don't have teacher bias,'' she said. ''But it's not good to use a single measure for anything, especially for something as complicated as what goes on in classroom.''
 
'I Love Complicated Words'
A recent visit to the third-grade classroom of Joan Grochowsky at P.S. 153 showed little concern about numbers. There, the students were smoothly reading words like ''ramifications'' and ''consequences'' and talking about the census. They discussed the ramifications of undercounting the elderly.
''I love complicated words in books, like 'elementary' or 'encyclopedia,' '' said Candiece Goodall, who is 8 years old.
Ms. Taylor, the principal, said with a sweep of her arms. ''This is what's important to me - thinking. ''Children have to learn to think analytically, deductively. The tests are good only as a guide for what you need for reading instructon for the next year.''
At Junior High School 217 and Public School 217, housed in the same building on Roosevelt Island, there were reasons why scores dropped that had nothing to do with how teachers taught, said the principal, Dorothy Bowser. The elementary school scores dropped 16 percentage points over last year, and those for the junior high declined 11.1 percentage points. The elementary school was ranked 180th in the city, down from 27th.
''There was a housing development that opened and a number of students came from schools that were economically disadvantaged,'' she said. ''We saw immediately there was a disparity in reading ability. We knew there was going to be a drop.''

HEADLINE: Dinkins Woos His Party To Win Its Convention

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, March 23

 BODY:
Seeking to promote his city's image and economy, Mayor David N. Dinkins, a vision of urban glamour, arrived in Indiana today, intent on persuading the Democratic Party to hold its national convention in New York City in 1992.
With a delegation that included the former Vice-Presidential candidate Geraldine A. Ferraro and former Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, Mr. Dinkins came to the winter meeting of the Democratic National Committee for a whirlwind round of hellos and handshakes that he hopes might bring $100 million in revenue to the city and its businesses.
''Why do we venture across the Hudson and into America's heartland?'' he asked before he left La Guardia Airport. ''Let me assure you, we will have little time for sightseeing. The chance for $100 million and 40,000 visitors is worth a weekend trip to Indiana.'' 
At a party with the Democratic national chairman, Ronald H. Brown, in caucuses with female, black and Hispanic party members and as host of a dessert reception featuring apple strudel, apple tarts and apple cake, the Mayor urged the Democrats to take their quadrennial convention back to the Big Apple, where the party nominated Jimmy Carter in 1976 and 1980.
 
'No City Is More Exciting'
''I believe that no urban center stands taller for the potential of a new Democratic majority than does New York,'' Mr. Dinkins said in remarks prepared for delivery tonight. ''No city is more exciting as a place to convene than New York. And no people are more passionate about the progressive ideas and ideals of our party than the people of New York.''
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch had begun tentative efforts to get the convention. But his stock with the national party was not particularly high, especially after his harsh criticism of the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the New York Presidential primary in 1988.
Mr. Dinkins, newly in office but long a party loyalist, has made obtaining the convention a major priority, part of his effort to become a national spokesman for urban concerns and to give New York a psychological and financial lift in times of fiscal austerity. He has set up a host committee of prominent New Yorkers to raise $20 million, mostly in private contributions and in-kind services, to support the convention, which would be held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and Madison Square Garden.
The city is to play host to the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage to America that same year, and officials acknowledged that the logistical and security concerns for both events would be costly. But they said the benefits of having the convention and the tourism it would bring outweigh the risks.
''For us, it holds some real economic possibilities, and it comes at a very interesting time,'' said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, Mr. Dinkins's chief political aide, who accompanied him here. ''With all the changes around the world and with people in Eastern Europe who'll be getting the chance to see our democracy in action, we'd like them to see it in New York.''
 
Other Cities in the Running
City officials said they believed their main competition was New Orleans, but Cleveland, Detroit and Houston are also in the running. After learning that Mr. Dinkins was planning to come here this weekend, Mr. Lynch said, some other mayors decided to come, too.
The host committee includes leaders in business, labor and entertainment, including Stanley Hill, head of District Council 37, the municipal workers' union; Preston Robert Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, and Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts. From April 4 to 6, they are to welcome the Democrats' site selection committee to New York for a grand tour. The committee is to recommend a site to Mr. Brown, who is a New Yorker, by May.
Mr. Dinkins said one of the biggest obstacles New York must overcome is the size of Madison Square Garden, where the general sessions would be held, while committee meetings would take place in the Javits Center. But he said New York could offer more space than the Omni in Atlanta, where the 1988 convention was held.
For his part, Mr. Brown said no decision had been made, and he would not speculate on New York's chances. ''New York is one of the finalists,'' he said, ''and clearly a city that I have much attachment to.''
At a reception at the Hall of Fame of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, Mr. Dinkins mingled with the Democratic crowd, admiring photographs of committee members' grandchildren as others pointed him out as one of the biggest celebrities in the room.

 BODY:

International
 Japan would open its markets to U.S. supercomputers under a preliminary agreement reached by the two nations. The pact will make it easier for American companies to sell their most powerful computers to the Japanese Government and to public universities in Japan, trade officials said. [Page 1.] Japan asked the U.S. for help in checking the fall of the yen, but the U.S. resisted, arguing that the reasons for the yen's weakness are largely Japanese and there is little Washington can do.  The Xerox suit against Apple Computer was dismissed almost entirely by a Federal judge. The copyright suit involved the screen display of Apple's Macintosh. [33.] Crown Cork and Seal agreed to buy Continental Can's food and beverage metal canning units. [8.] The F.D.A. approved a novel type of drug for the treatment of a rate genetic disease that devastates the immune system. [10.]

 A court order that had stopped the U.S. from seizing a savings and loan association in Illinois was stayed by an appellate court, pending a full hearing on the merits of the case. The action gave a lift to the Bush Adminstration. [31.] A lawyer who in 1988 pressed regulators not to seize a failing savings and loan association was given a $49,000 no-bid consulting contract last year to advise an agency involved in the bailout. [42.] The first Bush nominee to the Fed, David W. Mullins Jr., testified that he supports the central bank's current strategy of fighting inflation by keeping interest rates high. [31.] The auto industry's big spring selling season started poorly, with sales of domestically made vehicles down 9.5 percent. [31.] Orders for durable goods rose by 3.3 percent, the Government said, but the rise after January's record plunge offered little hope that manufacturing was pulling out of its slump. [32.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Stocks rose slightly after the rebound in Tokyo, with the Dow industrials advancing 8.56 points, to 2,704.28, in slow trading. It was the first increase in the Dow since Monday, and the week ended with a decline of 36.94. [34.] Prices of Treasury securities meandered in a narrow range before closing slightly higher. [34.] The dollar fell sharply against the yen as investors regained some confidence in the Japanese currency. Analysts said a rise in interest rates in Japan and a recovery on the Tokyo Stock Exchange helped support the yen. [40.] Prices of gold futures tumbled, with the contract for April delivery at $389.40 an ounce, the lowest settlement for a near-month gold contract since Nov. 10. [40.]

HEADLINE: 10-Day Vehicle Sales Off 9.5% As Season Gets a Slow Start

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 23

 BODY:
The automobile industry's important spring selling season has started poorly. Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks in mid-March were down by 9.5 percent from a year ago, with all of the Big Three companies reporting declines today.
The sales of cars made in American plants were down by 8.9 percent during the 10 days that ended on March 20. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the cars sold at an annual rate of 6.3 million from March 10 to 20, compared with an annual rate of 6.8 million a year earlier. The seasonally adusted annual rate for the preceding 30 days was 6.5 million. 
Light-truck sales were off by 10.6 percent in the period. Eight selling days were in each period.
The Chrysler Corporation was particularly hard hit, with its car sales falling by 29.9 percent, to 18,108 units, and its sales of light trucks off by 23.3 percent, to 20,199 units. The declines came despite an aggressive advertising campaign aimed at winning back buyers who have favored Japanese models.
At the General Motors Corporation, its automobile sales were off by 10.4 percent, to 82,740 units, and those of light trucks were down by 7.8 percent, to 44,112 units.
The Ford Motor Company reported a 10 percent slide in its car sales, to 51,703 units during the period, and a 5.5 percent decline in its light trucks sales, to 38,481 units.
The lackluster sales in the last three weeks contrast with the industry's fairly optimistic production schedules for the second quarter. Analysts said today that if vehicle sales remained soft in coming weeks, auto makers would be forced to revise their planned output for April through June.
''This defers the optimism,'' said Charles J. Brady, an automobile analyst for Oppenheimer & Company in New York. ''We had a situation where sales had been running meaningfully ahead of production, causing inventories to come down to healthy levels. If sales remain flat at this level, production increases in the second quarter will be only marginal.''
 
Ford to Idle Plant
 Ford said today that it would shut down its assembly plant in Dearborn, Mich., for a week beginning on April 2, idling 2,100 workers, because of a shortage of orders from dealers for the Mustang. But the company said its second-quarter production plans already reflected the downtime.
Some automobile executives suggest potential buyers are postponing purchases because they expect an economic downturn.
''There has been a slide in consumer confidence,'' said Joel H. Pitcoff, a market analyst for Ford. ''A surprising number of people are expecting interest rates and unemployment and inflation to go higher.''
General Motors hopes to entice customers back into showrooms with new incentives that were announced on Thursday. The cash rebates are being offered on its new APV mini-vans and two Geo models, the compact Prizm and Storm, as well as other slow-selling cars.
 
Tapping Big Demand
 
 Jim Perkins, the general manager of G.M.'s Chevrolet division, said the company was offering the rebates ''to tap the incredible demand for mini-vans still out there in the marketplace.''
But some of the analysts said the rebates could harm the company by cutting into future sales.
''At this stage of the sales cycle, it is impossible to argue that there is any pent-up demand out there,'' said Michael M. Luckey, the president of the Luckey Consulting Group Inc. in Cresskill, N.J. ''The impact of incentives now is to shift sales from one period to another.''
Together, the sales of cars made by the Big Three were down by 13.2 percent, while those of cars made by Japanese producers in the United States rose by 30.8 percent in the period.
The five Japanese auto makers also accounted for 14 percent of car sales during the mid-March period, compared with a 9.7 percent share a year earlier.
The sales of cars made by Honda of America Inc. rose by 8.4 percent, to 9,808 units. Mazda North America Inc.'s car sales increased by 87.3 percent, to 2,593 units. Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. reported sales gains of 70.7 percent over a year ago, to 8,580 units, while Mitsubishi Motor Sales America Inc.'s sales more than doubled, to 1,268 units. The results for Toyota and Mitsubishi reflect new production at their American plants.
The Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. was the only Japanese car maker to report a sales decline, as sales of its cars fell by 13.6 percent, to 2,515 units, and the company's light-truck sales slipped by 11.1 percent, to 3,822 units.

HEADLINE: No Shortage, but Costlier Coffee

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
No matter what economic changes are made next in Brazil, the world's largest exporter of coffee and the largest supplier to the United States, American coffee drinkers will almost certainly be paying more next month at the supermarkets.
Two weeks ago, before Brazil's new President took office and ordered dramatic changes to attack rampant inflation, Folger's, a division of Procter & Gamble and one of America's largest coffee roasters, announced a sharp increase in the price it charges stores for its coffees.
Last week, Maxwell House, a division of General Foods and the nation's largest roaster, decided on a similar increase, but did not announce it. ''Nobody asked us until now,'' a Maxwell House spokesman said. 
 
Lower Export Prices Seen
 Both roasters say they will go ahead with the increases even though some coffee traders believe the Brazilian economic changes could lead to lower export prices in the short term. The Maxwell House spokesman said the company's increases were based on future purchases of high-grade, more expensive coffee beans. He said the rise was also based on what he described as ''higher labor, packaging and distribution costs.''
The increases by Folger's and Maxwell House will lift the wholesale price of a 13-ounce can by 25 cents, or 10 percent, to $2.75. Higher-quality Colombian coffee will go up 35 cents, or 12.5 percent, to $3.15 a can.
Early this year, coffee futures prices rose swiftly, to eight-month highs, partly because of uncertainly about shipments from Brazil and other major exporting countries. Esther Eskenasy, a commodity analyst and trader for Cargill Investor Services Inc., said roasters, traders, exporters and others were closely watching Brazil's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, who took office on March 15.
Mr. Collor has already put into effect his plans to tame his country's runaway economic problems. His first actions included abolishing the Brazilian Coffee Institute, which controls the coffee trade and which has an estimated 17 million bags of coffee in storage. Each bag holds 132 pounds of beans. He also introduced a new currency with floating foreign exchange rates and put limits on bank withdrawals.
Coffee traders say the actions will probably increase Brazilian sales in the short term, as growers and others try to raise cash. Since the moves were announced, coffee futures prices for the May delivery have fallen about 6 cents. May prices closed yesterday at 89.3 cents a pound on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, off 4.3 cents for the day.
 
Investing in Coffee
 The May contract traded at a high of $1.5025 on Jan. 3, 1989, but after the termination of the International Coffee Organization quota system last July, the contract dropped; it sold as low at 72.75 cents a pound on Oct. 9, according to Commodity Research Bureau figures.
As recently as two weeks ago, prices were more than $1 a pound, in part because many of Brazil's growers were hoarding their coffee supplies. Even individuals there had invested in bags of coffee as a way to combat inflation, which was measured at 2,571 percent over the last 12 months. One result was an artificial coffee shortage in some markets, like the United States, that depend heavily on Brazil.
But many analysts note that there is no worldwide coffee shortage to explain the steep rise in either the futures markets or by American roasters.
Bernard Savaiko, senior commodity analyst and vice president at Paine Webber, said he thought Folger's and Maxwell House ''got carried away.'' He said that the Brazilian Coffee Institute will have about six months to divest itself of the millions of bags of coffee in storage. Since the coffee will probably be fed into the world market slowly, prices may not drop rapidly. In fact, he added, prices will eventually rise as the roasters enter the market to buy additional supplies of high-quality coffee.
 
Some Shortages
 While there is no overall shortage of coffee, traders have been kept guessing by international uncertainty. High-quality coffee is in short supply, and it is that category that American consumers have been increasingly buying in recent years. In addition, perhaps because of the lower prices, total consumption in this country increased a little late last year.
Colombia, the major supplier of high-quality beans for the United States, has already sold most of its exportable coffee for this season, which is one reason why this coffee is going up in price.
Another exporter, Mexico, which had oversold its coffee harvest to the export markets, had to buy up to 400,000 bags from other countries for internal use and to meet other commitments, which also led to upward pressure on prices. Mr. Savaiko said the move became necesssary because of the loss of part of the crop during an unusually cold December.
In addition, there have been reports of civil unrest in the Ivory Coast, which exports coffee to Europe. The reports alarmed European roasters, whose purchases put pressure on prices.
Brazil's 1989-90 coffee crop was ample, totaling 26 million bags, slightly above the 25 million of the previous crop year, the United States Department of Agriculture said.
Arthur Stevenson, a coffee analyst for Prudential-Bache, said production of high-quality coffee grown in the Minas Gerais region of Brazil would drop, carrying prices higher, Miss Eskenasy of Cargill agreed, saying, ''I feel the market will move higher but will do so by stages.'' She added, however, ''Even in Brazil they don't know what will happen to prices.''

HEADLINE: Fed Nominee Backs Policy On Inflation

BYLINE: By GREGORY A. ROBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
David W. Mullins Jr., the Bush Administration's first nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, testified today that he supports the central bank's current strategy of fighting inflation by keeping interest rates high.
''I would not disagree with the current policy,'' Mr. Mullins told the Senate Banking Committee at his confirmation hearing. ''The current policy has relatively high real rates. I think that is having a moderating effect on inflation, and I hope that will lead to lower rates.'' 
Mr. Mullins, 43 years old, has played a central role in the Bush Administration's economic policy as the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance.
 
View of Fed-Treasury Conflict
 In his testimony, Mr. Mullins said recent reports that the Treasury had been unhappy with the Fed policy, preferring lowering interest rates to stimulate economic growth and bring down the value of the dollar, had been exaggerated.
''Fundamentally there is no conflict between growth and reducing inflation,'' Mr. Mullins said. ''Reducing inflation is an important prerequisite for maximizing growth.''
Mr. Mullins's hearing lasted for more than two and half hours, unusually long for a nominee who is facing little or no opposition.
Several senators questioned whether Mr. Mullins would be an independent voice on the Fed board or simply a voice of the Treasury.
 
Questions on Greenspan Article
 Other questions centered on a recent article in The Los Angeles Times suggesting that Mr. Bush did not intend to reappoint Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve when his term ends in 17 months.
Mr. Mullins said he had met privately before his nomination in December with Richard G. Darman, the head of the Office of Management and Budget; Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. But he said that he was unaware of any displeasure in the Administration toward Mr. Greenspan and that he would be an independent voice at the Fed.
A former professor at the Harvard Business School, Mr. Mullins is a specialist in banking, capital markets and corporate finance. Aside from what he said today, his overall economic and monetary policy views are little known. He first gained national recognition when he served as an assistant on the report on the market crash of October 1987 conducted by Nicholas F. Brady, who is now Treasury Secretary.
When Mr. Brady came to Washington, he brought Mr. Mullins with him to help draft the Bush Administration's savings and loan bailout legislation. Mr. Mullins had primary responsibility for guiding the measure through Congress last year.
 
Defends Bailout Estimate
 He testified today that ''convincing and compelling evidence'' was still lacking that the $50 billion bailout was seriously underfinanced, as L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and many critics have argued.
Mr. Mullins was nominated to fill the remaining six years of the term of H. Robert Heller, who resigned his Fed seat to become executive vice president of Visa International, the credit card company.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the Banking Committee, said he would support Mr. Mullins's nomination. A vote on the nomination could come as early as next week.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David W. Mullins Jr., the Bush Administration's first nominee to the Federal Reserve Board. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: U.S. Resists Japan Plea To Aid Yen

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 23

 BODY:
Japan asked the United States today for help in checking the fall of the yen, but the United States went along only part way, arguing that the reasons for the yen's weakness are largely Japanese and that there is little Washington can do.
The request was made at a meeting here between Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
In a joint statement after the meeting, the two sides reaffirmed a commitment to close economic and monetary cooperation but did not announce any new policy initiatives.
 
 Emphasis on Currency Issues
 Mr. Brady and Mr. Hashimoto specifically mentioned cooperation in exchange markets in the statement after their six-hour meeting. 
The 50-word statement had not been expected and represented a concession to Mr. Hashimoto.
It was sought by the Japanese finance chief in a move to shore up confidence in Tokyo and halt a slide in the markets that has taken the yen to three-year lows and driven share prices on the Tokyo exchange down 25 percent since the first of the year, including a 3.1 percent drop in a volatile session on Thursday.
The meeting, scheduled more than two weeks ago, has attracted extra attention because of this turmoil.
The statement did not appear to break new ground and was similar to the declaration made by President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu after their talks in Palm Springs, Calif., on March 2 and 3.
 
'Speak for Itself'
 American officials declined to say whether there would now be greater joint intervention in the currency markets. Mr. Brady told reporters that ''the statement will have to speak for itself,'' adding, ''We'll continue to do what we have done.''
American willingness to issue a joint statement with the Japanese was a sign of concern that the steep decline in Tokyo stock prices could affect Wall Street and other global markets. As a senior Treasury official put it after the meeting, ''We want to make very sure that this adjustment gets through the system without causing major dislocations.''
Mr. Brady, a former investment banker, told reporters that so far ''the rest of the world's markets have operated pretty much in a stable manner.'' He added that it was ''very important'' that big stock market moves ''go through the world financial system in a way that people can continue to have confidence and conduct business.''
Asked what he hoped the markets would take away from the meeting, a senior Treasury official commented later, ''Stability and some real feeling that school will keep.''
A senior United States official told reporters before the meeting started that there were factors behind the fall of the yen that the United States could do little to alter. He cited investors' re-evaluation of Japanese assets and some increase in inflationary expectations in Japan.
''It's a simple supply-demand relationship,'' the official said.
Mr. Hashimoto, an important figure in the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, is eager to stabilize the financial markets, said Japanese officials, who added that this was important for his political future. Mr. Hashimoto was one of the few Cabinet ministers to be reappointed after Mr. Kaifu's party retained power in the February elections.
American analysts differed on what the United States should be doing. C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington policy group, said it was time to ''dust off'' a 1986 monetary intervention agreement between the United States and Japan ''and start a concerted effort to get the yen rising, which, in view of the underlying strength of the Japanese economy and the trade balance, should be rising.''
Mr. Bergsten said a powerful reason why Americans should act is that the weak yen undermines American competitiveness by making Japanese goods cheaper on global markets.
But John H. Makin of the American Enterprise Institute, another Washington policy research group, said, ''I don't think there is much the United States can or should do about it.''
What the United States does not want is turmoil in the foreign exchange markets.
 
Paris Meeting on April 7
 Mr. Brady is holding meetings with individual finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations before the group meets in Paris on April 7. Earlier this month in Europe, Mr. Brady talked to finance ministers of Britain, France, West Germany and Italy. A meeting is expected shortly in Washington with Canada's Finance Minister, Michael H. Wilson.
Today's meeting also took up bilateral trade issues and discussed plans for increasing the resources of the International Monetary Fund and establishing a new multinational bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to help the countries of Eastern Europe that are abandoning Communism.
At the beginning of this month, President Bush and Prime Minister Kaifu met in California, where Mr. Bush pressed Japan to do more to reduce its trade surplus with the United States, which last year totaled $49 billion. Mr. Kaifu promised to make reduction of trade tensions with the United States a top priority.
With the possibility that American retaliatory moves on Japan could be imposed as soon as this summer, Mr. Brady and Mr. Hashimoto today discussed a special campaign by the United States to make it easier to sell American products in Japan.
The campaign, which began last summer and is called the Structural Impediments Initiative, is aimed chiefly at fostering broad structural changes in Japan, like reducing the regulatory delays that hold up the opening of large retail stores, strengthening antitrust enforcement and reducing dependence on exports for economic growth.
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said Thursday in Washington that the United States would retaliate if the Japanese did not meet market-opening deadlines, but added that she remained ''very hopeful'' that we will have progress.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Up By 3.3%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
A rebound in dealers' orders for automobiles pushed orders for durable goods up by 3.3 percent last month, the Government said today, but the recovery after January's record plunge offered little hope that manufacturing was pulling out of its slump.
The Commerce Department said that orders to United States factories for items like cars, refrigerators and other goods meant to last at least three years rose to $121.56 billion last month, from $117.63 billion in January. The January decline was revised to 10.7 percent from the previously reported 10.5 percent. 
 
Lower January Rate
 Weak orders for new cars also pulled January's orders lower as manufacturers cut production and offered incentives to help dealers reduce bloated stocks of unsold cars. But workers were hired back in February and auto output rose.
Speaking of the February report, David M. Jones, an economist for Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York, said, ''It simply confirms the fact that the goods-producing sector of the economy remains very sluggish.'' But pointing to the small rise for February, he added, ''There is no threat of recession on the immediate horizon.''
The United States Chamber of Commerce, representing most of the nation's manufacturers, called the February increase ''puny'' and said it was discouraging for producers.
''High interest rates continue to hit this sector the hardest, and there is no let-up in sight,'' said Richard W. Rahn, the group's chief economist.
Orders for military tanks and ships rose sharply in February, but those for aircraft and parts fell for a second straight month.
 
Transportation Orders Up
 Total transportation orders climbed by 11.2 percent last month after dropping by 29.4 percent in January. But excluding transportation, orders rose in February by only 1 percent after falling by 3 percent the previous month.
Orders for durables, a primary part of American manufacturing, are closely watched as an indicator of the economy's health.
Industries making durable goods, which employ about 23 percent of the nation's work force, have been under pressure for months as exports have slumped and employment dropped as the auto makers, for example, laid off workers to cut back inventories.
Car sales fell in February, pulling total retail sales down from January levels, and they were also below the same levels a year ago in early March.
The General Motors Corporation announced new incentives this week to lure consumers. A survey by the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks last week said that the economy was expanding at a slow pace, but added that the automobile industry was vulnerable. Military orders are also under pressure.
 
Unfilled Orders Off 0.4%
 Unfilled orders, an indicator of coming activity, fell by four-tenths of a percent last month - the first decline in the order backlog since last August - after rising by two-tenths of a percent in January.
Shipments of durable goods rose by 5.9 percent in February, after a 4.4 percent decline the previous month.
The orders for military capital goods, like tanks and ships, jumped by 22.6 percent in February after falling by 33.6 percent in January. Non-military orders for such goods fell by 5.7 percent after a 13.7 percent decline in January.
In other sectors, orders for electrical machinery rose by 4.2 percent in February after a 15 percent January decline, but non-electrical machinery orders fell by 1.1 percent after rising by 3 percent in January.

HEADLINE: List of Japan Goals Cited

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 23

 BODY:
The United States Government has given Japan a list of more than 200 suggested policy changes aimed at eliminating barriers faced by foreign companies operating in Japan, a news report said today.
Quoting unidentified United States Government officials, the newspaper Asahi Shimbun said the recommendations ranged from an increase in public works spending to the release of the minutes of business group meetings. The newspaper said the proposals were more detailed and far-reaching than Japanese officials had expected and amounted to a plan to ''remake Japan.''
A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Taizo Watanabe, declined to comment today at a regular news conference.
The newspaper said the recommendations were presented as part of talks, begun last year, concerning the two nations' trade imbalance. The United States has called for tighter enforcement of Japan's Anti-Monopoly Law, controls on high land prices and higher public works spending.
The list of recommendations included proposals to consolidate the 13 Government offices that deal with land policy, the creation of a special antitrust division to strengthen enforcement of the Anti-Monopoly Law and abolishing legislation that protects small shops from competition, the newspaper said.

HEADLINE: East Bloc Trade Shift Seen

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOVER, West Germany, March 23

 BODY:
The United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, said today that a substantial streamlining of Western curbs on high-technology exports to Eastern Europe is likely to be completed by June.
In an interview, Mr. Mosbacher said, ''Cabinet-level discussions will begin soon'' on sharply trimming the list of restricted technologies of the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom. He cited telecommunications, computers and machine tools as areas in which restrictions need to be relaxed to reflect the changes in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Mosbacher played down reports of differences between the United States and West Germany on the trade status of Eastern Europe.
Helmut Haussmann, West Germany's Economics Minister, met with Mr. Mosbacher on Thursday. After the meeting, Mr. Haussmann was critical of the Cocom restrictions.
Mr. Mosbacher said, ''I was pleased to find that Economics Minister Haussmann and I agree on the need to differentiate between the trade status of the Soviet Union and that of Eastern Europe as far as Cocom is concerned.''
Mr. Haussmann said, ''Our common security philosophy should be strict controls on a hard core of exports that are really important strategically or militarily, not an export ban for everything that contains a chip.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Yen But Gains in Other Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the yen yesterday as investors regained some confidence in the Japanese currency.
Analysts said a rise in interest rates in Japan and a recovery on the Tokyo Stock Exchange after a string of steep losses helped support the yen, which has fallen sharply in recent weeks.
Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc., said traders believed Japanese yields would go even higher, which would make the yen even more attractive. 
The dollar fell to 154.30 yen in New York, from 155.11 late Thursday. In Tokyo early yesterday, the dollar rose 0.24 yen to close at 155.07 yen, and in London, it was quoted at a sharply lower rate of 153.85 yen.
Overseas dealers said the dollar was hit in afternoon dealings by a report, later denied, that Japan was moving to issue dollar-denominated bonds in a bid to add a layer of intervention to help the sagging yen.
The dollar was also hit by selling as investors apparently took profits before talks yesterday between Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and his Japanese counterpart, Ryutaro Hashimoto, in Los Angeles.
Although the dollar fell against the yen, it was higher against the West German currency, rising to 1.7135 marks from 1.7028, and it also gained against the French franc, the Swiss franc and the Italian lira.
Mr. Barbanel said the dollar's strong showing against other currencies was due partly to higher interest rates in the United States, and also to concerns about tensions between the Soviet Union and Lithuania. The dollar is seen as a safe haven in times of international political strife.
In New York trading, compared with late Thursday's quotes, the dollar rose to 1.5200 Swiss francs, from 1.5120; to 5.7720 French francs, from 5.7415, and to 1,260.25 Italian lire, from 1,255.50, The pound recovered somewhat abroad from its recent slide on Britain's economic woes and political uncertainty, rising in London to $1.6040, from $1.6015 late Thursday. But it fell in New York to $1.6010 from $1.6040.
Against the Canadian dollar, the United States dollar fell to 1.17505 from 1.17575.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Silver Prices Drop; Grains and Soybeans Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold futures tumbled yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange, settling $5.30 to $5.60 lower, with the contract for April delivery at $389.40 a troy ounce, the lowest settlement for a near-month gold contract since Nov. 10. European selling was heavy as the dollar resumed its advance against most other major currencies.
On other commodity markets, silver also retreated, grains and soybeans fell, energy futures advanced and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
Silver futures ended 4.1 cents to 4.7 cents lower in New York, with March at $5.043 a troy ounce.
 
Stronger Dollar a Factor
 Gold prices have skidded from nearly $430 an ounce over the last six weeks. April gold fell by $11.50 in this week alone. Gold is traded in dollars on the world market, so a stronger dollar makes the metal more expensive in terms of other currencies, discouraging foreign buying. That factor seems to be playing a larger role in the market at present than does gold's traditional role as a safe haven during times of inflation, which Britain is suffering, and political crises, like that now gripping Lithuania.
''The dollar is becoming the safe haven,'' said John Jonat, a trader in precious metals with Deak International Inc.
Prices of soybean futures fell substantially on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting expectations of traders that Brazilian soy exports may resume soon. Grain futures prices fell modestly. Exports of Brazilian soybean meal and oil have been on hold this week while the Government carries out economic changes aimed at halting runaway inflation in the South American nation.
Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 4 1/2 cents lower, with May at $3.56 3/4 a bushel; corn futures were 1/4 cent to 1 1/2 cents lower, with May at $2.58 1/2 a bushel; oats were 1 1/4 cents to 2 cents lower, with May at $1.47 3/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 5 cents to 7 cents lower, with May at $5.98 a bushel.
 
Fuel Prices Higher
 Petroleum futures advanced in technically inspired trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents to 39 cents higher, with May at $20.39 a barrel; heating oil was 0.45 cent to 0.70 cent higher, with April at 55.46 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.15 cent to 1.56 cents higher, with April at 57.66 cents a gallon.
Expectations for stronger cash markets next week prompted buying of livestock futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork bellies ended mixed ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cold-storage report, which showed a lower-than-expected amount of pork bellies in commercial freezers as of Feb. 28.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
With Bulbs, Light and Price Are the Key Considerations

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Consumers who think they can spot the bargains and the pitfalls in the supermarket aisles should pay close attention in the light bulb section, a part of the store where choices are multiplying, where common terms don't mean what people think they do, and the important measure, light, is almost always overlooked.
* Which gives more light for a given amount of electricity, a ''miser'' 55-watt bulb or a regular 60-watt bulb? Either. They are virtually equal.
* Which gives more light, two 60-watt bulbs or one 100-watt bulb? Either. They are about equal, too. 
 
* Can you save money by paying extra for a long-life bulb, which is advertised as lasting twice as long as the regular bulb? Generally no. The long-life bulb generally has a higher purchase price per hour of service, and it gives off less light than a standard bulb of equal wattage.
As is common in supermarkets, a pocket calculator is the surest way to evaluate the choices.
Bulbs are sold by wattage, but a watt is not a measure of light. It is a measure of energy consumed; in this case, of how much electricity the bulb uses. A second figure on the box, lumens, tells how much light the bulb gives off.
Some stores sell a 55-watt bulb meant to be a substitute for a standard 60-watt bulb. This is the first opportunity to misunderstand what is offered.
The packaging that suggests the 55-watt model as a replacement for the 60, and the price, which is sometimes higher, could lead a buyer to conclude that the 55-watt bulb gives off the same amount of light, although it uses 8.3 percent less electricity. In fact, the 60-watt bulb gives off 870 lumens and the 55-watt model, 810 lumens, or about 6.9 percent less light, with a small gain in efficiency.
 
Not All Bulbs Are the Same
 At the national average price of electricity, the 55-watt bulb would use about 30 cents less power over its lifetime. This saving could easily be outweighed by the higher price.
That is not to say that all bulbs are the same. They do vary in number of lumens delivered per watt of energy supplied, an efficiency measure similar to miles per gallon for a car. Generally, the larger bulbs are more efficient. So a 100-watt bulb typically delivers 1,750 lumens, which is just slightly more than two 60-watt bulbs.
A questionable economy is bulbs that are supposed to last longer. Figures will vary with wattage and brand. A standard 60-watt bulb might be advertised as lasting 1,000 hours, and a long-life bulb, 1,500 hours. At $1.75 each, the long-life bulb costs 12 one-hundredths of a cent per hour of service life. At 95 cents each, the standard bulb costs 10 one-hundredths of a cent per hour. And the standard bulb gives off 14.5 lumens per watt; the long-life bulb, 13.7. Still, the long-life bulb is a good choice if it is going into the ceiling fixture of your two-story entryway.
Far more efficient bulbs are available. Halogen bulbs, for example, deliver almost 20 lumens per watt, or one-fourth more light for the same amount of electricity. And fluorescents deliver 40 to 80 lumens per watt, or 2 1/2 to 5 times as much light per unit of electricity. Several manufacturers now make fluorescents that screw into a standard incandescent base, and these are available in hardware stores and home centers.
How important is efficiency in a light bulb? In commercial buildings, where lights are usually on all day, lighting efficiency is becoming a major consideration. For homes, the value depends on the use of the bulb. For example, a homeowner who substituted a 100-watt bulb for two 60-watt bulbs would be saving 20 watts. If the light burns for 6 hours a night, a customer in New York City and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk counties would save about $6 a year in electricity. At the national average price for electricity, the figure would be closer to $4.
That is a very modest difference. But in other applications, the choice is more important. For example, a consumer who keeps a 60-watt light burning 12 hours a day in a hallway or bathroom spends about $21 a year, at the average electricity price. A screw-in fluorescent would have an operating cost of only about $6.
The fluorescents sell for $20 to $30, depending on model, but they typically last for 10,000 hours, compared with 1,000 hours for the standard incandescent. Over the 10,000-hour lifetime, at the average electricity price, the fluorescent bulb would save the consumer about $34 in operating costs, and because it would outlive about 10 incandescents, it would save, at minimum, another $10.
But earning the savings would take the bulb its entire lifetime. That means that the usefulness of a better bulb depends on what it is being used for.
 
Is It Worth the Price?
 In a 24-hour-a-day application, achieving the entire savings would take 14 months, making the initial investment attractive. But in a spare bedroom used only a few times a year, it could take decades, and the consumer would be better off buying a cheaper incandescent.
In addition, fluorescents will not fit all fixtures and cannot be used outdoors.
For consumers who take the broadest view, there are other more cosmic considerations, not just the cost of electricity. Substituting a more efficient bulb can reduce the amount of coal or oil burned. And the less coal burned, the less acid rain; the less oil used, the lower the trade deficit.

LENGTH: 1610 words

HEADLINE: NO LONG-TERM PLAN ON MILITARY SAVING

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
At a time when receding Soviet military power suggests that hundreds of billions of dollars will be cut from the Pentagon budget in this decade, the Bush Administration and Congress are so absorbed in the politics of the moment that neither has begun to develop a strategy for using the money.
White House officials say no one in the Administration has been specifically assigned to examine how the military savings should be allocated in the last half of the decade, when by the Administration's own accounting the amount will be sizable.
This worries many scholars and some politicians, who fear that without forethought, the windfall will be frittered away. After the Vietnam War, unplanned and unrestrained social spending gobbled up the dollars saved by the American withdrawal. More Than a Mirage? ''The so-called peace dividend,'' said Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker, ''is not something that will magically appear like Athena fully armed from the brow of Zeus. The peace dividend will become reality when it is decided upon, planned for and managed over a period of years, as a matter of national policy.'' 
President Bush takes the position that the peace dividend is largely a mirage and that the small sums that may prove real in the next few years must be used entirely to reduce the Federal deficit. Some critics argue that the President is ducking the issue.
Others maintain that Mr. Bush is playing a cagy political game, avoiding policy decisions that might dent his popularity.
In any case, without forceful leadership from the White House, Congress is unlikely to act.
The Democrats, who control Congress, are riven by ideological and jurisdictional disputes, and they seem to be splitting into several camps over the issue of how to allocate domestic spending. So far this year, they have been unable to agree on the size and shape of next year's military budget, much less on a long-range view.
''The word 'plan' has gone out of style,'' said James David Barber, a political scientist at Duke University who is an expert on the Presidency. ''What has happened in American politics is its drift to sentimentality and emotion, which substitute for looking at the facts that face you at the moment.''
Uncertainties in world affairs and the national economy mean that the eventual size of the peace dividend cannot be precisely forecast. But it is clear that at least 40 percent of this year's $300 billion Pentagon budget is aimed at fighting a land war in Europe, a prospect that now seems remote, and that the military expansion the Bush Administration was planning as recently as last summer is no longer necessary.
If military spending is reduced by an average of only $10 billion a year, or 3 percent, for the next 10 years, the Pentagon budget in the year 2000 will be $100 billion lower than it is now (in 1990 dollars), and the cumulative saving over the decade will be $550 billion.
The money could be used to cut taxes, to reduce the budget deficit and begin paying off the $3 trillion national debt or to increase spending on domestic programs and international assistance. Or it could be used for some combination of the three. Critics say the Government should now begin a broad debate over these alternatives.
After the Vietnam War, the savings were spent without a plan or much public debate.
From 1968 to 1976, the military budget fell to $195 billion, in 1990 dollars, from $302 billion. Most of the money was used to increase Social Security and Medicare payments. Those expenditures were popular at the time, but they are one of the causes of the large deficit the country now faces.
If Mr. Bush has reflected on the matter, it is not apparent from his public statements. ''I think the American people want a cautious approach on this,'' he said at a news conference last month. ''I don't think any of us can see with clairvoyance what's going to happen the day after tomorrow.''
 
Ostriches and Unknowns
Mr. Bush's position has reinforced the conviction of some Administration officials that long-range planning is futile.
''Surprises tend to be negative, and we cannot plan for the things that will come up and bite us,'' said a top adviser to the President.
But others agree with an under secretary who said he was frustrated by what he called ''the ostrich response'' and added: ''We know we're going to be wrong. We know unknowns will occur. Nonetheless, if you don't think through what the possibilities are, you're liable to have such a narrow focus that you're unable to respond to the possibilities when some of them turn out to be true.''
Politicians outside the Administration say Mr. Bush's unwillingness to address the situation is based on two political factors: his reluctance to risk his popularity by taking positions that could generate opposition, and his feeling that discussion of a large peace dividend over a decade would lead to more demands now for spending on social programs.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, a potential challenger in the 1992 Presidential race, said that Mr. Bush was ''the best politician I've ever seen in the White House'' and that ''as a politician, he wouldn't do anything risky or controversial unless he had to.''
To that view, which is widely held in political circles, the Governor added an extra twist. ''Why should he fool with the peace dividend now,'' Mr. Cuomo asked, ''when he can save it till 1991, just before the election,'' and distribute it then for popular domestic programs?
Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, a leading Republican on budget issues, said Mr. Bush's reluctance to discuss the long-range implications of military savings probably resulted from ''a deep concern that advocates of every social program people have been scheming about, from child care to health benefits,'' would lay claim to the money and ''spend it three times over.''
Like many other lawmakers of both parties, Mr. Rudman said authority in Congress was too diffuse to develop a coherent strategy. ''The leadership on this must come from the White House,'' he said.
Congress has been further hampered by its peculiar rules for writing a budget. The Bush Administration has proposed spending $292 billion at the Pentagon next year, about $5 billion more than in the current fiscal year but about $6 billion less than what would be needed to keep pace with inflation.
 
Budget First, Then Plan
Congress is sure to lower that figure, the question being by how much. Some Administration officials suggest they could accept a modest reduction.
Logically, Congress would first address the position it thought the United States should occupy in the new world order, then decide what kind of military would be needed to protect that position and how much it would cost. Finally the legislators would draft a budget for the Pentagon and the rest of the Government. But the rules require the lawmakers to approve next year's budget by next month, long before the foundation has been laid.
Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, complained that he could not begin to take a long-term view because he was ''under great pressure to meet budgetary deadlines.'' He said he would like to be able to prepare a military budget based on an ''overall strategic look from the Armed Services Committee, but we're not getting it.''
The chairman of the armed services panel, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, maintained in a speech on the floor Thursday that he could not provide detailed advice to the budget writers because the Pentagon had not developed a military strategy that took account of changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney rejected Mr. Nunn's criticism and said the Democratic lawmakers were offering ''complaints instead of solutions.''
Mr. Cheney complicated the political situation by publishing a list of military bases that might be closed to save money. A study released this weekend by the Democratic Study Group, an organization of liberal Democrats in the House, concluded that 99 percent of the jobs lost under that plan would be in Congressional districts represented by Democrats.
A Pentagon spokesman said Mr. Cheney's plan was not grounded in politics, but Republican lawmakers acknowledged that there had been much chortling in their cloakroom over the discomfort the base list had caused Democrats.
Democrats in the House have such a large majority that if they are united, they can afford to ignore their Republican colleagues. Various Democratic factions got together last week and agreed on small cuts in military spending next year and larger ones in the years ahead.
 
'A Whole New Global Struggle'
Because of institutional jealousies, senators and representatives rarely work in tandem. Representative Les AuCoin, an Oregon Democrat on the military appropriations subcommittee, said the agreement of the House Democrats represented ''a recognition that it is suicidal politically and dumb in terms of policy for Democrats to simply be looking at the maximum number of cookies that can be taken out of the Defense cookie jar.''
Senator Sasser said he thought the Democrats in the House were merely postponing the tough choices. But in separate interviews, both he and Mr. AuCoin agreed that the budget problems this year paled next to the need for a long-term strategy. ''The global struggle we've been laboring in for my political lifetime,'' said Mr. AuCoin, ''is being replaced with a whole new global struggle, an economic struggle, and I wonder every day how we, how the United States, is going to figure in it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''The peace dividend will become reality when it is decided upon, planned for and managed,'' said Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker. (The New York Times)
