LENGTH: 1555 words

HEADLINE: While Land Prices in Japan Soar, Officials Fight Back With Words

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 24

 BODY:
Each of the last four years, the Government of Japan has declared a well-publicized war on this country's astronomical and still-rising land prices, the world's highest. But despite the strong oratory, the soldiers in the war never seem to leave their barracks.
The rising land prices have become as permanent a part of the landscape as Mount Fuji and the situation has been declared the worst domestic problem. Some people warn that high land prices threaten to split Japan into a two-tier society of haves and have-nots.
Examined closely, this nagging issue has become a mirror reflecting aspects of the Japanese economy that are rarely so clearly visible to outsiders, many experts say. These include the extraordinary influence that interest groups exercise, the inefficiencies at the heart of Japan's economy and the benefits accorded to industry at the expense of individuals. Is There a Scarcity? ''The problem is not scarcity,'' said Yukio Noguchi, a professor at Hitosubashi University and author of a recent book on Japan's land policy. ''There's plenty of land. It's a political and social problem.'' 
Property prices have reached stupefying heights. The Government, for example, recently paid more than $1 million a yard for the land to widen a stretch of road, 99.5 percent of the road's total cost. And a Tokyo finance company just began offering 100-year mortgages so that the burden of paying for a house can be passed from generation to generation - an innovative way to put home ownership within reach of more Japanese.
 
Cheaper in Manhattan
The best residential property in Tokyo now costs about $69,000 a square yard, while the top commercial space runs about $210,000 a square yard. Many small two-bedroom apartments in Tokyo sell for $1 million.
In recent weeks, the plunging Tokyo stock market has provided a pressing reason for Japanese officials to be cautious in trying to attack high land prices. Soaring property prices have been intimately linked to the 1980's boom on the Tokyo stock market and the general health of the Japanese economy.
The steady rise in the value of corporate land holdings provided a good reason for investors to bid up the price of companies' shares. Moreover, Japanese corporations used their land as collateral for low-interest loans, giving them inexpensive money to invest in new technology and new factories, Thus rising land prices helped finance corporate Japan's international expansion during the last decade.
Now, with Tokyo share prices slipping, fears have been expressed by bankers and brokers that land prices might follow stock prices down, precipitating a crash that could spread to financial markets worldwide.
But most experts in the economics and politics of Japanese land prices doubt that such a fall will occur, given the formidable array of special interests behind the current system.
''Europeans and Americans think the Japanese are so efficient in everything they do,'' said Yutaka Harada, a land-policy expert at the Government's Economic Planning Agency. ''But the land problem demonstrates that we are not interested in efficiency at all.''
 
Barrier to Foreigners
Japan's land prices have become an important trade issue as well. American companies say the prohibitive cost of land is a formidable barrier to foreign businesses entering Japan.
The real problem, Japanese experts agree, is not a shortage of land, as is generally assumed, but the web of special-interest regulations and tax laws that now surround land ownership. The result is a strikingly inefficient use of property.
For example, the Tokyo metropolitan region, home to 31 million people, includes 88,000 acres of undeveloped farmland. Even in central Tokyo, farm plots take up roughly 4,500 acres. It is common to see weekend farmers tending rows of cabbages or vines of table grapes amid towering apartment blocks and industrial structures.
In addition, Tokyo is built to less than a third of its modest maximum legal density; the average number of stories in the city's buildings is barely more than two.
There has long been an official chorus of disapproval about Japan's steep real estate prices. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu recently referred to Japanese housing as ''impoverished'' and acknowledged that the problem was creating social resentments.
Michio Fukai, executive director of the Bank of Japan, said in an interview, ''It is an issue of social justice.''
 
Decrees Fail to Work
But the outcry for change has never been matched by credible measures, which is why few believe the Government's latest pledges. As one example, even though the Finance Ministry has issued directives that banks restrain lending for speculative property purchases, such lending soared 14 percent last year, and prices continued to rise.
Also, any restraint exercised by banks was more than offset by sharp increases in property lending by non-bank financial institutions, such as leasing companies and insurance companies. ''Our big headache now is the non-banks,'' Mr. Fukai of the Bank of Japan said. ''We have no direct route to exercise control over them.''
There has been little apparent effect from a plan to have bureaucrats monitor land sales and simply order lower prices in transactions deemed too rich. When prices in Tokyo leveled off in 1988 after rocketing up more than 60 percent in 1987, costs simply shot upwards in cities like Osaka, up 50 percent in 1989, and Kyoto, up 80 percent. And those gains encouraged prices to rebound in the Tokyo area.
The total 1988 market value of land in Japan, a nation roughly the size of California, is estimated at $15 trillion, or five times that of the United States, according to the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
 
'Serious Disincentive'
''In the long run this is the most serious economic problem we have because it is such a serious disincentive for people to work,'' said Prof. Noguchi of Hitotsubashi University. ''It has such a big impact on how resources are allocated in Japan.''
In Tokyo, the Japanese policy has resulted in a crazy quilt of small, sometimes minuscule plots, rather than larger sites that allow more extensive development. In the middle of the Ginza, the most expensive commercial district in the world, there are Lilliputian structures on lots as small as 6 feet by 18 feet. A club, called the Mini-Bar, sits in a building barely wide enough for a normal-sized door, but it occupies a rectangle of property worth roughly $3.6 million.
Many economists agree that if the the problem were tackled with more credible policies, like significant changes in property taxes, the sweeping political and social repurcussions would be hard for politicians to face.
''What is needed is a very brave political move,'' said Takao Akabane, the former vice minister of the Economic Planning Agency. ''But most, if not all, of our politicians are short of such courage.''
Among the key problems cited by economists are: -
* Capital gains taxes of as much as 94 percent discourage land sales, with owners preferring to keep land idle rather than sell it for more efficient uses.
* Extremely low property taxes encourage people to buy and hold land as a store of wealth rather than put it to use. Annual land taxes in Tokyo run about one-tenth of a percent of the market value of the land, economists say, compared with about 4 percent in New York City.
* Too much urban land is still designated agricultural land and taxed at a rate about a tenth of regular land taxes. This provides little incentive for the land to be put to other uses.
* Tenants enjoy extraordinary protections against rent increases and eviction in Japan, a situation that discourages landowners from renting or from creating rentable property. ''From an economic standpoint, leasing is irrational behavior,'' said Prof. Noguchi. Mr. Akabane said the basic law was written in 1941 to insure that the families of conscripted soldiers would not lose their homes while their husbands, sons and fathers were fighting in World War II.
* When land is inherited, it is valued at a fraction of the market price and taxed at a low level, which encourages people to keep land idle as a store of wealth and a tax dodge rather than put it to more productive use.
* There is too much concentration of government and business in central Tokyo, straining supply in this area. ''That concentration has been a key reason prices have skyrocketed in this area,'' said Mr. Fukai of the Bank of Japan.
* The money supply in Japan has grown at a spectacular pace since 1985. The rapid growth was intended to cushion the Japanese economy against a recession when the value of the yen was doubled in an effort to reduce Japan's large trade surpluses. A side effect was that extremely low interest rates encouraged property speculation.
The first step in the Government's latest effort to halt the price rise has been to tighten monetary policy sharply. The Bank of Japan has just raised its official discount rate for the fourth time since last May. That has sent long-term rates, at which most real estate loans are made, to their highest level in six years.
 
'Not Optimistic'
''We are not optimistic that we are succeeding yet,'' Mr. Fukai said. ''We are still cautious because of the past experiences.''

HEADLINE: The Green Movement in the Fashion World

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
Saving the planet is very much in vogue. It's also in Harper's Bazaar, Elle and Mademoiselle.
It's the message on fashion runways, in marketing strategies, in jewelry and accessory designs, on shopping bags and totes, in advertisements and on price tags.
A naked fashion model wearing a hat of birch branches and lichen, as shown in Vogue this month, may not be everyone's idea of environmental awareness. But the pervasiveness of ecological themes in the images and marketing of fashion is undeniable. It is also somewhat paradoxical. 
The fashion industry, whose driving philosophy involves encouraging consumers to discard the old (and sometimes still serviceable) and embrace the new (and presumably more stylish), is now trying to push itself to the forefront of efforts to conserve and preserve.
The phenomenon goes well beyond apparel, to fashion in the wider sense. A SoHo furniture store sells only politically correct woods: tropical hardwoods are out. A Madison Avenue boutique stocks only cosmetics made from flowers or plants, including what it calls ''pure fume'' instead of perfume.
This extraordinary convergence of commerce and ecology calls into question fundamental notions about consumerism, responsibility and, ultimately, fashion.
 
Of 'Premeditated Waste'
''The irony is that we're talking about a business based on premeditated waste,'' said Stuart Ewen, the chairman of the Communications Department at Hunter College. ''If you were to do a study of the history of product obsolescence,'' he went on, ''the model would be fashion. The first industry that built in disposability as a feature of economic survival was the ready-made clothing industry.''
The environmental theme in fashion began as wispy touches and graphic exhortations in designer collections, not as some well-thought-out strategy of ''green'' marketing in which the environmental advantages of a product become part of the sales approach.
Tendrils of ivy dangled from the ceiling at a Paris fashion show; a carpet of grass covered a runway in New York; models marched along in T-shirts or carrying signs all bearing slogans like ''Clean Up or Die,'' ''Save the Sphere,'' and ''Environmental Protection Agents.'' And for the last few seasons, there have been the new ''softer'' styles, to suit a gentler, less self-referential age.
 
Leaves, Branches, Earth Tones
Where once the symbols of conspicuous consumption reigned - black, gray and red the prevailing colors, broad shoulders and tapered waists the dominant silhouette, reflecting a culture anxious to project success, control and victory over one's surroundings - now Pan, with cloven hooves, was leaving his mark on the runway. There were dresses with leaves, accessories with branches, and, everywhere, earth tones.
The environmental spin on fashion has now moved into the mass market, where ''clothes with conscience'' make an extra tug at the buyer's self-image.
Apparel companies like Ellen Tracy, Esprit, Bonjour, J. G. Hook and Country Road Australia are now promoting efforts to preserve the environment either through their advertising, their licensing arrangements or their direct contributions to ecological causes.
Bonjour, a jeans and sportswear company based in New York, has embarked on a program to ''change the individual's outlook toward saving the environment'' through educational tags. This summer, the first wave of what Bonjour executives said would be 50 million fashion items a year are to arrive in stores carrying tags with environmental tips from how to save water to how to reduce pollutants.
''I don't know if our campaign will sell a single garment,'' said Charles Dayan, president of Bonjour International. ''But it's definitely not a fad.'' $90,000 Raised for Preservation Hermes, the French luxury goods manufacturer, has raised more than $90,000 for the Rainforest Alliance, a preservation group, at fund-raising parties in its stores around the country. Hermes, whose silk scarves are among the most popular symbols of conspicuous consumption worldwide, has declared 1990 the ''year of the outdoors'' and added a line of nature-inspired products, including a $175 signature scarf.
Whether these tributes to nature will benefit the environment or even raise environmental awareness, with concomitant changes in individual behavior, is not clear. There is some skepticism.
Professor Ewen says the new environmental symbolism should be viewed as part of an overall change in America's economy, from one built on industrial production of hard goods to one based on ''pure representation.''
''Disembodied symbols, unconnected to material reality, whether we're talking about junk bonds, credit or information, are the primary product,'' said Professor Ewen, author of ''All Consuming Images'' (Basic Books, 1988). ''Going back to fashion, the environment has become a commercial cliche separated from real concerns. What can be attached to this year's fashion is merely the symbolism of environmental sanity.''
 
Fake Furs on the Runway
Green marketing is somewhat problematic in fashion. While a chemical company might introduce a line of more biodegradable packaging, apparel makers can offer little in the way of material improvement in their final products except to use natural fibers, and they go to great lengths to do so.
Last week in Paris, Frederic Castet, a French designer, responded to the critics of fake fur, who say it is more environmentally destructive than real fur because of toxic chemicals used to make it. Working with a French textile maker, he showed the first faux fur fashions made from a biodegradable synthetic fur on the runway.
''Some of these things are ridiculous,'' said Michael Leva, a New York designer who supports environmental causes. ''I don't see how you can design a collection that's kind to the environment.''
Lester Brown, the president of the Worldwatch Institute, has one suggestion: ''If the interest in environmental matters translates into fabrics that can be washed instead of dry-cleaned, it would be a contribution.'' Some dry-cleaning processes use chlorinated solvents that are toxic.
 
A Switch by a Master of Change
But Mr. Brown added: ''We need to see some value changes that will weaken the effect of changing styles on people's purchasing decisions. To reduce the stress on the earth, perhaps we will see fashion move toward more durability and simplification.''
The crux of the matter is not so much fashion's industrial processes as its underlying ethos of change. The more fashionable a garment is, the more likely it will soon be out of fashion. The influential Italian designer Giorgio Armani, whose New York store has sponsored ''Don't Bungle the Jungle'' benefit parties, is a master of such change.
Mr. Armani, a proponent of wide sharp-shouldered ''power'' looks for men and women throughout the last decade, has reversed course in the past few years, removing the padding from his jackets. He is now moving instead toward the slouchy, more natural silhouettes of cardigan-like jackets for women and the Ivy League sack suit for men.
It could be argued that if a man stuck with traditional tailoring for the last 10 years, he might have a closet full of serviceable suits rather than a group of outdated Armanis. But the fact that Mr. Armani is able to outdate himself so smoothly is the key to large-scale success in fashion. It thrives on change, but it must at least appear to be rational change.
 
Lag in Clothing Sales
Most designers and apparel executives, however, reject the idea that they consciously manipulate consumer tastes as part of a self-serving system of fashion change.
''I don't do clothes to be influential,'' said Isaac Mizrahi, a leading New York designer. ''I do them because they're beautiful and I can't help it. When I picture the ultimate woman customer, she keeps everything she buys and donates the clothes at the end of her life to a museum.''
Designers and manufacturers are already facing a fashion retailing landscape that has been slow for more than two years. Unit sales of most kinds of clothing are down, although price increases, based on the soaring costs of fabrics, especially silk and wool, have kept dollar volume high.
''Things go out of style too quickly,'' said Norma Kamali, a designer who gave her most recent fashion show in Central Park, where models wore T-shirts reading ''Acid Rain Squad'' and ''Earth Children.''
 
Emotions, Moods, Change
''Fashion appeals to the emotions and moods of human beings,'' Ms. Kamali said. ''These change quickly. That's why we're in such trouble now.''
Ms. Kamali suggested that there may be ''a whole new way of designing and presenting clothes'' that involves fewer designers and fewer stores - a shakeout, she said, that is already happening.
Others doubt that environmentalism will inspire profound changes in fashion. ''You'll notice we're not pushing going back to the fig leaf and the Garden of Eden,'' said an executive at a leading New York fashion house, asking not to be identified by name.
Mr. Mizrahi said, ''There will always be beautiful, luxurious clothes no matter how ecologically sound they are.''

HEADLINE: Prospect of Arms Pacts Spurring Weapon Sales

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union are increasing foreign arms sales in advance of major new agreements to slash the level of conventional forces in Europe, American officials and arms industry executives say.
The superpowers are preparing to sell other countries some of the weapons that would have to be destroyed once a treaty takes effect. In addition, huge amounts of arms and military equipment not covered by the treaty will become available if the two sides cut the number of troops in Europe, as now planned.
As the two countries disengage from regional conflicts, third-world nations feel a greater need to build up their own military establishments, the experts said. Thus, they said, improvements in Soviet-American relations have had the paradoxical effect of increasing the other countries' appetites for missiles, tanks, warplanes and artillery. 
The officials said that Washington would step up sales to increase the security of friends overseas, as a possible substitute for foreign aid and to keep military production lines open at a time when the Pentagon is cutting back its budget. For Moscow, the arms sales are a source of hard-currency income.
 
Concern in Congress
Representative David R. Obey, chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for foreign aid, expressed concern about the sales. ''I doubt very much that Congress is going to feel that that is an appropriate response to the changes we have seen in the world during the last year,'' he said.
The Administration recently sent Congress a classified report listing $30 billion worth of possible arms sales by the United States to foreign countries. The report identifies the sales most likely to occur this year: 56 transactions totaling $9.8 billion.
The United States is selling Egypt 700 M-60 tanks no longer needed by American forces in Europe. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said the United States was also talking to Thailand, Oman, Jordan, Pakistan, Tunisia and Morocco ''to ascertain possible interest in acquiring some of these tanks.''
The United States Ambassador to the Philippines, Nicholas Platt, on home leave this week, was working on a proposal to use surplus military equipment from Europe to help offset a $96 million shortfall in foreign aid promised to the Philippines.
 
Moscow's Idea, Too
Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, chief of the United States Central Command, which covers the Middle East and Southwest Asia, said the Soviets had similar ideas.
''The primary source of hard currency for the Soviet Union today is in arms sales, and I think it's going to continue to be that way, given the state of their economy,'' he said. ''So I have every reason to believe that if they have a lot of excess military equipment on their hands, we have a lot of countries that have got a lot of cash, and they're going to buy it, and the Soviets are going to sell it to them.''
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact expect to reach agreement this year on a conventional arms treaty that would limit five major types of weapons: tanks, other armored combat vehicles, artillery, aircraft and helicopters. Other weapons would not be covered and would not have to be destroyed.
A State Department official said the agreements would have a ''cascade effect'' as weapons spill down from the United States and the Soviet Union to other countries. Rather than destroying sophisticated aircraft in Europe, the United States could, for example, transfer such planes to Turkey, which would destroy older, less capable planes.
 
Arms Glut Is Predicted
Col. Ralph A. Hallenbeck, who retired in December as chief of conventional arms negotiations for the United States Army, said ''there will be a glut'' of ammunition, rifles, machine guns, antitank weapons, antiaircraft weapons, reconnaissance vehicles and other military equipment if NATO and the Warsaw Pact make drastic troop reductions in Europe, as now planned. ''It is unclear how either side intends to dispose of those weapons,'' he said.
A Pentagon official said it would be difficult to negotiate an agreement with the Soviet Union to prevent the dumping of surplus weapons in third-world countries because Moscow had a ''massive investment'' in such arms, having sacrificed decades of economic development to build them.
Even if Moscow accepted limits on foreign arms sales, Administration officials said they would object. In the next few years, they said, the United States will want to use surplus weapons as a form of security assistance for its friends and allies, a substitute for cash at a time when the foreign aid budget is squeezed by demands from newly emerging democracies.
Asked if it was wise to pour arms into the third world, President Bush said at a news conference last week, ''We still have security needs that we feel are enhanced by transfer of military equipment, sales of military equipment to friendly countries.''
To make up for cutbacks in Pentagon procurement, some defense contractors have tried to diversify their work, emphasizing civilian applications of military technology. Others are stepping up efforts to sell weapons overseas.
Joel L. Johnson, vice president of the Aerospace Industries Association of America, a trade association of 53 companies, said, ''Foreign arms sales will become increasingly important to American arms manufacturers as Pentagon purchases decline.''
''As the superpowers pull back from regional conflicts, that is likely to heighten the desire of smaller countries for a more proficient military establishment with better weapons,'' he said. ''International competition for those markets will become tougher and more frenetic.''
 
How One Company Is Affected
The General Dynamics Corporation, maker of the M-1 Abrams tank, illustrates the trend. Under the budget submitted to Congress in January by President Bush, the United States Army will sharply curtail purchases of such tanks next year. But in its latest annual report, published this month, General Dynamics said that foreign sales of the M-1 tank ''are projected to increase dramatically.''
Egypt has agreed to buy 555 of the tanks. The Administration informed Congress in October that it intends to sell 315 of the tanks to Saudi Arabia. In its latest report to Congress, the Administration said it might sell 200 Abrams tanks to Kuwait. Pakistan is talking with the United States about buying some, and General Dynamics is competing with a British company to supply hundreds of such tanks to the British Army.
Alvin A. Spivak, a spokesman for General Dynamics, said that the foreign business, combined with even a small number of sales to the United States Army, could keep open the company's tank-production plants. The plants, in Warren, Mich., and Lima, Ohio, would otherwise face the prospect of shutdown in the next two years.
Under Federal law, the President must send Congress a list each year of all foreign arms sales ''considered eligible for approval.'' The list shows all sales of more than $7 million being seriously considered. There is no guarantee that all the sales will occur. Some will be postponed or canceled, some will be added and prices will change.
While it is not possible to compare the new list with historical data in any reliable way, Administration officials said the total for 1990 would be at least as high as sales in the last few years: $11 billion in 1989, $12 billion in 1988, $7 billion in 1987 and $7 billion in 1986.
 
Seoul Is a Big Customer
The biggest potential customer this year, South Korea, is listed as a likely buyer of 120 F-18 Hornet warplanes, of which 72 would be manufactured in a joint production arrangement with the United States. Seoul could spend as much as $3.5 billion on the purchase and production of the planes. In addition, the list shows that South Korea might buy 81 UH-60 transport helicopters at a cost of $1.2 billion.
The next biggest customers are Saudi Arabia, which expects to buy $660 million of equipment for Awacs radar planes and $3 billion worth of light armored vehicles; Egypt, which plans to buy helicopter gunships, F-16 jet fighters and large amounts of ammunition, and the United Arab Emirates, which is listed as a potential customer for 40 F-18 planes costing $1.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Human Rights Abuses Raising Little Alarm in Peru

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
International organizations increasingly rank this strife-torn Andean nation among the world's violators of human rights.
''Torture, mutilation, 'disappearance,' murder and rape have become a hallmark of the armed forces' 'campaign against terrorism,' '' says Amnesty International's latest report on Peru.
But as violence by terrorists rises, human rights workers and diplomats detect a parallel rise in Peruvians' tolerance for their Government's methods. ''We are now on the level of Argentina, but in the Peruvian consciousness the dead are not weighing as heavily as in Argentina,'' said Nelson Manrique, a historian who studies the main rebel group here, the leftist Shining Path. 
During Argentina's military dictatorship in the late 1970's, security forces killed at least 9,000 people in a war on those accused of subversion. In Peru, a democracy, political violence claimed about 18,000 lives in the 1980's - a figure about evenly divided between victims of security forces and victims of the Shining Path.
Last year, the number of lives lost to political violence jumped 60 percent, to 3,198. The United States State Department said of Peru in an annual report that ''1989 was the most violent year'' since Shining Path announced its ''popular war'' in 1980.
Unlike the victims in Argentina, most of the victims of Peru's war on subversion are poor, rural and of Indian or mixed race. In Argentina, many were middle class, white and residents of the capital, Buenos Aires.
''The central problem is racial,'' said Francisco Soberon, coordinator of the Association for Human Rights, an independent group here. ''The peasant world is seen as a second-class world, so the majority of victims are unable to generate any sympathy.''
Mr. Soberon said 90 percent of the vicitms of Peru's estimated 3,000 political abductions were Indians or people of mixed Indian and European race.
Despite the worsening rights situation here, Peru's unfettered press seems increasingly bored with the issue.
''Human rights worker disappears,'' read a recent newspaper headline, buried at the bottom of page 14, on a missing co-worker of Mr. Soberon.
''Court absolves two terrorists for lack of proof,'' read another headline, reflecting widespread frustration in a nation where 5 percent of people arrested on terrorism charges are convicted.
Picking up the newspaper El Comercio recently, Enrique Bernales, a Socialist Senator who heads a congressional commission on violence, read about a confrontation between a peasant militia and the Shining Path.
''After a pitched battle of several minutes, nine subversives were captured,'' the senator read to a visitor. ''These were decapitated, and their heads were delivered to the authorities.''
''That's called extralegal execution, but you aren't going to see anyone in Lima writing editorials to protest it,'' he said.
Senator Bernales said interest in human rights was partly a victim of the country's economic crisis. Last year, Peru's economy shrank 12 percent and prices rose 2,700 percent.
In addition, concern grew in this capital, home to a third of Peru's 22 million people, that Shining Path was starting to threaten Lima. ''At their worst,'' a Western diplomat said, ''the leftists in Argentina never threatened to encircle Buenos Aires, cut off the food, cut off the electricity and make everyone starve in the streets. It's an issue here.''
On April 8, Peruvians are to vote for president. But human rights seems to be an invisible issue in the campaign.
In an interview, Luis Alva Castro, the candidate of the governing party, attributed foreign interest in human rights to the lobbying of ''overseas representatives of Shining Path.''
Mario Vargas Llosa, the center-right frontrunner, said that as president he would place greater controls on military conduct. The novelist said he would give the military better arms, radios and vehicles and bring schools, roads and clinics to Indian areas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
